The game uses movement-based progression (subjective) like hollow knight, metroid demon's crest etc. Essentially, as you progress in the game, you get more abilities that help you traverse the game. However, some of the abilities just lose their usability and only exist to bar you from certain areas.

The Gameplay
The game is a platformer, do not focus on the combat; the combat is pretty bland and repetitive. You're playing this game for the platforming
Personally I didn't find the platforming as hard as I wanted it to be. If you aren't very well versed in platformers ~~or don't particularly like them~~, you'll probably enjoy the game more.
The difficulty setting only affects the damage you take, so there isn't much of a difference between the difficulties depending on how good you are.
The game is also VERY forgiving. You can save almost wherever you are, making it a great platformer for beginners

OH YEAH THE STORY I FORGOT ABOUT THAT
Uhhhh it wasn't very noticeable, I guess you could find it heartwarming??? The game doesn't really try to engage you in the story and nor is there enough character development to feel anything. You SORT OF have to assume and make up the story in your head if you really want to feel the impact. 
Hopefully the sequel will handle the story better? I still haven't played at the time of writing this review.


Overall, it's a pretty mid game IN MY OPINION. If you're new to platformers it's a pretty good introduction to them. It's a simple and (debatably) easy platformer that is also very forgiving. (that is unless you go to places you really shouldn't be going to)

[i] Ori and the Blind Forest [/i] is a game that combines fairy tale aesthetics with hardcore Metroidvania gameplay; its art is unquestionably supreme, and its level design is horrifyingly hellish. Do not get me wrong, because I liked the gameplay a lot. What I mean by 'horrifyingly hellish' is that the level design consists of so many different kinds of puzzles and traps that there is not a single one-for-all solution for the challenges presented in the game. Jumping and running without thinking won't help you no matter how many skills you unlock. You have to constantly observe situations and adapt accordingly, which is without a doubt a solid proof of the excellent craftsmanship of the developers. I can see that they are seriously committed to the best of the best gameplay experiences they can offer.

That being said, this game has pretty straight-forward, and fairly predictable storyline. The developers did their best to maximize the dramatic effect of the story with their supreme art style and excellent camerawork, but the story itself is nothing special. Maybe this was intentional because this simplicity of the writing makes the audience feel like reading a fairy tale. Still, it's a solid conclusion that they did not invest as much effort into the writing of this game.

If you are looking for a game featuring the greatest kind of Metroidvania gameplay experience with stunning visuals, I recommend this game without a moment's hesitation. If you are someone just wanting to chill out and relax, go find some other game. This game might look all sweet and kind on its cover, but beneath it lurks a monstrosity ready to pressure your brain in every direction at the earliest opportunities; challenge it only when you are ready to fight.

[h1]Quality on every front, flowered with incredible amounts of beautiful charm.[/h1] 

Ori and the Blind Forest is a great gameplay, aesthetic and story experience. There is not much lacking in Moon Studios’ metroidvania. 

The story follows Ori and Naru living a quiet, undisturbed life somewhere deep in the forest of Nibel. Once the forest [strike]starts dying[/strike] goes blind and does not bear fruit anymore, Ori leaves his only family and embarks on a journey to save the magical woods. While he makes new friends, he does also brave many dangers and the game’s main antagonist - Kuro. 
The game has a few cutscenes. Sein is guiding our character through the game and the narrator that is supposed to be the light-god I guess, gives the broader context of the world. But beside him and Sein speaking in their funky language that is just subtitled on the screen, there is not much dialogue. Even if it’s just a few cutscenes and the story is not that long, the careful combination of music and aesthetic makes the way how it is presented a very beautiful plot. 
While ultimately the story revolves around the idea of maternal love, I also view it as a parallel to good and bad. One of the interpretations of the Yin-Yang motive you can make is that even in the absolute evil you will find a crumb of good and vice versa. The idea that the darkness is evil and the light is good loses its meaning once given proper context and perspective. 

Ori’s moveset starts with simple jumps, but with time it evolves into a very dynamic and flexible system. While the game doesn’t do anything too original besides the bash, an ability letting you bounce off enemies and their projectiles in whatever direction you want resetting your double jump, the quality of all the moves and how you can chain them in combos makes platforming with Ori very enjoyable. The game rewards skill and thoughtful usage of its moveset. 
Throughout the map you can find several types of collectibles – life cells, energy cells as well as experience and free ability points. The skill tree branches into 3 paths – combat, utility and efficiency. Leveling and unlocking the new abilities is fun and useful. 
In terms of combat, it starts with this weak flame homing-missile attack. Progressing through the game rewards you with stomp and charge jump. Once you unlock these the game encourages you to mix those attacks together in explosive combos, because the basic attack, even if upgraded, can take too long to kill the endgame enemies. 

The game looks amazing, the hand-painted environments, playing with colors and shadows makes this production a very aesthetic and eye-pleasing experience. Any screenshot of this game could be my wallpaper. 
The sound design has the proper oompf!, you can feel the power surging when you level up or smite the enemies or stomp your way forward. But the game’s score is something else. I needed to look up a fancy, new word to describe the music for that game – and it’s [b][i]amazeballs[/i][/b] it seems. It’s a great part of this production’s identity and success. It complements the aesthetic and story of this game perfectly. Fav tracks would be [i]Up the Spirit Caverns Walls[/i], [i]Returning to the Spirit Tree[/i] and [i]Light of Nibel[/i] as it is the ending theme of course. 

The definitive edition adds two new areas to explore and two new abilities for you to utilize. Additionally, it makes some quality-of-life improvements and adds some general polish to the game. 

I can for sure say that Ori and the Blind Forest is one of the most beautiful games I’ve ever played. Its picturesque graphics, amazing soundtrack, moving story and enjoyable platforming make this production worth playing for everyone. The game’s level of quality shows itself on every front, with every aspect of the game being at least very good. You can really feel talented hearts put into this work. 
Also it seems like a good starter for somebody new to video games. Engaging, easy to learn-hard to master and it does not require some crazy tier hardware.

I enjoyed most of this game and completed it, but I wouldn't recommend it to other players, especially those over 40, as there are a few chase levels/areas where you need to get every jump right or it's insta-death and you are taken back to the very beginning of the level.

These levels required dozens of attempts for me and it spoiled my overall enjoyment of the game - especially the final level, where after I finally beat it, my feeling was simply thank **** that's over, and I didn't connect with the games ending at all because of that, and I won't be replaying it.
A wonderful story that moves you without many words, lovely colours and the most beautiful music that lingers in your mind for a long time.

i enjoyed hollow knight, and I was looking for a metroidvania, if your in the same boat as me and you are wondering if this game is better or worse or a lil bit like hollow knight il talk about it. I also bought the bundle which comes with both the sequel and the definitive edition of blinding forest.

Things Ori did better than Hollow knight-
1. Movement: the movement in this game is very smooth and enjoyable, and the game uses it to great extent.

2. graphics: although hollow knight has great stylized graphics, this game overall looks great,

3. Platforming: the game has great movement and it also uses the great movement in boss fights, most of the boss fights in this game are heavily platforming focused. a lot like the game Celeste. 

4. Puzzles: Hollow knight lacked a lot of puzzles, which this game has a lot. There are a few puzzles that just get annoying after a while but at least they have puzzles. 
----------
Things Hollow knight did better than Ori and the blinding forest,
-combat: overall in terms of combat the game was lacking and hollow knight easily takes combat

-world building: I think the world is great and has wasted potential. the world is easily 2x the size of hollow knight but some areas simply seem dead and nothing seems to be going on in the areas.

-enemy variation: the enemy variation is very lacking, most of the time different regions just have re-skinned versions of previous enemy you encounter.

Game Length- now its no question that this game is shorter than hollow knight, and I don't think there was any way they could make the game as long as hollow knight, but I beat the game in about 13 hours with 70% completion. I was missing a great sum of hp and the blue things. I also missed 2 abilitys somehow? which my friend pointed out. A dash would have been helpful. 

------
should you buy this game? 
- yea, it satisfied me for the most part, the game lacks combat but is overall a way more chill and laid back experience compared to hollow knight, 
-I would also buy the bundle, although I have not played the second game, I think it is a overall upgrade compared to blinding forest, although I have not played will of the wisps yet.

Ori and the Blind Forest is an absolute masterpiece of a game, and it's easy to see why it's become a favorite for so many gamers. From its breathtaking visuals to its emotionally resonant storytelling, every aspect of this game is crafted with care and attention to detail.

First and foremost, let's talk about the visuals. The hand-painted art style is absolutely stunning, with vibrant colors and lush environments that draw you into the world of Nibel. Every frame of this game feels like a work of art, and it's clear that a lot of love went into creating each and every pixel.

But Ori and the Blind Forest isn't just a pretty face – it also has a compelling story to tell. The narrative follows Ori, a small guardian spirit, as they embark on a quest to save their home from an encroaching darkness. Along the way, they'll encounter a cast of memorable characters, each with their own motivations and struggles. The story is told primarily through visual storytelling and environmental cues, which adds an extra layer of depth to the experience.

Of course, no discussion of Ori and the Blind Forest would be complete without mentioning its gameplay. At its core, this is a platformer with Metroidvania elements, and it excels in both departments. The controls are tight and responsive, allowing for precise movement and platforming challenges that are both challenging and rewarding. The addition of abilities that can be unlocked and upgraded as you progress adds a layer of depth to the gameplay, giving you new ways to traverse the environment and overcome obstacles.

But perhaps the most impressive thing about Ori and the Blind Forest is its emotional impact. This is a game that knows how to tug at your heartstrings, with moments of joy, sorrow, and everything in between. The relationship between Ori and their adoptive mother, Naru, is particularly touching, and there were more than a few moments that brought a tear to my eye.

In conclusion, Ori and the Blind Forest is a truly special game that deserves all the praise it has received and more. Its stunning visuals, compelling story, and tight gameplay come together to create an experience that is as unforgettable as it is beautiful. If you haven't had the chance to experience it for yourself, I highly recommend giving it a try – you won't be disappointed.

I'm just gonna start this review by saying I am extremely bias because despite the 15 hours of playtime on steam that isn't even scratching the surface of how many hours I've poured into this game. I own both Ori titles on Steam, Xbox and Switch and have all the achievements for the first game on the last two platforms which just leaves the Steam version and I'll get to that one of these days. The point is Ori and the Blind Forest is a solid Metroidvania that has pretty much everything I want from the genre, a beautifully realized world with adorable and lovable characters and wonderful traversal mechanics as you explore and unravel the mysteries of the forest. Overall Ori as a character and as an IP means a lot to me and about the only negative thing I can say about this game is that the combat can be a bit repetitive though there are more options than people often realize. If you like Metroidvanias with quick and nimble movement and are into the more fantasy and magic oriented setting I would definitely recommend giving Ori a shot though as I established at the beginning I would probably recommend it to everyone anyway. Ori is usually pretty affordable too so even if there isn't a sale you won't be breaking the bank

An absolute classic in metroidvania platformers. Though the difficulty gets a bit challenging towards the end, it was fun the whole way through and ends at the perfect time. The level design never feels repetitive and always challenge the player in unique ways that never overstay their welcome. The puzzles were just challenging enough for you to feel like you were using your brain, but not much more. Both the visual and auditory aspects shine brightly and make the game an absolute wonder to experience. The story is a bit basic, but I feel a more complex story would have just bogged it down. Even with 100% completion, I never felt like it was a slog and never felt I was wasting my time grinding. My only complaint is that there's 0 replayability. this game would severely benefit from a ng+. other than that, a beautiful (and beautifully frustrating) game that will be remembered as a classic for generations to come.

[h1]Bello arte visual hecho un juego[/h1]

1) [b]Magnífica intro[/b]. Ya desde el comienzo, los gráficos son [u]bellos[/u]. Tiene una hermosa [u]ambientación[/u], y hermosa [u]música[/u], que se pone muy copada en los combates.

2) Entiendo que muchos juegos lo tengan, pero me encanta que practicamente [b]no haya[/b] penalizaciones por morirte. Hace el juego muchísimo más llevadero. En [i]Hollow Knight[/i], por ejemplo, una vez morí 2 veces y perdí muchiiiiiiisimos puntos que tenía acumulados. [strike]Putee un poco xD[/strike]

3) [u][b]ME ENCANTA[/b][/u] que puedas guardar cuando quieras y donde quieras, siempre y cuando no haya enemigos cerca. Nuevamente, comparándolo con el [i]Hollow Knight[/i], por ejemplo, que sólo tenias checkpoints en los banquitos y en lugares específicos.

Ese último es un punto [b]importantísimo[/b] para mí, porque odio morir muchísimo en los juegos. Me hace sentir que "pierdo el tiempo". Ese sentimiento empeora muchísimo si, encima, cada vez que muero tengo que caminar una banda hasta el lugar donde me mataron. Tener el checkpoint o guardado ahí al lado, mejora [u]DEMASIADO[/u] la situación, al menos para mí.

En fin, éste es un juegazo. Lo disfruté de principio a fin y lo recomiendo a todo el mundo.

If you're like me and thought about expanding the Ori experience by grabbing the original on a discount after you completed Ori WotW - don't. WotW is a masterpiece that does everything that this original does, and infinitely better at that.

There's a number of incredibly glaring game design flaws in this original, but the biggest one of them all is the lack of auto-saves. In a game that is all about surviving hazardous environments. To save your game you need to get and use Energy to create a manual save point on the map. Obtained this one item but made a wrong step or got hit by a stray mob projectile? Have fun doing everything **again** from where you last saved and acquiring it again - or going out of your way to find an energy cell somewhere so that you can create another save point further ahead. And believe me, you need a save a **lot** - everything either hurts like a truck or one-shots. You can easily get stuck in one segment for hours upon hours because you have a save point with 1hp in the middle of another endless corridor of one-shot hazards. 

tl;dr Ori WotW is a fantastic game. Don't sully your experience by playing the original.

Only in the last 5 years have I returned to PC gaming and, having been a Sony console guy, its been great finally playing some of the Switch titles I missed out on. As is almost always the case, this is a great game. I tend to like combat more than traversal, which gave me a little concern heading in, but the game just works. Its beautiful and compelling while also being very fun.

I am only a few hours in but I love it. If I had one wish though, it would be having a dash from the start. Avoiding enemy aggression feels very limited as I am just moving out of the way, though I just got the bash function which is sweet. I am sure the dash is coming, its just a thing I notice with a lot of MV games, where they withhold some skills that I think maybe should have been available from the start.

But this is such a minor thing, the game is incredible and I am looking forward to the rest of my playthrough.

This game is an overall fantastic experience, with beautiful music and visuals and very fun Jump N' Run gameplay. I loved my time playing this game, and getting familiar with the more and more complex mechanics was a ton of fun.
The main problem hampering the experience is the unfun combat: you spam the attack button, until the enemy dies, while said enemy shoots stupid multi-attacks which are a pain to dodge. This caused me to completely ignore most enemies and just rush through.

The game is beautiful, the art, sound, storytelling and game mechanics make it an entertaining and engaging game.

Amazing game.  Beautiful art, excellent controls, level design, story...

Only 2 small gripes with it:

1.) Jumping, and especially double jump, are disappointing and pathetic.  That said, the game gives you some really cool alternative ways to gain latitude, arguably much cooler than double jumping.

2.) A small issue with the story.  Overall the story is great, but this one decision the writers made kinda irks me.  Still enjoyed it and would recommend.  Spoilers ahead: [spoiler] Ori's caretaker/friend dies at the start of the game, and is later resurrected.  The death is hilariously silly, but I think the authors were trying to make it serious.  Basically, this creature couldn't go 10 minutes without eating, and despite having tons of fat reserves starves to death while Ori is taking a nap.  As for the resurrection, it just happens perfectly.  NO downsides, no costs.  Don't like this kind of resurrection in stories because it cheapens any deaths that might happen. [/spoiler]

Ori and the Blind Forest is really enjoyable.

Pros:
+ Very beautiful landscapes
+ Very fluent moves.
+ Well optimized
+ 'Cute' story and main characters
+ It rewards exploration with many power-ups which give access to new skills
+ Character can be customized. Game can be finished with just the basic skills, but some upgraded skills may be quite useful.

Cons:
- Most puzzles are easy, but some details are easy to miss and you may get stuck in front of something without knowing exactly what to do (this is different that knowing what to do but getting constantly killed in the process. That happens, too, but that's not an issue for me)
- Story takes a bit to ramp up, the first couple of hours are somewhere between boring and confusing, you don't know exactly what to do or why.  It feels a bit like random exploration.

A beautiful game that still holds up, though the sequel outshines it in a lot of ways. It has a few very punishing mechanics - manual checkpoints as a resource and lots of instant death hazards being the main two - but it's gorgeous, emotional, and worth giving a try.

[h1]Genre: Metroidvania/Platformer[/h1]

Introduction to this game is just amazing, and I thought this game would offer interesting story, but soon it became clear to me that gameplay is what this game is about.

You play as some unknown creature and your goal is to help the Spirit tree recover three light elements: water, wind and warmth of the forest Nibel, where game takes the place. There is not much to say about the story, it's pretty simple, but I thought ending was done done well and it's pretty sad. The beginning of this game is also pretty emotional.

Gameplay wise this game is great. Combat mostly consists of simple attack which is like an orb that you shoot at your enemies, and also you have charge attack. There are also some other ways to attack the enemy, but I mostly just used the basic attack. Enemies aren't hard, and I played on hard difficulty and there are no bosses in the game, so combat wise this game is fine, suitable for this type of game. However, platforming is the strongest point of this game. Through the game you will unlock many different abilities, like climbing the wall, double jump, gliding through the air and so on. Platforming was really fun to me, and there were some really hard looking sequences, but most of them didn't feel like challenge thanks to these awesome abilities. Even though this is metroidvania, I never felt like I needed to go back and collect stuff which I couldn't before, because the game isn't hard, so you don't really need to go back. One "unique" thing about this game is how you save the game. Aside from some main events where game will automatically be saved, most of the time you will save by filling your blue orbs, which are used for charge attacks and saving, and then spending one of these orbs to generate a save point. Once the save is done, you can come back to this save location to save as many times as you want, or just create save location somewhere else, but you can only have one save location at the time (previous one will dissappear as soon as new one is created). Blue orbs get filled while fighting enemies, breaking stuff etc. This save point is also used to upgrade your abilities. Overall gameplay is pretty good, and I enjoyed it.

I already mentioned that there are no bosses in this game, however there are 3 rush sequences which happen once you find one of the three light sources. As soon as you find them and press action that area will start falling apart and you will need to run for your life. Those sequences were the best parts of the game for me, and they were done really well. Epic music during them helps too. The world is beautiful and not too big, just how I like it. Game took me 10 hours to beat it. Music is also great.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- Rush sequences are amazing
- Great gameplay
- Ending is done good, and it's pretty sad
- The world is beautiful

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- The story is a bit confusing and barely there

[h1]Verdict:[/h1] I enjoyed my time playing this game, and even though at times you feel like game can get a bit repetitive, you get introduced with new abilities, so it helped the game to stay fresh. I think it's a pretty good game, but I can't say that beating this game filled me with desire to play the second game, especially since I heard that world is bigger, and I prefer games like this more linear.

[i]Note: This explains how I rate games in my reviews. https://imgur.com/s7VB3Vj[/i]

Picked up again this game after many years, the thoughts are exactly the same.
The game looks and sounds (not a huge fan of this melodramatic fantasy fairy tale music, but it's well done) great. The graphics detail and animations are worth of a movie.
But the character movement absolutely kills this game. It's so sluggish, there's a one second delay in jumping and moving that breaks everything I want to do. 
From trying to land in a little platform (SO FRUSTRATING to have to waste time in such a simple thing traversing the map, it's probably one of the worst movements I've played in a supposedly perfect game), to trying to avoid the super fast attacks and projectiles from enemies. 
It's just horrible and it absolutely frustrating because I'd really love to play this game further and see all the beautiful sceneries, but it's just such a pain..
Everything else seems to be just top quality, but a metroidvania platformer with bad movement is just a bad joke for me. 

First review:
Well, again the Steam rating system is a misleading and useless one.
Here we have a beautiful production, that out of question. Beautiful graphics, sound (nothing special or new, though) and animations.
But what is this? A Metroidvania platformer with frustrating movement, 8 jumps out of 10 you'll be short or the character will run off the small platform when you're trying to get him in the centre, it's so annoying that something so simple is so hard to do, it pisses me off.
So, the very core of the game is a platformer where the character can't jump or move little bits properly. That's a fail from my point of view.
I see how it's hard to give this game a thumbs down, is not a bad game, but I don't find it fun, and Metroidvania is one of my favourite genres, but I get frustrated often enough to leave the game before I get to 2 hs straight play. 
I wish Steam would change the score system to points and allow the users to be specific on what they like and what they don't just rating aspects of the game, besides leaving a long explanation on a review and a Like/dislike system, it's absolutely obsolete.

Beautiful, varied landscapes and an emotional story. The extensive game world can be explored at your own pace and in almost any order. The skills are extensive and will be introduced gradually. The game is relatively difficult, but new things are introduced little by little and you get the opportunity to practice your new skills. There are a few passages where you have to do "the right thing" under time pressure and the controls aren't always perfect. Other than that, the game is a true masterpiece. I strongly recommend using a controller.

The music is a driving force in the story, and it's really enhancing the already exciting experience. Also I usually listen to the soundtrack on it's own...
It has unique visuals, with good cutscenes and loveable characters.
The gameplay is really good, you have to be on your toes sometimes, but the difficuly is scalable, so no worries. If you have a spare nervous system which you don't need anymore, then you can sacrifice it on the Unhinged achievement's altar.

Combat becomes just jumping around and hoping you get lucky enough to kill everything or running away from enemies rather than target selecting and attacking when there is an opening. The game introduces a dash through projectiles mechanic but then there are some projectiles that you cannot dash through. I just want some meaningful way to deal with enemies that isn't jumping around and spamming shoot mindlessly. If you want a fun game, Hollow Knight is 1000x better than this.

A very beautifuly looking game with overall good gameplay if you're not expecting anything.

As a metroidvania, its a pretty linear one, and it doesnt have many moments where you NEED an ability from later on an early game area to progress, as most of the times, it just holds an ability/health/energy cell and thats it.

And while the combat kind of sucks, since all you can really do is just hammer M1 and spam stomp to kill shit, the moveset is where this game shines the most, while sure, the floaty controls may be disorienting at first if you're coming from a precise platformer, you WILL get used to it at some point, and once you do that and get Bash, man, pulling bash chains is just dopamine generator, and when you pair it with the Light Burst, there's not a SINGULAR area you can't just fly over to if you know what you're doing.

The only real critism I have towards this game (outside of the combat) is the insta-kills, since most dont really have a need to be instants, and its kind of annoying when you're running around with like 13 life cells collected and just fucking die because your pinky toe touched a laser.

Also the save system, while interesting, since it makes you choose between having access to things like Light Burst or not be sent like 3 years back after dying, can be kind of hard to get used to since most games just auto-save. For those struggling with this, if you see an area with a lot of lava, spikes or those lasers on a timer, just save, especially early on where you wont have many ways of using energy anyways, its risk reward system also becomes moot when you backtrack and collect a bunch of energy cells so you can also do that.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a visually stunning and emotionally captivating platformer that takes players on a heartfelt journey through a magical, mystical world. Developed by Moon Studios and published by Microsoft Studios, this game stands out not only for its breathtaking visuals but also for its compelling narrative and engaging gameplay.

From the moment you embark on Ori's adventure, the game envelops you in a lush and vibrant forest filled with enchanting creatures and a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack. The hand-drawn art style is nothing short of spectacular, creating a picturesque environment that feels alive with every pixel. The attention to detail is evident in every frame, making Ori and the Blind Forest a true work of art.

The narrative is a poignant tale of friendship, sacrifice, and resilience. The game introduces players to Ori, a guardian spirit, and his journey to save the dying forest from impending doom. The emotional weight of the story is conveyed through minimalistic yet powerful storytelling, making it easy for players to connect with the characters on a deep level.

The gameplay mechanics are well-crafted, blending tight platforming with a cleverly designed progression system. As Ori gains new abilities, the world opens up, revealing hidden paths and secrets that encourage exploration. The platforming challenges are both exhilarating and challenging, requiring precision and quick reflexes. The balance between difficulty and satisfaction is finely tuned, ensuring that each triumph feels earned.

The game also features a unique checkpoint system that allows players to create their own save points, adding a strategic element to the gameplay. While the difficulty may pose a challenge at times, the sense of accomplishment upon overcoming obstacles is immensely rewarding.

The musical score, composed by Gareth Coker, deserves special mention. The evocative melodies enhance the emotional impact of the narrative, creating a truly immersive experience. The combination of visuals, storytelling, and music forms a harmonious trifecta that elevates Ori and the Blind Forest to a level of artistic brilliance rarely seen in video games.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a masterfully crafted game that transcends the boundaries of its genre. It offers a visual and emotional experience that is both enchanting and memorable. Whether you're a fan of platformers or simply appreciate the artistry of video games, Ori and the Blind Forest is a must-play title that leaves a lasting impression. 7.5/10

I played Hollow Knight and then tried Ori. Sadly, Ori just isn't fun for me. It seems to nearly ONLY be about platforming and avoiding environmental traps like spikes etc, which is fine but in 5+ hours I haven't encountered any fun boss or monsters, which is what I loved about Hollow Knight - the mix of boss fights, soo many enemies AND platforming.

I can not get my head around this game. Maybe its just not for me.

I love Metroidvanias. I love platformers. I love difficult games. This is all three of those so I should love it, but they don't blend together in way that's fun for me. Platforming sequences that require pixel perfect execution, with enemies that do contact damage, where you have three or less hit points, and where failure sends you back to your last *manual* save? That's an anti-pattern for a Metroidvania, which is supposed to encourage taking risks and exploration. 

Its a shame because the visuals and music are genuinely breathtaking. It's clear to me that's doing a lot of the heaving lifting here and giving a badly designed game much more attention than it deserves.

Despite its age, they never fixed the stuttering (unless you install optimization software).  If that bothers you, just buy the Switch version (1080p / 60 fps / no stutter).  

As an "action-platformer" It feels incredibly fluid and addicting to play.  A couple surprising things:  Compared to other metroidvanias, this is far more linear and many sequences of the game are precision-platformer heavy (think Celeste and Super Meat Boy).
Fun little platforming based Metroidvania. Not very deep but definitely a small simple experience.

Personally I am not really a fan of Metroidvanias, but this one was pretty good.

+ natural obstruction/progression (this is something I usually dislike about Metroidvanias, because often areas are simply not accessible, because the door won't open for you at the moment, which feels very unnatural. In this game instead, you can't access certain areas yet, mostly because you don't possess skills like a double jump)
+ beautiful environments and music (though I sometime couldn't distinguish background and foreground)
+ fun and diverse ways to deal with enemies
+ game is not at all repetitive, especially because it is a <10h game

- before unlocking multiple skills the gameplay is quite boring 
- sometimes there'd be an event where you have to escape from something and basically ace a parkour in a certain amount of time. This parkour is often very long and if you die, you have to start from the beginning of the whole parkour, which can be quite frustrating

Summary: If you like Metroidvanias, then this game is a must. Otherwise I'd still suggest at least trying it, since I enjoyed it as well.

Nice game. It was harder than I expected. The visual style made me think it was going to be a different kind of game. It reminds me of Metroid series. There is a lot of back-tracking when getting new specials to collect things previously inaccessible areas. You can save often, which is nice, because there is a lot of dying. There is a lot of instant kill rooms that need to be done a certain way. Some areas were frustrating. Re-spawning is quick to try again. Overall I like the game and played it to the end. It took me 10 hours to beat as a casual player. 

The graphics are very bright and look great. My main complaint would be projectiles are often lost in the bright graphics. Your character is shooting their sparks and the enemy is shooting their sparks. It is difficult to dodge because you can't see what is happening with all the flare. I had to predict if there is another shot hidden in the explosions because I really couldn't see it. And most enemies in the game have projectiles so this was an issue throughout the entire game.

The game is a 2D platformer. There is a background and foreground plane for nice visuals. But a few times I was unable to differentiate the play field from the art. Like there were some lava waterfalls that block passage as a game mechanic. But one or two lava waterfalls were foreground elements and I didn't know I would walk behind it. There are spikes everywhere in the game. Some just hurt you, other ones are instant kill. I still cannot tell the difference even after finishing the game. Many times spikes were difficult to see and I walked right into them. The foreground layer hid a lot of spikes. The traps in the game were often unclear because the graphics are so busy.

For years I’ve heard Ori and the Blind Forest is a fantastic metroidvania, and while I don’t play a lot of metroidvanias, I have really liked a few of them, so last sale I finally decided to pick it up. While this is a fun game, it’s not really what I think of when I think of metroidvania.  Ori and the Blind Forest is extremely linear, both in level design and progression. I never felt like I had to look at my map top figure out where to go next and I never unlocked a new ability that made me go “I can use this to to get past that obstacle I saw 2 zones ago”. In fact, I don’t think I ever felt the need to go back to previous zones. To me, backtracking, non-linear design, where upgrades are exciting because you know exactly where to use them in a previous zone is a staple of the metroidvania genre, but I am by no means an expert, so maybe I am just misinformed.

Ignoring my metroidvania complaint, what you do get is a decent linear platforming game. Ori controls well, the world is quite good looking, but combat sucks and there are sections that feel very badly designed. To start with, the combat auto targets with no way to manually target, so its just you spamming attack while dodging enemy projectiles. It’s extremely simple. While most of the areas were fine and some even provided a fun challenge, there were a small hand full of sections that relied of memorizing environmental patterns through trial an error with no saving or checkpoints for decently long stretches of time. These sections could feel quite frustrating, but luckily there were not too many of them.

Overall, I did have fun with Ori and the Blind Forest, but I do not think it lives up to the hype. Still, I enjoyed my time with it and would say I had fun, so considering you can pick this up for a fiver, I’m still going to recommend it. A fun, but flawed, game can be a great purchase when the price is so low.

For the first time since childhood, I'm not playing a game to finish. Today there are games with dozens of worlds to explore, but these games fail to keep the player connected to the screen. Although I have very little free time, this game keeps me glued to the screen with its small, sweet world, making me want to go to every point of the map. Even if I know that I won't find anything unusual, as soon as I get the ability to go to a point that I couldn't go to at first, I want to run from one end of the map to the other, enter that place and see what's there. The game increases the enjoyment of the game with its visual style and gameplay variety, and enchants people with its music, narration, and spatial atmospheres.
I haven't enjoyed a game this much in a long time.

Before I started the game I had already heard a bunch of stuff on how good that game would be.
So to get the confusion out of the way: Yes the game does a lot of things right and it's well done for it's audience.
The art and the music are an easy drawing point, obviously gorgeous.

The movement of Ori feels good, but has the kind of acceleration that Sonic has. Looking at the included early prototypes it makes much more sense. It looks a lot like Sonic or similar games that focus on platforming. So if you keep pushing you'll accelerate your jump. Movement in general has a sort of momentum which makes it fun to run around. On the other side of that is the problem that precise jumping and sometimes seriously minimal margins for error and such a control scheme don't really go that well together.

Generally I'd fault the margins that you have to make mistakes one of the worst points of the game. The balancing doesn't scale well either. Either they wanted to have spikes to make players stop midgame and sort out scrubs who don't deserve to get the ending or they just were bad at testing.

Another thing is the huge arsenal of jumps and movement options you have.Jump, double jump, loaded jump, projectile deflecting jump, dash, mid-air dash, float. Not sure if I didn't forget some. You might think that that would be great as you have various options for solving the jumping puzzles. Yeah, sorta. But it means that you stomp a barrier, jump, dash, double jump, float, projectile deflect, wall grab, load jump and float with projectile jumps again. It's as if the designers couldn't decide which of those fancy movement patterns they should keep when they made their first prototypes and kept them all in. I don't remember any game that has 5 dedicated jump buttons that have further variants due to where and how you trigger them. It makes for quite some useless complexity.

When you play this game, you need to be aware what it offers. If you like getting chased by a boulder and have to figure out where to jump (which means you die a lot while figuring out where to go), then Ori got you covered. If you don't like to die 15 times to some strange falling rock because you missed one projectile to jump up from, don't play this game. Mind inconsistencies as well: there is a lava rain that you avoid while moving upwards. You still need to go further upwards, but suddenly, there is nothing to be fast enough anymore. Did the lava blobs work for jumping from them earlier? No. Do the work now? Yes. Why? Well, they are smaller now! Random rule-changes like that are really common as well. Often it's trial and error what is background and what is dangerous foreground. Looks great, but isn't very readable - specially since the design changes quite often. The developers see that as offering variation, but readability of obstacles should not be sacrificed in my opinion.

I did expect a bit more from the story as well. It's cute, don't get me wrong. It's rare enough to see protective mothers take the main stage, so that's a positive. The story is just a lot like the game: evoke some mood, then there follows some action. The action made rarely sense to me. It is cute though and therefore enjoyable.

So generally the game is quite hard mostly due to being unfair. If you like to bash your head against a wall until it breaks, or kaizo traps in general, it might be one of the entry point games with a beautiful world and high production value. To me, those design patterns are awful - and even after completing the challenge there is no relief or feeling of a win left. It's a game held in high regard, but I'll be very cautious to recommend it to anyone. I can see that happening, but in general I'd recommend to search for alternatives.

Horrendous platforming. Momentum lost for no reason. Ori has a double jump and can get a third but you are better off not jumping. It'll kill you 100% of the time. The escapes are just abysmal. Do yourself a favor just play Earthworm Jim. You'll actually have fun.

Decent metroidvania themed game! Few notes:

Lore/Storytelling: Compared to other games I have played/reviewed in the past, the story-line lacks depth, however it makes it quite easy and simple to understand. For me, I actually enjoy this "easy-to-understand" style of storytelling, when compared to similar games such as Hollow Knight (which I kinda never understood). Since others may find it too simplistic, it ranks about average - 6.5/10. 

Art/Design: AMAZING!!! Stunning visuals, which feel smooth and flush. Due to the "high resolution" nature of the game (not pixelated), it makes it seem more 3-d and more of a modern game. The use of color is perfect, and the colors are quite saturated/powerful in nature, resulting in the game standing out more. Even if the game is quite old, it still holds its own as my singular favorite "eye pleasing" metroidvania game - 10/10.

Game-play: Decent would be the word for the game-play. The exploring aspect of the game is decent, albeit a little overdone (similar things over and over again), while the mechanical aspect of the game is better. It includes similar movement abilities to other metroidvania games, with the use of wall jumps, dashs, etc. I found that the movement was decently flush, however there were too many different skills/controls for my liking (Also, the dash was kinda wonky, imo). The flow of the game was amazing, with the difficulty progressively getting harder at a linear rate, resulting in the game always feeling challenging to play. Lastly, the game in my opinion is WAY TOO SHORT! I always explore all regions, and it still only took me less than 10 hours total. Taking everything into account, the game play ranks at a 6/10.

Final Score: 7/10
Decent/Meh metroidvania, with some flaws mainly in the gameplay region, resulting in a lower score. Honestly, the art style of the game absolutely carries the game itself, and without it, the game would rank horribly. 
Probably wouldn't play again, however I will be writing a review on its squeal soon! ("Ori and the Will of the Wisps"), and hopefully it ranks higher.

Ori and the blind forest is so much worse than the sequel, Ori and the will of the wisps. It fails to be a metroidvania and a 2D platformer. While you do find new abilities in each area, there is no reason to backtrack as the upgrades from backtracking are useless. The platforming doesn't get good until the very end once you have unlocked all the abilities, early to mid game you either don't have any cool abilities yet or you have to carry a heavy orb which strips you of all your cool abilities.
Even if it wasn't sold as a platforming rich metroidvania, it still isn't a very good game. The combat is pointless, you just tap x and a floating orb shoots things for you. All the bosses are platforming set pieces so the combat doesn't matter anyway. There is only 1 mini boss enemy but its incredibly easy, it just has lots of health (press x lots of times while walking left and right).
The save system is awful, you have to create checkpoints yourself. In a first play through, you will forget to save many times, losing you a lot of progress which would be avoided with auto save or physical checkpoints.
The tech tree adds nothing to the game, it simply serves to make the combat, platforming and secret hunting more bearable.
I don't think the visuals are as noteworthy as some others seem to think. They can sometimes make it hard to differentiate spikes and platforms, especially when wall jumping - a touch too far will get Ori impaled on the tiniest grey thorn, other times you can walk through a pit of spikes without a scratch. The backgrounds can also interfere sometimes in the same way.
The story is a joke. A forest creature is dying, Ori says "I am the Lorax, i speak for the trees.", then the forest creature is magically revived by tree energy. This is then repeated throughout the game.
I don't understand how this game is so overrated, but I am glad it is, as otherwise it wouldn't have got a sequel. The only redeeming feature of this game is the 'bash' platforming ability but its also in the second game too, Ori and the will of the wisps, which is so much better than this game in every way.
Just play the second game.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a masterpiece that redefines the gaming experience. This game is nothing short of breathtaking; its stunning visuals, emotionally immersive storyline, and enchanting soundtrack create an unforgettable journey. From the very first moments, I was captivated by the rich, vibrant world and the touching narrative that unfolds throughout.

The level design is a work of art, seamlessly blending challenging platforming elements with a heartfelt story. The gameplay mechanics are fluid, making every jump, every puzzle, and every encounter feel like a work of pure magic. The attention to detail in the animation and environment is awe-inspiring, drawing players into a world that feels alive and full of wonder.

But it's not just about the gameplay—the emotional depth of Ori and the Blind Forest is what truly sets it apart. The bond formed with the characters and the emotional rollercoaster they take you on is a testament to the incredible storytelling.

The musical score deserves special mention; it complements every moment perfectly, adding an extra layer of emotion and depth to an already profound experience.

In short, Ori and the Blind Forest is a masterpiece of gaming artistry. It's a heartfelt journey that touches the soul and leaves a lasting impression. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone looking for an unforgettable gaming experience.

[h1] Ori and the Blind Forest: Definitive Edition [/h1]

Ori and the Blind Forest is a game that I've known for the longest time but never gotten around to playing - until now. And while my first impression of it was very strong, that initial reaction slowly waned and fluctuated as I continued to play. That's not to say I didn't enjoy it. I certainly did, but overall, I'd say Ori and The Blind Forest had the potential to be a lot better than I expected. It's visually stunning, fun, and annoying all at the same time. My thoughts in more detail: 

[h2] The Positives ▼ [/h2]

[b] 1. The Art [/b]
The most impressive thing about Ori and the Blind Forest has got to be its strong visual and artistic direction. Despite releasing in 2016, it hasn't aged a day, and I'm confident it will continue to look timeless for decades to come. Never have I ever played a game that looks more like a painting in motion, and considering this is the very first game Moon Studios has ever made, I can't imagine how much better it's going to look once I move on to Will of the Wisps.

[b] 2. Great Soundtrack [/b]
Aside from the incredible art direction, another aspect that stuck with me long after I finished the game was its beautiful OST. It does a fantastic job of setting the mood and atmosphere of a scene, situation, and location. It's the backbone behind many emotionally hard-hitting moments, and I can't praise it enough. 

[b] 3. Enemy Variety [/b]
One of the things I appreciate most about Ori is the respectable amount of variation when it comes to enemies. Overall, there are around ten unique kinds of foes, each with distinctive looks and strengths that force players to adapt and use different evasive strategies when approaching them. Because of this, it helps to prevent the gameplay from ever feeling too stale and repetitive.

[h2] The Average ▼ [/h2]

[b] 1. The Action [/b]
Ori and the Blind Forest is an Action Platformer, and while the platforming held up its part of the bargain, I can't say the same about the action. Truthfully, it's not that mechanically exciting or engaging to play. And most combat encounters, especially in the early game, can be won by mindlessly spamming the attack button or some slight variations of it. It's serviceable and decent enough, but it's nothing to write home about. 

[b] 2. The Story [/b]
In general, I think the writers succeeded at what they set out to do, and that's to tell an emotional story about parental love and the pain that comes with losing those we care most about. However, it left me with some questions, especially regarding how certain things in the world of Ori work. Even after reading multiple wikis, I'm still just as confused, and I can't deny that it certainly did take some enjoyment out of the experience. If you're wondering what those questions are, I'll post them below, so unless you've finished the game, don't look. 

 [spoiler] The Spirit Tree is supposed to act as the caretaker of the forest. Why release a fatal flash of light if it means killing dozens of innocent forest-dwelling animals? [/spoiler]

 [spoiler] We learned that Ori isn't the only member of his species. Why does it matter so much to the spirit tree if one goes missing? How is that a valid reason to release that deadly flash of light? I could understand if he were the last of his kind and the spirit tree was desperate enough to trade dozens of lives for his, but that wasn't the case. [/spoiler]

 [spoiler] How does Gumo know where to look for Naru to revive her? He conveniently showed up despite never knowing her location. [/spoiler]

 [h2] The Negatives ▼ [/h2]

[b] 1. Annoying Level Design [/b]

Pretty much every fault that I find annoying about Ori and the Blind Forest, in one way or another, ends up having to do with its level designs: Unsatisfying to explore, trial and error gameplay, and environmental hazards. 

‣ Let's talk about what I believe to be the game's biggest flaw: It's just not as satisfying to explore as it should be. Allow me to explain why. Exploration is a crucial part of the gameplay loop of Ori and what makes it so fun. It's the driving method by which players collect items and upgrade their many stats. However, these items are almost always locked behind some obstacle that prevents players from getting them unless they have unlocked a specific ability needed to solve the problem. While this design choice is normally appropriate when done in moderation, the problem in Ori is that it feels lopsided. When I explore an area, it feels like, constantly, I'm running into items that I cannot obtain at least half of the time, if not more. All it does is create unnecessary and excessive backtracking, make exploration unrewarding, and encourage players to wait until the very late game to begin fully exploring the map rather than during. This dichotomy is the epitome of blue-balled level designs, and it's annoying. 

‣ Another aspect of the level design that I found annoying is how it progressively got more trial and error as time went on. There were many times when you, as the player, would simply die because you had no idea what to anticipate. Falling down and not knowing there are spikes at the bottom, Kuro slamming into a cavern and causing rocks to fall on you, etc. It's moments like these when players would have no idea what to predict or anticipate and are given next to no reaction time to evade danger, are annoying and make every death feel less about your lack of skill as a player and more to do with the game creating an unfair situation where dying feels almost a requirement before one knows what to do. 

‣ I kept the least impactful issue for last, and it has to do with how [u] some [/u] of the environmental hazards just don't do a good enough job contrasting against the rest of the background, thus making it very easy to get hurt by them on accident. And for anybody playing on hard like I did, the problem only gets worse because these hazards often deal insane damage to your HP, and sometimes, there are environmental hazards that will just outright kill you in one hit. Keep this problem aware in your mind, and you'll be surprised by how often you'll get screwed by it. 

[h3] My Final Thoughts [/h3]
Despite my problems with Ori and the Blind Forest, I believe it remains a worthwhile experience. It's a good game, albeit with some rough edges, but one that I still think has a lot of entertainment and artistry to offer to the players. I recommend considering Ori and the Blind Forest on your list of games to buy once it goes on sale.

You will smile.
You will laugh.
You will be captivated by the beautiful art of Ori's world.
You will love these characters in no time at all.
You will get upset at yourself for failing to help Ori complete his journey because you're stuck on a puzzle.
You will persevere and overcome your weaknesses.
You will learn new skills and adapt to every scenario the game presents.
You will conquer every puzzle the game throws at you; not because you're great at platformers or because the puzzles are just hard enough to pose a challenge without being impossible, but because you want to see the story through to the end. 
And at the end of your journey, you will cry.
Yes you will cry.
And in that moment you will understand. That childhood joy from playing your favorite games you thought you'd never see again? You feel it again. You felt it every hour you played Ori. You just didn't realize what it was until it was all over.

Maximum mark possible: 10/10. Perfect music, perfect artistic implementation, perfect tale plot, perfect control and gameplay, perfect optimizations, perfect level design. No platformer arcade can be done better. The game features antigravity (by means of upwards air currents), variable gravity, variable time flow (bash skill), water capacities, light emitting entities, and snowfall. There is no raining in this game, though. Graphics has optimal balance between softness/bloom and crispiness.
Unfortunately, levels are not procedurally generated in this game. Levels are master-crafted by talented designers. Game locations depict classical combination of dirt, fire, bogs and icy plains. Air substance is also utilised with the concept of levitating. It seems you do not HAVE to achieve powerups in [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jPdnR0sAqO4]predefined order[/url], although the final boss will not be playable until you get ALL of them. Levels are stitched seamlessly. There is no concept such as loading screens or special doors or definite edges between locations. But you need special abilities learned by reaching the most deep part of each location.
Game uses ethereal voices as means of narrating the plot. The game even features its own music theme in various arrangements throughout the crucial parts of the plot. Although it is not always obvious how to open some doors or solve some puzzles (because new concepts appear on average 3-4 times per level, e.g. deflecting spider missile), this way it makes you explore more. Most frequent obstacle in the game are spikes. Falling does not hurt you.
XBOX gamepad is suited best. Generic gamepads may have issues with some buttons/actions available still only on keyboard (e.g. climb, grab), as key mapping is not implemented in this game. The game runs smoothly even on integrated GPU, which is not always the case with AAA platformers.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a visual treat of a Metriodvania that is a tad limited due to it's simplified map and it's art style in game play. Ori also has a story that got me thinking about it's themes more than I thought I would, which is a testament to how it tells it's plot over the course of the ~10 hour runtime.

While really appealing to the eyes, the visual style in game play through me off a bit. Something about Ori's frames and animations made the game hard to follow sometimes. This doubled for some enemies as well; it wasn't clear sometimes what could or could not hurt me due to the colors, particles, and how the background and foreground meshed together. By the end of the game I got mostly used to it and by no means did it ruin the experience. The visuals should be seen as a positive, as they are absolutely gorgeous. Even playing this in 2024, there is no clear comparison. Each area has visual identity due to the wide variety of colors used, with the game even going as far as to not re-use background elements. 

While the game is pitched as a Metroidvania, it feels much more like a linear platformer in terms of it's progression. To me, part of the fun of the Metroid titles is the piecing together of the map utilizing both your new abilities and knowledge. Instead, Ori and the Blind Forest points you right where you need to go. There is no real mental "mapping" step that occurs when piecing the map together. The only time I needed to note places to return to was for upgrades, not story or mandatory progression. 

Some smaller cool things of note is it's checkpoint and upgrade system. Checkpoints are made by you, created using a resource in the game. There aren't too many abilities competing for that resource, so I never felt like the mechanic was explored to it's full potential, but it still was a neat idea. The interesting thing that I found in Ori's upgrade system is that by the end of the game, I was maybe only 3/4 through all the upgrades. This made choices throughout the game more meaningful as I knew I wouldn't obtain enough resources to fully flesh out the upgrade tree without farming. I like that, wish more games followed that lesson. 

Overall, it's a solid Metroidvania I would recommend to anyone, even those that aren't particularly invested in the genre.

As much as there is to love and praise about this game, certain aspects make it frustrating and unsatisfying to me.

I can enjoy hunting hidden extras, but the way difficulty in Ori works makes health upgrades unsatisfying. You've gotten more health? Good job. The same set of enemies with a different colour to the last do three damage this time. Even spikes work like this. 
This attempt at scaling difficulty is so transparent and uninteresting (contrast with how Axiom Verge introduces new enemy types and reuses old ones in interesting ways) that I question whether it's worth including at all. If you're gonna reuse the same few enemies anyway, why not forgo player-upgrades so you don't need to buff enemies? If anything there'll be players drawn to this sort of beautifully rendered game who'd find concept art and the like more rewarding for reaching hidden goodies.

Regrettably, there are also problems with the escapes concluding dungeons.
I can understand making them peaks of drama and difficulty, but the result is frustrating and tiring. If anything it reminded me of the soulsborne experience. In Dark Souls after every failed attempt at a boss you're returned to your last bonfire. Sure, sometimes the run back to the boss is more long and annoying than necessary, but you get that breathing space before it's back to rolling for your life to epic music.
Meanwhile Ori does not give you that breathing space. The escapes are sprints and with each failed attempt you're just back at the start with the music still going strong. That's why it feels tiring. The difficulty makes breaks necessary, but there isn't a natural place to take one. The music loses any feeling of awe as you (well, the likes of me anyhow) struggle to overcome the same obstacles.

If you can overlook these flaws then Ori and the Blind Forest is lovely. But they impacted my experience to the extent that I cannot.

TL;DR: Ori and the Blind Forest is a beautiful platformer with a heart-felt story and compelling art style. Unfortunately, the grindy and annoying game mechanics gradually wear away any enjoyment I was getting from my first impressions. 

As mentioned, the game is visually beautiful, and the definitive edition really shines. The environments, characters, and effects are all designed with a compelling and consistent art style. The animations are also wonderful and full of character.

Unfortunately, the art style is SO consistent, it makes visually parsing the environment extremely difficult. Determining the difference between an environmental hazard and background decoration is a bit of a learning curve, leading to a lot of unpleasant surprises. 

This game is also full of a LOT of sudden, cheap, and unavoidable deaths. Many areas rely on you having died before and knowing what's coming. Personally, I'm not a fan of that type of 'tutorial'. The save system is very manual, and you need to spend energy on saves, so if you are either low on energy or forgetful, these cheap deaths can set you back pretty far. 

This game also has a metroid-vania style world that you can traverse freely, but will need to come back to areas after unlocking abilities that allow further progression. This is fine for the most part, but enemies respawn immediately upon leaving an area, meaning you will have to fight through the same group of enemies multiple times just to get from A to B. 

The enemy respawning and non-linear progression also makes it difficult to figure out where you need to go next, re-killing the same enemies over and over are you wader around aimlessly. Some people might like this style, but it feels like a frustrating waste of my time. 

If you really like metroid-vanias, then this game might be for you. Personally, the gameplay is more frustrating than fun, and the nice aesthetics aren't enough to overcome it.

Long review ahead, no spoilers. Ori has become that game for me that I now compare all other games to. I've played it all the way through at least twice at this point and I can easily see myself  playing it through every other year or so. It's just a spectacular game and I'll outline my reasons for saying so below. As of this review I have logged just over 40 hours, have of course played the second one (Will of the Wisps) and for reference I play on PC and enjoy other games such as Terraria, Hollow Knight (although I never finished that), Spyro, Gris, and Kena Bridge of Spirits. 

1) Game-play is fantastic. And I mean this in every sense. No where is the game clunky, glitchy, or buggy (at least not in my experience). Movement and platforming are extremely smooth and not frustrating (when it was frustrating it was only a skill issue not a game issue). You progressively learn more skills that you can mix and match to fit your play-style and different combat situations. Combat itself is challenging but if you've been playing the way the game teaches you to play and use  your abilities appropriately it's not overly challenging (punishing combat is why I didn't finish Hollow Knight for reference). 

2) Puzzles are just challenging enough and very rewarding. I love puzzles-platformers/games, I love finding secret collectibles and generally enjoy games where the main character is trying to make the world better or fix it from evil. Like the combat, the puzzles can be challenging however if you are learning the skills the game is trying to teach you usually they are self-explanatory and I don't recall having to watch many walkthroughs to figure things out (plus that takes the fun out of it). The Puzzles themselves are training for whatever combat you may need in that level or beyond and I think they do a fantastic job at preparing you for that. 

3) Like most - if not all - other reviews rave about, the atmosphere is incredible. Again, I mean this in every sense. The emotional story-telling is on point (I've cried every time). The level/map design is superb with every area so distinct and unique. And THE MUSIC. The music is absolutely incredible, and it also is unique per section of map which I love it's not just the same music the whole game. The game is so beautiful to look at and play, it's actually not annoying to run around at the end collecting everything and finding hidden places because it's just so pretty (yes, I'm a bit of a completionist and so I had to get that achievement😂). 

I literally could go on and on, but if you're still reading this and haven't purchased/played the game what are you still doing here?

I feel Ori and the Blind Forest is as much a work of art as a game. Developed by Moon Studios and published by Microsoft Studios, released in 2015 for Windows and Xbox One, and later gracing the Nintendo Switch in 2019 through the further improved Definitive Edition, Ori and the Blind Forest captivated me throughout my 22-hour playthrough. For an overview, Ori and the Blind Forest is a 2D Metroidvania, a genre known for its focus on exploration, item collection, and backtracking to previously unreachable areas. You play as Ori, a delicate white spirit, and guided by Sein, the embodiment of the Forest's Spirit Tree, players embark on a story filled with challenging platforming and surprisingly complex puzzles. The game beautifully balances agility and precision as Ori navigates the lush world while Sein provides the means to battle foes and shatter obstacles with Spirit Flames. The most enthralling element is the stunning attention paid to the artwork that paints the environment of Nibel. Mahler explained, "You see this tree in the background and this mushroom and this rock? That's the only place you'll ever see those assets." What feels like endless gorgeous artworks paint the environment of the ancient forest world known as Nibel. This pairs with a simple but elegant story that made me tear up as the credits rolled, with the ethereal orchestral soundtrack composed by Gareth Coker (Halo Infinite, ARK: Survival Evolved). 

With the definitive edition comes behind-the-scenes filming the recording of the soundtracks, and seeing the live performances of these pieces really put into perspective the effort that went into making this game. It is no wonder it was nominated for best independent game. This is by far the most satisfying character to control I have experienced. Best played with a controller, platforming with Ori is enough to maintain the game's enjoyment alone. This is combined with numerous mechanics that all blend into what is the best platformer released for the modern system generation. One standout feature is the "Soul Links" save system, which allows players to save their progress at any point, provided they have collected enough energy cells. The scarcity of these cells forces players to be careful with their use, adding an extra layer of depth to the game.

Additionally, a simple but effective upgrade system lets players enhance Ori's abilities, making the journey more manageable as they progress. Newly unlocked powers align with the following unlocked areas: the ability to jump from forest lanterns. These are also present in the early area of Nibel but can only be accessed later to reward those who retrace their steps. This is further expanded upon in the definitive edition, adding 2 new areas that provide a deeper backstory to the character of Naru, along with 2 more abilities and the inclusion of the spirit wells, which give the ability to fast travel between areas. This reduces any slight tedium in backtracking. However, it does not make backtracking a fruitless effort for those who wish to refrain from using the wells. For a first playthrough, the story is an emotional story of reunion that genuinely brought a tear to my eye. The balance of the account to gameplay enables subsequent playthroughs to not be marred by the repetition of the story beats; it does not become **** overall; this game is absolutely unmissable.

Great game. A sweet story, beautiful artwork and just enough original ideas for a distinct feel. I particularly enjoyed the well-balanced difficulty together with fluid controls -- Ori makes you succeed in jump-and-run sequences you didn't even know you could manage.

The one thing I didn't like that much might be the in-game music: Apart from the title theme and the escape sequences, the soundtrack is just unremarkable and generic.

+ Beautiful Artstyle and soundtrack.
+ heartwarming sweet story.

- Moving forward in this story is such a pain.
- Horrendous save system. (Why can't it have autosaves??) 
- Ori sometimes feels like moving a boulder or like moving on ice.

I truly wish that I would love this game, however I find it hard to love.

The art style, soundtrack and story is good but I find it frustrating to move around and actually play the game. Firstly the saves. It works on the fact, you can create save in a safe space that cost energy. Good... if it wasn't unintuitive to save the game manualy when platforming. I can't even count the times when I have covered great chunk of the game, died and then appeared half map across because I forgot this game does not have automatic saves. 

Doors that are energy locked cost energy, so it isn't just about how many energy balls you have collected but if you have managed to get there without spending energy. Together with having to manually save that cost energy it was frustrating to find gates that I could possibly past but I couldn't because of how it worked.

The shooting mechanic seems alright, however it takes so long to kill the enemies and there is no way how you can fight back at a close combat to knock the enemy off you if they are about to hit you. When you have flying enemies dashing at you, this becomes quite annoying.

The labyring misty woods felt wonky and horrendous to navigate through. 

And then there are the controls. Movement abilities should make you be able to cover more areas in the map. What they shouldn't be though is that getting them is necessary for Ori to be actually controllable. Before you get double jump it is pain to jump onto any platform that is just a few pixels too high for ory to climb on. Jumping on walls is hard and even when you get the double jump traversing through the world is such pain in the ass before you get bash ability that makes it at least somewhat playable.

If you want to play Ori, just play the sequel.

Dive into the mesmerizing world of "Ori and the Blind Forest," a metroidvania that stands out for its breathtaking beauty and heartwarming narrative.

Pros

World/Art design:  Ori's forest and its inhabitants are a visual feast. The meticulous artistry brings characters and settings to life, imbuing each place and stage with a distinct ambiance. The cold tribe emanates a sense of mystery and a haunting history, while the volcano exudes intensity. The exploration of the intriguing mom tribe is a highlight, showcasing a unique and captivating design.

Story and world changes: While the narrative follows a simple premise, it evolves into a compelling tale, centered around Ori's quest to reunite with their mother. The motivations of the main villain add a heartbreaking layer to the story. As the plot progresses, subtle changes in the environment, such as the purification of water, enhance the world's vibrancy and sense of life.

Escape sections: The game's pinnacle moments come during escape sections, offering a perfect blend of challenge and visual splendor. From cleansing water to floating out of the cold tribe and escaping the bird, these sequences are both visually stunning and audibly captivating. The cinematic and beautiful design of these segments elevates the gaming experience.

Music: Gareth Coker's musical composition deserves high praise, seamlessly complementing the game's theme and design. The soundtrack excels in delivering tranquility during serene moments, such as underwater sequences, and intensifying emotions during challenging sections like escape sequences. A remarkable job in enhancing the overall experience.

Mobility: While initially feeling a bit sluggish, Ori's mobility becomes a source of enjoyment as abilities are gained. Glide with the feather and navigate through enemies and projectiles, offering an interesting and entertaining mechanic. By the game's conclusion, the sense of accomplishment from mastering these abilities is truly satisfying.

Cons

Death and saving mechanics: The frustration lies in the dying process, especially during platforming sections with thorns. It's easy to succumb to these hazards, and the saving mechanic exacerbates the issue. While it's effortless to save frequently, it feels more like a chore than a strategic choice. A different approach, encouraging less frequent saves and more substantial retries, could enhance the overall experience.

Enemy design and Combat:  Combat lacks the engagement expected from a metroidvania. Although new abilities spice up the combat, the primary mechanic — the spirit flame — feels mundane. Dying easily during combat, combined with a lack of impact from hits, leads to a less satisfying combat experience. The enemies themselves lack excitement and prove more enjoyable to avoid than confront.

Summary: "Ori and the Blind Forest" is a stunning game with immense potential. From its exceptional art design to the heartwarming music, it captivates players. While there are areas for improvement, the game ultimately stands as a remarkable journey filled with heartfelt moments.

I simply don't understand the praises this game gets. It's definitely not a bad game, but after 4 hours, it's more frustrating than good. And not frustrating because it's challenging, frustrating because its mechanics and gameplay, arguably the most important parts of a platformer in my opinion, are shallow.
The one thing I can give Ori is the graphics. The game looks absolutely stunning.

Simply one of the best metroidvania I've ever played. The art direction and musics are absolutely magnificent. Contrary to what some critics say, the scenery and platforms are perfectly obvious and we easily understand the element we can interact with. The scripted action scenes are just completely gripping. It's been a long time since I've been so emotionally involved in a game with pure mindblow moments. 

The difficulty level is well balanced if we take time to build-in the character power and we always know what to do even if precise instructions are not provided. 

There are a few negative points : 
1) only 10h to 100% the game and only 6 hours to finish the game (it definitely mean I loved this game if 6 hours lifetime is among the critics!)
2) The gameplay of the saving points. 

Point 2) was for me the most frustrating. This is really unusual in modern game that the player has to deal by themselves on the saving points. That being said, I am not sure developpers could have made it differently without affecting the game experience (that is amazing!). They even provided a healing mechanic with the save such that players have some "interest" to save regularly.

This frustration is just arising because such gameplay mechanic is almost never encoutered and usually developpers pre-determine the locations of checkpoints, such that players are not used to "keep in mind" to save ! When thinking about it, this could make any game easier when used with wiseness since each player could choose to save between hard obstacles, fixing by themselves their own difficulty treshold. I have to admit that the fact that I forgot to save during a few very long phases challenged my self-control at few occasions (even twice or three times in a row...) and that's why I decided to put it in the negative points. But this is more a warning for future players : Do not forget to summon your checkpoints !

Overall: a fun game, worth your time, but marred by a few frustrating let-down moments. 

Cute presentation and fun traversal abilities, and I found the pacing to be just right - individual gimmicks rarely outstay their welcome, and are replaced with something fresh on a pretty regular basis. I enjoyed exploring the world and progressing through the adventure.

However, it is rough around the edges. I found many hazards blended into the environment too much or were poorly telegraphed, which led me to run straight into them; and the controls in general aren't tight enough for some of the more demanding platforming sections to be truly enjoyable. Missing a few QoL changes, like allowing me to skip certain dialogue/story beats if I've seen them once, because I made a save point just before them and keep dying just after them. Story is also fairly bland.

Thank you, Moon Studios, Microsoft Studios, Wabi Sabi Sound Inc., MediaLab, Lionbridge Game Services, and all those who contributed to this game and the series. I'm well on my way to played the sequel soon. <3
