I picked up Ori and its Sequel in the Summer sale of 2023. I have heard about this game for Ages and the art style was always an attraction, but i felt the platforming might be beyond my Skill set, as i am more of an RPG/FPS player. I even tried to refund it within 2 hours as i felt i was not enjoying the game. Somehow common sense prevailed and i persisted. I am Happy i did.

The game has 3 major positives :

1. The Artstyle : its a beautiful looking art piece. The Setpieces, the colours and the lighting is so damn good
2. The Music : If i don't speak about the masterpiece music, it would be a disservice to this game. The Music against the environments match  and the chase sequence music puts you on the edge. 
3. The platforming : Once you slowly get the hang of the controls and abilities the platyforming is butter smooth. You can seamlesly pull combo moves and its so fluid that you feel its a GOD ( though you are a sweet little spirit)

Cons : The platforming can be a bit hard at times and some boss fights are a pain. 

I highly recommend everyone plays it once, and slowly plod away and enjoy this masterpiece.

This game is very difficult. I admit that I am not a great player, but after getting through one section that required I do numerous deflection jumps chained together with other skills and if you mess up you die and have to start the chain over again, I am done. I had the game set to easy, but this only affects combat. The platforming is not for amateurs.

Never has a game had me feel more like a brainlet. "How the **** was I supposed to know?" Was my creed. I constantly died during chase scenes, puzzles, and combat. Learning by dying constantly is not only the opposite of fun and rewarding, but it completely destroys any love for the art and music of this game. What I'm left with is bitter disappointment. Do i blame the game? Or myself? I'll say that I did find the usage twists of both enemies and abilities alike intriguing. The way that some enemies can be abilities in their own right is awesome. Using them in tandem with your own kit is incredible, feels nice and fluid. Some levels feel like just that, levels. They don't feel very immersive at all, then when you inevitably start the death snowball you begin to hate it even more. I think this is just a platformer thing after watching Mac's review for the second game. "For 10 minutes I did have fun... but the rest of the time I wanted to kill myself." Exactly/10.

I get straight to the point: Is this game a bad game? No.
But there's a FAR better game out there and its name is "Ori and the Will of the Wisps".
Ori and the Blind Forest feels like a semi-roguelite because of how many baffeling trial-and-error passages the game has. Its saving grace is a save-system that lets you save yourself in exchange for a magical ressource. The problem stems from the fact that you'll forget the system exists A LOT a first and so will eventually see annoying/unskippable cutscenes a lot. Enemies and their placements feel punishing sometimes - not in a good way and the main character tends to feel "floaty". I applaude the devs for trying some new sort of "battle system mechanic" (Ori mostly attack over homing-missle-attacks) which sounds cute in theory but plays rather disconnected and ... not all that great. 
The music and artdesign are the bomb tho..

Overall: The story itself isn't deep (good but not deep!). You can watch a summary on YT and walk right on to the next game.

Lets get the CONS out of the way:
Keybinds: Ori doesn't let you change the keybinds, which sucks when the defaults are less than optimal. This was the most glaring issue for me as my pinky finger would constantly be dying from pain trying to juggle between the shift key and control key while the rest controlled the character with WASD. It went to a point where i used both hands on the left side of my keyboard to get through an area without mobs, just had difficult platforming.

Combat: The game's combat is shallow, the main combat system only allows u to spam left click for it to auto target and kill mobs. There's some variation like charged attacks but thats more or less all it offers.

OST: While Ori has some absolutely beautiful scores, it lacks in variety. They become a lot less special by the time u hear the same soundtrack for a similar sequence for the 4th time.

Mobs: To be specific, mob variety. Often time it will be the same mob I saw in the last area with a different coat of paint. Instead of throwing poison, it now throws magma.

Pixelated sprites: speaks for itself, a lot of the times i was noticing a lot of compressed image cards, specially during cutscenes.

Most, if not all of these issues can be stemmed from it being an Indie game, and aren't really an issue throughout the amazing 10hr content (and more) that Ori offers. And I hear all of these were not only fixed, but even improved upon in the second game so my expectation and hype for it is real high.

Now onto the goods:
Gameplay(8/10):
Despite the combat being "meh", Ori's platforming is next level. It gives you a bunch of skills to help you traverse the world. The different obstacles you face are all unique and really feels like the devs made the different skills first, and then found out every possible obstacle for it instead of doing it the other way around. I almost never found myself doing the same thing.
Speaking of abilities, bash has to be one of the most unique things you can do in a game. It is easily one of the most satisfying maneuvers you can pull off in a video game after Sekiro's deflection.
The skill tree is very minimal, but it's necessary and doesn't feel shallow. It allows helpful upgrades to your skills or just percentage increases to damage for combat. 
The gameplay loop in Ori is always changing right until the end even with just a handful of abilities and its really fun and fluid. 

Story and Narrative(7/10):
Ori's story isn't all too complicated but the narrative makes it a bit hard to understand at first. It really is gameplay focused where it shines the best. But Ori's story had some pacing issues at the beginning I felt, but building slow and lasting characters for players to care about in a 10hr game with rapid fast gameplay can be difficult, and the game it felt like just wanted to get on with it to the actual gameplay part. The game tells the story about Ori trying to save the forest by restoring its different elements back to how they were in hopes to save his friend, or guardian rather, Naru. The story is fine, and really wraps everything together, but don't expect it to leave a lasting effect or anything 

3.Visuals(9/10):
Artstyle > Graphics is a motto I live by and Ori is a prime example of this. The visuals of Ori speak for themselves. The animations are fluid, with a painterly artstyle combining 2d and 3d imagery to make a final lively product. It really feels like the devs were able to portray exactly how they imagined the game would look like in their minds and it is absolutely mesmerizing. I have no doubt a large majority of people bought the game just off of visual appeal because it looks absolutely gorgeous in every setting. It is now in my top 5 favorite games in terms of visuals.

Score(8/10):
Ori's score is magnificent despite the lack of variety. They fit the scenarios and really make you feel like you are about to achieve something great putting a great deal of pressure in your mind during timed sequences. For a small indie studio, OSTs like this isn't expected, I will absolutely be listening to some tracks in my offtime.

Final score - [8.5/10]
Ori and the Blind Forest is an amazing short experience providing satisfying gameplay elements focusing on platforming, incredible visuals and astonishing soundtrack along with it. I have a feeling the second one will becoming one of the best games I have played period.

I made a huge mistake when I decided to buy this game. I regret it. Yes, the visuals are appealing. That's where the good parts end. Everything else is extremely bad. This game is annoyingly difficult. The saves system is ridiculous. Because of these two facts, you have to repeat the same thing again, and again, and again. (Did I ever tell you what the definition of insanity is?) The gaming process is as follows: You navigate the map a little bit. If you are lucky, you don't die in the process. Most times, you are not lucky. The controls are very hard, and the map design is built around the idea of pressing the correct button (usually the jump one) in a very exact and precise moment. If you fail to do it, you fall. Then you have to repeat the same thing again. In some cases, you just fall, then it's simpler, you just retry. In other cases, you fall to your death. Then you have to retry much more, from the last point where you saved. Things as simple as jumping up to the next platform of the level can take dozens of retries and a lot of time which I cannot consider anything else then wasted because this process does not bring any joy and, when and if you finally succeed after many failed attempts, there's no taste of satisfaction, only bitterness and frustration. I mean it. Here's the platform right in front of you. In order to jump to it, you have to press the button at a very specific point. One pixel below, and you will miss and fall. A fraction of second earlier or later, and you will miss and fall. And the worst thing is that you cannot even save. Yes, you can technically save in almost any point of the game (arbitrarily chosen by you, not a predefined checkpoint, wow), but only if you are lucky and have the specific resource which runs out very quickly. So, in the end, you cannot really save often. If you die, you respawn at the point where you saved last time and have to repeat the whole navigation process from that point. Let me give you an example of how it works: You just spent fifteen minutes trying to jump to the next platform. Nothing complicated, just a trivial jump, but this game and its controls are so hard that you had to spend fifteen minutes on about hundred jump attempts. Finally, you succeeded. You cannot save because you are out of the save resource. Then you get the next jumping challenge. You fail it and fall to your death. You respawn at the save point. Remember I mentioned how you needed fifteen minutes and a hundred attemps to jump to that first platform? Do it again. No, it didn't get any easier. After that, you'll get another attempt at the second jumping challenge. Guess what, you failed it again. That's normal, in the end you probably need a hundred attempts for this one, too. Respawn at the save point. Now do the first thing again for several minutes. Then you get you third attempt on the second challenge. And so on. Sounds easy, right? Let's add some enemies. The combat isn't hard, but enemies can and will kill you many times. When it happens, you respawn at the latest save point and have to repeat the whole thing again. Sometimes, enemies and jumping challenges are happening at the same time. For example, you have to climb the wall, and directly under you there is an enemy which will instally kill you on first touch. Don't fall. (You will. Many times.) In other situations, an enemy can attack you while you are trying to climb the wall or jump the platforms. It was already hard, now it's closer to impossible. You die, and repeat, and die again. To make it even less fun, the enemies respawn crazily. You walk away just a little bit, and then you get back, and the enemy you just killed is there again. I had a case where I was stupid enough to, after killing a particularly hard enemy, save on that very spot. In a minute or two, I died and respawned at that place, and guess what? The enemy respawned at that place, too. And remember that enemy under the wall you have to climb? It respawns immediately after you start climbing the wall. You kill the monster (which wasn't easy and took several attempts), then you start climbing the wall, and the monster reappears directly under you in that very second. Have fun. (You won't.) Die and do the same thing. Again, and again, and again. Did I ever tell you what the definition of insanity is?

TLDR, I think I might be in the minority, so seriously look up some gameplay and be extra sure you want to play this game. I hope you love it as much as I didn't.

For context I'm a metroidvania fan, and hollow knight is the gold standard for that genre in my eyes. I played the game on hard mode and I think my only regret is that the game would have probably been a little faster if I had picked normal. I really wanted to like the game and I saw a lot of yt vids recommending it and the Overwhelmingly positive reviews. This was not my experience.

This game wasn't a through and through a bad experience. The story was sentimental even if it wasn't that deep. I think that it has a few strong emotional moments including the very beginning that resonate well, but I don't know if there enough to really call what we experience a compelling story. The presentation of the game is 10/10 though. It feels like every aspect of the visuals and the audio are working together to convey a theme or feeling. It all feels unique and stylistic in a good way.

My main issue is the gameplay. While I think the pace of progression is good, I don't like the ability system. You can unlock abilities as you go but there isn't very much decision making going on in that section. Pick all of the 1 point abilities, then the 2 point abilities, and then decide which 3 point abilities to pick. Also I really feel like Ori doesn't jump high enough. Maybe that's a strange complaint to have but I never felt like Ori felt good to control. The best feeling is when you're blasting past screens using you're abilities perfectly, but that rarely happens and I think the controls can sometimes not work well together. My main complaint is that there are a few sections of the game where you have to escape an area, and on paper I love that. It's a way of merging gameplay and story while re contextualizing levels you've already gone through. At the end of the day though I just found those parts annoying as I repeatedly died.

The rest of the game was easy but those escape sequences would always take what felt like way too long to beat and by the end of it, those 3 events turned my experience from just positive enough to give a thumbs up to a negative one.

Again, I hope this review doesn't apply to you. I really would like people to love this game because the developers clearly put a lot of love into this work. I didn't like it however and I think it's useful in case anyone out there is like me,

Words can't describe how incredible this game is. Genuinely moving to tears almost.. the game itself, the characters, the bonds, soundtrack, intensity. It was the first xbox 1 games I played and holy.. when I say I can't recommend this game enough I mean it. 1000/10 would play again!!!!!

Perfect game for my Steam Deck. You can easily pick it up and put it down. Great story, soundtrack, and gameplay. I needed something to scratch the itch after playing Hollow Knight and this game did the trick. On to the sequel!

When I found myself crying in the prologue, I knew this game was going to be good. In the end, it turned out to be my favorite platform game ever. Frustration and satisfaction were mixed inside of me through the whole game: I would scream at the screen, alt+f4 the hell out of it and then still come back-- just to get mad all over again lol When I finally got through some really difficult levels, however, I felt like I was at the top of the world. It's this kind of game. 

The mechanics are endless: You can jump, you can hover, you can thrust yourself into any directions using enemies/enemies' attacks, you can swim, you can climb, you can run... This brings lots of possibilities when getting through some levels. The controls confused me a bit at the beginning, since they're so many, but nothing that 10 guides and a lot of hard-work wouldn't fix. (lol)

The visuals... I don't think I even have to say anything, do I? My ex-boyfriend actually studied this game at college because of how beautiful it is. I mean, look at it. Each level you find yourself in, there's a new world waiting. Things can be soothing or scary, and yet they're beautiful at all times. You don't even mind dying 1300 times in your first gameplay! Just look at the scenery, dude. 

The soundtrack is extremely relaxing and melancholic/nostalgic... I don't even know. The visuals + soundtrack combo are what make your eyes teary. And boy did I cried way more than I thought I would playing a platformer game lol If you think you'll only shed tears in the prologue, you're wrong. 

Anyway, I love this game a lot. It made me feel a bunch of emotions, and also brought this part of my human soul that is connected to nature. Yeah. I think even people that aren't into platformers should give it a try. I wasn't really into them (lol) until this. Now I guess I'm really taking Celest and Hollow Knight out of my wishlist... By buying them!~

Historic Review:  Games I played months if not years ago – I decided to start reviewing right at the end of 2023!  Memory of a trepanned, ADHD toddler with impulse control issues notwithstanding.  

Teaboy's Basic(ish) Reviews....I read a lot of reviews when looking at games on Steam, and it quickly gets tiring – those who write involved, down to the micron scale reviews, although helpful, end up like looking at War & Peace when you’ve only got time for a quick 5 minute dump!  This is middle of the road and to the point – not easy for me as I tend towards sesquipedalian loquaciousness!  Vociferously Verbose?  Alright, verbal diarrhoea.  (Although I hate panning a developer’s work and all the time, effort and love they put into designing these – it is their life after all – this is my honest, personal opinion of my level of enjoyment.  Sorry devs!).  

A note on time played:  My Steam clock does not seem to work properly, indeed, it even minuses time on occasion!  Plus, I have a tendency to wander off and leave games running at times, so time played may not be entirely accurate!  


Teaboy’s Tonsil Titillators or Toenail Titbits!  (Rating)  

Tonsil Tickler (Totally Tops):  The frenchy of which you always dreamt!  To quote a master, “She’s got a tongue like an electric eel and she likes the taste of a Man’s tonsils!”.  An absolute masterpiece and joy to play.  

The Tits (Terrific):  Everyone loves playing with these!  Not THE best bit, but such fun on their own you can be lost for hours....mmmm.  What most games you really like score – perfection is so rare after all.   

Torso Teaser (Taker of your Time):  It’s a flat stomach....sure it’s nice to look at, run your fingers over, slobber on a bit, sometimes that bellybutton gets your motor running....but it's just basically the corridor between the two ‘gaming rooms’.  The definitive ‘Meh’ - the middle ‘sideways thumb’ option for which everyone on Steam cries.  

Todger/Tadger & (scroTum) Taters (Tedious):  Is it an ‘a’ or is it an ‘o’?  Who cares!  The meat can be fun to play with for about 5 minutes of your entire day, the rest it just hangs there and generally gets in the way of doing something else.  The main problem of course, is the two veg sticking to your inside thigh.  This is what this game feels like – the occasional/rare bouts of fun, the rest bobbing like a 19th century British Policeman (now you know why!).  

Toenail Tornado (Total Toss):  A playthrough so appalling it’s like being trapped in a Turkish sauna with the ugliest, hairiest, fattest, sweatiest beast of a neolithic hominid who’s trimming his toenails using pliers and the splinters are reminiscent of a scene from the Normandy Landings.  My god how did this get released!?  


Teaboy Touts (Score):  TONSIL TICKLER!!!!!!!!!!!!


The Review:  

This is for both Ori And The Blind Forest & Ori And The WIll Of The Wisps (they are effectively the same game).  

I think this is my Favourite Game Of All Time - hence the dozen exclamation marks above (my fave number)!  When I played the 2nd one, I preferred the 1st, and I Still LOVED IT!  

This is an action platformer that is more platformer than combat but plenty of both - unlike things like Blasphemous which to me is just hack n slash.  This one requires learning and skill with a bit of timing to boot.  Both games have the same controls and movements and map type and controls.  The differences are obviously a different map (same layout format) and a change in the skill progression.  In the 2nd game you purchase upgrades from a couple of creatures and you have to juggle abilities by selecting appropriate ones as you go through the game (there are many more than 1st game).  I'm not much of a fan of this, after playing Baldur's Gate on the Playstation 2 with my brother (we always pronounced it Bal Jers - sounds so much more fantastical than the Boulders they pronounce it in game!) so many times as we Loved it, then the sequel introduced crafting and we spent So Much Time in the selection screens reading n swapping n forging....it totally destroyed the flow of the game.  Luckily, Ori is not like that, it's much more basic/easy, but due to my personal experience I don't like the interruption.  But for others it adds choice.  It also is necessary for progression on a few occasions.  

Other than that, both games are pretty much a continuation of each other.  Playstyle is identical, which is the Perfect decision by the devs because the first game was Excellent.  Don't fix it if it ain't broke!  You increase a dual power bar as you level up, allowing more/stronger abilities.  The abilities you get are great fun and vital at the same time - they get assigned to buttons of your choice as you unlock them.  

A lesson to newbies I learnt the hard way - if you can't do something/get somewhere, it is because you yet lack the ability!  I tried for ages to get places until I finally learnt that I had to go somewhere else and earn an ability!  So if stuck, go to another area of the map you've yet to do.  Trust me, you'll find a new way to jump or whatever and then you go, "Ahhhhhh! 
 NOW I can go to that other place."  In the 2nd game I deliberately upgraded one skill tree to get a particular ability I knew from the 1st game makes it so much easier, however, I could not get it after getting all the upgrades it required....it was the same old story as above - some abilities are earnt through in-game progression, you have to open a part of the map/do something/complete some quest AND upgrade!  Take note!  

Movement speed is super important in platformers as many games are so sloooow.  This game is, yet again, perfect!  You move quickly, and the abilities can boost that significantly.  This is important as the map is large and there are, in my opinion, too few jumpgates.  Still, going back and forth is a lot more acceptable than most games that force you to backtrack.  The hardest part of this game is finding all the hidden items which will be the greatest reason for backtracking.  There is sadly a single glitch in the 2nd game whereby about half of players, myself included, could not 100% the game as one 'complete the set' never goes above 97% (one gem short kind of thing even though you've found them all).  

The action AND platforming can be frenetic at times, which is actually massive fun.  Boss battles can be a bit annoying - like a side-scroller where you have to learn the right way by dying constantly and repeating.  This the ONLY flaw in this otherwise perfect game in two parts!  

And the music....the opening title screen tune....It is heartbreaking that it is so short - it's one of the most brilliant little tunes I've ever heard.  Pure joyous magic.  

Sadly, it seems from the ending that they will not be making another.  I'd buy it without a second thought if they did.  I wonder if it's like Batman and Halo - originators didn't want to spend their entire career developing the same game so handed it over....and they got worse.  Still, I'd buy it and hope!

Amazing, smooth gameplay on Steam Deck OLED 2023. The game is rendered perfectly and looks *beautiful*. One caveat is that the game is optimized for 60 frames per second (FPS). So even if my OLED deck supports 90 FPS, I had to reduce my deck frame limit down to 60 for it to work smoothly. At the default system-level 90 FPS the game is playable, but sometimes it felt like there were frame drops or random slow motion. This went away as soon as I frame capped the game. No change made in in-game graphics settings, running at 800p presumably on high settings. I imagine the frame limit issue is exclusive to the OLED deck due to the higher 90 Hz screen and may not exist for the LCD deck which is locked at 60Hz, i.e., the game should work flawlessly on LCD deck out of the box.

Gameplay: 4.5 | Narrative: 3 | Graphics: 4.5 | Soundtrack: 3.5 | X-Factor: 4

A short but sweet platforming adventure!

GAMEPLAY:
The platforming in Ori and the Blind Forest feels great to play through. The game really starts shining once you unlock a multitude of abilities, such as being able to cling onto walls, charge jump boosts, and dashing. I wish dashing was an ability unlocked earlier, because it feels so satisfying to use in sync with jump boosts (but understandably, it's introduced late because it wasn't an ability in the original version of the game). Surprisingly, gliding was a mechanic in this game as well. Combined with wind bursts present in the overworld, it made for really smooth and fun gameplay that I wasn't expecting from a platformer. Mashing the shift button to glide and re-equip my glider to control my height was funnily enough, reminiscent of Breath of the Wild. One of the most surprising mechanics that I ended up loving was the ability to launch yourself in any direction after making contact with enemy projectiles. The game devs did an amazing job creating intentional sequences involving this unique mechanic (in particular, I'm looking at you, Mount Horu)! For completionists, you'll have to do a lot of backtracking later to get all collectables, as there are plenty of segments of the game where you can't proceed without a specific ability. I do wish that teleporting around the world was a little more accessible to make this more convenient (e.g. instead of having to be at a tp spot, you can teleport to one of your choosing from any area). However, with all things considered, I didn't find backtracking later as repetitive as I thought it would've been because I was having a blast with all the new abilities I had (especially the ones that made me be able to traverse the world faster!)

The game peaked for me in all three "chase" sequences that followed all the main areas of the game, whether it be climbing out of a massive flooding tree, or gliding out of a collapsing ice cavern. The difficulty felt just right, and with stakes on the line, successfully escaping was satisfying. The puzzles given throughout the game were quite fun as well for the most part (a select few were perhaps a bit more tedious than fun), and gave more identity to the platformer. The combat was an interesting element for the game. I believe that at its core, the game serves as a platformer, and the abilities that accompany that is what makes the game feel great to play. The combat, consisting of left clicking near enemies to get an orb to attack them, felt separate from the identity of what made the game fun to play. While I didn't necessarily dislike the combat, it felt unrewarding in the literal sense of what it gave you (small amounts of points to spend on skill trees) but also in the sense that it took me away from constantly moving. There are also no boss fights in the game, so combat never gets put to the test or goes anywhere meaningful, further creating this idea that the combat was an afterthought to the core of the gameplay.

NARRATIVE:
There's a story here, but to be blunt, nothing too notable. Ori lives in a forest, the forest loses its life force, they travel to three locations to revive the forest, succeeds in doing so, and the forest is saved. As the game is a platformer, I suppose the main purpose of a story is to provide the player a reason to explore and go places, and the story does just that. There are a few cute themes sprinkled here and there, like a parent's love for their child, but it feels like the story doesn't go above and beyond what it needs to.

GRAPHICS:
This game looks great. Having beautiful visuals to look at while zooming through the world made it all the more engaging. The darker areas of the game had the perfect, uninviting atmosphere, while the well-lit areas were breath-taking to look at.

SOUNDTRACK:
The ambience of the overall music felt on point with the game, but wasn't particularly moving or memorable.

OVERALL: 4/5
Ori and the Blind Forest is definitely a game to remember. I haven't played through that many platformer games yet, so I might be biased when I say this, but this game has its own identity within the genre. Some things will feel familiar, and some things will still yet surprise you. What more could a platformer enjoyer ask for? Anyways, if you haven't Ori-dy tried the game yet, do it! ...(i'm so funny guys i can't)

[h1] Touching platformer: Ori and the Blind Forest [/h1]

Rating: 8/10

[h2]Gameplay and Difficulty(8/10):[/h2]

Ori and the Blind Forest has really satisfying platforming mechanics and map traversal options. At the start the game may feel clunky at times, but after an hour or two you unlock your first few new abilities that allow you to travel faster through the map and you can access new places. The definitive edition added the fast travel to the spirit wells, but the spirit well locations were quite few and far, so they were only useful occasionally. Otherwise I don't have anything else that bothered me about the movement in the game.

The combat is quite basic though. You basically have only two types of attacks: rapid fire and larger explosion type of attack. You can upgrade some of the traversal abilities to deal some damage to your enemies, but those don't feel that convenient. So all in all, the combat is OK.

From gameplay standpoint everyone can find fitting difficulty level for themselves. There are normal mode that is good for most people and then there is the hard mode for those who are looking for more challenge. Most hardcore gamers may also try to beat the whole game with only one life.

[h2]Graphics and Sound (10/10):[/h2]

Graphically Ori and the Blind Forest is phenomenal. Even after multiple years the game doesn't show any signs of aging. It still looks very impressive.

The soundtrack is also very good and complements the environments and the story. Peaceful places have solemn soundtracks and when the gameplay needs it the music can be quite thrilling at times.

[h2]Story(8/10):[/h2]

I liked the story. The story really tugs at your heart strings and it does it successfully and the end leaves you wanting more.

[h2]Replayability (6/10):[/h2]

After you have seen the story there is only the achievements and leaderboard positions that you can try to climb as far as possible. You can try to run the game as fast as possible and you should be able to finish it under the 3 hour mark to get all the achievements. If this interests you then it might be a positive.

Of course, your first run is not that fast. I played quite casually through the game and collected everything on the map and I completed the game under 10 hours. So the game still has fair amount of gameplay in it.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]

I can recommend this game for everyone who enjoy platformer games and metroidvania type of games. The story, music and graphics were the high points of this game and very rare games have all these as good as this one.

An extremely emotive, visually vivid, and aurally appealing Metroidvania with intermittently insane difficulty spikes.

[h1]B+[/h1]

Save yourself the frustration and watch someone else complete this game.  The graphics and soundtrack along with how Ori looks while escaping areas in this game are definitely worth watching without all the death frustrations.

Exploring in this game was very frustrating because I was constantly dying in one hit.  Once I learned how to get past this spot I would die at the next spot within less than five minutes.  This cycle continued repeatedly over and over again.  I wish there was some breathing room in between these deaths to enjoy exploring this beautiful game.  Ori would also sometimes not perform certain actions at critical moments leading to more deaths.  I also do not like it when these deaths are related to something that was off screen or very hard to see.  It feels cheap and adds to the frustration.  

Combat was boring.  Only one button to press for a limited range homing projectile to attack a random enemy.  There were also no bosses to do combat with.  Escaping seemed to be the bosses.  Ability upgrades were also generic and did not add much to the game-play.

Overall I was more frustrated getting through this game rather than having fun.  I was given the next Ori game as a gift and heard it improves a lot from the shortcomings of this game.  Watch and enjoy someone else complete this game and then play the next Ori game.

The story, the music, the graphics...it's a work of art. There's a reason people are still playing this game, even 8 years after release. It holds up.

That said, there are also parts of it I found to be incredibly un-fun. While easy mode is certainly *easier*, it's not *easy*. At all. The main advantages of easy mod are that:

-Resources (spirit light, energy, life) are more abundant, and upgrades cost less (helpful for sure)
- Enemies have less health and deal less damage, but there are still looooots of enemies/obstacles that will kill you instantly. Overall, i found the combat difficulty to be easy even as someone who doesn't usually play these sorts of games, but then you land on a spike and you have to do it all over again anyway.
-  The boss sequences (e.g. [spoiler] escaping the ginso tree, battling kuro, etc [/spoiler]) have a checkpoint in the middle so you don't have to do the entire thing in one go.

TL;DR: this game requires a lot of precision (often under time pressure), and the sheer frustration of some sequences made me question why I was willingly doing this with my free time. But the story and the world are truly magnificent, and that's what kept me coming back.

[h1] Introduction [/h1] 
Ori and the Blind Forest is an action platformer, featuring beautiful artwork and music. The game's story is simple and linear.

[h1] Movement and Platforming[/h1] 
The movement system starts off slow and gets interesting during later parts of the game. I found "Bash" and "Light Burst" working together as unique. The platforming overall is good. Once the player has collected enough abilities they can zoom across the map fast.

[h1]Combat[/h1] 
The combat is poor and boring. Your choices of killing enemies is to mash your attack button, reflect bullets, dash and stomp, throwing bullets. You can also charge up your attack by holding however this consumes "energy", which has to be managed for saving. Basic attack focuses multiple enemies at once with splits but doesn't have a priority system in place for assisted aim, example closest enemy has a chance to not get hit when fighting multiple enemies. The enemy variety is also lacking.

[h1]Cons[/h1] 
Art getting in the way of the player during platforming.
Lack of auto-saving during escape sequences and the escape sequences being frustrating to go through due to unpredictability as well trial and error. Auto-saving only happens when the sequence starts and ends.
Poor saving system overall, Cutscenes and dialogue will replay when player hasn't saved and dies. Having to manage your "energy" during gameplay for fighting, saving and platforming. 
Teleporting to a new place does not save the game, making it an extra step to do while watching a long animation each time.
Clunky controls and too many buttons, including no key/controller remapping.
Getting stuck because of the game throwing a switch into an odd place or using a mechanic in a specific way that has not been introduced before to progress further.

[b]TLDR[/b]: Beautiful and good platformer with questionable game design. I would recommend this game for a try, however if you are prone to frustration, i would not recommend it. There's also its sequel Ori and the Will of the Wisps, which is a major improvement.

This is one of those games that kinda peaked my interest because I love metroidvania's. So, I bought it, put it in my "I'll get to it later pile" and left it there for years..... what a mistake that was. I cannot believe how long I waited to play this masterpiece. And that IS what this is, a MASTERPIECE and so is its sequel.

I won't spoil the story here but I will say that this game is all about loss and dealing with loss. While there are moments of true sadness (this is one of 3 games ever to bring me to legitimate tears, The Last of Us and Mass Effect 3 [Mordin!!!] being the others) but it is so much more than that!

Gameplay - A masterclass in metroidvania design. Exploration, discovery and character advancement and development are at their best here. Combat is very well done. Simple but still possesses depth. Challenging but  not overly so. It's definitely not Soulslike levels of challenging. But it is also rewarding and rarely feels unfair. Movement (especially late game with some added abilities) is seriously satisfying. 

Graphics - Incredible! Beautiful! The art style perfectly compliments what this game is trying to achieve and accentuates the themes and mood that permeate every aspect of this game. There are also some seriously breathtaking set pieces on display here.

Music & Sound - The sounds are completely adequate. More than is needed for a game of this type. The music is again, best in class. Yet another example of a perfect pairing between theme and mood to fit the game. I love it so very much.

Rating: 10/10

I don't know what else needs to be said. This game is a must buy. My wife even loved watching me play it and she has a hate for all video games that goes down to her very core. Just buy the game already. You won't regret it at all.
Amazing Game!

It's really hard to recommend this game when Hollow Knight came out 2 years later and improved on every single aspect of the genre. I know it's not fair to review an older game using a newer game as comparison, but after playing Hollowed Knight, you realize just how absolutely annoying every enemy in Ori is and how it is a chore instead of fun fighting them. Also, your one main attack is one that you constantly have to button spam; no just holding down the attack button because we are apparently going back to the 80s Nintendo days. The only reason why the game doesnt let you to just hold down the attack button is because it would just reveal how weak the combat is; since there is never a moment in the game where you shouldnt be attacking and there's no punishment for always attacking regardless of the enemy and situation, the game would just devolve into holding down the attack button from the moment the game starts to the moment the game ends.

The level designs way overuse floor spikes, with many of them impossible to see until you land on them and will immediately end your run. Levels are not designed in such a way that they are fun to explore, because they are not made so that the players intuitively know where to go next, and it's never clear if you are in the right area the game wants you to be or if you are in an area that is designed to come back at a later time. And before someone calls me a casual, understand that every single game with deep exploration and branching paths, even Dark Souls, cleverly tricks and guide the player into going where the player needs to go next, in such a subtle way that the player doesnt even realize it. This game doesnt know how to do that at all.

It's objectively not a bad game; it just doesnt deserve its overwhelming score.

Platform: PC (Xbox Game Pass)

Completion Date: Oct 27, 2019

A platforming-centric metroidvania with the worst combat I have ever experienced.

Pros
-The artwork is phenomenal.
-The bash mechanic.
-Good to great music.

Cons
-The combat is miserable. Mash X to fire glowing blobs while enemies try to ram you or fire their own glowing blobs back (some of the enemies are basically just glowing blobs).
-Visual clarity is awful. So many enemies, items, and attacks in this game are glowing blobs that things can get confusing pretty quickly in combat. Also, sometimes the background/environmental art gets in the way of gameplay.
-The story loses any sense of weight once resurrection gets involved.
-Their is no fast travel mechanic so if you want to go around the map and get all the secrets you missed/were unable to get earlier you need to walk there.
-The mist woods as an area is kind of a pain in the ass.
-Can't disable help/tool-tip popups (reminding you that you have an upgrade point, etc) and they sometimes interfere with gameplay by obscuring platforms, enemies, etc.
-Sound effects are bland to annoying for enemies/combat.
-Music  and sound effects get way too loud in the chase sequences.
-Buttons on the controller cannot be remapped.

Neutral
-You have a Navi but it is less annoying.
-Controller vibration is crazy, I strongly recommend turning it dowm.

For anyone looking at this game for the beautiful scenery and a relaxing experience, do NOT buy it.
Levels are poorly designed, with a focus towards extending play time at the expense of player frustration.
Hazards in chase type events are positioned just out of sight to force multiple reruns from preventable obstacles, puzzles are based on finicky positioning rather than wits, and character control is made unintuitive to encourage unnecessary deaths from lack of perfect coordination.

This game sure is a mixed bag. While it boasts stunning visuals, the gameplay falls a bit flat. The character movement lacks precision, coming off as floaty. The save system is peculiar; there are times when you can frequently save your progress, and other times when you're left wanting. Intriguingly, the game uses the same currency for saving, opening gates, and executing powerful attacks. This system might have been tolerable if the health mechanism was effective. However, the game is riddled with instant death attacks, thrusting you back to your last save point. It almost feels as if this was their solution to complaints about the sudden death challenges. In the few hours I played, my feelings alternated between genuine enjoyment and sheer annoyance due to some design choices.

"Ori and the Blind Forest" is a mesmerizing and emotionally charged platform that stands as a work of art in the gaming world. This enchanting adventure, developed by Moon Studios, takes players on a captivating journey through a lush and mysterious forest.

Visually, the game is a masterpiece. The hand-drawn art style and attention to detail create a stunning and immersive world. The forest's beauty is juxtaposed with its danger, giving the game a unique atmosphere that keeps players engaged and in awe.

The game play is equally impressive. The platforming mechanics are tight and intuitive, offering challenging yet satisfying experiences as you navigate through the forest's perilous terrain. As Ori, the game's agile protagonist, you'll unlock new abilities and upgrades that keep the game play fresh and exciting.

One of the game's standout features is its storytelling. "Ori and the Blind Forest" weaves a touching and emotionally resonant narrative as it explores themes of friendship, sacrifice, and the power of determination. The characters, particularly Ori and Sein, are endearing, and players become deeply invested in their journey.

Gareth Coker's musical score is a perfect companion to the game's visual and emotional elements. The music sets the tone beautifully, enhancing the emotional impact of the story and the game play.

While the game is a true gem, it's not without its challenges. Some players might find its difficulty level to be on the high side, with certain sections requiring precise timing and quick reflexes. However, this difficulty adds to the sense of accomplishment when you overcome obstacles.

In conclusion, "Ori and the Blind Forest" is a must-play title for fans of platforms, artful storytelling, and immersive experiences. It's a visually stunning, emotionally engaging game that leaves a lasting impression. This game is not just a gaming experience; it's a work of art that showcases the potential of the medium.

A decently challenging platformer with some creative mechanics built into its powerup system. The music is pretty and the environments and puzzles can be quite creative, but I find myself distinctly un-immersed. 

The game balance shifts from careful save energy management to just letting you drop a save point after every jump so rapidly that it feels like the game's only way to compensate is to throw more no-mercy challenges at you to kill you with a single mistake. It could have easily had you respawn at the last safe platform when you fall into a pit, but instead it forces you to save literally everywhere just in case some bullshit enemy is around the next corner and one-shots you and your pitiful health pool. Not helped by the fact that sometimes its difficult to tell what's in the foreground and whats a danger on your plane of movement, or the fact that all the blurry light particles flying around sometimes makes it difficult to tell what's a threat in time to dodge it.

And the story, while presenting a veneer of wholesome adventure about love and family, falls apart at any level of scrutiny. It feels like the morals of the story are that it's fine to behave with reckless disregard for others' safety if you miss someone (whom you've never properly met), choosing found family over biological family is a mistake, anger over legitimate wrongs done to your family is bad if the target of your anger is more important than you, and so on. The narration literally calls the Ori's decision to stay with their adoptive parent a "mistake" about 15 minutes of gameplay away from revealing that [spoiler]the light that called Ori to their biological home had repercussions that killed literally everyone who journeyed to that location.[/spoiler]

This is a tough one to choose between recommending or not. On one hand it's a great atmospheric platformer with some interesting twists on the genre, the biggest one for me being no boss battles, but on the other I kept getting to a point where the game stopped being fun because of...

Chase sequences, there are just too many of them, combined with unforgiving error margins and inconsistent enemy/projectile I ended up being happy when they were over rather than feeling accomplished for having beaten them.

YMMV and if you love long combos of twitchy platforming there's hardly anything to fault.

Fun, though frustrating at times. The story feels very cookie-cutter, but it's presented beautifully. THe art and music are fantastic, obviously. Honestly, though, I prefer Ori and the Will of the Wisps, which is basically just 1000x better.

Edit: After replaying both multiple times, I can certainly say both games have their charm. WOTW is more "traditionally" good but BF does create simply a different vibe. Just please don't buy the regular edition, it has some really strange and frustrating changes.

Ori is a beautifully crafted, jump movement game, and although most of the game is fun to maneuver and puzzle around, there are too many unfun escape sequence sections where you need to almost become a speed runner to pass. Do not expect any boss fights to triumphantly end levels, or any rpg elements beyond experience point power ups. The game is excellent in its focus on mechanical puzzles and movement, and thoughtful in its story, but it is missing further depths of play to relish in your hard earned abilities.

Apparently Ori gets brought up whenever video games as art is discussed. I understand that it's a beautiful game with a memorable soundtrack. The themes are there and the characters get introduced in a natural way without too much explaining.

However, art or not, it's still a video game. I want to play it. The very first moment I get the control of the intro character, I want to see what happens when I try to walk off a ledge. You cannot, there's an invisible wall. It's a minor flaw (barely a flaw at all) but personally it's infuriating and lazy design. You want to put a mandatory slow walking introduction but you don't want to think outside the box [i]at all[/i]? You could easily put an alternative hidden route there and you don't need an invisible wall. Art games and invisible walls, Mona Lisa and rotten teeth.

Not to mention Ori's very much a game for kids (and manchildren). If I was under 15 I could see it becoming a favourite. The story seems simple and effective and the visuals kick ass.

How about the gameplay? Brace your mouse arm to get tendonitis because you are going to mash the mouse button for a ridiculous amount of time. For the short while I played the enemies got noticeably more bullet-spongy and every time you plan to hit an enemy once, it's one mouse click. I see no reason for it, you could easily just hold the mouse button to fire continuously. Wall jumping controls felt awkward and most of the reviews state that the end game platforming gets more and more difficult.

I'll leave this one to people who instantly want to immerse themselves into Ori. I'm just a cynic who wished the whole intro sequence for the fat kidnapper to die off.
The art style in this is absolutely stunning and the controls feel very smooth. The story is touching as well, so go play it! Oh and just look at Ori, so cute!

Fantastic game! Everything about this game is so well produced, the music, the characters, the story, the art, and especially the game play. Ori and the Blind Forest has to be one of the best game I've ever played. There was never a moment where I felt bored, every moment was too enjoyable. Every aspect of the game felt ever so refreshing, dynamic combat system, ingenious puzzles, interesting story lines, there is no other game that can top this masterpiece by Moon Studios. The art style itself is just a masterwork, paired up with the high production cinematics, everything in the game is just candy to the eye. And can we talk about the music? Every OST composed by Gareth was so full of vibrancy, there was never a point where the music did not fit the theme of the section in the game. 10/10 game would play again.

Overall, 10/10 can't wait to continue exploring the world of Ori and uncovering all of the secrets that the game has to offer. And once I finish Blind Forest, I will be very keen to play through Will of the Wisps as well.

A great storm separates a newborn spirit named Ori from the Spirit Tree that protects the forest of Nibel. Adopted by a curious creature named Naru, she quickly takes the role of a loving adoptive mother and cares for Ori as they grow up. Life is peaceful and idyllic until one fateful summer when a strange darkness creeps in and twists the forest, withering the fruit trees and poisoning the water, bringing famine and death. Newly orphaned, Ori flees from their home and meets a mysterious light named Sein who knows why the forest has changed - and needs Ori's help restoring it to its natural order.

9-40+ hours to complete, Ori and the Blind Forest is a fantasy metroidvania RPG with puzzles and platforming. This game is difficult. In my first playthrough on Hard mode, I died over 400 times and truly didn’t enjoy playing until after the first “dungeon”, The Ginso Tree, where the world suddenly opens up after gaining vital movement skills. Regardless, this game is a genuinely wonderful experience that I wish many more people would play. The story was handled amazingly well despite having such little dialogue. Areas are fun to explore, and you are frequently rewarded for your curiosity with lots of hidden places and secrets to find.

I wish I could like it.  But I don't.

I've played 2D platformers for years.  Decades, really.  Metriod, Zelda, and Mario; Castlevania; Mega Man, and the wide plethora of knockoffs.  I wouldn't brag, but I certainly would categorize myself as reasonably competent.

This game's gorgeous graphics pulled me in right away.  The plot, while simplistic, was captivating.  The intro was moving, even.  And off I went, to solve puzzles, earn experience, and gain power-ups, all the while keeping a weathered eye on my mana and life totals.  Very throwback; very classic; with a touch of newness.  I was hooked.  Oh, look; an [obstacle] that I can't circumvent; surely therefore I'll find [power-up] to help me with that, later on.  Don't forget it's there!  Probably something juicy behind it!

Then I started encountering some more challenging areas.  More difficult enemies.  More convoluted jumping around.  Eh, no problem.  Just takes getting used to.  I got used to Mario.  I'll get used to this guy.  That's part of the fun; it's a puzzle world, filled with danger, interlaced in jumping around challenges.  If you like that sort of thing.  And I do!  So I pressed on.

Then I started encountering some *really* challenging areas.  Skin-of-your-teeth jumps.  Unforgiving monsters.  But you can save your game almost anywhere.  So repeating attempts is not that inconvenient.  Aside from the tedium and frustration of attempting the same series of jumps, dodges, and attacks over and over until you've circumvented the situation.  Only to find a similar scenario right around the corner.  Hrmph.  But hey, that's, uh, still part of the fun, heh, right?  It's a challenge!  It's uh... it's an experience!  Something to relish when you finally triumph!  Yeah, that's it!

Then I started encountering some really, REALLY challenging courses.  Like, five or more absolutely flawlessly timed jumps in sequence, in different directions; or instant death.  Ouch.  And you know what?  After my eleventeenth attempt, it just stopped being fun.  Mind you, I'm only a small fraction of the way through the game at this point.  And I'm already frustrated beyond my tolerance point -- which, I really do want to say, is pretty flexible when it comes to these sorts of games.

Since I'm throwing the game under the bus, at this point I'll also mention its somewhat silly experience point system.  It'd pretty easy to farm exp if you really wanted to, since if you walk five steps off the screen after defeating a big, fat monster, you can walk back and find that big, fat monster has respawned.  And it has three talent trees (well, lines), but the trees are locked against acquiring various power-ups, so you end up just spending points in all three lines anyway.

Perhaps it's harsh; it is, after all, just a 2D platformer.  But the level of challenge it presents reminds me of a sugar-hyped-up pre-teen bulding the "Ult1m4t3 M4r10 Ch4ll3ng3 L0L", where you have to jump perfectly nineteen times in eleven different directions at just the right moment or you die and start over.  It gets old fast.

One of my favourite platformers. The music, gameplay, and environmental storytelling really made it an unforgettable experience

Do I recommend this game? Yes, but this is one of the cases where I kind of regret there is no mixed button on Steam for reviews. It is one of the most visually stunning games I have had the pleasure of playing, the art style is great, the sound fits the game very well, the story while simple is told in a way to evoke very powerful feelings and the basic platforming is very very enjoyable. What is my problem with the game then? Simple, it is the chase scenes and I will try to explain why.

First of all to understand my point of view, you have to think where platformers started. They were made to be arcade games where every try cost you a quarter (or an equivalent), thus the games were made to be hard, but if you yourself got better at the game you could definitely feel it throughout the game. Also there was no cheap difficulty of having to replay the level several times to know exactly where damage will come from, since it would have been a blatant money grab. In this game death means nothing (except for a waste of time), but the frustration lingers.

Now imagine two worlds, in one world the difficulty of chase scene is dynamic, meaning no matter how well you executed the first part of the chase scene, it gives you nothing. No additional time whatsover. Thus the whole chase scene is just a series of precisely executed moves, that even if you make just a small mistake at the end, means you are replaying the whole thing again. When you finally finish the scene, you are not happy you did so, you feel relieved.

In the other world, the chase scene itself is on a timer. After several tries you execute the first half of the chase extremely and you have some stumbles in the second half, but since you did so well in the first half you manage to recover from your mistakes and eventually finish the whole. You feel proud of your accomplishment, because you steadily got better, you saw the progression and even if you stumbled a few times along the road, the fact that you got better managed to carry you through the whole thing.

I am fairly sure you know which of these worlds you would prefer and which of these worlds you will encounter in this game. The chase scenes in this game are not a challenge, they are an inconvenience.

The bird had every right to eliminate Ori and his cult of the tree!! WHAT A NICE REWARD FROM THE GOSH DARN TREE!!!!!!! The first time I died should be canon because it leaves the mother bird to take care of her only child left PEACEFULLY, and that murderous tree can stay in it's slumber FOREVER, and never kill another bird!!!!!

Besides the story of restoring a bird-killing tree, the gameplay and controls took some time to get used to, but with a little time spent in the game, I got the hang of it and was swinging and gliding around like Tarzan (or George of the Jungle, if you prefer). Was super satisfying to pull off maneuvers and chain beautiful platforming combos in diverse and challenging environments. I beat the game, and I want to genuinely like this game, but it's so hard to. The mechanics are nice, along with the skills you get, but the sheer amount of frustration I experienced while playing was honestly ridiculous. Really felt like the developers went overboard on the difficulty of certain sections (not to mention the spikes. So. Many. Spikes.) Ori and the Blind Forest is supposed to be an emotional game, but between the frustration and there being way too many long gaps in the small amount of story you get, it's hard to feel the emotion either.

If you like metroidvania games mixed with really challenging platforming, you'll like it, but personally, I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone who doesn't like major frustration as part of their playing experience.

[i] For context, I 100%  the achievements [/i]

Ori and the Bind Forest was my first metro-vanilla 2D game. This is a perfect game if you want to get into the metro-vanilla genre. Here are my pros and cons 

[h1] Pros [/h1]

Music - The music of games is something that I do not pay attention to much in many games, but this game is special. The music score is so incredible and makes some areas feel very atmospheric.

Art Style - The art style of this game has held up incredibly well considering that it is a 9-year-old game at the time of writing this. The art style of fantastic, and the world and the characters are made incredibly well. 

The World - Each part of the world has its unique look and thing to it. Each part is unique and enjoyable to explore 

The 100% achievement grind - This game will take you around 25 - 30 hours to get all the achievements to expect for the super hard 4. They are the following

-Complete a game in under 3 hours
-Complete a game without using any skill points
-Complete a game without dying once
-Complete a game in the One Life difficulty (This achievement was added in the definitive edition of the game. I would recommend just doing the One Life difficulty to complete the final two in one game)

The achievements that I mentioned force to you play at your best and are hard to complete. They probably added 30 hours to my playtime. I just completed the last two today, and I broke down crying because of how happy I was. What I like how this game has incredibly rare and incredibly hard achievements. Of course, you can install SAM and get all the achievements with a click of a button, but deep down, you will feel guilty. 

[h1] Cons [/h1]

Combat - The game is not combat-focused, which could be a positive to some, and negative to others. Anyway, the few pieces of combat that this game does have is pretty shallow. You just spam your attack button while stomping when you get that ability. Also, the game has no bosses, only escape sections which are very good 

The amount of One-Shots - This con is what made the last two achievements so incredibly hard. There are many, many things that one shot you, no matter how much health you have. Some things do a ton of damage that one hit kills you. 

[h1] My Final Thoughts [/h1]

This is a simple, yet incredibly good metro-vanilla-type game that I would highly recommend you try. You will have fun playing, and be immersed in the atmosphere. However, if you do not 100% of the achievements, it might be expensive due to the amount of playtime. I would recommend waiting until this game is on sale because you can get really good deals. I got the first and second games for only 11 dollars, which is a steal.

If you like Apple products, I imagine you'll like this game. If they annoy you like they do me, maybe think twice before picking it up.

Ori and the Blind Forest offers a certain experience, and it just wasn't for me. I enjoyed most of my time with it. It was fun - not necessarily amazing, but good. But over and over, I found myself getting annoyed by small things - unclear mechanics, puzzles that require you to do something you've never done before, the fact that you can practically softlock yourself by saving deep in enemy territory with low health (you respawn with the same amount of health you save with). Individually, they wouldn't be a big deal, but there were a lot of them, and they added up.

Tangent (no spoilers): [spoiler]That last one might sound like something you'd only do on purpose, but because you can save anywhere [i]and the game is designed around you being able to do that[/i], it's easy to repeatedly save with a little less health and a little more progress and run out of health before you reach the next heal. It is possible to reload a previous save, but it's really not obvious that it's an option, and in my opinion it's a mistake that it has to be an option at all.[/spoiler]

The best analogy I can think of is Apple products vs Android/Windows/Linux. Apple products are smooth, sleek, and easy to use by default, but a lot of people dislike them because (among other reasons) there are so many limitations and lack of advanced features/customization/tweakability. If you want something to just work with as little effort on your part as possible, I would guess you like Apple products (a totally valid opinion), but if you want it to work [i]well[/i], I'd imagine you prefer to avoid them (which is where I personally stand).

Ori and the Blind Forest is the embodiment of an Apple product here. It does an amazing job at the aesthetics - everyone says it's a beautiful game, and I agree. I just wish it didn't come at the cost of everything else.

Enjoyment at its finest

Alright. **Ori and the Blind Forest: Definitive Edition** is NOT done and dusted.

It's an unquestionably beautiful game with stunning artwork and exceptional detail. You could truly get lost in the visuals which might be some of the best in any video game ever. It's truly that breathtaking and evocative.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3007766422

The audio is similarly well done. Not quite to the peerless excellence of the artwork, but the OST is ethereal and pretty, and the in game tracks all are perfect for what they are.

The platforming and combat are extremely tight and the controls are as responsive as I've seen in such a game. Also, the upgrade system gives you a very real sense of progression, allowing you to access new parts of areas you've already visited, and just to enjoy a steady flow of new abilities.

The story, so far as I got into it, was pretty dark and sad. The intro can really make you feel pretty bad, and as you progress, you realize that while the game steers you in a hopeful direction, the path is littered with heartache.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3007766385

So, this all sounds like a winning combination of aspects that come together into a brilliant gaming experience, and that is actually factual. What I realized however, is that I don't have the patience for the increasingly complex puzzles, which require very precise platforming, multiple reflex based phases, and aiming that I can do, but not without getting pissed off lol. The actual solutions are pretty obvious, but the actual act of accomplishing them is more than I am personally willing to put myself through.

So...I definitely recommend this game if you are patient and don't mind repeating the same thing over and over trying to get it just right, rinse and repeat. If instead, you are at all impatient or prone to rage quitting games, this is a game better YouTubed instead.

Ori is one of those games that I could replay over and over and not get bored. The platforming is hard at first, or the enemies feel like they kill you too quickly. You feel clumsy but as you put points in to your abilities you find that Ori is actually a bouncy bean and hops from place to place with the ease of someone who's done parkour all their lives. I'm slightly biased now because whenever I think of Ori I'm reminded of my Ma and funny memories with her while playing this game, but the story should resonate with most people. Loss, hurt and anger are all emotions we've felt at one point in our lives. The graphics and music soundtrack is gorgeous, just be prepared to listen to the same part over and over for a section you can't get the parkour or timing right on. Love this game, it's got my wholehearted recommendation. I got all the achievements for the original Ori and I'm putzing through the definitive edition achievements when I have the free time because this game deserves that little gold medal beside it.

First time i played this game it blew me away, Ori and the blind forest is an amazing experience. The story, visuals and soundtrack really stand out as the best parts of the game. The story is simple, yet powerful in it's execution. The visuals are what make the Ori games unique, they're beautiful and make these games stand out. The soundtrack can only be described as magical, it elevates every part if this game. The combat is nothing amazing, it's very repetitive. However, I fell the combat was sacrificed in favor of the platforming. The platforming sections are the best part of the game no doubt, they're fun and thanks to all the abilities you get throughout the game (most notably bash), Ori's take on platforming feel like a breath of fresh air. I love Ori and the Blind Forest and even though the game has it's flaws and the cracks really start to form on multiple play through, like the story being very short, it still stands out as a beautiful entry in the platforming genre of games.

Don't let the cute looking visuals fool you, this game is very hard and frustrating.
This is another example that proves that graphics aren't everything. Gameplay is what matters most.
The graphics look good, the story is light and interesting, the music is great, but the crushing difficulty broke everything for me. I tried to get through the game to see how the story ends, but the extremely difficult gameplay made me rage quit at every session.
The developers were really creative in making the enemies really annoying, designing insta-death traps everywhere, weird platforming mechanics and other shit. I give them that.

Controls are a big issue as well. The character always moves a bit further than you intend, the movement acceleration is weird (I can't find the correct words to describe this). You can easily get stun locked to death or get snapped to a death trap, which feels really cheap. I'm not new to this kind of games and not a newbie gamer. This game has serious issues with controlling movement, which is a crucial aspect of the game. I could swear I can make all jumps and platforming with much more ease if it was any other game of the same genre. I like a good challenge, not cheap artificial so-called difficulty.

Most of the skills you unlock feel useless. I'm already past half of the game, unlocked half of the skill tree points, and they only have very little to non-existing effect on the gameplay.

FYI The game doesn't have auto-save. You save manually anytime and almost anywhere as long as you have a power cell left. So save often.. if you still decided to play the game...

I didn't want to win a medal or get a world record, I just wanted a good game to enjoy and relax, and have a good time. This game clearly doesn't offer that. I would rather play Dark souls than this game. At least Dark souls is fair, Ori isn't.
I'm glad I didn't buy the second game (Ori and the will of the wisps). What a waste of time and money.. and what a disappointment.

This is one of those instances I wish I could give a neutral review. Overall the game is good but it has a very bizarre design choice. Why in the world would you give the player a total of 15 health points, damage reduction, and even difficulty options (???), and then design tons of instant-death hazards? Ori is obviously inspired by games like Metroid, and yet I don't remember *any* Metroid game with as many tedious deaths as this one. It also flies in the face of the pretty visuals and the traversal mechanics you unlock that give you freedom of movement; you're moving along swiftly enjoying the visuals, and then if you get hit by the wrong thing, instant death.

The stats say I have over 200 deaths and I believe it. Really hoping the sequel has better level-design.

It certainly has its moments and some unique gameplay mechanics but late game puzzle platforming gimmicks with screwed up inverted controls, gravity, and other shenanigans are really more annoying than fun. The game also suffers from lack of ability to reload, so you have to basically constantly commit suicide if you take a hit because there is no point in going any further if you screw up early in long segments as enemies and spikes do so much damage. I probably spent half my time just wasting time killing myself on spikes on purpose. I used to hate instant death spikes but ori made me want them back because the time waste trying to kill myself was immense. The devs knew this too - there is a death counter. How many platformers have a death counter?

The game accidently let me save on spikes and softlocked. You can find many posts on steam forums you will see lots of posts of people with softlock situations. You have to quit to menu to find the hidden mechanic to load a previous save. It's not hinted to exist at all. 

Now the art style. It's nice, high def, muted pastel asthetic, but has a lot of visual clarity problems. Spikes and hazards blend in and often overlap with edges of what is normally walkable areas. The problem is even non-spiky parts of spikes will hurt you. How do sides of long shafts of spikes hurt you? Some of your and enemy projectiles look the same and are the same color, especially with spiders. You are both making big multishot flashes all over the screen and so you can't even see their projectiles. You have to stop shooting so you can even see them shoot back at you. 

There are also areas you can't ever get back to with upgrades that can be missed forever. Fun! Oh, I and hope you enjoy playing 5 minute long escape sequences from these forever gone places where you die in 1 hit and have to redo them over and over to find that couple pixel on the map where you can hide don't die. Die at the 4 minute mark, well start over before you can find those pixels. These are very controversial parts of the game and are love it or hate it for most people.

Ori and the Blind Forest is the second most beautiful game I've ever played, and the only reason it's not first is because it has a sequel. Every mechanic is introduced in a natural way that lets you teach yourself how each ability works and how they interact with those you've previously gained. All the mechanics flow together to create fluid, extremely satisfying platforming and exploration. On the aesthetic side, the game is in a league of its own. The level design is gorgeous, the atmosphere is immersive, it's clear that every aspect of the game had so much care and love put into it. However, the gem of the crown has to be the music score. No spoilers, but multiple times I've made it to the end of certain areas only to stop, die, and restart the area *just so I could keep listening to the music*. It's that good. Buy this game, then buy the sequel.

This game looks really good, and sounds really nice too. I sound like a broken record. At least this one has a good narrative. It's simple, but the themes it presents, it presents them emotionally and without filler. It's prologue literally made me buy the game.

But I don't recomend this game, not at all. The level design is kind of all over the place. The distribution of challenges is well done. The problem is within those challenges, and the dynamics that ensue from the game's mechanics.

(played the default difficulty; don't know about easier or harder ones)

Basically, there are a lot of challenges that you have to know beforehand. There are some that are literally random. And some that are kind of random - skill mix, but let's just focus on the first ones, which are sufficiently abundant. The game gives you, surprisingly, a save button to save anywhere in exchange for resources, and it even has the kindness to let you recover health by doing so. This sounds great: auto-balancing challenge with resource management. It is all, however, a dirty lie, because the resource is so abundant that you can just save after every challenge, practically.

This makes the game a constant back and forth between saving, the devs laughing at your face for not knowing what was to come, then you avoiding the trap, and repeat. The game does have difficult sections, so it's not like it's all a breeze. My favorite ones, are, however, those in which they don't let you save, but still set a bunch of gotta-know traps so you have to reset from the start of the level sequence.

I can't say much about level design of secrets, because although I began taking notes of places I wanted to re-visit and clues for that, I dropped it when the game dropped the ball. Also, minor complain, why is it so frequent in this game to have foreground elements that look like background elements. Which kill you. Aa.

Besides all of that, it feels mechanically nice. Maybe a bit too much buttons to press, but that's just getting used to it. I don't like how Ori just accelerates like a motorjet, but again, that's just me. Also, the game pretends to have mini-bosses. They are not, they are a joke. And not even a funny one. Then again, with the level design matter, I wasn't going to recommend it anyway, at this point I'm just clowning.

Ori and the Blind Forest is one I've been putting off for a while now. Very glad to have gotten around to it.

Pros:
- This game is absolutely stunning visually. Every environment feels distinct, and the vibrant color palette ties it all together to bring this intricate world to life; animations are also fantastic. The game manages to be melancholic, oppressive, adventurous, and lighthearted all in the same breath.
- You can't mention Ori without talking about the soundtrack. Each song is composed beautifully, accentuating key moments and making exploration all the more enjoyable.
- Ori himself controls phenomenally. Every movement feels fluid, and all of the many abilities you will unlock over the course of the game fit together to make some of the most satisfying movement from a platformer I've seen in quite a while (Bash is the greatest thing ever).
- Combat is basic but there is still a good amount of enemy variety that helps to keep things fresh.
- The narrative is executed very well for the most part, and delivers a simple yet touching story.
- Exploration is great, and each level was a joy to go through, especially the action-packed escape sequences following each of the three main 'dungeons'.
- Extra Definitive Edition content is also a welcome addition, providing yet another fun and well-crafted area to traverse.

Cons:
- For a metroidvania, Ori is almost completely linear. This is not a bad thing inherently, as each section of the game is masterfully crafted your first time through. However, side content/exploration/backtracking that followed the main story did not feel particularly inspired, and ended up being lots of locked doors that I simply needed late-game power-ups to access (Which I do not mind, but most of these were simply that and nothing more. I would have liked to see a bit more effort here - such as extra puzzles or combat encounters). It can't have been that bad though, because I still decided to 100% my save file.
- Soul Link is an interesting and unique mechanic, but I do still have somewhat mixed feelings about it.
- Despite the commendable enemy variety, the combat mechanics themselves are a bit lackluster, and fighting enemies did feel somewhat repetitive by the late-game.
- There are admittedly a couple story moments that I found a bit pointless, lowering the impact of other events considerably (will not be elaborating to avoid spoilers).


Ori and the Blind Forest is a triumph, and it's insane to think this was Moon Studios' first game. I am greatly looking forward to playing the sequel.

7.5/10
Very heartful game

Ori and the Blind Forest is a great platformer, but it might be lacking in replayability if that's something you like about metroidvania games.

The platforming itself feels great, with every new mechanic you get access to throughout the game lending itself very well to making movement feel fluid and seamless. Combat is a bit on the dull side, with very few differing enemy designs across the whole game, the player often getting to meet reskinned enemies with slightly different behavior and upgraded stats as they progress. As such, there are no bosses, with chase sections that test your platforming skills taking their place. This admittedly fits the game's strengths to a T.
Outside of gameplay, the game's visuals, sound design, OST and the storytelling complement each other perfectly to deliver a great atmosphere and make the forest of Nibel feel alive. Exploring the wilderness is made very intuitive thanks to how the in-game map functions, though it might make it a bit too easy if exploring is what you enjoy most out of a metroidvania.

Very fun, and I'll likely play it again! For sure recommend it.
