This game is beautiful. The animations, the backgrounds, the enemy designs, the cutscenes, it's all just breathtaking. The soundtrack and sound design is just as good, really fitting the tone of the situation and feeling like a movie. I'm afraid, though, that the gameplay doesn't live up to this game's presentation.

The platforming physics are incredible. Near the end of the game, after obtaining all of the abilities, platforming through the final section felt immensely satisfying. Being a long-time Mario fan, I love 2D platformers to death, so needless to say, those segments were my favorite part of this game. Of course, since I've already played so many 2D platformers, I've become quite good at them. This, I believe, is why I enjoyed this game so much. Which leads to my next point.

Here's the big platforming nitpick: This game can be hard. The wrong kind of hard, the frustrating kind. The way you save your game is quite unconventional, using entirely manual saves that take some of your magic energy to create. Imagine Celeste's respawn system, but instead of it triggering at the start of every room, saving is entirely done by the player, and can be created on any solid ground. Forgetting to save and needing to replay sections can be discouraging, and I ended up doing that throughout the entire game. even up to the final area I was forgetting to save at times. If you're out of magic energy, it can be very tough to make progress. And if you're in a section with very few energy pickups, you might just get stuck there for a while.

And now we talk about the combat, the weakest part of this game for most people. It's just as simple as people say it is. The whole thing is just spamming the X button, which is less than ideal, but I didn't mind it much. The enemies can be tough to dodge at times. I don't know what it is about them, but some enemies' attacks are so frustrating. Think of the Primal Aspids from Hollow Knight, but this time there's more like 3 or 4 enemy types in this game that are like them.

The Definitive Edition adds two abilities to the game which I have mixed feelings about. These abilities are the Dash and the Light Burst, and they make platforming a bit too easy. They are entirely optional pickups, but the strange thing is that the skill tree lets you unlock upgrades for these two powerups without ever picking them up in the first place. For example, I saw an upgrade on the skill tree with the description "Allows Ori to also dash in midair." (something like that) and when I spent my points on it, I was quite disappointed when I realized it was an upgrade to an ability I hadn't found yet. So please, if you end up playing this game, and you unlock or see something you don't understand, just look it up. This doesn't mean the Definitive Edition is the worse version though. It adds a fast travel system, which I used extensively during my playthrough, as well as more accessible difficulty options. So in the end the positives of the re-release outweigh my problems with the new abilities.

This is the longest Steam review I've ever written, but I've never played through a game where I had this much to say about it. This game isn't perfect, It's quite flawed actually. But I really, thoroughly enjoyed playing through it, and I hope whoever is reading this decides to try it out. If you're still indecisive, maybe wait for a sale and try it out then.

Everything in Ori and the Blind Forest is just solid. The chase sequences were definitely the best part of the game play with music and art style being a super tasty icing on the cake. Ori and the Willow of the Wisps discussion is more suited for its on review but I'll comment that the sequel 100% improves in every aspect from the first game. 
A lot of reviews mention the comparison between Hollow knight and both Ori games, but I think the comparison does not apply nearly as much to the first game. Apart from being in the same genre (metroidvania 2D platformer) Ori and the Blind Forest and Hollow Knight have very little in common. Mainly because the first Ori game focuses on platforming, escape sequences and puzzle solving rather than fighting or exploration. The game is essentially linear compared to Hollow Knight's multitude of ways you can traverse the map. If you're looking to get Ori and the Blind Forest, it won't be like Hollow Knight.

First metroidvania and I love this style of play. In a really cool overhaul, having a skill tree is really good and but also not mandatory to advance the story but gives a big boost, little stupid bugs on the other hand (like stuck in a corner under infinite jump animation, puzzles that weren't validating or that had to be updated by death), Cool DA chill and quiet music. 

The progression of the game is really intuitive, when you get a new skill, the difficulty and the learning curve is really easy, and a neophyte of metroidvania and even video games in general can understand and come up with difficult passages quite easily.
The level design is well thought out, and when you think you can't access parts, you just have to watch carefully.

[b] Positives part [/b] : Really dynamic gameplay, can progress at own rhythm, nice DA and musics. Easy to learn and to master, et hard to master if you want to be tricky. Replayable.
[b] Negatives part [/b]: Got too much bugs for the achievements, could finish the game more early.

[b] Warning [/b] (for those who wants to 100% the game or for those who wants to get some achievements) :

- For the achievements who need to kills ennemies with some specifics attacks, there is a chance to not get the achievement if you have died in the session before, so for this restart the game and steam, it should work
- For the One Death achievement, if you have died and you have restarted directly through the game, instead destroy your save and start over in another one.
- If you play a big game, to discover the game, be careful with the "difficult mode", do not try to have all the skills, it requires 1.5 x more points or even twice as many to obtain them all.

Beside that, it was really good. Go play it !

Its a traversal metroidvania.  You gain abilities which helps you go to another area and reach ever higher heights in the game, the combat is severely lacking, but the artwork, music, and direction of the story is top notch.  If you had to pick one metroidvania to play till the end of time, hollow knight still gets my pick (best combat, great traversal, excellent story and mood, and omg huge world), but this is a very nice short and sweet metrodvania that never stops being exciting.  there are no boring moments, if anything, the lack of quiet moment probably strikes against it (hollow knight had some excellent quiet moments which lets you appreciate how far you've come!), but the loop is extremely tight.

Highly recommended, but not if you're not good at platformers.  for those who're not good at platformers, just watch the longplay video of the game, its worth watching once if only to get the idea of how good the art, music, and story direction is!

It was okay I guess? Far from a bad game, but I think it's the sort of thing I'll finish and never feel a particular need to come back to. The presentation really carried the game for me. The world design, animation, and general ambiance which is established is really on point. It's very pretty, but that aside the mechanics are just meh. Not offensively bad, but far from being remarkable. The combat was way too simple. Your basic attack essentially boils down to button mashing at a distance and the other skills presented (with maybe a single exception) are just somewhat generic and boring at times. The other reviews I read also hyped up some mind-blowing emotional story which I simply didn't think was there. It was a fine story but other than maybe the intro it never really pulled me in and make me feel for the characters and world the way some reviews would make you believe. So yeah, not bad but not great. Despite my criticisms I'll still give it a positive review because it's still a competently made game which held my interest for its duration, but I personally wouldn't pick it up at full price.

I can't believe I never reviewed this game until now. I was blown away by Ori, which happened to be my first platformer. I definitely struggled quite a bit at first, and with one spot in particular, but that only strengthened my love for this game (and game style). I never felt like the controls were clunky or difficult to use. The system for energy and health is great as are the power-ups. Really, I have no complaints.

Then we have the graphics. I have never been so impressed by a game's design than I have with Ori. The fact that it's hand-painted just blows my mind.

And then, of course, the story. I'm a crier, but I haven't cried during video games before. That changed with this one. It was such a good, emotional story about perseverance and the strong bonds of familial love.

10000000/10 - If you're unsure about this one, get it.

Heartwarming story, fun platforming, and great visuals.

Although I enjoyed Ori and the Blind Forest, the movement isn't as accurate as I would like it to be; and having to rely on enemies for some sequences can be frustrating. But the poor save system was my only real complaint. If you run out of energy cells, it can really shoot you in the leg.

Overall, I recommend Ori and the Blind Forest. 7/10

Not gonna lie I did find this game frustrating at times. Even though the easy difficulty is advertised as a casual experience for those who just want to enjoy the story, it can be still pretty hard especially towards the beginning when your movement abilities are very limited. But as you progress and keep unlocking new skills the game gets gradually more fun and less punishing. It does throw you new challenges by introducing interesting game mechanics along the way so the gameplay never goes stale or gets too easy but you'll lose less hairs when you have many recovery options in your arsenal and can make up for small mistakes. And overall it's worth struggling through the hard parts because this game is plain beautiful. Each level in this interconnected world is designed wonderfully both from an aesthetic and gameplay standpoint. Very much recommended even if you're new to platformers.

I played Will of the Wisps first, and it's crazy to see how great this game is and how the sequel does everything 10x better somehow, like wtf?

As someone who played both Ori games back to back, I will say that I do like Will of the Wisps a lot more. That isn't to say this is a bad much less weak game, it's still a great metroidvania worth your time! The way the world begins to open as you go somewhere new, gain a new ability, have a tutorial built into the environment as you climb/explore outwards, and then backtrack through once unreachable paths is handled to a masterful degree. As well as most mechanics overall working for what the game wanted to accomplish.

I will say, some sections can easily feel uncomfortable to play, and they can easily overstay their welcome due to issues I find in the movement system and pacing, I find that the ice temple (I forget the name of it, sorry!) is generally poorly communicated as well as designed, the puzzle mechanic is hard to pick up on because it never gives you a space to tinker with the gravity mechanic used there, as well as the chase section being unreasonably difficult and poorly communicated to the player in most aspects, this made it hard to trust that I would enjoy following chase sections, and sadly, I think the final chase before the credits is also pretty bad in communicating to the player. Adding on to that with the end-game area being a massive spike in difficulty from the rest of the game, it can get frustrating to play with generally poor pacing of difficulty and easily frustrating execution of mechanics. However! I find that majority of the game is a genuine pleasure to go through and experience, the rough edges do not ruin the whole package for me, as there's lots of great aspects here! (This is also where I mention I think that Will of the Wisps executes basically everything here I had problems with to an extremely phenomenal level of game design and you should totally play that game too)

[b] INTRO. [/b]
Bought the game to relax from my examination week. However, to my surprise, the game turned out to be an exceptional experience, surpassing my expectations of it, so I decided to create a review. Ori and the Blind Forest effortlessly blends stunning visuals, enchanting storytelling, and tight gameplay mechanics to create an unforgettable gaming experience(mainly due to dying), like literally I can't recount how much I died from this game, which made me more stressful which is a good thing right?..

[b] Story [/b]
The game introduces players to Ori, a small guardian spirit tasked with restoring the forest's balance after a catastrophic event. Through the course of the game, Ori's journey becomes a metaphor for self-discovery, friendship, and sacrifice. The storytelling is done primarily through visual and atmospheric cues, with minimal dialogue, yet it manages to tug at the heartstrings and elicit genuine emotions from me.

[b] SOUND DESIGN [/b]
The game's sound design and music deserve special mention. The orchestral score composed by Gareth Coker perfectly complements the game's visuals and emotional beats The melodies are hauntingly beautiful, capturing the essence of each moment. Combined with the atmospheric sound effects, the audio immerses players in the world of Ori and adds an extra layer of immersion. 

[b] VISUAL [/b]
One of the most striking features of Ori and the Blind Forest is its breathtaking visual design. The colors are rich and varied, seamlessly transitioning between serene and tranquil moments to intense and action-packed sequences. The visual beauty of the game is further enhanced by the fluid animations. In short this game is good in sense of atmosphere, visuals, sound design.

[b] GAMEPLAY [/b]
Beyond its aesthetics and narrative, Ori and the Blind Forest boasts polished gameplay mechanics that are both challenging and rewarding. The platforming elements are finely tuned, demanding precise timing and nimble reflexes. Although I recommend this game [b] I WOULD NOT [/b] recommend it to people who are looking to play [b] tension-free gameplay[/b]. While Ori and the Blind Forest offers an incredible gaming experience, it's important to note that the gameplay can occasionally be intense and challenging, leading to moments of frustration. It's like a relationship with a mischievous spirit that tests your patience, and occasionally makes you question your life choices, but you can't help but keep coming back for more for the sake of completion. ㅜㅜ

[b] CONCLUSION [/b]
Ori and the Blind Forest is an extraordinary game that excels in the visuals, storytelling and.. gameplay(if you like intense challenges I guess). Would I play it again? YES AND NO, I have a love-hate relationship with this game so I can't really decide.

Ori is a metroidvania title that not many people talk about now days in lieu of Hollow Knight but the two titles were big influences on one another and at the time they came out were both raising the bar for the genre. 

First and foremost the Ori games look and sound beautiful, the artwork and animation are impressive with special attention being paid to lighting and particles that give the game's ethereal world so much atmosphere only added to by the orchestral world-music score. The game looks like a high quality animated feature every step of the way. The gameplay is all about mobility. The world is built to be a playground that you slide, twirl, jump, and bound through making Ori feel like they're truly at home in the forest through control alone. 

Every motion naturally flows into another and the world design encourages you to make use of every option, with the later movement unlocks only making every journey even more swift and natural to counterbalance the world map's constant expansion. Combat is simple and revolves around button mashing to bypass foes but this game isn't about fighting its the puzzle platforming. Using the high quality movement mechanics to navigate spatial challenges in beautiful spaces collecting items to continue forward. 

Each area has an elemental gimmick that is used to provide new movement challenges keeping things fresh throughout. It goes to show that creativity doesn't require crazy new ideas, even basic platforming and old level themes can be executed well to provide a rewarding gameplay experience. This game even foregoes boss fights, instead presenting big cinematic platforming sections that challenge you to get from A to B using all the tricks you've learned in the previous area. It's actually really clever to see Ori playing constantly into its biggest strength.

The story is minimal but revolves around the cycles of life and death in the large ethereal forest setting. Just as the gameplay focuses on doing one thing well, so too does the story focus on singular strong themes that resonate throughout the entire game and left me tearing up on several occasions.

Overall Ori is a solid metroidvania and while it doesn't have flashy tools or hardcore combat its game design goes to show the strength of minimalism and remains a masterclass in moving through 2D spaces.

This game is not good. If I had to summarize it in a sentence, I'd say it feels like an unusually ambitious game development project for college that expectedly falls short of actual "game" quality.
I spent a good amount of time on this game when I was younger (10, 11, 12 maybe) and tried to pick it up again to finish it which I had never done before. I did this because one of my most trusted game reviewers said it was one of his favorites of all time and because it was on sale for cheap. I still refunded it because it didn't feel worth keeping.

What are the issues? From what I either experienced or looked up on YouTube after refunding it, this is what I can gather:
- The environments are ugly and dark. No, this is not a setting on my computer. Everything feels so abysmal, even the lighter and cheerier areas. Never once did I see something and go "Wow! That looks visually impressive, or even visually tolerable!" 
-The story can literally be explained in thirty seconds or less. There are no captivating details or lore or intricacies to the world that make it worth mentioning. When I say within thirty seconds, if you're a fast enough talker, you can probably explain every lore-related game mechanic in an additional twenty.
-The save system is so lame. I don't want to have to see the same cutscene over and over again because I don't have energy or just forgot to save. Either they should have done autosave or they should have just done a more integrated and widespread checkpoint system of sorts, making ability upgrades a mobile endeavor.
-The mechanics are truly awful. What kind of combat is there? You click a button and it hurts enemies. No aiming or anything rewarding associated with it. You can also hold down a button if you feel saucy. The platforming is punishing, but not really punishing for the sake of difficulty, more like punishing because the jumps aren't outlined well enough to land consistently. The jumping, climbing and other mechanics didn't feel polished at all.
In summary of that section of the review, traversal, managing saves and combat were just chores on the way through a semblance of a story that literally could have been cranked out in twenty minutes in a conference room.

What does this game have to offer? It's not intellectually challenging or emotionally moving enough to grab my attention, but the "spiritual" adventure that it pushes is almost equally underwhelming when the world feels so uninspired almost all of the time. I might just be a hardass but this game is an incredible letdown. I'm going to buy the next one at some point to see if it improves upon the formula, but if it doesn't then I really have nothing good to say about this series. I'm pretty upset.

First off, let me preface by saying that this is one of those games that make me wish for a "mixed rating" option. It's not bad, I just personally think there are better alternatives for pretty much everything it has to offer, and my experience didn't come close to the hype surrounding it. The art is outstanding, but as a metroidvania, it feels to me like it falls short on every single aspect compared to its peers – which is apparently a sentiment [i]not[/i] shared by many people. I'll go into detail below, spoilers will be marked.

The exploration is not very interesting or rewarding – the game tells you exactly where you need to go, and due to its extreme linearity, you get absolutely nothing from going off the beaten path; in terms of secrets, most of what you get is XP that you'll have probably maxed out by the time you get to the last dungeon regardless of how much you've actually explored, the rest is health/mana upgrades that become basically useless down the line due to unlocking skills that drastically reduce damage received and mana costs. The only case where I can see these secrets being actually meaningful is in hard more, but it's pretty clear that this difficulty setting was not intended for a first playthrough due to the fact that almost everything one-shots you in the early game, aka the part where you're supposed to play around the most to figure out the "rules" of the game.

Combat gets stale real quick; bash is a very cool power – if you play on controller, that is – but it completely erases the need to dodge enemy attacks, so encounters become a matter of mashing the (auto-aim) attack button as quickly as possible while holding the bash button as soon as you see something move. It could've turned out interesting nonetheless if the devs had gotten more creative with enemy designs, but alas, only two of them have gimmicks that actually require you to approach them differently; for everyone else, spamming attacks and bashes is more than enough. The other powers are basically useless in combat, aside from the insanely powerful ground stomp whose AoE is so humongous that you're more likely to hit enemies by accident than miss them.

Platforming is nice, arguably the best part of the game, but it's not as good as dedicated platformers, and I personally don't think there's anything that makes up for the difference. Besides, I feel like some sections are somewhat poorly balanced, with hazards either dealing so little damage that you can just walk on them without issue or instantly killing you for a single mistake – in which case, you'd better have set up a save point not too long ago, or you'll have to make your whole way there all over again. Admittedly, the sheer speed you can traverse the map with in the late game is quite satisfying, but it feels like the game actively tries to slow you down at times, making it feel kinda pointless.

Finally, the story. It starts off great, and you get the sense that things aren't quite the way they seem from the beginning. But in the end, it left me really confused about its message. Like okay, [i]"don't let hatred consume you or you'll lose the things you care about the most",[/i] but how can you look me straight in the eye and tell me that [spoiler]Kuro is the bad guy for desperately trying to protect her only remaining child from the god that murdered her entire family along with Ori's adoptive mother just because he lost track of Ori, and [i]HE's the good guy???[/i] The one you serve throughout the entire game with no second thoughts? It doesn't make any sense to me. I was expecting a nuanced take on the balance between light and darkness, something about neither of the two things being inherently good or evil, and as such, neither deserving to be overwhelmed by the other. What I got instead was a banal [i]"light is good, and if darkness has to be suppressed for its sake, then so be it. What's that? Innocents dying because of this? It is what it is, man."[/i][/spoiler]

That's about it. As I said in the beginning, I don't think the game is terrible, but I just don't see any reason to recommend it over pretty much any other metroidvania I've played, unless you're a fan of platformers trying to get into the genre and you're put off by "traditional" combat, or conversely, you've exhausted all other options and are itching for yet more metroidvania (which was more or less my case, but in hindsight, I should've picked something else).

This game is actually misery to play. Other than the art style and music, I have nothing good to say about this game. Game play is awful, power progression is awful, clarity is awful, exploration is awful and story is awful.

To start off, the combat is almost non-existent in this game, it consists of button mashing a single button to kill enemies while standing completely still and once you are 30% through the game there is really no reason to ever kill enemies again. the damage done to enemies is so small its a complete chore to sit there for 15 second to kill a single standard enemy. Once you get the ability to launch off enemies, I think I maybe killed 10 enemies the rest of the game. You do not scale with the enemies and the abilities you obtain through the skill tree are all but useless.

Movement in this game is not smooth in the slightest, it is way to floaty and non consistent. CLimbing up walls is a headache, trying to land precisely on a platform is a gamble and waiting for a specific enemy to line up perfectly for a platforming section is a casino slot machine.

When traversing the world, it is near impossible to see what is going to kill you. Are those just boring bushes or are those spikes? It is so unclear when something will damage you it is hilarious. This game greatly sacrifices any clarity for the sake of art direction. The least enjoyable parts of the game were the "escape" portions in each of the area. These were not a test of skill, but a continuous beating your head against a metaphorical wall until you finally escape. You are running along and a rock falls on your head with no visual clue, time to restart the entire sequence until I get surprised again by some BS. The only way to know is through trial and error, so you end up being forced to do this portion a ton of times until you know all the gimmicks that will be thrown your way. A skilled individual should be able to do these in just a few tries not be forced to die at every step of the way because of lack of clarity.

Exploration is almost non existent in this game unless you are trying to 100% the game. Extra health doesn't matter, extra soul doesn't matter, getting new skills in the skill tree do not matter. Unless you want to explore to see a hole in ground and get a shiny orb to get more useless stuff, exploration is worthless. There are no cool ares or power ups that you get from going out of your way to explore the world. Also there are so many points in the game where you can't go back and get something you missed so if you are trying to get everything and miss it once, you're fucked.

(spoilers) And for a game that is known for its "great story" I was appalled at what was going on. The purpose is for you to restore the forest and save this magic tree while trying to escape the wrath of an owl. Turns out the tree absolutely murders the the owl babies and now we are still supposed to save the tree?? Fuck that I'm teaming up with the owl and burning this place down. I'm not trying to save a baby owl murderer. And at the end the only way for the owl to save his last baby is to get himself killed by the tree. That is so fucked. I hope in the sequel I get to burn the tree down.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a beautifully aesthetic yet challenging platformer which progresses fairly typically of metroid style platformers. While the challenge is very clearly present, it doesn't make world progression overly cryptic which is quite nice - most of the challenge comes in navigating hostile environments, which  can get a little annoying at times. To give an example, some environmental spikes have extremely deceptive collision detection, and there are certain parts of the game involving extreme timing and perfection and may require several restarts. There were a few areas that felt like some of the harder levels in Super Meat Boy (very challenging). That said, if you play the game right, you won't be backtracking too much, which is a particular peeve of mine typically present within this genre. Acquired abilities are useful outside of their progressionary intent, which is also refreshing.

I can't however mention enough how beautiful this game is. The art style is lush and vibrant; terrain and backdrops look almost as though they have been painted, creating a truly joyful atmosphere. The soundtrack is also pretty solid and only adds to the games charm. There is a story present, albeit a basic one, but this certainly doesn't detract from the general gameplay, and some feels were had in certain parts of the game. I thoroughly enjoyed this game and will look forward to playing the sequel! The most important advice I can give regarding this game, is to not be fooled by the Ghibli-esque visuals. This is a TOUGH game, harder than Hollow Knight and instead more comparable to the Path of Pain sections at certain points.

This game is a masterpiece, strongly recommend for those who want challenging gameplay and good graphics.
The soundtrack is incredible and fits in so well with the different parts of the storyline. The controls and mechanics are introduced at a pace that keeps the game interesting, while also giving you time to learn them so you don't get overwhelmed with all the moves and abilities that can be used. I have completed the main story on normal mode, and the gameplay is challenging (and sometimes a bit rage-inducing) but it stays interesting by giving you a vast range of unique areas to explore, and puzzles to solve. The main character, Ori, is animated so well and when using all the different abilities, the animation is smooth. While there are no 'bosses' in this game, this is greatly redeemed by having [spoiler]various fast paced escape sequences where you utilise what you have learnt in a challenging race against dangers that are so beautiful and they make you feel so good once you complete them :)[/spoiler]
My only criticisms are that the manual saving is a bit awkward and a lot of the enemies are just re-skins of previous ones, with slightly different abilities.  

However i have a few tips for those who are new:
- You will die a lot, Don't let the graphics fool you, this game is difficult. If you wanted a relaxing game, this is not what you are looking for
- Save your game a lot. The game doesn't autosave very often and if you die you will go back to your last save so do this to avoid losing your progress.
- Early game spoilers: [spoiler] Collect as many life/energy cells as you can earlier on so that you will find late game a lot easier. Often in late game you wont be able to save due to a lack of energy so more energy points helps with this :)[/spoiler]

Ori is a Metroidvania style platformer. It is a gorgeous game, and has some really great level design. I especially loved the escape sequences for their added tension, and the feeling of flow that they create. I do have one complaint that took away a decent bit from my experience, though.

I typically enjoy the hard difficulty on most games. But on Ori, I would recommend avoiding this. The combat in this game is a bit of an afterthought, and hard mode REALLY demonstrates this. Mashing one single button while an orb does all the work for you is NOT fun, especially when hard mode just nerfs your health and damage making these sections last even longer. Pop it in on normal or even easy to hide these issues and you're in for a fun time.

This game deserves praise for its good ideas (the bash move is especially genius), but even more for its presentation. The visuals and soundtrack are both stunning. Combined with the story, this feels like playing through an A-tier Pixar movie. Also, without this game, Ori and the Will of the Wisps wouldn't exist-- and that game is an absolute masterpiece. 

7.5/10
Gem

Is it pretty? Yes. Is it fun to play? Absolutely not.

Floaty controls, auto-grabbing/hopping of ledges, an art style that makes background hard to distinguish from foreground, unintuitive hazards and mechanics, a completely uninteresting combat system that involves spamming a single button which auto targets enemies which is 100% invalidated and made pointless by bash, a single path upgrade system, pickups that don't matter, special moves able to be bought before they are able to be used, all enemies that exist solely as a means to attack you and interrupt platforming, boss fights that are beyond meh, forced cutscenes which cannot be skipped that replay every time you respawn unless you save afterwards, and a map that is the same in every area except with different background textures ... this game is the most overrated thing I have ever come across.

It is very clear the game designers were artists and not gamers. There is nothing fun about this game. There is no real incentive to exploring, no gratification in the platforming, endless frustration with the game taking control out of your hands, the areas are uninteresting, the levels are designed in ways that are annoying and not fun, mechanics are applied inconsistently, there's hardly any variety of enemies, the screen moves too slowly and can't keep up with your character which is too zoomed out to see clearly with all the foreground/background objects being intermixed ... it is literally almost every single aspect of the game that is the problem.

The only thing this game has is that it is pretty to look at for the first 10 minutes. Then it is just a colorful blob you can't tell what's happening and you walk into tiny spikes or hot objects you couldn't tell were spiky or hot and die instantly.

Buy Ori and the Will of the Wisps instead of this.

This game rated 10/10 for style and 4/10 for substance. The presentation-- from the music and sound design to art and animation-- is incredible, and from a surface-level perspective makes Ori and the Blind Forest a strong contender for Games As Art. The visual aspects in particular were probably groundbreaking when it released, and show no signs of aging or being obsoleted. But the story and gameplay are lacking depth. The story relies on cheap tear-jerker plot elements to get the player emotionally invested, and doesn't have much to say beyond "family is good" and "be nice to people." The gameplay vacillates between simplistic but workable sections and frustratingly precise scripted sequences. Overall I don't regret playing the game, but I'm still walking away hoping that the sequel provides better mechanical elements to complement the superb stylistic elements.

beautiful aesthetic

The atmosphere is amazing, but I wish the awful game design didn't try its very best to pull me out of it during the first two hours of me playing it.

For a platformer, the motion feels too floaty and uncontrolled for the environment. It might be better with a controller than with a keyboard, but a [i]remastered[/i] version of a game should just get this right. But that's only where it starts; it's often very hard to estimate, from looking at the environment and having had some exercise with your motion, whether you should or shouldn't be able to make the jump with your current abilities. If you're making a Metroidvania platformer, this should be a disqualifying quality.

Not only is it hard to estimate whether you can make that jump, but also whether the enemy that's barely even on screen can jump on top of you. This makes you want to run away at the first sight of any enemy that you haven't seen before (or sometimes even that you think you've seen before, but this shapeless blob looks slightly different and has wildly different attacks), and get ready to spam your attack when it gets near, because enemies take a ton of hits before you're done with them. And this is "normal" difficulty.

But what prompted me to uninstall the game, where the two times that the game design, in the sense how the game signals to you how to progress towards a goal, wasted my time.

In [spoiler]the first half of Black Root Burrows[/spoiler], the game will teach you a new mechanic by sending you through a whole obstacle course. After you're done with it, you're in a nearly empty room ([spoiler]the jumping puzzle immediately before you dispel the darkness in Black Root Burrows[/spoiler]). This is usually a game's way to tell you that [u]you don't really have to learn any new tricks, you just have to apply them[/u]. And that will leave you stuck, until you figure out that you can also drop the object you're holding, which is not something you were taught (through necessity, or hints, or by accident) during the obstacle course. What's worse, once you drop the object, all your dynamics have changed, so you'll jump over [spoiler]the ghost platform next to you[/spoiler] the first time around. You're going to need a few attempts, which each take a frustrating half a minute of retrieving the object and using it to get back up again. There's a reason that failures result in fast retries in games in this genre, but this game missed that memo.

I only did that puzzle because I was stuck on another puzzle. I had pushed a rock into what clearly was a "slot" near [spoiler]the well near Thornfelt Swamp[/spoiler]. If an object "slots" into something, then that's usually a game's way to tell you [u]it is in the right place and you don't have to touch it anymore[/u]. At that point, I could wall jump, so I tried jumping up from this rock onto a wall next to it, but I only grazed the corner of that wall each time. I didn't have the double jump ability that the ability tree hinted on, so I figured I needed to get that first. After scouting the entire map for something I might have missed, and getting stuck in the aforementioned part of [spoiler]Black Root Burrows[/spoiler], I returned to the rock. As it turns out, you can't push or pull the rock out of the slot, but your attempts to do so ever so slightly rotate the rock, giving you just enough pixels of extra jump height to jump up that wall.

[i]Ori and the Blind Forest[/i] really has nothing on [i]Hollow Knight[/i] (Metroidvania platformer) and [i]Celeste[/i] (not a Metroidvania, but a focus on skillful platforming). Those games at least left me with the feeling that I should've known better and could've done better each time I died or failed a jump.

[h1] Ori and the Blind Forest REVIEW: [/h1] 

[b] Ori and the Blind Forest [/b] is a [u] platform-adventure Metroidvania video game [/u] developed by [b] Moon Studios [/b] and published by [b] Microsoft Studios [/b]. The game was released for Windows and Xbox One in March 2015, and for Nintendo Switch in September 2019. Players assume control of [u] Ori [/u], a small white spirit, and Sein, the "light and eyes" of the Forest's Spirit Tree. Players are tasked to move between platforms and solve puzzles.

Let me start off with saying how [u] BEAUTIFUL LOOKING [/u] this game is ( and [b] Will of the Wisps [/b] gets better ). From the first 10 minutes into this game you already are amazed by the beauty this game throws into your eyes alongside tears because of what happens and how they set up the game of telling a story of [b] friendship, selflessness, and loss [/b]. This game indeed made me shed a few tears at a few moments of the game. The [u] Soundtrack[/u] of this game is also super chill and amazing to listen to be it in-game or outside of it. The [u] Gameplay [/u] is pretty straightforward and expected from a platform-adventure Metroidvania game but there is something about the movement that is in this game that is super easy but hard to master. As you play through the game you learn new [u] skills for combat and movement [/u] to use like powerful jump, hanging on walls or slamming into the ground with force BUT with new skills comes new challenges to master, an example is that Ori can fire energy orbs at nearby foes when he isn't avoiding them completely, and those creatures can be difficult to overcome. The blobs that stick to walls and ceilings? They aren't much of a hassle, at least until they coat the surfaces you need to cross and spit acid onto the ground. This game is in no shape easy even on easy difficulty, you need to learn from your mistakes and failure and master every move to be able to move into next area. Not gonna lie i actually did almost rage quit the game or shouted few bad words when i was playing on the hard difficulty but it was not that i was frustrated or game’s fault but instead it was just me failing on a part cause i either miss-timed it or rushed and the custom save system where you can use one energy point to save whenever you feel like to was the best choice developers did for this game 👏. The best part of this game has to be the [spoiler] the escape sequences few rooms have to offer as you restore light to this lost forest. They are intense and pulse-pounding BUT it makes you appreciate the game's visual artistry.  Multiple layers give each environment a lovely sense of depth [/spoiler]

[b] Overall to summarize. Ori and the Blind Forest is a beautiful, heart-touching and very clever game from Moon Studios and its story, soundtrack, world, graphics and art style is beautiful from start to end. Gameplay is also super fun to play and level design always keep you on thinking to be fast and responsive. I HIGHLY Recommend this game for its price point and looking forward to playing Will of the Wisps next [/b]

Sadistically difficult.

Admittedly, I got lured in by the beautiful graphics and 'Overwhelmingly Positive' review score. What an amazing beginning. Emotional, beautiful, heartfelt. 90 minutes in I was screaming obscenities and white-knuckling my controller.

The nanosecond timing and pixel-perfect jumping required totally ruined the experience for me. Like, it was just brutal. Apparently I'm in the minority here, but I feel like the thematic elements and the difficulty don't compliment each other.

I didn't expect walking simulator-type difficulty, but I also wasn't prepared for how absolutely enraging the experience would be.

this game captivated me from start to finish. i picked it up hearing nothing but good praises about it, and it turns out, its true. the gameplay is a perfect blend of platforming and exploration, offering both challenging obstacles and rewarding discoveries.

the story is beautifully crafted, evoking a range of emotions with little to no voice lines and very few expositions from a third-person perspective, akin to storytelling in a book. the characters and their relationships are endearing. i found myself genuinely invested in their fates, which made the game all the more immersive.

one aspect that truly impressed me is the game's attention to detail. every pixel feels meticulously placed, and the level design is a work of art. the controls are smooth and responsive, allowing for precise platforming and satisfying combat encounters. backtracking to older maps once you unlock higher-tier skills also felt very rewarding, always offering new exploration experiences.

above all, Ori and the Blind Forest Definitive Edition is a testament to the power of storytelling in gaming.
it effortlessly combines breathtaking visuals, a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, and a touching narrative to create an unforgettable experience. the only unfortunate thing for me is that this game is relatively short, but there are ways to challenge yourself if you're looking for more playtime.

Writing this review fresh off of finally beating the game, I can say it was a rollercoaster ride.

OatBF is a musical and artistic masterpiece, telling a simple but fairly interesting story full of emotion and magic. There is a lot to like here, including many good gameplay ideas that should work in theory.
However, the experience is unfortunately soured by some frustrating level design, repetitive combat, and sometimes overly complex/clunky controls which WILL cause unnecessary deaths. The manual save system also caused a lot of frustration for me.
You will find out quickly that this is a DIFFICULT GAME, even on normal difficulty, and I was very close to changing to easy a few times just so I wouldn't have to rerun whole sections for the 6th time (e.g. chase sequences which do contain checkpoints on easy), but I only gave in to 1 section.
I was mainly playing this for the story, and given I'm not an avid metroidvania player, had I known how frustrating it was going to be, I might not have bought it.

However, after taking some time to collect my thoughts, I am glad I got to experience it, and while I personally won't be playing it again or buying the sequel, for anyone who enjoys this style of game, there's plenty here to satisfy your tastebuds, and the experience alone is worth the discounted price.
gud game make me cry

Steam has a binary rating system, but I'd rather stay neutral about this. I sure did expect more since everyone praised this game.
Pros:
- Graphics - it is really good, and the game doesn't require cool hardware to show its beauty. And there is something to show you for sure.
- Puzzles - they are really fun and kinda complex, don't know if i got stupid with primitive games that are common place these days, but i had to look for solutions a couple of times, or simply got lost, not knowing what to do and where to go.
- Variativity - sometimes i couldn't reach a secret place, or get through these obstacle courses, and i had to improvise, and it worked. Though later I would find out how i could do it with some new skills, or simply there were another way, still this is some satisfying feeling. But what makes it more thrilling - you don't even know, was that a developer's idea, or you simply doing it wrong, but at the end of the day you got what you were coming for, and this is still a small victory.
Cons:
- Length - I don't know if that's only my personal opinion, but I got the feeling like the game pretended to be longer, but this is a small issue since you already beat the game in like 10+ hours.
- Game design - I guess, this is personal too, but still, I thought you have to acquire a lot of skills to move forward and complete the game. I finished it and had like 40% of these soul link upgrades, but what made me ask a more serious question - I didn't have all the abilities that come from "trees". How is that possible for a metroidvania game? If I don't need all of these, why would I even bother vacuuming the map and playing for another 20 hours - to collect orbs that give me nothing? To make my playthrough easier because I didn't git gud?

In conclusion: if someone asked me if he should play this game, I'd say "if you don't, you won't miss anything, and this is actually not that great". I felt like I just wasted my time and achieved nothing.

Purchased in a sale after i have it on switch. bottom line, i have a rtx4090. Even at 1080p this game is not optimised.  game stutters are every jump, every heavy special effect area drops to under 10fps. I have the known resolution bug which prevents you from going up past 720p. i did the work around fix by going to the .exe and changing the DPI setting. this gave me the option to correct the screen resolution, but this is just a work around. The frame rate still drops way below 30 in any resolution. 

Dont get me wrong the game is great and have completed it on Switch, hence the double dip. The pc version is so bad i feel ripped off even at sub 4 GBP. 

what a cheap port which, judging by the internet, has not been bothered to be fixed since 2015 launch.

I like this game a lot. The environments and music are both absolutely stunning. I can't overstate how good this game looks and sounds. Just beautiful. The story also pulled at my heart strings and had me in tears a couple of times.

As for the gameplay, you may have heard that the combat is bad but that only apply's to the basic attack. The "Bash" move you get early on is incredibly fun. It lets you catapult yourself off enemies and projectiles and even redirect projectiles into other enemies. Just use that as much as you can.

The platforming is where you'll really be tested anyway. The dungeons and boss fights are all platforming gauntlets. There's an occasional puzzle, but this game is a lot more Super Meat Boy than you might guess. Meat Boy isn't really my cup of tea, but the art, music and the bash move really carry it for me.
meow

A fun Metroidvania-style platformer with lots of cool abilities and extremely beautiful and vibrant visuals. The game was challenging, sometimes frustrating, but overall a decent balance if you're willing to tough it out. I liked the puzzle sections but I won't lie about some of the solutions being unclear. I had to cheese some of the platformer puzzles to progress in the game lol. 

Now let's get down to my skill issues: I had a hard time 100% my save file due to an area that I missed which the map didn't indicate. I guess maybe that can be due to user error but it was literally a small section in the Ginso Tree that I visited but didn't step on. I literally went up and down the whole tree a good half a dozen times and let me tell you, I was about to cry lmao

With that being said, I didn't have as good of a time that I hoped I would with this game. Maybe it's because of the game's reputation and I expected a lot more from it. That's definitely a me problem though. There's various gimmicks throughout the game, especially in the major sections, most involving puzzles and platforming. I enjoyed a lot of them and when I figured out the solution to some of these section I was like "Ohhh, I get it now. That's really that's cool." 

I also liked the save anywhere mechanic but I do realize it could be a problem for some. You have to be strategic as it uses your energy but if you're like me then you did lots of the collectibles and abilities to mitigate this problem. Although, I can totally see this being extremely frustrating for younger players. 

I liked this game overall. The story was predictable and a little too saccharine for my tastes. It's the visuals and gameplay which I would say are mostly really good. The music was also good but some of the sections where the music is supposed to be emotional didn't really hit for me.

Once you get the full arsenal of movement the game becomes a lot more fun and almost trivial once you get the hang of things. I did have lots of fun zipping around and using enemies as bounce pads. The game rewards exploration and searching every nook and cranny to find something that can make Ori a much more fun character to play as.

I'd say the hardest parts about this game for me was honestly the sections with the owl, especially the last one. I was getting so mad after dying over and over that when the ending of the game occurred I didn't really care. I wish I felt some type of happiness or satisfaction with the ending but I didn't. Again, a lot of my problems boil down to skill issues and minor gripes with gimmicks, puzzles, and difficulty in some parts. 

I definitely would recommend this game if you're into platformers and/or metroidvanias. It's challenging and it has lots to offer in it's core gameplay loop. Would I play this again? Maybe but I don't plan on doing so anytime soon. If you're a completionist then this is probably gonna be one of more simpler games that you can 100%. I don't like giving out number scores for things but if I had to then I'd say this is a high 7, low 8. Overall, good game, I liked it but I didn't love it like everyone else.
Apart from a couple of really unfair sections, where you have no way of avoiding death traps unless you already know what's coming, the game is really, really good. It's also incredibly beautiful.
Good music, music is good. Kinda short tho, also i don't like the 3D but 2D style. Still very enjoyable though 8/10, really great game, but it just didn't connect with me too much.

Ori and the Blind Forest is an "every frame a painting" style game, and the music and sound design matches the art in its quality. The movement is very smooth - from the painfully restrictive state at the beginning of the game, it gets ridiculously round and multifaceted towards the end. It really is a platforming game, with added combat elements (compared to Blasphemous, Hollow Knight, Gato Roboto etc where the combat is just as if not more important than the parkour). 

What sours the impression somewhat is the writing. While the platforming is satisfyingly challenging, the story is basically on the level of childrens television - kinda like the Trine series. We solved all our issues with the power of friendship!- and then it ends... rather unimaginative for an IP of this quality.

Further, the dialogue of the wisp and the tree might as well not be there, as it brings nothing to the table (kinda just worsens the game, really). To compare with a different but similar game - Hyper Light Drifter has literally no dialogue in the entire game, and handles story and would-be dialogue exclusively through images and a wonderfully executed visual design. Gris has no dialogue to speak of either, and it probably functions better for it. Having what's essentially just the wisp from Zelda constantly explaining everything in all-too-concrete terms (we need to go to Fire Mountain and get the Fire Stone!) ruins the immersion more than it helps the player - it's a reminder that it's all Just A Game, and after experiencing HLD (or any other game in which the dialogue is handled in a less obtruse manner), a "Just A Game"-game just doesn't cut it. At least not for a perfect 10.

But while there's some whacky bits in the story... won't lie, I was kinda touched by the final scene.

First impressions after just finishing the game - definitely in the upper half of the X/10.

Title: A Disappointing Bluff

Review:
Ori and the Blind Forest is an over-hyped game that fails to deliver on its promises. The captivating visuals and beautiful music may initially deceive you into thinking it's something special, but underneath the shiny surface lies a game that disappoints on multiple levels.

The difficulty is not a rewarding challenge, but rather an endless source of frustration. The relentless obstacles and punishing gameplay overshadow any enjoyment that could have been found.

The violence within the game feels excessive and unnecessary, disrupting the enchanting atmosphere that initially draws you in. The stark contrast between the stunning visuals and the grim violence leaves you feeling disconnected and disengaged.

Ultimately, Ori and the Blind Forest relies heavily on its superficial charm to mask its shortcomings. It's a disappointing realization that the game's appeal is nothing more than a bluff, leaving you with a hollow experience.

In conclusion, this game fails to live up to its reputation and falls short in delivering an enjoyable experience. Don't be fooled by the shiny look and pretty music, as they are mere distractions from the lackluster gameplay and overall disappointment that awaits you.

The game is also really challenging and I love it. Give yourself a treat and buy this gem (if you are into the genre it's a must).

In reality it's just far too annoying to play:

- Attacking requires spamming one button while jumping around dodging enemies (just make it auto-attack FFS)
- Platforming sequences are more frustrating than fun, requiring many retries
- Managing your save spot is cool in the beginning, but running out of energy to save is very annoying, especially when inside a tough platforming sequence

I really enjoyed the first three hours, but it became too frustrating to continue.

I am very very very very conflicted on this review. I wish i could vote mixed instead of thumbs up or down. They attempted to make a game to please platformer fans and metroidvania fans all at once which just doesnt work. I saw a steam review that stated "Your average platformer fan doesnt want to be drip fed power ups and be lost with tedious back tracking while your metroidvania fans dont desire the more linear powers that have to be given to appease the platforming. It just doesnt mix." and as a platformer fan myself i have to agree

The pros:
- Amazing art design and world
- Emotional story that never fails to tug at your heartstrings 
- Decent combat with exceptional parkour.
- Amazing first 1/3 of the game where i would make no changes.

Hugely massive con:
- The level design is absurdly bad even for a metroidvania game. After the first of the 3 artifacts i had to look up a specific guide for where i was every 15 minutes and this is apparently really common. Every quick 1 minute long "here is the dumb way to go/solution" video got posted by unknown channels but they all got 200-400k views. That is insane that so many people have to flock to help because the level design is something to be ashamed of. Even on repeat i would probably be lost replaying an that is no fun so i decided to not go for 100% even tho i love the story and the actual gameplay.
- Another massive problem on my run was the developers not level designing for agility upgrades, since i got triple jump early i entered areas i should not of even been in...... i was in misty woods before the first artifact and another time i got lost because a crusher also shot me through the floor and i thought it was supposed to happen. When you unlock new areas too the game wants you to go to a specific area that isnt even near the new area because there was a crack in the ceiling that you can now break even tho the room was forgettable and you ran right past it and its in the middle of the map. Sometimes no hand holding just leads to sloppy level design


TLDR: Story is amazing and so is the artstyle and gameplay but idk if i would recommend due to lazy level design and unforseen player upgrades that can get you lost with no sense of how to return. I will give a thumbs up but i would suggest watching a walkthrough for the story instead. Literally cant give a thumbs down because the story rocked



EDIT AFTER 100%. Opinion on level design hasn't changed and this game is a nightmare for achievement hunters. No stone unturned is literally bugged, good thing i had a back up save to do a certain strategy to raise my secret count. Be careful if going for 100%, so many bugs. Even having any save game on your files where you bought an ability will void the achievement to do a run without buying abilities.... Had to download someone else's save online to correct that issue.

This is the first game my partner recommended a couple of years ago, when he found out I wanted to play PC games. And what a very high benchmark Ori and the Blind Forest was! Even after years, it remains to be my favourite game (tied with Spiritfarer).

I fell completely in love with Ori - the visual masterpiece along with the heartfelt story behind it and the immersive music. It's beautiful, challenging and yet it respects you as a player with how the game save mechanics work. There are some difficult sequences but they aren't too much that they make you give up on playing.

I found the death count intimidating at first but ended up laughing at myself with 1,000 deaths before I finished the game. My second play was marginally better at 600 deaths but funny enough, I'm not so hung up on the death count because all of it was worth it. Totally love the experience this game brings, and I'd continue replaying it in the future.

The bad part is that every time I finish this game, I feel like there's a gaping hole in my soul LOL! I also got Ori and the Will of the Wisps immediately after, but couldn't bear playing it yet because I don't know what I'd do with myself after I finish that game too...

[h1] One of the Best Metroidvanias Ever Made [/h1]

The title says it all. And unbelievably fantastic representation of the Metroidvania genre with more of a focus on platforming than combat. A must-buy in my book.

Story-wise, this game has only a handful of characters with no dialogue in-between them (other than narration) and yet somehow puts every AAA game to shame with how emotionally impactful it is. A lot of people found the first 10 minutes of the game to be a tear jerker and the ending is somewhat similar. We witness character growth between 2 of the characters and honestly its great how nice and minimal yet well done the story is. 

The game is one of the most beautiful 2D games I've ever played (and the sequel is even better). There's more of an emphasis on platforming than combat in the gameplay and that is mirrored by the level design as well. This is opposed to Hollow Knight - which is more combat based - and Metroid - which is very mixed. It also lacks any of the RPG elements in Symphony of the Night and instead takes a Metroid approach, which is totally fine. There are plenty of times throughout the game when I thought "That has to be all the skills in the game... right?" they hit you with another one completely changing the way you can traverse some areas. 

Unlike Hollow Knight, which I found to be almost devoid of power-ups, this game has plenty. Although I will say by the end of the game they aren't nearly as useful. The game is chalked full with every corner having invisible walls, and short little puzzles to unlock more health, magic, or XP. 

Since combat is not nearly as important in this game its understandable that combat is also the weakest part of the game. You get an auto lock-on projectile, a ground-pound, and an one that lets you bounce off of enemy projectiles. But since combat isn't that important they never really throw that many enemies at you too often and the boss battles are non-existent. The sequel improves on this aspect considerably.

The Definitive Edition adds two optional new areas to explore and that have power-ups as well. Its not that huge of a difference, and so I wouldn't say its absolutely necessary to buy the Definitive Edition. 

All in all, this is one of the best Metroidvania games of all time. I've played every Metroid game and would have to put this up there next to Super Metroid in my opinion (not as revolutionary though, just enjoyment wise). You're getting a good 8 hours of gameplay with fantastic art direction and great potential for exploration. And for the price it's at? [b] 100% you must purchase this game! [/b] The sequel is also just as good and improves upon many of the mechanics in the game.
aweesome

Ori and the Blind Forest looks cute on the outside but it's a difficult metroidvania platformer, especially on hard mode (I died +650 times). It's tough and challenging so it felt great to figure out how to pass areas. I used a controller, which felt right for this kind of game.

Beautiful environments and a cute story - there's a recurring theme of loss and new beginnings. Nice to see Ori go from a fragile weakling to a powerhouse over the course of the journey, which doesn't feel like a slog. Finished the game in 11-12 hours.

I do have a few gripes though. First off, there's no new game plus. I learned it's not uncommon for players who've played hard mode to attain only around half the upgrades by the end, which is what happened in my case. I discovered a power that's pretty much used to unlock doors to get stat and ability boosts just before I finished the game... by that point there's no incentive to level up unless you like returning to the places you've been and goofing around, which I don't.

This could just be an issue with my laptop but I also had an issue with the audio/video sync during cutscenes.

Looking forward to play the sequel in hopes that the devs brought more of what was great about this game and improved the pace of levelling through the game.

I actually genuinely enjoyed Ori and the blind forest, alongside its sequel, Ori and the will of the wisp, these games have inventive platforming mechanics, open level design that allows players to tackle scenarios in marginally different ways to each other so as to increase the level of satisfaction in the completion of its challenges and oh yeah they are pretty looking.

Unfortunately, they do not stand up to scrutiny and this mainly comes down to the unnecessary and inelegant inclusion of its metroidvania elements, which hinders the platforming core that is the crucial aspect that makes Ori stand out from the rank and file. 

Firstly, we must acknowledge that platformer fans and metroidvania fans are more dissimilar than they are alike, in spite of the latter´s frequent inclusion of the former´s elements. This means that by making a platformer metroidvania hybrid, the developers had to juggle several conflicting priorities that arose from trying to please both crowds, ultimately culminating into an experience that does not know what it wants to be.

Platformer fans appreciate and thrive off the inclusion of fun movement mechanics, engaging and demanding levels and the knowledge that they are improving at their parkouring skills, whereas Metroidvania fans tend to appreciate more extrinsic rewards, where improvement and progress is dictated by the constant drip-feed of power-ups, stat buffs and keys, whether they be power ups or just resi style keys, to open up the world. In essence, one thrives off the challenge faced and the dexterity acquired to match such odds where as the other is more concerned about the power fantasy.

Moon studios has NOT juggled these two divergent demands sufficiently deftly. The metroidvania world is both too simple to satisfy metroidvania fans but enough of a time waster with lack of relevant obstacles to bore even the most patient platformer fanatic. The mechanics are fun, but they are never pushed to their true limit by the level design, souring the experience for platforming fans, yet being too complex for metroidvania fans that want the progression in the game to level out the difficulty rather than feel the technical demand ramp up as the game progresses.

Even when given the chance to mitigate these conflicting demands by having the metroidvania platformer hybrid become more than the sum of its parts via tasteful mixing of platforming and metroidvania ideas, moon studios fails to deliver.

All optional secrets lead to a power up and little else, rather than, let´s say more fully fledged levels that rewards players who engage with the game and expand the initial scope of the world map, aspects that both types of players would greatly appreciate. Or how there´s a dearth of glitchless sequence breaking that the metroidvania genre is known for, creating diverse path for all the players, yet the game prefers to railroad you constantly.

What hurts most about any game, is not its faults but rather its missed potential. When I see what moon studios could have achieved with Ori, but ended up compromising with a middle of the road release,  I can´t help but tear up. 

Feel free to buy the game, I am sure it will last you a playthrough; now as to anything beyond that? Well, I have my doubts there, that´s for sure.

Great game. If you like Metrovania games, this is an easy buy.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a beautifully written, interactive, catchy, fast-paced, and visually stunning game. The story is simple but effective, and the characters are endearing and relatable. The gameplay is challenging but rewarding, and the art style is simply breathtaking. If you're looking for a game that will take your breath away, then Ori and the Blind Forest is definitely worth checking out.
enjoyable story line, great graphic art, all around enjoyable game.
Beautiful. Absolutely breathtaking graphics. The story from what I've gathered so far is pretty great, and Ori is so cute like- I wanna give them a hug fr fr <3

This is a near-perfect metroidvania for me. It's fun to explore, get lost, backtrack, unlock new abilities and rediscover how you can interact with each of the many diverse environments. Upon completion, I got a very satisfying feeling of accomplishment and well-spent time.

I'm a slow player, but it took me around 15h to 100% the map and get all achievements that are available on the first play-through. At first, I thought it's a pity that the map doesn't have markers, but in the end I was able to get all collectibles and discover all secrets without getting bored with repetitive backtracking or looking up online guides. Once you unlock some abilities or beat some "bosses", it becomes easier to traverse other environments, which makes it faster and less boring to go back and get some collectibles that were unavailable before. 

The game is pretty well-balanced in my opinion: there were plenty of challenges that required multiple attempts and a combination of puzzle-solving with precision, but it was never so hard that I would rage-quit. I also liked chase challenges instead of boss-fights, just a personal preference, but it was more fun and less anxiety for me.

I usually play several games in parallel, depending on the mood, but once I started Ori, I couldn't stop until I finished it. Surprisingly, this wasn't because of an engaging story, but because of the fun gameplay and overall very enjoyable experience. I think the story-telling just didn't click with me (the god-like tree talking), but the animation in cut-scenes was amazing, just like watching a professionally made short animated film. The animation in the game itself is beautiful, it has an original style, detailed backgrounds and interesting character designs. I played it on a Steam Deck, but always connected it to the big TV screen to enjoy the visuals in details. It's like playing a Pixar movie with great visuals, solid sound design, and a good family friendly story. The movement is fun after you unlock some upgrades however, you do sometimes get stuck on things you wouldn't expect to. This game does have a few flaws that make it less engaging and a bit boring. The first being the brainless combat where your projectile automatically locks onto enemies, making fights just dodging and mashing the attack button. Second being the ability to place checkpoints almost anywhere with no punishment for dying, making it easy to cheese parts of the game or mindlessly kill yourself with no care because there are no repercussions. Exploring can be enjoyable but some music would have made it better. I'd recommend this game for the movie-like experience but if you want fun game play this may not be for you.

I'm rating this as negative because if you're reading negative reviews you want a more nuanced critique of the game.

Ori has many things going for it - it's gorgeous, for starters. The music is beautiful. The art style, the aesthetic, the tone, it's all nailed to a T. The story, though simple, is evocative and simply told with minimal exposition. Honestly, the first 5 mins of this game has more story than Breath of the Wild does in it's entirety (fight me)

Where Ori really needs to be criticized though is in it's difficulty curve. Don't get me wrong, the gameplay is fun, challenging, and can be really rewarding. The platforming mechanics that you unlock throughout the game are really fun and integrated well into each area. However, the game really isn't combat focused, so it doubles down on insane platform challenges and puzzles, that get progressively more obnoxious as time goes on.
I've played Celeste. I am used to punishing pixel perfect platformers. But Celeste typically restricts things to being short loops, one screen in length. Ori makes you go through guantlets of difficult platforming sections that are riddled with one hit kills. Not really much point in having a difficulty setting if you just die in one hit 90% of the time anyway.
I actually played Ori when it first came out, and I couldn't beat it. It made me angry dying and really felt like I was being punished by the level design rather than not knowing how to use the mechanics. I swore I would replay it at some point, so now, here I am after having beaten it. It was still as obnoxious as I remember, maybe even more so, but I am glad I played it.
Ori is not for the faint of heart, and I wish it was actually an easier game that was more combat focused so that casual gamers could enjoy it's beauty. I still recommend it, but if you want to beat this game, you gotta be a "git gud" gamer. 
I'm gonna play the sequel next as I've heard it's better, hopefully it alleviates the problems I had with it.

I remember buying this game for my sister a few years back. Didn't think much of it at the time, but I thought it would be a nice gift for her. I remember seeing her playing it from time to time, the message indicating that she'd started playing it popping up on the corner of my screen. There was always a certain small pride in seeing that, because to me it meant that she was enjoying my gift.
Last September she committed suicide.

After everything had more or less settled down from that, I sat down and booted up her computer. All that was on there was Chrome, Steam, Word, and a few games. One of them, of course, was Core keeper.
She had played this game to pieces, clocking over 170 hours and owning practically everything the game had to offer. She had used every square inch to its maximum potential, and was making ridiculous amounts of loot. It was only then did I see just how much she loved my present. No other game she played quite captured her affection as much as this one. None of her friends really knew about it, however; it seems like she preferred to keep it to herself. Like it was her own little bit of heaven she could turn to whenever she wanted.

And because of that, I can't help but smile whenever I play this game.

I cannot recommend it enough; every bit of hard work the developer put into this masterpiece shows in every single aspect. The music is catchy and memorable (I'll often find myself humming certain tunes from it), the world feels lived-in and natural, and the gameplay is incredibly laid back and enjoyable. It's hard to stop once I get invested in the game; minutes can easily turn into several hours. And now, with the multiplayer beta, I play for even longer with my friends, each of us dedicated to our desired jobs. Most of all, however, we're all just happy to be together.

I really don't get the huge amount of praise for this game. It does so much wrong, and doesn't have much going for it other than aesthetics. A game needs a hell of a lot more than that though, and this game doesn't provide.


Story: 
Overly emotional, poorly implemented and uninteresting. Overall, pretty terrible.

The story is all about some magic trees that you need to revitalise. It doesn't hint at anything, or give you insights through clever world/level design, it pauses the gameplay, and makes you sit through annoyingly long cutscenes. It does this a lot, for pretty much every minor thing. There's a statue here? Better make you stop and wait while i explain the significance of it. No you can't skip it, and no you don't have a choice. You aren't allowed to do your own thing and have fun.
Honestly this really bugs me. If your game is story focused, that's fine. If you game has a deep lore or backstory, awesome. If you don't let me discover things through my own curiosity, then you may as well not bother. Grab my attention and pique my interest, then let me find out more. Don't force it, encourage it. Whenever something is added to an area to give backstory, it stops the game and starts a cutscene explaining everything in more detail than i care about. It makes a big deal out of everything, and even slows down my character as i approach the cutscene, as though it knows i'm bored and wants to spite me. Frankly, i don't care. If i want to know the significance of this random thing, i'd be paying more attention to clues and hints, or i'll interact with it. The story is honestly bad enough to completely ruin the game for me. I would let it slide if it weren't so intrusive, but it's too obnoxious to ignore.


Gameplay:
It's okay, but it's not good.

Your main attack is shooting little energy bullets. You don't shoot on your own, you have a little Navi like sidekick who does it. You don't control him. You tell him when to shoot, but not what to shoot at, or how he should position himself. If an enemy is behing a stick, you're screwed. How could this little flying fairy ever reach the other side of a stick. He doesn't hover a tiny bit higher, or move forward a little, he just waits until you have bad positioning. It's also extremely boring. Fighting is just standing somewhat near the enemies and repeatedly pressing X. It couldn't take less skill. You also get a lot of abilities throughout the game. These are really cool abilities with a lot of variety, and they all feel great to use. The way they're incorporated into the game is terrible though. One of the first ones you get is a little explosion ability that lets you break things. It only breaks these specific things at the start though, not anything later on. This cracked wall is different from the other cracked walls. Not visually, but why make sense, when you can instead add artificial length and more backtracking. Some of the abilities also have more complex capabilites. They aren't intuitive, and aren't explained at all though. The game has already shown that it is more than happy to pause everything while it sits there and talks, but that's only for the unimportant stuff. It doesn't stop to tell you how the game actually works. It doesn't explain the things that you need to know, and it's not designed well enough to teach you without explanations.


Controls: 
Meh.

Platforming is floaty and slow, fighting is bad, and the abilities aren't worth noting. The upside is the animations are outstanding and make everything feel really natural, but they are at a lower frame rate than the rest of the game for some reason, which kinda ruins the only good aspect of the movement.


World:
Pretty, but poorly built.

Graphics are great, the map is dense and detailed yet simple enough to understand and explore without getting lost; and the world is really nice to be in for the most part. This world is pretty great, but from the moment you get the dash you realise how not great the world is in terms of playability. This is also extremely apparent when using abilities outside of the area you got them. It feels like the abilities were added after everything else, which makes exploring extremely uncomfortable. The game also tries to prevent sequence breaking in a terrible way. If you try to just damage boost past spikes it's usually fine, but if you do it in certain places you will die instantly. Some spikes deal 3x as much damage as other spikes right beside them, as though the devs realised their mistake last minute and fixed it in the quickest way possible.
I forgot to mention the enemies, but overall they're pretty great. Not much to complain about. Wide variety, and interesting. The only issues with them steam from the controls, not the enemies themselves.

OST:
Beautiful. Really damn beautiful. I'd recommend buying the OST, but not the game.
