Despite it's noticable flaws, this is still an amazing game.

The best part is definitely the stunning visuals, every area of this game is absolutely gorgeous. And the accompanying music that plays is beautiful. I actually like this OST more than Will of the Wisps'.

This is a more platforming focused metroidvania than other metroidvanias I have played. It's where the gameplay really shines, as the combat is probably the game's biggest downside. The sheer amount of different movement options you have at the end of the game is insane. And the well designed levels compliment the movement system as you can almost always figure out where to go and which ability to use to get there.

The great platforming is probably at it's peak in the escape sequences of the game. These are the game's replacement for bosses. Now, these are masterfully crafted as they don't feel out of place like in many other games. And they aren't extremely easy either, you will fail at least a couple of times before you do them right. And the songs that play in these are so freaking good. I swear there is no better feeling than restarting the escape sequence right as the main theme leitmotif starts playing.

I don't know how to explain the story too much without spoiling a lot but know that it's very touching.

The main flaw of the game is the combat. It's just a button mashing simulator with absolutely zero depth because you don't even have to aim the attack. Although the abilities you can use for combat are really fun. I have seen many people point out the game's save system as a flaw because of the save points that you can create. I personally don't find these that bad, I usually forget they exist most of the time.

There are a bunch of other smaller flaws, but even with all of this, the good aspects heavily outweigh the bad aspects of this game. Almost everything besides the combat is amazing. I highly recommend checking out this game and it's sequel.

Ori and the Blind Forest: DE is easily one of my favorite games of all time, if not my favorite of all time period. I've beaten the game so many times now, and three times on its One-Life mode--once on my Switch, once on my friend's Steam account, and most recently again on my own Steam account (with 100% completion!). So even though I'm listed as 23 hours into this game, I've played it for many more.

There are many things that make this game wonderful in my mind, but I'll give an overview of my favorite things in a non-spoiler fashion.

TL;DR: Give this game a shot; it's well worth it.

GAMEPLAY (Excellent!)
First off, Ori and the Blind Forest has easily some of the best movement in any platformer I've played. Ori feels very responsive.  In the early game, Ori feels good enough as you just run and jump through the map. But, as the game progresses, the various abilities you unlock allow you to soar across the map with high speed and high precision. Ori spends a ton of time in the air, but you always have a ton of control.

The game isn't easy, either. You're given a wide variety of abilities that string together in very interesting ways, and the game expects you to learn how to use them and use them well. The challenges the game throws at you demand a certain degree of mastery over the controls and Ori's skills, as you'd desire for a platformer. Given how I've played it to death, the difficult is somewhat diminished in my mind now, but I do recall that I took hundreds of deaths in my first playthrough--a good thing in my mind as a gamer who likes a challenge. But, even if you prefer easier experiences, you're allowed to save (almost) anytime and anywhere, so you can typically lock in your progress after clearing a difficult challenge only once. This allows the game to be difficult without being too punishing. The game also has an Easy mode for inexperienced/relaxed players.

As a side note--you may have heard Blind Forest described as a metroidvania. This is nominally true, but it honestly it plays fairly linearly; if you're looking for a distinctly metroidvania experience, this isn't quite the game to find that. Most of the metroidvania parts will be missed entirely unless you're going for 100% completion, and even then they play more as a "come back to this area later with a new ability to explore this small nook with bonus rewards."

I say all that to say: Treat Ori like a linear platformer game. that's where it shines, and it shines brightly.

STORY (Simple but Heartfelt--no spoilers, I promise)
Because I'm promising no spoilers, I won't say much. All I'll say is that the story is deeply heartfelt, which I always love in a game. It's not particularly deep, so if you're looking for a story that will leave you with something to chew on for an extended period of time, you won't really find it here. Instead, the story is simple--which is the right fit for what Blind Forest is--and it ties the game together beautifully.

GRAPHICS (Beautiful!)
This game is gorgeous. If I recall correctly, every environment was painted by hand and then imported into the game. 

MUSIC (Stellar!)
Gareth Coker is a stellar composer, and it shows in this game. I do think he outdid even this soundtrack in Will of the Wisps, but I still find myself pulling up the Blind Forest soundtrack on Spotify here and there. Every track is memorable in its own way, and helps the game really hit home with the wide range of emotions it explores throughout.

REPLAYABILITY AND PLAY TIME (Depends on you! But probably honestly not too replayable.)
In my mind, replayability is a non-factor for a game's quality, and way too much emphasis is placed upon it in modern game reviews. But that's a side rant that I'll spare you for now. I'll just cover this since I know some people care about that sort of thing.

Ori and the Blind Forest's replayability is contingent upon the type of gamer you are. If you like beating a game once and then calling yourself done, Ori will give you an experience that's loads of fun but won't last too long--maybe around seven to ten hours on a first playthrough, depending on your skill with plaformers? (Again, I've played this game to death, so I don't have a good sense of this anymore, but my playthroughs nowadays tend to take three hours to 100% the game--given that I die infrequently, if at all, and already know where all the secrets are.) If you want to get all the achievements, including the ones related to One-Life mode, you'll need to replay the game several times to do so. Again, given the game's linear nature, the repeated playthroughs will be similar to one another, so most of the replay value comes in refining your abilities in the game and watching yourself improve.

In a nutshell, if you get a kick out of grinding and watching yourself improve your skills--and won't be TOO devastated by dying to an instakill two-and-a-half hours into a One Life run of the game for the final achievement (and there are many, MANY instakills in Blind Forest)--Ori has a ton of replayability. Otherwise, don't expect too much from repeat playthroughs.

CONCLUSION (BUY THIS GAME!)
BUY THIS GAME! It's well worth the price, well worth the time, and well worth the tears if you happen to be an emotional gamer.

-----

*Yes, I know Ori is canonically ungendered. But also, I've always thought of him as male, not to mention that his voice gets deeper in Will of the Wisps--a distinct indicator of puberty in males. ;)

I think I came up with a pretty good test for detecting a psychopath. All you need to is:

- Chain someone to your gaming chair;
- Make them play first ten minutes of Ori and the Blind Forest;
- Listen to any "awwww" sounds. 

Seriously, this game is so awwww-some that I don't think most human beings have a capacity to withhold such overwhelming cuteness, unless something is terribly wrong with them. Going through Ori's intro sequence is like watching a duckling that falls to sleep next to a bunch of small kittens. This game enchants you quickly, sucks you into its world in a matter of seconds and just like someone who failed the aforementioned test, it will never let you forget it.

In case it wasn't obvious before and by some miracle you've missed all the screenshots, I'll state the obvious: it's a TRULY BEAUTIFUL GAME. Vividly drawn landscapes and happy fluid animations are parts of its charm, but combined with an ABSOLUTELY GENIUS SOUNDTRACK create a true feast for the senses; one that will only be depreciated by inventing edible strawberry-flavored monitors. The simple act of just pacing around is a great audio-visual experience, but along with the looks comes a surprisingly well-written story, giving our movements a deeper purpose. Despite its simplicity and Disneyesque qualities, it's told quite well, shifting the moods along the ride. While Ori is generally a joyful experience, it can also be full of tension or filled with grim solemnity. Each area has its own mood, making the world feel incredibly alive.

Game's great atmosphere and soothing colors are important for other reasons, namely calming us down. Ori has a QUITE HIGH DIFFICULTY LEVEL, that's usually somewhere between "that's gonna be a challenge" and "Oh, hell no". The whole game area is one giant level, divided into smaller areas, creating something that gaming PhDs would call "Metroidvania-inspired platformer". While at first the road ahead is quite easy and straightforward, Ori quickly learns a bunch of new abilities that broaden the area of exploration to the size of New Caledonia. Curiosity and good eyes are often rewarded with the additional XP and power-ups, so there's a good reason to stray often from our path, but it's also incredibly easy to get lost in the huge sprawling environment. And sometimes you're going to waste time trying to beat a challenge that looks do-able, but it can only be done with certain skills that you don't yet possess. Some sections are just also old-fashionably hard, especially when you had the misfortune of saving the game with a low amount of health. When you painstakingly try to make your way through the level for the 20th time even the beauty of the world around can be lost. 

Despite giving us a harsh time now and then, Ori and the Blind Forest remains a PHENOMENAL game. The definitive edition is probably the best way to start the adventure with it, since it offers more content, new abilities, option to adjust difficulty and various quality of life improvements, etc., but you still won't be disappointed by going for the original version. It is still one of the best games I had the pleasure of playing and after 200 titles I'm not stating this lightly. It's an incredible experience and a total must-play. 10/10. My thumb is up so high that I'm going to look like a Statue of Liberty on this one!

I wanted to like this game, there's just a host of factors that have caused this game to be little more than infuriating. I played the entire game, start to finish, and completed all achievements not requiring subsequent runs, so I feel like I have a good understanding of the game.

To start, I'll admit that the art is objectively, beautiful. However, with so much detail on the screen, combined with the size of your character often makes it hard to understand what is hitting you. Projectiles from enemies can either camoflague into the backdrop, or just be small enough that you can't see them among the many other things on the screen. I understand that the size of your character is supposed to make the world seem bigger, however I feel it negatively impacts the game to an unreasonable level.

The movement in this game felt like shit to me the entire time. This game is some of the worst implementations of wall jumping and double jumping that I've experienced in my entire life. I see many ways in which this game strives to be unique, with the mechanics being one of them. Admittedly, some of the concepts I like, like the Bash movement allowing you to launch yourself off of enemies. Some I wasn't fond of, but I understand the purpose for, such as the saving. Saving in this game is much more of a risk reward mechanic, and while I personally don't like the way saving works, I don't think the decision to treat in game saving in the way it is is a particularly bad thing. However, referencing back to the double jump, it seems that this mechanic was changed from the typical double jump system just for the sake of being different. Being different doesn't automatically equate to being better. If the goal was to make the game harder, you can do this much more effectively through more difficult platforming sections based on environment, rather than player control. 

While I did praise the "Bash" system earlier, I found that the hitbox within which I could activate the ability was spotty, especially during the tree climbing segment. I found many hitboxes to be illogical, be it some of the spikes or enemies jumping next to you and failing to indicate the area in which you are able to be damaged.

The damage scaling in this game really doesn't make sense to me. When you have 3 hit points at the beginning of the game, spikes deal 2 damage. As you progress, you gain more hit points, but the damage from spikes and other enemies scales with you. Supposedly this system really forces you to explore and find as many secrets as you can to raise your health, but it still is an illogical way to scale difficulty throughout the game, at least to the degree that it is. 

The story for this game to me is, for lack of a better word, average. Without spoiling what happens, it is at first glance a meaningful story, however if you put even an ounce of thought into it, the story is in no way deep or special. I don't even think this game necessarily needs to have a sprawling beautiful story, but people treat it like its the greatest story ever told by man, while in reality it's on par with a Disney movie. 

The world building in this game feels highly disconnected. While each of the locations is beautiful, they all feel very separate from each other. You have your typical water section. Your lava section. Your forest section. Your dark section. Each of these environments in an echo chamber is great, but as I played through the game I felt no sense of coherence between the areas that had been created. 

Finally, the combat system is just all around disappointing. No thought has to be put into any sort of fighting throughout the whole game, it's just repeated left clicking. This would be fine of combat was sparse, but there is frequently enemies that you need to take care of, and the clicking becomes monotonous. 

In short, I feel like there's just always a better game for you to be playing if you feel the urge to play Ori. If you want world building and combat, play Hollow Knight. If you want platforming and a meaningful story, play Celeste. I'm hoping I enjoy Will of the Wisps more than this one.

This game was long on my wishlist, and now when I am actually playing it, I am disappointed.
It is simply too hard for me. I started with Normal difficulty, then switched to Easy, but it didn't help. I'm a middle-aged casual gamer, and I play with a keyboard and mouse.

Some parts seem deliberately nasty, it's like the developers just wanted to push the player into rage-quitting. It feels like Meat Boy - if you like such a gameplay, go ahead and prepare yourself for a lot of dying - but that doesn't suit the game's atmosphere IMO.
Many parts of the map are inaccessible until you get the required ability, and I had to learn that by watching youtube walkthroughs.

It's a pity for me because I really wanted to enjoy the game.

Edit: As a completionist, I finally finished the game with > 2100 deaths. What a rage!

gameplay

A cute exterior hides a difficult metroidvania filled with beauty. Definitive doesn't get you trading cards but Original edition does. So know that. The definitive gives you an extra two places to go to, which, while nice, isn't essential but you will fill up your ability trees faster thanks to the extra exp.

Cool metroidvania that de-emphasizes combat - as you have an infinite ranged attack that automatically seeks out enemies - and instead focuses on gorgeous atmospheric environments and its novel system of placing your own checkpoints. The interconnected regions of the forest are visually and mechanically distinct, though none of the game's stylistic choices break the mold. The level of background detail rarely affects readability, but that problem is far more pronounced when it comes to enemy projectiles, which often blend in with your projectiles or the drops from enemies, all of them being effectively just moving glowy bits.

My biggest criticism would be that the game does not unlock its full fun potential until your character, Ori, does; that is, until you've unlocked a solid selection of movement options. Once that has happened and you've become accustomed to the controls, even returning to previous sections of the map becomes a blast.

As for the story... I'm not crying you're crying

This is a complicated game to recommend. The OST is absolutely stunning, the art is very pretty and the story is touching and well executed. But the levels, man. 
I almost quit because of one sequence that required either near perfect inputs for a long stretch of time, or to previously grind like a madman to spec out the protagonist's mobility. The difficulty of this game comes mostly from trial-and-error, that I despise in videogames as it punishes the player in a first, blind run, and from confusing level design, which again, punishes the player for no reason. Physics are a wee bit junk, first run and I got clipped into a wall and didn't know what to do, it can get a bit grindy, easy mod is normal mode, levels are a bit too set in stone, not a ton of space for creative manouvering unless you unlock another movement ability. 

In the end it was 100% worth it, would buy again. It's a seriously good game with some tearjerking moments and tight movements.
Just make sure it's not a game you play while working 9 to 5, it can be stressful. If you can exercise patience, you'll enjoy it.

The graphics are beautiful, the music is pretty, the story is cute...but it just isn't fun to play. The controls are fiddly and difficult. The general darkness and color choices make it hard to see where the platforms are and what is a monster. There is an easy mode, but it doesn't affect time run mechanics, which is a huge accessibility issue. I literally cannot proceed from the bash mechanic water run, because it requires perfect reflexes and perfect timing, and there is no room for any error. The water speed should be much slower on easy mode! Most of the "puzzles" are not actually intellectual puzzles but reflex tests: You have to brute force the correct timing for pressing each button, by trying the same sequence over and over again. It just isn't fun or satisfying in any way. The game also saves randomly after some sequences and cut scenes, but not all, so if you forget to save after one, time to watch it again! Make it consistent at least! All that said, I think there is something very wrong and disturbing about a game that just makes me want to plunge the cute main character into the spikes over and over again...

One of the vey few games I've actually finished recently! Not only is the visual style quite appealing, but the difficulty level on normal difficulty is actually NORMAL. If you - like me - ever played Hollow Knight and got frustrated over the difficulty level, then you will love Ori!

It's not based on boss fights, it's all about arcade - jumping, dashing, evading, attacking. No part of the game gets frustrating, even the hardest parts seldom require more than ten tries to get past. Also, the saving system is quite nice: basically, you can spend an Energy point to save before a hard passage and then immediately return to this checkpoint if you fail.

The only critique I might have is that sometimes it requies quite some precision when trying to land on a slim platform - without it, I would probably have died 20% less.

All in all, it's a superb game. I beat it in 10 hours on normal difficulty and spent another 5-6 hours to collect everything and explore the whole map.

10/10 points and I'm looking forward to play the sequel!

Ori and the Blind Forest is a fun but flawed game. 

The first thing to note is that this game is not Hollow Knight. I've seen it recommended in the same breath, but this game is about platforming not combat- there isn't even a proper boss battle in the entire game. So make sure to go in expecting that. 

Secondly, the game has no checkpoints. Instead you make your own checkpoints consuming the same resource you use in combat. That took me a lot of getting used to, so be sure to save as often as you can to avoid having to redo a difficult section over and over again.

With those two things in mind, Ori is a fun game with an adorable story and artstyle.

Played the free DEMO WINK WINK.... Fell in love with the game like everyone else. So i bought the package money well spent. This game is magnificent in combat and graphics. I want a white cat named ORI.

game was like 10-12 hours (took me 12 but I'm also not the greatest at platforming and this game has some janky hitboxes). 8/10, both fire areas were insufferable and annoying, the escape sequences were too long, there's areas where you're expected to dodge stuff falling from the sky but their timing and position was RNG which made playing a section over and over so much more annoying because your view is so limited/zoomed in that you can't meaningfully react and dodge the falling shit which led to getting hit which meant basically just letting the game kill you because you need that health for a future section and there's no way to regain health besides finding health pickups or investing a dozen points into a skill and wasting your energy to save the game to regen 2 points of health (which is practically useless because every enemy in the endgame does like over 4 damage minimum. although i did finish on hard mode so maybe the other difficulties may have less damage dealt). also the janky hitboxes made climbing so much more annoying than it needed to be. 

anyway, it's fun! it's a fun little metroidvania, wish there was more to do, more enemies instead of reskins, and some intended paths were more clear, especially in Sorrow's Pass because i was stuck there for like 30 minutes (tbf it was my fault because i forgot an interaction you could do but still, only time i had to look up a guide), but I still got most of the stuff done (76% completion) without really trying. not gonna 100% because I can't be bothered but I had fun! if you like metroidvanias but don't want much combat deeper than spamming a button or holding it down for a big attack, this will probably be right up your alley. the platforming is really fun and i'm excited to see how the sequel builds on this.

Really beautiful game with fluid, tight mechanics. I don't usually like platformers but the movement is so smooth that it makes this game a joy to play. The projectile redirect mechanic is one of the most fun abilities I've used in a game. All the upgrades feel natural and play into each other to make your movement increasingly complex and satisfying. I didn't think I'd really like this game but I ended up binging most of it in a day, so I think they achieved something pretty special with how this game controls.

The devs also clearly put a lot of work into the animations and responsiveness of the environment. So many things react to the physics of the world such as floating rocks temporarily sinking under your weight. It really makes the game world feel alive. Coupled with the relaxing, lovely music and art direction, the game looks gorgeous.

My one major complaint is the amount of camera shake, especially during the escape sequences. It does help add to the tension of the moment, but the amount of shake is completely overkill and makes for a frustrating experience when I can't see what's going on. And the escape sequences in general are just stressful and un-fun because death means starting from the beginning. It can get really tiring. Not to mention it can take the wind out of the final moments of the game because instead of feeling the thrill of an exciting escape, I just felt relief that the annoyance was over.

[h1]My Rating: 4/5[/h1]
Excellent, but it is unforgiving so be ready for the difficulty of the game to escalate in important parts.

While I previously recommended this game, in retrospect, I realized that I was just trying to be positive. In all honesty, while I did have fun at times, I didn't like this game very much, and I have very little interest in revisiting it. 

The platforming can be brutal, and I hope you remembered to save, because if not, you're losing progress. The combat is kinda bad, mostly due to how simple and bare-bones it is. My biggest annoyance though is the lack of bosses, instead championing long escape sequences which simply aren't the same. I know it isn't a rule, but I really like my metroidvanias to have boss battles to put my skills to the test.

On top of all that, while the graphics and music are all great, the story isn't, and feels about as bare-bones as the combat. I'm generally not one to gripe too much about a video game having a mediocre plot, but the gameplay, for me at least, wasn't fun enough to justify it. Some people really like the plot, but I personally was not very impressed, nor was I especially emotionally rattled.

This game isn't a bad game. However, I didn't really enjoy myself all that much in retrospect, and because of that and the reasons behind it, I don't think I can actually honestly recommend it. Go play the sequel, Will of the Wisps. It improves on every single thing I complained about here.

9/10 superb metroidvania with an emphasis on platforming reminiscent of DK. Amazing gameplay, visuals, music, sound, and overall atmosphere. Great level/area design and exploration. Fast travel is well-done and revisiting areas to find missed secrets doesn't feel like a chore. Overall, it's a real joy to play.

Three things you should not expect from this game:
1. Combat. You take out plenty of naughty critters but the emphasis is on platforming more than combat. Notably, there are special platforming sequences instead of bosses in the usual sense.
2. Puzzles. There are a few little areas that take a some planning or thought. This aspect of the game could have been taken to the next level while staying true to the overall feel of the game.
3. Story. There's not a lot going on with the storyline. What's there is heartfelt and fleshes out the characters a little.

Let me start off by saying this is a very beautiful game. 

From the music to the graphics to the atmosphere the game presents is a masterpiece in motion.  the mystical forests, marshes, and caverns shimmer with radiance. It's like watching a painting of light dance about the screen. And Gareth Coker's haunting score keeps you enthralled for the entire story. When I hear the orchestral score that plays when you're climbing the Ginso tree it sends chills down my spine... in a good way.

The controls, especially when playing with an Xbox One controller, are very responsive and fluid. There was no delay whatsoever in input, and this is very important because the game has a massive number of platform jumping puzzles sending you bouncing all over the place where even the slightest error will send you careening down to your death. 

The game is pretty forgiving when it comes to life and death, allowing you to try again as many times as you like. There's also a system that lets you save your game almost anywhere. Without this I would have quit the game long ago.

But, yes, I wholeheartedly recommend this game as long as you are okay with nimble-fingered jumping puzzles. If that's your kind of game then this will not disappoint.

The game follows the story of Ori, a spirit who lives in the forest of Nibel. Ori is tasked with restoring the forest to its former glory, but must first navigate through perilous environments and defeat powerful enemies. Along the way, Ori meets several characters who offer guidance and aid in the quest.

One of the most impressive aspects of "Ori and the Blind Forest" is its art direction. The backgrounds are simply gorgeous, and the character designs are both charming and unique. The game's lighting effects are also top-notch, creating an immersive atmosphere that draws players in.

In addition to its stunning visuals, the game features a beautiful and haunting soundtrack that perfectly complements the action on screen. The music ranges from sweeping orchestral pieces to more intimate piano compositions, and is one of the highlights of the game.

Finally, the game's story is both touching and powerful. The themes of loss, redemption, and sacrifice are woven throughout the game, and the characters are all well-written and sympathetic. By the end of the game, players will feel a real sense of attachment to Ori and the other characters.

Overall, "Ori and the Blind Forest" is an incredible achievement in game design. It offers a challenging platforming experience that is both visually and emotionally stunning. It is a must-play for anyone who loves games that are both beautiful and meaningful.
great game with fun challenging platforming and an amazing soundtrack, visuals and story

Ori is a good game, not exactly a great one, but its highs like the Ginso Tree are very high, that being said, the game has a lot of things holding it back, its nonexistent combat system, its set pieces occasionally delivering cheap shots and an overall jank to some of its mechanics, but dont let that dissuade you, its a quality Metroidvania, that has a really wonderful visual style, the soundtrack wasnt to my taste, but its full of quality ambient and mood setting pieces. Its not very long either, which means it doesnt over stay its welcome, and for the price its well worth it. I have heard a lot of these issues are solved in the sequel, and i hope they are, the game otherwise had some really satisfying gameplay, and the artstyle was one of a kind. I give it a 4/5, definitely worth it if you're looking for something short, sweet, and nicely poignant.

I will preface the following rant by saying I beat the beat the game all the way through.

Unfun platforming, uninspired music, boring and contrived story, difficulty is artificial (everything is a 1-2 hit kill, lots of cruel booby-traps you could only see coming with precognition, platforming sections with moving parts that aren't synced up so getting through is RNG), un-intuitive controls and UI, constant cutscenes always stopping gameplay in it's tracks for no reason, the entire game is riddled with bad design choices which punish the player for trying to enjoy it.

And it's still better than the original, this version has a dash(the platforming was not designed around air dashing at all, makes it much easier), ranged attack(you can miss this for the entire main story), fast travel(i know right, the last one didn't somehow, a metroidvania without fast travel), and some less major QoL changes and bug fixes.

Admittedly not very buggy though. Carried by pretty visuals right until the end

This review is for the definitive edition specifically. I had horrific stuttering that made this edition unplayable. I spent hours trying to troubleshoot, from compatibility mode, to forcing D3D9, to setting CPU affinity, to turning off G-sync, to limiting my monitor to 60 Hz, to increasing CPU priority. I have a  beefy computer with 12600K CPU and 3070 Ti GPU so it's obviously not a lack of computing power, and the standard version runs fine. Luckily I bought Ori forever ago and was able to play the standard edition, but if you're considering buying this, don't! Try another version, maybe a console version would run better. Good luck!

After starting the game years ago and for some reason abandoning it again quickly, I decided to pick it up again. I had quite high expectations due to the universally good reputation this game has and I have to admit that I was not disappointed. 

The game is beautifully designed and offers a good balance of challenging level design while not being overwhelmingly difficult. The combat is pretty straightforward and while being fun in the beginning, it gets a bit stale towards the end. The save feature is also pretty ingenious and I personally really liked the way it was implemented. I think some people might dislike it but I digress. 

I would've liked a bit more focus on the puzzling aspect in this game and an easier (or more accessible) way to quickly travel from one point of the map to another. Sometimes it also wasn't that intuitive to figure out where you had to go next to progress in the story but these were all minor "flaws" in an otherwise awesome game. 

Overall, a really good platformer with an engaging story, beautiful visuals and above all - a beyond masterful soundtrack.

Ill preface by stating that the graphical style in this game is beautiful, unfortunately...it goes downhill from there. 
The first like 10 minutes of the game is extremely disengaging and a bitnof a slog, where it really isnt a game. Its a narrative setup but displayed in a way that just frustrates the player. Im ok with cutscenes of story elements to kick off a game, but 10 minutes of half forced slow walking and half slow animation, where the transitions are not even clear...it just completely draws you out of the game and was a huge turnoff. 
When the game finaply does start the movement feels ok, and you learn your new abilities and the progression felt nice. The metriodvania style of backtracking with new abilities wasnt awful to start but the game got unclear fast. There were lots of frustrating bits where it doesn't feel like you're dying because you did something wrong, but for something on the games end, which is not fun. 
Overall i was so excited for this game from what id heard about it and the look of it was gorgeous. Unfortunately the product i got was a quick refund after ultimately having next to no fun while playiing it.
Do not recommend.

My feelings on this game are... strange, to say the least. I'll start with the obvious - this is a playable piece of art. The graphics are stunning and the music is absolutely amazing. It feels like walking around a painting.

The combat is a little bland (you can get through most encounters just by mashing X) with a few interesting abilities to spice it up, but using them is pretty much optional. The environmental puzzles are interesting and the platforming feels pretty good, albeit floaty. The level design is clever, but the map design overall is average (if we're talking metroidvanias).

Let's adress the elephant in the room - this game can get very difficult, expecially if you don't really play platformers all that much like me. I truly started to enjoy myself after around 2/3 of the game, when I mastered the controls and got some of the more interesting abilities (like dash, for example). Before then I got stuck quite a lot, but you could blame that on me being pretty shit at platformers.

Overall, it's a beautiful and interesting game. I mostly played it 'cause I wanted to experience the story myself before getting around to the sequel, but I still enjoyed it nontheless.

The game has excellent music and world building. The progression of the game felt organic and the challenges felt proportionate for the stage of the game. The platforming difficulty increased as the game progressed and became both more punishing and rewarding for performing better. The game does a great job of teaching you to play by playing the game itself. It is incredibly easy to become immersed in this game.

I tried to like this game, I really did. But the fact is, it's not really fun.

The visuals are stunning, and the sound design is wonderful, but the overall experience is not rewarding. In many cases you get stuck in repeatedly attempting clearing a sequence of events, where the only way to learn the correct set of move is by dying repeatedly. You always go back to square one (the most recent save) and you get severely punished even for the slightest mistake. For example, if you miss a jump and fall onto spikes, you die with up-to four strikes (I played the normal setting). Given spikes usually cover a large surface, there is no way to avoid getting multiple strikes, which effectively makes it 1-2 strikes before dying.

Experiencing this over and over makes the learning curve really steep, and non-rewarding. And when you finally get to clear a sequence, you are just met with another one of similar difficulty, This gets frustrating and dull eventually, to the point I just did not want to play anymore. I gave up in the second tree quick-action sequence (wind) since it was really long, spikes and geysers are semi random, and there is no way to save mid-way (which means, if you die you have to repeat everything from the start). 

Don't get me wrong, I am well familiar with action-platform-exploration games, and usually am all down with the "git gud" approach. It's just that even when you "git gud" the overall experience is not cathartic at all. It felt more like playing "guitar hero" than playing a platformer.

If you are into challenging, rewarding, action-platform games, I recommend "Hallow Knight" or "Celeste", which are much more rewarding (and boast much better controls). Your time is better spent there than playing this one.

Ori is a dream to control, moving him is so fun and satisfying! The game uses momentum based physics, more akin to Sonic the Hedgehog, so It does take some getting used to for some of the more difficult platforming elements; however, once mastered, moving around is so much fun! My absolute favorite part of the game is the sensational bash ability! A true game changer and what makes Ori unique in my opinion. A must play for any fan of both classic metroidvania games and side-scrolling platformers!

Ori has beautiful visual and music combined with a minor but very emotional story. I sadly just can't recommend the gameplay aspect.My core issue with the game is the checkpoint system, and an overreliance on Trial & Error.Ori has a manual checkpoint mechanic, where you can pop down a respawn point by spending a point of energy. In the early game, this is made frustrating due to you having a very limited amount of energy. It gets better as the game goes on once you have around 5+ to spend, but the game is also incredibly stingy with refills on both your energy and health.Checkpointing saves your state as is, meaning if you happen to scrape by with little to no health, a respawn will bring you back in that condition. This means you'll have to complete long sections of the game starved of your core ressources, or bungling all the way back to a proper savestation to refill. There are energy refills scattered in the world, but the game is incredibly stingy with these drops. I ended up basically never using the explosion attack, since that takes energy too, and why would I spend it on an attack when I might lose out on a critical save later on?The absolute worst part of the game are the escape sequences after every dungeon. These are 95% trial & error, there are parts where you'll die half a dozen times because it just isn't clear where you're supposed to go. I almost gave up on the final one because I could not figure out what it wanted me to do on the final stretch, and keep in mind, you are replaying this ENTIRE section EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. YOU. DIE. At this point, I could probably play the final escape blind.The ability unlocks are also not particularly interesting, and just make number be bigger for the most part. I never ended up finding the dash that is mentioned in the air dash upgrade, which should probably already tell you the game isn't very invested in that side of it.I might just be past tolerating games with instantkill spikes and "Do it again" as their core gameplay-loop, but if you enjoyed that part of early gaming, you're probably gonna like Ori too.

A medida que você vai jogando (e morrendo) e coletando novas habilidades (e morrendo) e explorando o mapa (e morrendo) o jogo vai se transformando em um jogo bastante divertido. Assim que você vai se acostumando com tantas habilidades novas, o jogo sobe de nível!A história tem seu peso e confesso que depois de fazer 100% na minha primeira jogada com centenas de mortes para chamar de "aprendizado" :D no modo normal, fui verificar as conquistas e olha, elas realmente motivam! 30 horas depois eu já tinha terminado uma segunda vez no modo difícil e depois fui atrás da conquista final de finalizar o jogo sem morrer e sem utilizar pontos de habilidade no modo "uma vida". Enfim, JOGAÇO! Vale muito a pena pelos gráficos, jogabilidade e história! Não se engane achando que é jogo infantil, mas também não é nada do outro mundo porque consegui platinar... E lá vamos nós para a sequência!

TLDR: A visually stunning game marred by mediocre gameplay and a forgettable narrative. I played through the game on Hard, and some of my feedback may not be as applicable on easier difficulties.

PROS: The art and soundtrack are top notch. The opening sequence is fantastic and is very effective at engaging the player emotionally early on. The movement is fluid and satisfying, and the cinematic 'escape' sequences are exhilarating, at least for the first five or so attempts. Among an otherwise basic kit of skills (wall jumping, double jumps, dashes), a few of them felt innovative and refreshing, like the Bash move that allows you to catapult yourself off of enemies and redirect projectiles, which they utilize to great effect in the platforming.

CONS: Ori lacks the subtlety and ambiguity of its counterparts in the Metroidvania genre. Hollow Knight is a prime example, a game where you slowly unravel the mysteries of what happened to the broken world around you, and each new discovery spurs the player onward in search of more answers. Ori places you in a similarly shattered world, but by contrast, every time you happen upon something new or interesting, your Great Value brand Navi companion tells you exactly what took place and why, sucking all mystique and wonder out of it immediately. Good Metroidvanias make you feel like an explorer, and give you the satisfaction of piecing things together as you go along. Ori and the Blind Forest makes you feel more like a tourist:
"Here you'll see the abandoned mountain home of a dead race. They were trying to (spoiler), but then (spoiler) happened and they all died. Here's a half baked gravity puzzle, and then it's on to the next attraction."
"This is the main antagonist. Watch this short cutscene, which will show you their entire backstory and plainly spell out their motivations. Yes, I know we're only 1/3 through the game, but we're on a tight schedule and still have at least three more biomes to herd you through."

The cinematic 'escape' sequences mentioned above could have been really cool moments, but quickly lose their charm. They are littered with obstacles that insta-kill you, and are almost impossible to anticipate until they've already caused you to restart. This turns what would be really cool and memorable moments into exercises of frustration that require you to brute force your way through with trial and error, hitting every snag along the way at least once.

Ori uses insta-kill spike pits as a crutch, and while it offsets this by allowing you to spend energy to create your own save points virtually anywhere you want, it really stifles the movement-centric mechanics of the game. Slightly mis-timing a jump or getting the wrong angle on a Bash often sends you straight back to your last save point, and because the onus of placing them intelligently is left to the player, this can sometimes erase so much progress it made me want to turn the game off. It also forces you to sit through any cutscenes or dialogue you went through since your last save (because nothing says "fun" like re-watching the same unskippable gameplay interruption over and over).

Before anyone dismisses these criticisms with "git gud", I completed the path of pain in HK. I don't say this to brag or claim I'm some god gamer, only to communicate that these complaints are at least in part due to poor game design, and not just a skill issue.

If you're still waiting on Silksong and need something to tide you over, there are certainly worse options out there. Ori isn't a bad game, and if you enjoy the genre you should check it out while its on sale. It certainly has its flaws, but none of them are game breaking.

[b]TLDR[/b]
Ori & the Blind Forest is one of the best platform/metroidvania games I've ever played.Although the sound & story may have been at exactly the same level, the gameplay alone makes this game worth every penny.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]For me, it's the very best part of this game. The mechanics are so innovative & crisp that every new skill you learn is a treat to use.It is sometimes difficult but not frustrating, just make sure to save frequently. The pace of the game itself is also quite enjoyable as you learn a new skill, are put to the test w/ it until you feel comfortable & then have to use that skill and all the others you learned to continue progressing, beautifully well crafted.[h1][b]Sound[/b][/h1]I really enjoyed the sound, the main theme is remarkable & I keep humming it now & then. I actually enjoyed the narrator's deep grumble & the sound effects were okay too. Nothing exceptional though, I believe it's not exactly at the same level of the gameplay.[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]This is where I might differ from some of the other reviewers. I really enjoyed the story & the characters BUT, I don't think it is that extraordinary.I think it's a well crafted world, the foe is menacing but relatable too & all in all the characters are interesting.But I don't think it compares to the likes of, for example, Hades. It's quite bare bones & although I enjoyed it, I believe the main "Story" is still the gameplay.

I really like the visual style, the setting and the premise, but after 43 minutes - I just couldn't progress any further. The sudden spike in complexity shows that this game targets far more skilled platformers than me, which is sad. I wish there were a way to continue for me, but it just won't work and the amount of playing the same level over and over just doesn't suit this game IMHO compared to other games,

One of the best and most satisfying game I've ever played.
I'm not particularly good on platformers but this game felt very balanced between challenge and sometimes frustration.
There are a select few moments where you can't save as you please. In these very well chosen and rare instances you have to proof your skills you've acquired.
The soundtrack and the atmosphere suck you in and gives you a feeling of belonging and fulfilling.
The balance between riddles/puzzles, acrobatics and fighting is very good.
There were some moments where I wished as a completionist to be able mark stuff on the map for later time when I have the skills, but the game fills that gap with skills which show you missed elements depending on your skill order around the middle of the game.
Recommend this game unquestioningly.

TLDR: sluggish control and weird save mechanic. Still a great game with amazing escape sequences. Close behind Hollow Knight.

Great game, but I few details still annoy me:

1) Controls feel sluggish. Especially when wall jumping. Game developers often add a bit of limpness by adding slight delays between characters’ actions, but they went overboard here. If you are using a mouse and keyboard on PC, this is exacerbated by the fact you use the same hand for movement, jumping, wall climbing, dashing and so on, which makes some combinations a tad tedious, just enough to become annoying. 

2) Instead of using check points where you can save, the game uses energy which you collect to save (weirdly enough you even have to unlock the ability to create your own save points). This feels like a huge flaw to me as checkpoints are supposed to be part of a good game design. They should dictate the flow of the game, giving well-deserved respite to the player and control over the level difficulty to the game designer. In this game you can save at places I feel you should not and sometimes forget to save at places you absolutely should have.

There are a lot of pros though, the magical world and music being this game's biggest strength. I am about halfway through and I find the story and world-building compelling. The escape levels are absolutely amazing. I got this game on sale for about 10 USD which is absolutely worth it. I think even 25 USD which is its full price is good value.

Bottom line, the metroidvania platformer genre has had some masterpieces which set the bar high recently (I am thinking of Hollow Knight here). This game is not a master piece due to some issues, but it's pretty close.

Không vui chút nào, tôi đã không cười. Trò đùa của bạn thật tệ, tôi sẽ thích trò đùa này nếu nó được xoá khỏi đầu tôi và bạn vui lòng từ bỏ nói lại cho tôi trò đùa đấy. Nói thật, đây là một nỗ lực kinh khủng khi cố gắng để mang một nụ cười ra khỏi tôi. Không phải cười, không phải hehe, thậm chí không phải là một sự bùng nổ tinh tế từ thực quản của tôi. Khoa học có nói trước khi bạn cười não của bạn chuẩn bị cơ mặt nhưng tôi thậm chí không cảm thấy một chuyển động nào dù là nhỏ nhất. 0/10 trò đùa này thật tệ, tôi không thể tin là có người lại đủ pháp lý để cho phép bạn được quyền sáng tạo. Lượng sức mạnh não bộ mà bạn đã đưa vào trò đùa đó có thể tạo năng lượng cho mọi ngôi nhà trên Trái Đất. Hãy có một nhân cách và học cách tạo ra trò đùa, đọc một cuốn sách đi. Tôi không nói điều này để trở nên buồn cười, tôi thực sự có ý đó về cách mà đây chỉ là sự bi hài trong hài kịch. Bạn đã giết chết sự hài hước và mọi hành động hài kịch trên hành tinh. Tôi rất thất vọng vì xã hội đã thất bại trong việc có thể dạy bạn cách hài hước. Thật lòng mà nói nếu tôi đặt tất cả sức mạnh và thời gian để cố gắng và làm cho trò đùa của bạn buồn cười, nó sẽ yêu cầu Einstein phải xây dựng một thiết bị để tôi có thể kết nối với năng lượng của một tỷ ngôi sao để làm điều đó, và thứ duy nhất mà trò đùa đó nhận được từ mọi người là một sự khinh bỉ tinh tế. Bạn thật may mắn vì tôi vẫn còn chút cảm thông cho bạn sau khi kể trò đùa đó nếu không tôi sẽ nhận hết mọi tội ác chiến tranh từng được ghi lại trong sử sách chỉ để ngăn cản bạn cố gắng mang đến bất kỳ sự hài hước nào nữa. Chúng ta nên đặt trò đùa đó vào sách giáo khoa để các thế hệ tương lai có thể cảnh giác khỏi việc trở thành một thất bại tuyệt đối trong hài kịch. Tôi thất vọng, tổn thương và bị xúc phạm hoàn toàn khi thời gian quý báu của tôi đã bị lãng phí chỉ để não tôi có thể hiểu trò đùa đó. Trong khoảng thời gian đó tôi đã lên kế hoạch giúp đỡ những đứa trẻ mồ côi, nhưng vì điều đó bạn đã làm tôi đã phải giải thích với một cách ít tục tĩu nhất về nỗ lực khủng khiếp của bạn trong hài kịch. Bây giờ những đứa trẻ đang đau khổ khi không có bữa ăn và không có ai để đổ lỗi ngoài bạn. Tôi hy vọng bạn hạnh phúc với những gì bạn đã làm và tôi thực sự hy vọng bạn có thể bước tiếp và học hỏi từ nỗ lực đáng thương này.

A beautiful game whose artstyle and world remind me of the old Don Bluth movies. The beautiful artstyle and understated score lead to a wonderful experience to play through. That said the worlds you travel through are fairly basic in design with forest, swamp, mountains, ice, and fire all the hallmarks of a Mario game. I never minded this as the visuals were enough to elevate rather basic design elements.

The gameplay itself is incredibly tight and precise and you'll need that precision for the difficulty that starts smooth but ramps up quickly. The save system is the one element I went away with hating, it's never a challenge and I never felt that I was without a save point unless I simply forgot. Which isn't challenging me it's just punishing my poor memory.

Overall an incredible experience that was very much worth it.

A very visually gorgeous game with emotionally moving moments during its runtime. However, buyer beware. If you think this game is going to take it easy on you, you're wrong. While it is a Metroidvania, Ori takes more design inspirations from precision platformers like Super Meat Boy and Celeste than it does from Samus' or the Belmont's adventures. Instant death lasers, ceiling traps, spike traps, lava pits and chase sequences are out in force and won't let you pass without a little effort and persistence.

If that's not a problem for you, then yeah, this is a good game to buy. I offer my sympathy to anybody who tries to beat this game on the permadeath mode.

I want to love this game. I really do. Graphics and atmosphere are magical. The OST is amazing.

But after trying to finish it for the second time, I have to come to realize, I just don’t enjoy my time playing it.

The controls are floaty, which is not ideal for a platformer that requires precision.
The combat is extremely basic and mostly consists of pressing one button while running back and forth a lot. 
As a tradeoff to the beautiful environments, there is very little visual clarity. Oftentimes you can’t make out which areas to avoid, especially on a whim. This makes sections with fast movement (such as falling) death traps.

Due to these things, deaths more often than not feel out of the player’s control, which is about the most frustrating experience a game can provide.

Just the fact that I move my ass and bother to write a review means a lot... So here we fucking go:

BASIC DESCRIPTION:
This is one of those 'beautiful' games focused on visuals, but there is much MUCH more to it. 
First of all! Don't get the impression it's a solely "kids game". The story is simple, yet beautiful and as you grow attached to it, it has some moments, where you can't help but shed a tear and if you are a more of an emotional person... Then this is one of those games that will make you cry. 
Another thing is... The game feels a bit too difficult for children in my opinion. If you're a casual gamer though, it's going to be a comfortable challenge. Sometimes you have to think a little and when you get past an obstacle, the feeling is very rewarding. It's not overdone to the point, that would make you lose interest.
One of the things that really surprised me were the amazing and unique, yet simple game mechanics, that are mostly based on the mobility.
This title easily became one of the best games that I have ever played and the feeling after finishing the game was: "Damn... Why did it have to end so soon?"

Overall traits of the game:
+ beautiful visuals and soundtrack
+ a perfectly polished, smooth game (haven't experienced a single glitch)
+ unique, amazing gameplay mechanics
+ simple, yet beautiful story
+ epic, dynamic sequences
+ easy and simple controls
~ especially early game there are "you haven't unlocked this ability yet, come back later" obstacles. (However it doesn't feel so invasive in this title like in LEGO games for example)
- There are rare occurances, where you're stuck and don't know what to do or where to go (happened to me 2 times), it's mostly the fault of overlooking something though.
- there's an ability explanation missing near the end-game that you have to find by accident or google up. (You need it to progress)

Overall rating:
9/10

Me myself, not only have i been playing games my entire life. (40 years)  i am also a game Dev and this game, tho good, it is highly flawed. Floaty controls, impute drops,  weird impute designs ( down is a ground pound?!), bad enemy placement/ spawning, and along with poor trap placement (blind jumps). Instead of fixing any of these issues a save system that lets you save anywhere was introduced. Sadly,  you are forced to use it or else you will spend hours retreading difficult areas.  This breaks the immersion as it is easy to get lost in this beautiful world and then you end up paying dearly for that mistake. Also the saves are tied to your abilities which is REALLY odd design choice.

  The world falls into the same issues of many modern games. That being where a rich environment is created but its hard to distinguish background and foreground elements due to the amount of content on screen or just lack of hues to separate the elements. Particle effects also plague visibility too. Issues like this should not exist in games today and are usual a sign of poor beta or game testing with actual testers. As a dev you know your game and you can easily look past glaring issues like this as you become numb to many of these as time goes on. So having testers that are not part of the game design team is important. I don't know why this game is in the shape its in or if testing is the issue. I just mention the things i notice from my years that normally lead to these issues when you see a product that people obviously poured allot of heart and soul into. Its not a bad game. its actually a very good one but these issues with my background are unforgivable.

PS. I am only finishing this game because i spent  40 on it. Its a Good game, a flawed master piece.

Probably the best thing about this game is the soundtrack. I say probably because pretty much everything in it is an equal level of amazing. The soundtrack always stirs up feelings for me but that's only because it came with the gorgeous art and touching story. With that being said, gameplay is still important and it does really well here too. The combat is frankly not the best or most intricate system but the game is a platformer and it's the best one I've played yet. The movements are incredibly fluid and there are a bunch of different movement abilities, but it rarely gets overwhelming. Most sections have a pretty clear path to the end. The only two complaints that I have with the game is that the combat gets kind of stale and it's not super well balanced for all stages of the game, and I wish there were more story in this story because it's just that good!

edit: decided to play a little more recently and it still majorly sucked, all because of the dumb death mechanic. will probably play more to give a better review but i really doubt i will like it. the devs are so full of themselves and the games are way too overrated

It's just not very well thought through. Yes it's pretty but the combat never gets less dull or avoidable (yes even when you start flinging yourself around which is where this game is at its best). The save anywhere feature removes any sense of tension and in fact often makes dying preferable to carrying on because it will return you to higher health. There's such a minimal trade-off with saving that it incentivises saving frequently to avoid the drudgery of repeating dull platforming. The upgrade tree is also terribly thought through because early on you unlock an ability and then with no explanation nothing happens (even if you press the correct key from the controls settings) because Ori hasn't learn the base version of that ability yet, and won't for quite a while longer. WHY? Why is that a good design decision? What's the point of an upgrade tree if it's just as linear as the level progression?

So much of this game's 'challenge' is die - learn - try again. The cinematic boss fight-type sections at the end of dungeons are particularly bad at this because you can't save mid-way to shorten the learning loop. I know that sounds like Dark Souls but the difference there is that difficulty and harshness are part of that game's aesthetic. This game is really easy and cuddly, except you just have to die to learn more frequently than you should which just speaks to bad design imo.

[b]What it does well:[/b] I like the markers so I know where to go next if I'm busy and leave the game for a while, I like the option to change difficulty midway through the game (although I was already quite OP by the point I realised this), I really like the challenging pinging about sections - that should be the whole game.

[b]TLDR:[/b] Game rarely offers space to feel clever or solve problems in your own way so you keep trudging along the obvious path, and the path isn't that stimulating.

If you've not already played Hollow Knight go get that, otherwise I'm here waiting for Silksong too...

Alright, this gave goosebumps.

First of all I want to talk about the soundtrack. It's just, outright amazing. It fits the atmosphere perfectly and the quality is just on another level.

While the lore isn't that deep, it's presentation is just marvelous. I really cared about every single character.

Don't expect there to be advanced combat, but what you can expect are really fun mobility mechanics. It's maybe not the most advanced one ever, but it indeed is great.

The escape segments are also one of the most memorable things about the game. They are really well designed, and the difficulty is neither too hard nor too easy, just on the spot.

Overall, it's a different experience, and one that you must try.

Brilliant game - Played it back in 2020 as I noticed it had alot of praise surrounding it and I wanted to see what all the hype was. Played it and I loved it, everything about Ori felt so fresh and fun and exhilarating. The tricky mechanics are so amazing and the devs put such a effort into every little thing and you can really feel it. I love Metroidvania games and after Hollow Knight being such a stand out with it's soulslike ways. 
Ori reminded exactly of that with more of an action replay save mechanic for deaths which is perfect if you don't like having to make huge trips across the map again just to be killed by a tricky jump or the environment.

Playing it again now in 2023 and having forgotten most of the paths and where all the skills are to get around for navigation, it felt really fresh to me again and I really enjoyed it, this time challenging myself with 0 Skills spent and doing the game on hard mode it felt really challenging and having found a ton of the items from just pure luck i'd put it down to I managed to have a really good time yet again with this fantastic classic. 

It's a 10/10 from me!
After completing this game, it's a solid exploration platformer with stunning visuals, a fantastic soundtrack, and a cute story told in a simple but emotionally effective way.

Nice graphics but just a bad game overall. Finished it on my first attempt on hard with 100% completion and the whole time it felt like a tutorial stage that had been stretched out into a full game. The combat is bland and underdeveloped and the game also suffers from being overly simple (you can easily finish it on hard in 2-3 days) while being frustrating at the same time. 

This is because rather actually implement fun challengers that reward skilful game-play, the developers simply threw in long sections that require memorisation and constant respawns due to the overuse of instakills , bad controls and poor hit detection. All these sections are easy to beat but the constant respawns and playing the same sections over and over again is just annoying rather than fun. It's made worse by how bad the controls are; other than basic movement, jumping and attacking you have 8 other abilities each of which is mapped to a different buttons/keys.  It’s insanely stupid to have to juggle directions plus 8 other controls in sections that require timing & precision, especially when you rarely ever need more than 2 abilities at any given time.  You often end up often triggering skills by accident causing further unnecessary respawns. 

The respawn situation gets even worse due how bad the hit detection is and the sheer level of visual noise on the screen. The glowing art style and number background and visual effects often means you can’t see exactly what can kill you and what hazards are around you. Even when you do see the obstacles you will often get hit by something that clearly didn’t touch you. This also happens when triggering abilities that rely on enemies to shoot at you. The game is very inconsistent about deciding whether a projectile is too close or too far and then you have times where the enemy AI decides it just not going to even fire at you. That doesn’t sound bad but this often happens in the middle of escape sequences where you are relying on the projectiles to trigger abilities so you can escape. But the game just says FU and get to respawn. 

Good metrovanias have a blend of good combat, deep exploration, fun challengers and an engaging story; Ori and the Blind Forest has none of those. Instead it feels about on part with a 2005 flash game that has been given AAA studio money for graphics and music. Metrovania’s are supposed to be about freedom and exploration and the skills system should have been about allowing the player to tackle problems in multiple ways and rely on skill rather than basic memorisation.  Even the story is extremely lacklustre; the intro tricks you into the thinking it might be something of a deep emotional story, but no the game basically has no story. A bunch of stuff happens and then everyone’s happy again.  

Some people might still enjoy it for the visuals and  music but in terms of actual gameplay, a turd served on an expensive plate is just a lump of shit. Ori is a nice looking lump of shit but you're probably best looking at it from a distance rather than putting it in your mouth.

Spoiler alert: This is not Hollow Knight.

Extra spoiler alert: This is still it's own masterpiece.

The focus of this game is the platforming. With complex platforming mechanics and some of the cleverest level designs of any game I've played, solving puzzles and challenges trigger that dopamine consistently. The clever level design is my favorite thing about this game. And I was personally surprised by the way the mechanics (skills/abilities) were implemented. The limitations they were given. The longevity of their relevance in the ever evolving challenges the game presents.

The platforming isn't the only thing great about this game. It's visually stunning with a moving story with some emotional moments and twists. The music score sets the mood and atmosphere well, and is both beautiful and memorable. I will definitely play the sequel with the same confidence I have in Hollow Knight: Silk Song.

I recommend anyone considering this game to give it it's due and treat it as it's own experience. For those who love platformers on the whole, or who are open to then for the experience they may provide, this one is worthwhile.

Okay, no.
Perhaps not my cup of tea, perhaps overhyped it for myself over the years, but also this is clearly not the best of modern platformers.

There is no autosave, so you need to spend magic/light/crystal/sadness. You also get to collect like a dozen more types of magic/light/crystal/sadness to open doors, other kind of doors and unlock broken ****. Somehow I think this could have been streamlined to be less complicated. Now the gameplay loop is: run to collect as much **** as you can, DIE, spawn far away because you forgot to save, run to another direction, get one-shotted by a random tank monster, spawn in the same place as before, run to the closest door/other door/broken **** and either incrementally advance the story OR, god forbid, open a door to a new place where to die.

After recently trying out the elegant masterpiece that is FEZ, the convoluted mechanics and artificial collect-a-thon nature herein feel even more pronounced.

The audio-visual presentation is fine, but I would argue this is also somewhat blown out of proportion by those who like the game. By modern (2023) standards, the visuals can actually be confusing, not knowing which parts belong to background and which are platforms. The controls are not very fluid in my opinion. Music is fine, fictional language nonsense sounds believable too, I guess... Not much to say about the story, other than it is a generic and sappy tale of magic/light/crystal/sadness...

Welp, went and deleted the sequel from my wishlist.

Ori embodies the best that platformers have learned over the years. The game combines art, technology, and great level design.

Projects like Ori and the Blind Forest, whose quality surpasses the barriers of their own genre. Although platformers have long been an alternative, Blind Forest bears the hallmarks of mainstream generosity, and perhaps that's why you'll fall in love with the game immediately. You will be thrilled by the visual artistry, the generously conceived game environment, the atmosphere full of emotions, the seductive gameplay, in short, everything.

In terms of functionality, all the concepts so typical of modern platformers appear in the game. For example, very soon you will try motivating movement and logic puzzles. Personally, I never get tired of just jumping between moving rocks, because I get really scared doing it in Blind Forest. Moreover, the game lets conflicting emotions compete, and although it portrays the danger as truly menacing, the hero among the stones dies with a rather funny crunch. Like cracking a nut.
A sense of levity is what makes small games big, too, and as much as Ori is more thoughtful than funny, it has no problem lifting itself lightly from time to time. A similar ability also accompanies many aspects related to the physics engine. Thanks to it, the protagonist sometimes breaks the laws of gravity and can fly above the ground for tens of seconds without wings. However, what stuck out to me was the glowing arrow indicating the direction of flight, with which he looks like a cupid. [b] 50% [/b]

The artstyle and story are just too sappy for my taste. The controls feel a bit sluggish, which makes the platforming tedious and a bit frustrating to play (might be skill issue though). Also, it pretends to be open world, but is actually kinda linear, so it's not really clear if you are achieving anything by just exploring or if you should follow the main path. Over all, Hollow Knight was just better in every aspect.
Tbh the game speaks for itself, but here is one statement for you: "Just beautiful."

Alright, let me tell you about Ori and the Blind Forest - the game that made me cry more than a Nicholas Sparks movie.

First off, the graphics were absolutely stunning. The hand-painted world was like a fairy tale come to life, and the characters were so cute and cuddly that I just wanted to reach through the screen and give them a hug. But don't let the cuteness fool you, this game had some serious challenges.

The gameplay was a perfect balance of platforming and puzzle-solving. I loved how I had to use Ori's abilities to navigate through the world and defeat enemies. And don't even get me started on the escape sequences - they were like playing through an intense action movie!

But let's talk about the story. It was like a Pixar movie, except with more tears. I mean, I was emotionally invested in Ori's journey from the get-go. I cried when Ori's mother died, I cried when Ori's friend sacrificed themselves, and I cried when Ori finally saved the forest. It was like someone was cutting onions in my room the whole time.

And the soundtrack? Don't even get me started. It was like listening to a beautiful symphony, except with more whimsy and emotion. I found myself humming the main theme long after I finished playing.

Overall, Ori and the Blind Forest is a must-play for anyone who loves platformers, puzzles, or crying uncontrollably. The game is a beautiful work of art that will stay with you long after you finish playing. So grab some tissues and get ready for an emotional rollercoaster - you won't regret it!

Ori and the Blind Forest is a stunningly beautiful and emotionally rich game that is a must-play for anyone who loves platformers. Developed by Moon Studios and published by Xbox Game Studios, this game is a masterpiece of game design, with its breathtaking visuals, compelling story, and engaging gameplay.

At its core, Ori and the Blind Forest is a classic platformer, but it is so much more than that. The game takes place in a vibrant and fantastical world, filled with unique and interesting characters, and the story is one of the most moving and memorable that I have ever experienced in a game.

The graphics in Ori and the Blind Forest are simply breathtaking. The game is hand-painted with meticulous attention to detail, and every frame is a work of art. The colors are vivid and bright, and the animation is fluid and graceful. The character designs are imaginative and whimsical, and the world is filled with a sense of wonder and magic that is rare in modern gaming.

But what really sets Ori and the Blind Forest apart is its emotional depth. The story of the game is heart-wrenching, and it is told with such care and tenderness that it is impossible not to be moved by it. The game tells the story of Ori, a guardian spirit who must restore the forest of Nibel to its former glory. The story is one of sacrifice, loss, and redemption, and it is a truly remarkable achievement in storytelling.

The gameplay in Ori and the Blind Forest is just as engaging as the story. The platforming is challenging and satisfying, with a variety of obstacles and enemies to overcome. Ori can jump, climb, and use various abilities to navigate the environment and defeat enemies. The game also includes a wide range of puzzles, some of which are quite challenging, and they add a level of depth and complexity to the gameplay that keeps things fresh and exciting.

One of the most impressive aspects of Ori and the Blind Forest is the way it seamlessly integrates story and gameplay. The game's narrative is told through a series of cutscenes and in-game events, but it is also conveyed through the environment and the way Ori interacts with it. The game's world is full of hidden secrets and details that add to the story, and exploring it is a joy in and of itself.

The music in Ori and the Blind Forest is simply stunning. The game's soundtrack is composed by Gareth Coker and features a mix of orchestral and electronic music. The music is hauntingly beautiful, and it perfectly captures the game's sense of wonder and magic. The game's sound design is also excellent, with high-quality sound effects that add to the game's atmosphere and immersion.

Another thing that I appreciate about Ori and the Blind Forest is its attention to detail. The game is full of small touches that make it feel like a labor of love. From the intricate character designs to the way the wind blows through the trees, every aspect of the game is polished and refined to the point of perfection.

In conclusion, Ori and the Blind Forest is a game that everyone should play. It is a beautiful, emotional, and engaging experience that will leave a lasting impression on anyone who plays it. The graphics are breathtaking, the story is moving, and the gameplay is challenging and satisfying. It is a game that truly captures the essence of what makes gaming great, and it is a testament to the power of the medium to tell stories and evoke emotions.

Unpopular opinion here.
It's a nice game but the difficulty setting is really ridiculous. I'm all for a game with a choice of challenging content, but there should be a good choice for the difficulty. Let me give precise examples.
I started with hard, thinking that I can simply change the difficulty later. So I encountered monsters that charge with high speed and would just one shot me with like 11 damage when my HP is only at 3 or 4. I find it difficult to pass the monster so I changed the difficulty to normal.
Turns out that monster still charge at me at the same speed, with damage down to 7 to one shot me. Wow.
And then just now I was at another flooding challenge. It's a pretty common stage in rpgs, running away from flood, you know, except the flood would immediately move faster when you run too fast. So running fast and doing everything perfect don't help anything, and there's no checkpoint......

But the fighting mechanics itself is pretty easy. It's the mobility part that becomes ridiculously difficult at some part of the game. As I said, difficult content is more than fine, my complaint is that changing difficulty to normal or easy helped NOTHING about it. At certain parts, frustration is an understatement. More like torment than a challenge. And I've right finished another resident evil game so I don't suppose I can't do basic controls. 

But then obviously the game receives generally positive feedback, and I agree the atmosphere, gameplay, music etc. are pretty well. But I'm not recommending this to anyone without good finger flexibility and real patience.
