'Ori and the Blind Forest' is truly one of the best games I've played yet. Had I made this review after only finishing the game once, I would've meant that with a tiny grain of salt. However, after playing through the game multiple times and finally getting all the achievements, I realised that there's so much more to this game than a heartwarming story and gorgeous visuals. 

Some may have found it troublesome, but playing as Ori felt so amazing. The fluid movements, running around from place to place while chaining together bashes and dashes, gave me a level of satisfaction that no other game had given me before. Again, it's something that may be to another's distaste. I've personally had moments where I fatally overstepped a narrow platform or flung too far off a wall and into spikes. But once you get the feel for Ori's movement, getting from point A to B is downright addicting at times, and it's definitely worth getting used to, both for ease of progression and for the enjoyment factor.

Combat, while admittedly lacklustre, only stays that way for the first third or so of the game. Once you unlock bash and stomp, you pretty much have to try to die from enemies. And that's not to say that you can't deliver death as easily as well. With enough powers and ability points, Ori goes from a fragile tree spirit to an absolute power unit. As I mentioned before, chaining together all these movement and combat abilities feels so good and powerful, it was downright jarring every time I started a new playthrough. 

And of course, I can't forget about the music and sound design. From the area-specific music tracks, to the sound effects played when Ori uses a power, they all add to the game experience beautifully. They're great, they're memorable, and they can make you feel emotions ranging from second-hand grief to absolutely unstoppable savagery.

Overall, an absolute masterpiece of a game. It has it all: beautiful visuals, enchanting music and sound design, emotion-packed story, and fluid satisfying gameplay. I highly recommend giving this game a try, and if you enjoy it, you'll most certainly enjoy the sequel. A massive thank you to Moon Studios and anyone else involved in the production of this game, and I look forward to seeing what new games they work on in the future.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a platform-adventure Metroidvania video game developed by Moon Studios and published by Microsoft Studios. The game was released for Xbox One and Microsoft Windows in March 2015, and for Nintendo Switch in September 2019. Players assume control of Ori, a small white spirit, and Sein, the "light and eyes" of the Forest's Spirit Tree. Players are tasked to move between platforms and solve puzzles. The game features a save system called "Soul Links", which allows players to save their progress at will with limited resources, and an upgrade system that gives players the ability to strengthen Ori's skills and abilities.

The game was developed by Moon Studios, a collective organization without a set location. The distribution rights to the game were acquired by Microsoft a year after the beginning of the game's development. The game story was inspired by The Lion King and The Iron Giant, while some of the gameplay elements were inspired by the Rayman and Metroid franchises.

Upon release, the game received critical acclaim, with players praising the gameplay, art direction, story, action sequences, musical score, and environmental design. The game was also dubbed as one of the titles that represented art in video games. Moon Studios co-founder Gennadiy Korol said the game was profitable for the company within a few weeks after its initial launch. An expansion, called the Definitive Edition, was released in March 2016. A direct sequel, Ori and the Will of the Wisps, was announced during Electronic Entertainment Expo 2017 and was released on March 11, 2020.

Wikipedia's article about art defines it as a "diverse range of human activity, and resulting product, that involves creative or imaginative talent expressive of technical proficiency, beauty, emotional power, or conceptual ideas". Therefore, I strongly disagree with people who say that computer games cannot inherently be art. 

This game is art expressed as a beautiful Metroidvania game.

7.7/10
This game relies a lot on the artistic parts and has magnificent visuals and music. And it doesn’t stop there and has some good gameplay too, which is not a common thing in today's gaming. The number of abilities are somewhat questionable because of how towards the end you have this mess of a toolkit to work with which is not quite beginner friendly but since it’s not hard for the average player to get around, we can move on from it. Let’s say you got comfortable with the movement set, in that case, Ori offers a truly good amount of interesting level design and stretching mechanics in fun ways. At the price of making the game complicated, Ori introduces some fresh and clever platforming mechanics which to my knowledge have not been seen elsewhere. 

The story is a mix of “Disney cartoon” and stereotypical “video game story”. It acts as to just give purpose and meaning to what you do in the game. It’s not memorable, it’s not interesting, but it’s not annoying either. This little cute story is just there to be there and honestly that’s pretty much all a good game needs in my opinion so it doesn’t matter to me.

Unfortunately they’ve played it a bit safe in terms of design choices. The formula is too similar to Metroid. At the earlier parts of the game, there’s so little you can do and everything’s blocked. There’s this lack of simplicity and for every bit of interesting gameplay, there’s a new mechanic to be introduced. But I will give them the credit for making abilities usable in multiple cases and designing levels which give the player the choice to how they’re going to approach each level.

With the early game being quite boring it’s so easy to start the game and quit it after the first 2 hours. But the closer you get to the ending, Ori gets more and more fun and interesting.
Brilliant Game

So far, I think will of the wisps is quite a bit better. I am not liking the flow of this game. It seems off, especially because its not as smooth and far more linear. Plus, the difficulty is kinda wack.

Edit: After playing some more after my initial review, I can say without a doubt that Will of the Wisps is considerably better. I honestly don't like this game as much for a variety of reasons. The progression here seems more restrictive and not as fullfilling. There are waaaaaayyy to many chase sequences that really serve absolutely no purpose. I get the feeling that the game just expects you to know what to do ahead of time, and if you don't then there is nothing you can do except die just so you can learn from it and account for it in the next go. Will of the Wisps was always good at allowing you to react and overcome anything if you were good enough. Whereas, in this game, you are doomed to die or fail certain parts due to not knowing what the game wants you to do or how the puzzle is to be solved until its too late. It makes you blindly jump into the abyss just so you can see that there was a small thing you were supposed to land on but you had no idea it would have been there without first jumping down and dying just so you can see it (and no, there's no way to react in time unless you got lucky and just happened to land on the small platform you needed to land on). There are countless examples of the game relying on you pushing forward and failing just so you can see what you actually need to do. Will of the wisps was not like this at all, and you could always rely on your abilities and skill to get through the unexpected, and if you died you didn't feel like the game was setting you up for failure from the start. I just think Will of the Wisps is better in every way, and because I played it first, it was very hard to play this game and enjoy it.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a beautiful game in every facet of its being. The visuals are vibrant, detailed, and create a dreamlike atmosphere. Visually, this game is a work of art. 

The story is simple and touching. The classic theme of light and darkness is pervasive and depicted in a yin and yang type fashion rather than good vs evil. The music's ethereal charm matches the visual style well; gentle and unobtrusive without betraying a sense of fight or flight urgency when appropriate. 

The developers did an impressive job of giving the player lots of mobility. Movement is fast and fluid, and combat is well polished. I seldom found myself frustrated by anything other than operator error. Many of the abilities to unlock enable you to traverse the world more gracefully, as well as access new areas of the map. There are situations where speed and timing are critical and your mastery of these skills is put to the test. 

Ori is a comfy and beautiful game with satisfyingly polished controls that I think just about anyone could enjoy.

TL:DR - good music mixed with fantastic map, gameplay and other things. 9/10

The soothing music when you enter, the fantastic music that they have worked on and fit very well to the theme they are portaying.
The game's reward system for doing the secrets and going the extra mile to actually have more of something made it fun and worthwhile to grind for it.
The gameplay and abilities you gain are fantastic, and the game makes you use them the second you get them, and then regularly to makes you use them so you remember about them and dont forget.
The map is very well-made, a fully connected map that adds a lot of secrets that you do not have the current skills for, making you backtrack at a later date, and getting you in the mindset of "while im at it, i could go for {This}, making you lost in the map.

now, im gonna nitpick a little bit.
i disliked the save system, making you use [energy] to actually use save, which was tough in the start, and an annoying thing i had to do in the end.
Some of the abilities needed to use [energy] to fire, something that i lacked in the begging, and finding [energy crystals] was sometimes a hassle. That fixed itself midway of the game, where i had enough [energy], and [life] to not need to spam heal ability constantly, and making the game more fun.

[h1][Review #26]
Ori and the Blind Forest[/h1]
Ori and the Blind Forest is a platformer that can be both thrilling and relaxing at times. Sometimes, you get to explore the phenomenal world of Nibel without much interference, other times, chase sequences and intricate platforming levels gets your adrenaline pumping and keeps you on your toes. The narrative, though not extensively voiced, is able to hit you with all sorts of emotions based on the animations of the characters.

Each biome in the world is being differentiated by their colour palette, and while some enemies are native to one biome, others can be found throughout the world. As you play, you will gain new abilities that will either help you in traversing or combat. There are also a skill that are designed to be viable in both situations, which I really loved. [spoiler]That skill being Bash, which propels you towards a direction while redirecting the projectile you used in the other direction. [/spoiler]I had so much fun playing with that spell. After obtaining said spell, enemies and projectiles that normally you can only avoid turns into a way to explore new areas or even kill other enemies, which is an incredibly smart design.

In the game you will encounter a huge amount of platforming sections. I am really impressed by all the different mechanics the game incorporates into the platforming levels to keep them fresh and unique even though you are doing the same thing: platforming. [spoiler] There really are a lot of unique mechanics that changes the level gameplay such as teleporting, wind, swimming and much more. Besides the small platforming sections, you also have large non-stop action sequences that will usually last 2 to 3 minutes. In these sections, you will have to make use of all you know to successfully get through it.[/spoiler]

Another thing I really liked about the game is that it is a lot less punishing than other similar games like Blasphemous and Hollow Knight. You don’t lose anything other than your progress, unlike in Hollow Knight where you’d lose all your money or in Blasphemous where your max mana will get reduced.

However, as with all games, there are definitely areas of improvements. For one, while I understand while saving is disabled in action sequences where you have to keep moving, in some other places that you can explore at your own pace, I think it’s bullshit that you can’t save because of “unstable ground”.

The game’s backtracking system is atrocious. You won’t be able to explore everything first time through because there are areas where you require abilities you obtain in later stages, yet there are no stats to show you what is missing within each biome (only shows how much you've collected relative to the entire world, which really does fuck all), forcing you to search around frustratingly. The energy doors exists to creates an arbitrary progression wall that blocks you from entering the area unless you have enough energy, which is rare during the story as you will be spending them creating save points or defeating enemies, which adds on to even more redundant backtracking.

That said, if you like platforming games, definitely try this out. Even if you don’t, give it a shot because not only is it less punishing compared to similar games, some of the platforming sections are really memorable.

A master class in game design. The surprising amount of unique and intriguing mechanics and clever level design makes this a fantastic game through and through. With regards to the story, every cutscene had me either on the verge of tears or with a wide grin all without saying a single word. A must-play for any platformer fan.

WOW what an amazing ride. I did't know what to expect from this game but holy crap this was GREAT!

Highlights:

1) Exceptionally well done visuals, with a 3D feel. This is a 2D platformer but the environment has things happening in the foreground, middle ground and background - creating a dynamic and immersive experience.

2) Beautiful design and FX creating a vivid and colourful experience from start to finish.

3) Masterful soundtrack that you could even listen to off game to just relax or feel good.

4) Very user friendly controls.

5) Relevant skills that you unlock to greatly diversify your platforming experience. Towards the end game, the platforming is exceptionally intense - making great use of your acquired skills; which in turn makes for a really satisfying experience, once you succeed.

6) Great usage of secrets and hidden power ups, in combination with stats on the pause screen; to encourage you to explore and uncover all this game has to offer.

7) Perfect length - I completed this game, 100%, in 13 hours. I'm only missing some combat trophies, but I explored everything and acquired all items, skills, and power ups. 

8) Excellent storytelling - This game uses some cut-scenes, but mostly uses in game text/narration as you progress, to tell you the lore and plot. These transitions were so smooth and packed with emotion that I didn't expect at all. The story also unfolded in a way that I didn't anticipate and I found it to be an awesome experience.

Important Note: The platforming gets very difficult as you progress. I died over 300 times in my 13 hours finishing this game. If you do not like platforming, then do not buy this game as it will drive you mad. If you are okay with a challenge and welcome it, then this game will blow you away; and you will feel great satisfaction in completing it. 

I have nothing negative to say about this game at all and I am really looking forward to now playing the sequel.

Simply put, very frustrating without any payoff. If you're looking for a metroidvania like Hollow Knight or, ya know, Metroid, look somewhere else. Though it has a lot of elements of a metroidvania, they're almost universally primarily action combat focused, whereas this game is almost entirely platforming focused. That wouldn't be so bad, but it still tries to be a metroidvania with it's enemy placements. Again this wouldn't be so bad, but all you can do is spam an auto-targeting attack. Again, all of this wouldn't be too bad, but I've been playing on hard mode, where enemies take forever to kill and WILL one shot you for the first hour or more. Then, when you have more health, sure you don't get one shotted but the health pickups are VERY rare so you end up dying way too often. AGAIN, this wouldn't be TOO frustrating, but enemies respawn almost as soon as their off screen.

Ultimately, I'll probably put the time into finishing the game, but it's been a VERY frustrating experience without any signs of it getting better.

If I never stumbled across this game, I wouldn't have learned how to play the piano. 'Tis right, I detested music, it annoyed me, all of it. Until.. I clicked on the game's trailer and my ears were blessed with: DUN DUN DUN DUUN DUUUUUN, DUN DUN DUN DUUUN!! Like wOaH!!! wOaH mAn!!! hOld my antidEprEssAnts, mAn!! Gorgeous. Gareth Coker expressed the beauty of *Epic Orchestra* and now I'll never forget it, I can play Restoring the Light, Facing the Dark on my piano now. Along with other Ori pieces, and more pieces to come. Thank you Coker. I've got an Ori plush sat on my corner shelf cuddling a flower.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a true masterpiece of a game. The visuals are absolutely breathtaking and the emotional story will leave you with a sense of wonder and awe. The game's platforming mechanics are challenging but fair, and the game's many secrets and collectibles will keep you coming back for more. The game's soundtrack is also one of the best I've ever heard in a game, it perfectly complements the game's emotional story and breathtaking visuals.

One of the things that makes Ori and the Blind Forest so special is how it manages to convey so much emotion without relying on dialogue. The game tells its story through its visuals, music, and gameplay, and it does so masterfully. The relationship between Ori and his companion, Sein, is especially well-done and will have you rooting for them both throughout the game.

In conclusion, Ori and the Blind Forest is a game that should not be missed. It's a true work of art that will leave you with a sense of wonder and awe. The game's visuals, story, and gameplay all come together to create an unforgettable experience that will stay with you long after you've finished the game.

Forgot why I gave up on this game years ago. It just sucks.

-Combat is braindead, avoid projectiles while spamming your own homing projectiles via the attack button.
-Exploration is too linear, and there really aren't all that many collectibles either. The platforming difficulty is nice, at least, but this is hardly a Metroidvania.
-The story seems moronic -- I can't tell if you're expected to feel sad every time someone dies, since if that were the case players would be crying nonstop after 100 deaths per hour.
-The aesthetic would be pretty if it distinguished between foreground and background, but as it stands, there are way too many instadeath moments from being unable to tell what is scenery, what is a living enemy and what is a deadly fall into spikes. The further I get, this seems to be an intentional design choice.

Between the floaty controls and the confusing artistic design, the game has a very ethereal feeling that could work well if it were not intended to be challenging. There's promise in here, it's just not for me.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a wonderfully beautiful game. The story isn't anything complex, but it isn't bad either. It is simple, and heartfelt. The story, to me, isn't the bread and butter here anyways. The gameplay, visuals, and music are top notch. Rarely do I see a game with this pleasing of an aesthetic. I had seen nothing else like it until this came out. Each area of the world is uniquely colored to give each of them their own personality and feel, and the same goes with the music and the enemies. The gameplay is nothing short of exciting as well. Fast paced, and responsive, it feels great to move around the world as Ori. Unlocking new abilities to traverse becomes so fun, and by the end, you master it and feel a very satisfying sense of flow. It is the combination of all these things that provide a unique experience with Ori that I can only describe as a blissful, immersive melancholy. In summary, Ori's enchanting atmosphere, and satisfying gameplay provide an absolute worth while experience. Highly recommended.

This game is really very good in almost every aspect. The music is is epic and orchestral. The visuals are enchanting. The story will have you strapped in for all its ups and downs.

However, for me personally, it commits a cardinal sin for the genre of Metroidvanias which renders it pretty much a glorified platformer. The combat... It's almost an after thought. Not only is the whole thing done with auto aim, SERIOUSLY the computer chooses which target to attack based on proximity (Often choosing the wrong target when multiple are on screen), but the computer auto connects each and every shot without any aiming on the part of the player. Further more, the enemies in the game are nothing more than rudimentary pattern driven obstacles to make the tricky jumping parts more difficult. And finally, because You don't even have to aim, you can basically skip the entirety of the uninspired and almost useless combat ability tech tree. Why use abilities that require mana and such when you can just spam the attack button while standing out of enemy range?

Often I would get pulled out of the immersion by yet another moving platform and spike pit arena, not because it was too difficult, yet simply out of tedium and disappointment. It became a game I want to finish not because I enjoyed it, so much as just to see the narrative end with slightly spiteful intent. 

When I finally get around to beating this one I will give the sequel a try to see what they did with it. Hopefully it learned for the previously mentioned mistakes.

Edit: On further play, I have seen that the story is actually garbage. Some how the magic light from the tree kills owl babies for no reason. Yeah, you heard me. A tree calls to some stupid forest rat with light. The owl babies see the light and die because ... They saw light? And the big owl gets mad and kills the tree. So the "Villain" is actually completely justified and the story makes absolutely no sense at all. Don't cry about spoilers either. I just did you a favour.

I will also take some time to reiterate just how tedious the jumping arenas in this turd are. It IS NOT a Metroidvania. It is a platformer...

I don't like Ori and the blind forest, despite what most people say about the game. The graphics are weird, the gameplay is a little dull. The story is something more like a Studio Ghibli type of thing, which while engaging in a movie i can't say the same for a game (well, at least THIS game). What a shame

Ori is definitely up there as a game with one of the most beautiful visual of all time, you can just tell there are a lot of love and effort put into all the backgrounds and characters in this game, as an artist I definitely appreciate the art a whole lot, the compositions, the colors, the animations, they're all absolutely amazing.

Overall, the gameplay is very good, as a person who plays a lot of indie games, I'm very familiar with the metroidvania and platformer genre and I must say that ori quite excel with both genre, although I wouldn't say the best. The metroidvania aspect of ori, in my opinion is a bit easy, all the secrets are pretty simple to find and the powers aren't super unique, so there aren't a lot of creative puzzles utilizing these powers, even with all that, I still think it is very fun, finding all the secret upgrades is still very satisfying and I like looking at the map to look for things I had missed. The platforming aspect of ori is very good, all the boss fight sequences with kuro have all been very fun and thrilling, I love all of it, especially the final one.
 
I give this game a 9/10. Definitely playing the sequel next.

Looks great, music is fantastic, story makes you really feel & the gameplay is just as good as the rest of it.

As a fan of metroidvania games, I had a blast with this one. It was a little short, taking me just under 10 hours to 100% complete, but I loved every second. The art was phenomenal, the gameplay was fun and engaging (prefer using a controller over keyboard and mouse) and the music was some of the best I ever heard (it had me tearing up on the title screen before I even played the game). It was worth every penny I paid.

Now, to be fair, I had also completed hollow knight and super metroid, both of which were better games as a metroidvania. The secret design was put to a minimum, mostly just with hidden paths or needing a new power up and returning. The map is pretty helpful to the point where all the extra markers are just to remind you to return. Also, the speed and physics can be difficult to get used to (I had no issue personally but i see a lot of people did)

I don't play very many games all the way through. I typically lose interest about half way in. Not only did I finish now i'm trying to get all the collectibles and getting 100%. This game was just amazing all around from the music to the game-play to the story. I played on hard and the challenge was enough where it had me raging but not to the point where I never wanted to play it again. Every little bit of progress felt rewarding either with a new ability or more story. At the ending they did a good job of including all of what you have learned through the game. It's defiantly worth more than $5 so this is a steal.

The plot and art style are spectacular, and the soundtrack is even better! A wonderful, sad story wrapped around solid game mechanics and captivating game play. If you liked Celeste, it is worth it to give this one a shot. Moon Studios knocked it out of the park.

My thoughts are better summed up by some of the other negative reviews, but basically the game is frustrating. It's trying to be a metroidvania, but it ends up being more like a platformer with "combat mechanics" (mash the X button) that don't serve to enhance the game. The core of why this game frustrates me is that the platforming is generally really fun, but so much seems to get in the way of that.

The environments are beautiful, but there were many times where I wasn't able to tell what was background/foreground which led to frustrating moments. The soundtrack was pretty good. The story, on the other hand, was boring. Its essence is "the power of friendship", but that doesn't work when you don't feel attached to any of the characters.

It is a beautiful looking game, but sadly that's one of the few positive things I have to say about it. I was recommended this game because I enjoyed Hollow Knight, but in my opinion they don't feel all that much alike. In Ori, you move fast, which is nice, but the jumping is kind of floaty, fast and inaccurate. Not a huge problem though. The combat is very boring, which is a bigger problem. But the worst thing to me is the save system. You can put down a save spot whenever you have energy cells, which recharge at a snail's pace unless you find crystals, and that save spot is an actual save spot, as in if you die, you're gonna have to watch any and all cutscenes again if you didn't save after watching them. On top of that, you'll need energy cells to do other stuff too later on, which means that either you'll have to run the risk of not saving and having to collect all the items and sit through any tips you got again if you die, or you'll have to wait for the cells to recharge. I don't know, maybe I missed something, but it felt really bad to me.

I can see why people enjoy it, and I can see why people who enjoyed this, enjoy Hollow Knight and vice versa. It's just really not for me. Figured I might as well put in the full 2 hours before refunding it, to see if it would change my mind, but I didn't manage to keep playing for that long.

Ori and the blind forest is not my favourite metroidvania game but it is a mighty fine example of the genre that is so expertly crafted and fun to play that everyone should try it even if you're not a fan of the genre or never played one before. 

It's quite short and navigating the world map is easy enough making this the perfect entry point to the genre. 

Positives 

Incredibly stunning game with a gorgeous artstyle 

Fantastic ost 

Quite a simple but very moving story that may have you in tears 

Very fluid controls, using oris abilities and navigating platforming sections is very satisfying. 

Short and sweet with many diverse locations and a skill tree that makes the game repayable 

Negatives 

Chase sequences which can be a bit frustrating, not sure if I just suck or what but they took me a few goes. 

Combat isn't bad but it's extremely basic to the point I found it be quite boring, not a massive drawback but not a positive either 

Again this is mostly personal preference but the save system was a bit annoying because I'd forget to save at crucial points 

Conclusion 

Whilst it's not my favourite of the genre ori and the blind forest is one of the best examples of the genre done right and I fully recommend this game to anyone who hasn't experienced it yet, just don't forget to bring some tissues.

This is a game I initially didn't love. The game is flawed in so many ways, especially compared to its sequel. I played its sequel first for no particular reason, and then the original (on my switch). From this lens, I immediately noticed so many ways the sequel was better, which made me paint blind forest negatively. Now I appreciate the original much more, it is truly a wonderful game. Visually the art style is simply superb, the way the character moves and flows through these natural yet fantastical environments is astounding. While unfortunately a large portion of this game's environments is either a trope or a forest, there is just enough variety throughout. To avoid spoilers, the extra content in definitive edition and the Southwest portion of the map was most memorable. Combat is awful, spam fire to win, don't play this game expecting good fighting. Enemies with their simplistic patterns serve more as obstacles to the overall movement, which is phenomenal. While some movement upgrades are superfluous, the way they all function to expand Ori's traversal serves the insanely well crafted platforming design. The unique options alter the way you think about the game, like bash, which re contextualizes every single enemy and projectile in the entire game to great effect. The act of moving as Ori impresses, she (he?) certainly shows off amazing platforming chops. While the world Ori bounds about is artistically well designed, the progression structure is very linear. Go here, go here, go here, is the name of the game. Every area you explore is far more dungeony than open, this allows the devs to create planned directions and challenges for the player to keep up the pacing. However, it takes away from that feeling of discovery. the only thing to find outside of powerups that match like keys to the story, is currency and health/energy upgrades. The skill tree feels very strange, I wouldn't call it bad, but something isn't right in this context. Moving away from those small points, the story is amazing, I would say better than the sequel. With amazing cinematography, and a way of delivering story through show (outside of some exceptions) rather than tell, the narrative driven home is very engaging. One small but important to me "problem..." While this isn't a big deal to me anymore, when I first played the game, most frustrating was the save system. Essentially, saves are almost entirely manual. While on one hand it's amazing to let the player save whenever they please, I personally don't want to think about saving when I'm encapsulated in a game world. So forgetting to save because I was having so much fun, dying, then being sent back upwards of 10-15 minutes was hugely disappointing. While in retrospect it is pretty easy to drive a habit of saving every couple of minutes, it was a massive deterrent early on. To cap things off, the score is great, though I prefer the sequel's. So many tracks in this game are full of life and energy, some incite feelings of fear or anxiety, and others just set the various moods so well. While I can recall about half of the games tracks though, many others were unfortunately not super memorable. 

In summary, I adore the storytelling and platforming. I like the world and music. I find the progression okay. But I despise the combat. In general, it's worth overlooking those blase elements to praise what Or excels at.

To fix resolution problem change the "high DPI settings" of the game executable:
- Find the game executable oriDE.exe on your system (manage > browse local files).
- Right-click the executable, then select Properties.
- Switch to the Compatibility tab and click on Change high DPI settings, under "Settings".
- On the new window, under "High DPI scaling override", activate the checkbox: [✓].
- Select Application from the dropdown menu and confirm with OK.
- Click Apply, then OK on the Properties window.
- Launch the game, resolution should be changeable now.

I am so sad I have to write this review: I was more than ready - I was eager - to like the game. 
Soundtrack is nice, and the game itself is very pretty. Unfortunately, it is also one of the most annoying games I have ever played. It is so frustrating, I am honestly not following the plot any longer, I am not sure what is the point any more, I am just hoping to be done with it and move to a better game. Just so that you understand how done I am, I am following some video on YT in the hope it spares me a few attempts and a few minutes of playing.
I love complicated puzzles - but these are not even complicated puzzles: it is literally a matter of pressing the right buttons at exactly the right time in the right combination, hoping to get lucky this time. I have listened to the same three chords of soundtrack about fifty times in a row, because there are some traps that can only be overcome via repetition, as to learn perfect timing. 
I am horrified at the idea of having gone down the wrong path and having to walk back to the beginning to start again. I have already bought Will of the Wisps, and I am hoping SO HARD it's a better game.

I love and hate this game all at the same time in equal measures. On the one hand, it was a rewarding game. On the other, it can drive you mad.

This game requires a lot of dexterity in the hands. If you're over 30 (which I am), this will be insanely difficult, even on Normal Difficulty. Even though I'm trained to type at 70 words per minute, that has done nothing to prepare me for this game. A lot of this game requires precision and speed. 

If you play games to relax, this game is REALLY not for you! This is not the little relaxing game that is made out to be. But if you really like a challenge and exercising your hands a lot, then I would recommend this game!

Running contradictory to the often serene and welcoming environments of Ori and the Blind Forest, this game is a seriously challenging metroidvania, with significant emphasis on platforming and combat. By the time I finished and then reloaded to go back and get 100% on the map, I was left mostly satisfied with little interest in replaying for some of the more difficult challenges/achievements. If you're looking for a "one-and-done" experience, you could certainly do worse and there's enough material here to fuel a long weekend's worth of play.

It's probably immediately clear that the game is gorgeous and has a distinct presentation in mind. Along with the vivid colours and natural shapes is an orchestral soundtrack that helps provide a ton of atmosphere for many areas and elevating already heightened energetic sequences. The best word to describe the world and its friendly inhabitants is charming. Even though most of the narrative is conveyed in non-verbal cut-scenes or with a spartan line of text here or there, there's enough meat to be engaged with what's occurring and can at times make for quite an emotive experience.

Unfortunately as well realised the world is, I found it too many times leaning towards form over function. Far too many times I was unable to gauge what was a hazard in the foreground or background, where certain hazards were in relation to platforms and so on. Though death has minimal consequence so long as you're reliable with placing manual checkpoints, it nevertheless is frustrating to go for a jump and die to what you thought was a safe space and not a trap. There are also several blind jumps requiring leaps of faith which I don't appreciate at the best of times, but especially not in a game with a difficulty such as in Ori. 

Though exploring the world can be fun when you have enough momentum from chaining jumps and bounces between enemies and platforms, I found that I was having more fun towards the end simply moving around when I had various abilities rather than a slower paced jump between ledges. Though you obtain a double jump fairly soon after starting, the game immediately gives the impression that it'd have been better if you started with it anyhow. There's also a dash found in an optional area that really gets you moving, but I only found this after initially beating the game and then going back to complete everything. That you can even upgrade the ability before you get it seems a bit daft to me.

The upgrade system in general seems very tacked-on. The upgrades themselves are useful for sure, but something like a triple jump being locked behind the end of an upgrade tree seems generally unnecessary. I will say though that being able to upgrade the ability to detect secrets is quite welcome, especially in a game of this type, but zooming in on the map can be frustrating at times as there's a lack of real granular control over zooming out. I think just generally unlocking abilities through discovery is far more meaningful than grinding enemies to get experience to spend. 

Combat itself is also massively improved by having more abilities at your disposal; again I'm left wondering if the game wouldn't just be more fun if some of these were available to you from the start. At any rate I found the combat to be fine, but mostly by way of button mashing. There are fun combos you can pull off, again typically towards the back half of the game when you have more abilities, but a lot of the time it boils down to fire, wait, fire, wait. Though I wouldn't call some enemies bullet sponges, they definitely feel like they take one or two hits more than would be ideal.

What compounds issues I have with both the platforming and combat though are the controls. Whilst most of the time they respond absolutely fine, there are moments, too frequent for my liking, where I'd be convinced I'm pressing to do one thing and having that not be replicated on-screen. A good example would be a ground pound and pressing to drop from a ledge. If you're rapidly moving it can feel like the game isn't quite keeping up with you. Sometimes this can be a minor hiccup, but it also led to many deaths.

Scattered throughout the game there are chase sequences. Though not quite auto-scrolls, they fulfil a similar function. With some of the above criticisms in mind, these can be incredibly frustrating and seldom satisfying when getting past them. Between instant-deaths through not being able to clearly see hazards due to the art design, to being bombarded with hazards that make first-time runs unlikely, I generally found them to not be fun. Though in retrospect these sequences don't last too long, they also have no checkpoints which can make them particularly frustrating if you die to something you didn't expect to. As a whole the game can be quite inconsistent with regards to what constitutes an instant-death, so having to hope that in these chase sequences they're not present isn't exactly a great feeling.

Despite my many issues with the game, it is still generally enjoyable to play. When everything is working fluidly it boasts dynamic movement in enjoyably challenging spaces. Though it has rough edges to it, the glue holding the game together is very strong. Enough that I had little doubt about seeing the end, but perhaps not enough to make me want to come back to it in the future to do casual replays or challenge runs. 

*Played on Hard difficulty and with a controller throughout.

A short, but decent platformer/metroidvania, wrapped in some of the most visually appealing Ghibli-inspired artwork, lighting and particle effects I have ever seen in a game. Definitely worth $5, but maybe not if it cost as much as a typical full-priced game. Due to the heavy post-processing going on, you might want to pass on this if your hardware is a potato.

Although Ori looks a bit cutesy and childish with its Pokemon-esque main character, this is a moderately challenging platformer. You will die, often. Thankfully it's gore-free and you instantly respawn at your last save point without any fanfare, and you can pretty much quicksave wherever you want most of the time. The drawback is you lose all progress since saving, and since you just pop back into existence like nothing happened, this can cause the player to forget to recollect any gained powerups. Save often, because the developers are very fond of instant death traps you don't see until they've killed you.

Although this is technically a metroidvania, most of the upgrades are typical platforming fare; double-jump, dash, stomp, climb. Ori's wall-jumping puts Samus to shame. Combat takes a backseat, and there aren't any real boss fights. The Three Plot Coupons of Power are sitting around unguarded, so you just collect them and then survive a lengthy instant-death escape sequence where you can't save, so you get to redo the entire sequence from the start each time you die (making these the hardest parts of the game).

Ori is a short game. A new player going in blind and doing plenty of backtracking for secrets will probably 100% it in less than twelve hours. There is an achievement for completing it in less than three. For some reason there is also an RPG-style upgrade tree which might give the illusion of customization and replayability, but the truth is it's just three linear upgrade paths, and you will probably max out all three by the end, so it doesn't really matter. Any replayability will come from doing challenges like the one-life mode or a playthrough without taking any optional upgrades.

Taking heavy artistic cues from Studio Ghibli, the story is an appealing, but formulaic, fairy tale. You are a forest spirit of pure light, your opponent is a not-quite-evil-but-hostile beast of literal darkness. Collect the Three Elemental Powers to restore balance, but the most powerful force of all is motherly love. It all looks really great, but don't expect a groundbreaking narrative or any interesting twists.

Ori and the Blind Forest is best defined by the word "Beauty". It is a game where not only are the visuals breathtaking, but the music creates a sense of majesty, the story feels so intimate and powerful it can move you to tears, all while the gameplay is so smooth that you feel truly free while traveling through the world. 
On the note of the gameplay alone the "Bash" mechanic is singlehandedly one of the most innovative and great tools a platformer could ask for. It re-contextualizes combat from the enemies acting as obstacles to enemies becoming bridges and helping hands to travel around. The game was also bold in its execution of replacing boss fights with escape sequences (AKA the best parts of Metroid). 
The only critique I have for the game is that despite the main themes being forgiveness and compassion even to creatures that do a lot of harm, there is no way to beat the game without "killing" a lot of enemies which are described as brainwashed by the setting.

Personal note:
Ori and the Blind Forest was one of the first games I picked up as I was pulling away from online multiplayer games. And this game utterly wowed me and made me aware of the potential fun, amazement, and storytelling potential Singleplayer games have.

It's a solid Metroidvania that focuses more on platforming and puzzles more than shooting or attacking. It's definitely beautiful and controls well, and brings in new mechanics at a good pace to keep things interesting for the entire 9~ish hours of gameplay.

The game is a bit shallow, though. You don't have a huge variety of different attacks or moves (compared to, say, Super Mtroid), the game is fairly short, and none of the puzzles are particularly complex or difficult. If you want to play a classic Metroidvania I would recommend Bloodstained before this. If you want to play a platformer I would recommend Celeste (2D) and Neon White (3D) before this, especially Celeste.

If you're working your way through the genre, make sure you play Ori and the Blind Forest before you play Hollow Knight. I went the other way around and this looks so unpolished in comparison that, while I did still complete the game, it was too easy, too simplistic and generally not very satisfying.

I would imagine that it's serviceable as a newer gamer's introduction to platform games, but unless you're really into the art and animation style there's not much beyond that.

I consider myself to be very strict when viewing games.

That makes this game quite an odd one, because I have virtually nothing to criticize about it.
The gameplay, as far as my criteria goes, is just about perfect. It's smooth and responsive. It’s a tad bit limited, but I quite like that aspect. This is a platformer first, and a fighting game second. So having your primary damage source be a floating ball that follows you around is quite nice in my opinion. It also lends an air of innocence to the main character since it’s not them directly attacking things most of the time.
If I had to list one gripe with the gameplay, that would be in the level design. Specifically, a certain escape sequence early in the game. A similar, smaller scale sequence earlier on would have been a good idea, as the difficulty jumps very steeply in that particular sequence. Since this is the kind of game that could easily attract people who are new to 2D platformers, that escape sequence could ruin the day for a few of them.

On the topic of the story, it is quite lovely. It's not incredibly complex, but it is a slight step up from your usual predictable plot line.

I would go out of my way to praise this game for being a visual masterpiece, but I see no point in doing that, since its blatantly obvious from just one look at it.

It is worth mentioning that this is one of those games that is more about the experience, rather than the challenge. At least that is what it’s desighn seems to imply. Something I personally like since I find it to be significantly more enjoyable than the “You did something hard, welcome to the club” aspect of some games. Though that’s just me, and the game still can be challenging for some people.

Overall, this is a fine game. This is well and truly one of my favorite games. The few dozen hours I’ve spent in this game were more pleasant than the thousands of hours I’ve spent in most other games. And I would wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone who thinks they would enjoy this kind of game.

Afer 8.6 hours I completed the main story with 52% of the achievements unlocked. Even though I play most of my Metroidvanias more thoroughly, I feel satisfied at this moment. 

Ori and the Blind Forest is a quite fast paced game, I would describe it as a parkour metroidvania where trash enemies are mostly there to get around even faster. 

What I really found interesting was the idea that you change the world through completing parts of the game which enables you to get to formerly unreachable places. 

Through skillpoints you get the option to unlock passive and some active abilities. One path is a offensive path, another a defensive one and the third (the one I chose to complete first) helps with exploration. This shows you where the hidden items are (and what they are). This also plays into the whole fast paced stile, you never spend long to shoot on walls in order to find secrets (like in other Metroidvanias) but you exactly know where the items are. You "just" have to find how to get there. As far as I know those are all just upgrades to your health and energy containers... which is the reason why I won't bother to get them all. 

As I said, I saw the ending and I am satisfied and touched by how it all played out. 

I played it on normal difficulty and found it the right choice for me. I never felt like I have to do some backtracking for some upgrades to health and energy because of the way this game's save system works: You can either save on some of the few save-stations or with one special ability which creates a save spot almost anywhere in the world (you have to clear the area from trash enemies first). This uses up 1 energy container which can be refilled through collecting some kind of ore you see occationaly. 

Don't forget to save as often as possible though, since if you don't, all items you collected will have to be collected again. I wasn't happy about this at first, but as I got more and more energy containers, I learned to safe frequently. 

I recommend this game because it was a fun fast paced ride and the game had a few surprises of how to manoeuver the character through some passages and to solve some puzzles. There were some challenging platforming sections but it never felt unfair and it was so satisfying when you got through them alive. 

I expected it to be a 8.5 / 10, I was pleasantly surprised so my verdict is a solid 9 / 10.

I wanted to love this game, I wanted to like this game, and at the end i just wanted to get it over and done with.  The soundtrack to this piece is an amazing work, the art of this game is excellent, the gameplay is total garbage.  there are a multitude of levels and sequences that are absolutely absurd and break the smoothness of previous gameplay and immersion in the story. It is undeniable that Ori and The Blind Forest is beautiful, but sometimes, that beauty with overloaded effects can work against the player. Moments where you simply cannot see where you are or what you are doing because the bright and colourful effects explodes around Ori are far too frequent. Sometimes the foreground blocks the view of the game. The game's graphics effectively hinders gameplay, instead of working to serve it as it should (you know, as a video game).

I usually don't care about linearity in a Metroidvania game, I love Metroid Fusion, but the way Ori's level design comes together really does not feel all that novel: when an area connects, it's less of the joy of discovery and more of "oh, here again." Much of the usual backtracking is also confined to simple items, and most of the games "big areas" are more or less separate, including the three main dungeons.

The level design at the local level for each of these dungeons is marvelous. Essentially, Ori and the Blind Forest is a puzzle platformer first and foremost; its openness is nothing too impressive, and its combat is quite mediocre. But the platforming challenges are design very well, testing the players both in their ability to understand how to navigate, as well as their platforming skill itself. The skills you unlock are used frequently in conjunction with one another in increasingly more elaborate platforming puzzles and set pieces, showcasing some of the most exhilarating moments.

The problem is, the control of the platforming itself is not that satisfying. The jumps and movements are far too floaty and momentum heavy, making it feel much more imprecise than it should be. This leads to extremely frustrating sequences in set piece moments where you are constantly dying because of input error that you didn't mean. For example, while gliding, the only way to lower your altitude is to let go of the gliding, since pulling down the analogue stick would result in stomp (and instant death in most areas that require gliding). However, the speed of your movement while you are gliding is very much momentum-based, and sometimes it's so easy to accidentally stomp straight down you the spikes.

Then there is the downright mediocre combat. Basically, you spam the attack button, which fires auto-targeted projectiles at your enemies. Problem is, the range and aiming is difficult to gauge in the mess of a fight. There is no way to snipe enemies either. Combat in fact does not evolve after getting stomp, which has pretty limited uses anyway. Considering that most of the enemies throw projectiles at you in a pretty random manner, it becomes far too hectic for it be sophisticated. These enemy projectiles also works to further frustrate platforming, since the last third of the game depends on you to use a skill that lets you bounce off of these enemy projectiles--which becomes incredibly annoying when these projectiles are fired in a random pattern and timing, while your in-air controls are pretty unsatisfying already due to how imprecise it is to keep the momentum.

I'd recommend this game if you really like 2d platformers I'm talking REALLY LIKE 2D PLATFORMERS. It does it's job really well, but personally, I don't think I would play it again, or play the second game. I originally bought the full pack because it was on sale; 2 versions of the first game, and ori and the will of the wisp because originally, I was intrigued. I was dragged in by the beautiful graphics, and I had just finished hollow knight so I thought I would give this a try. In the end, I finished the game, not because I wanted to or was invested in the storyline, but simply because I refused to give up and leave a game I knew that if I stopped now, I would never finish it. After pulling through, I swore off the game and though I recently gave Ori and the will of a wisp a try, I don't think I will be finishing that.

Pros:
The series in general is very well made. The art is beautiful and the music is just perfect. The game mechanics are pretty smooth and straightforward too, you gain abilities throughout the game, go through difference regions, defeat enemies, collect items, and progress. 
The movement is a little challenging sometimes and the puzzles are varied, so if you are an avid 2d platformer player, you'd probably enjoy this. 
The save system is very VERY nice. You can practically save anywhere as long as you have the mana for it. This has saved my life so many times since the map is so big and occasionally unforgiving. 

Cons:
I think it is just me, but sometimes I confuse the background with what I am actually able to step on. The art is so detailed that personally, sometimes I get a little confused. Speaking of confusion, there are a few moments where I just get confused. It varies from what I'm supposed to be doing, where I'm supposed to be going, etc. I don't see many other people running into this issue though so it may be me, but at the final stretch of the game, I got so confused that it took me 4 different sessions to find out where I was going, and by the end of it, I was just so sick and tired that it didn't even feel good to complete the game. 
The storyline and timed gameplay. Timed gameplay is great when done well, and personally, I think ori and the wisp only did decent on it. With the number of timed scenes, if you're not extremely comfortable with the controls, it can sometimes take several tries and I am talking SEVERAL. As for the storyline, it is sometimes easy to get distracted from the main story. Of course, there are some holes in the story but i'm not here to complain or point those out. The issue with the story, is how easily it is to just completely forget why you're doing what you're doing. 2 hours into this game, and I already pretty much forgot the main story because I was so busy being frustrated and lost. 

In Summary,
You should get ori and the wisp if you're a huge 2d platformer fan, the art and music is masterfully made and almost every aspect of the game is smooth. However if you're not a 2d platformer fan, I recommend you give it a little more thought. Don't go buying the full bundle like I did, and just give the first game a try first.

This game is gorgeous, the effects make the 2.5D game look stunning without truly adding additional dimensions. The game features unique and interesting transversal methods, interesting puzzles, and character movement that just feels good. Ori's character animations occasionally do little spins and flips make the controls feel that much more agile and spry. The soundtrack is also amazing, they feature oboe pretty often which I'm a big fan of as an oboe player myself. The game is great for those who love 100%ing games and collecting secrets.

This game is definitely more platforming-based than combat, any combat sections are pretty small and there is rarely a need to aim (when you do have to aim, it's often in a more puzzley manner, even in combat). There are a couple arenas where you must defeat enemies to progress, but they are few and far between, and generally not very difficult. Usually they serve to [i]teach[/i] mechanics, more than to prove mastery of them. Mastery of mechanics is demonstrated in dramatic quick-time platforming sequences. Failure during those sequences doesn't break immersion - even though it resets you all the way to the beginning of the sequence, there is no gap or skip in the music, which keeps the sequence from feeling old even when you're on your 20th try. Completing the sequences feels amazing, as it generally requires a minute or two of uninterrupted platforming while using a variety of transversal mechanics.

Honestly I cannot recommend this game. The checkpoint system is annoying, the escape sequences take up way too much runtime, and the waypoints direct you exactly where you need to go next robbing you of the exploration of a metroidvania. While I think the bash is one of the best abilities I've seen in a metroidvania the way it can re-contextualize the entire game is not fully capitalized on, and instead it is mainly used as a platforming tool. overall  10/10 art 5/10 map design (in the context of a metroidvania) 4/10 combat (which is understandable this is a platforming and puzzle based game) and 10/10 frustration

This game has an interesing way to save your progress. You get introduced to it within the first couple of minutes playing the game. Still, I consider this a very mild spoiler so read on on your own risk:
[spoiler] You may save the game anytime in most spots as long as they are considered "secure", e. g. not on spikes. But in order to save the game, you need some energy that doesn't recover automatically. This also means if you didn't save your game for 5 minutes and die - BAM! You just wasted 5 minutes of your life. With all those games with checkpoints today, this game felt harsh in the beginning but ultimately gives you more contol over your saves than most games today.[/spoiler]

[b]Music[/b]
Personally, I think good games need a good soundtrack and this one sounds great. Are you a fan of typical, modern Disney movies with it's sad-romantic-(sometimes)funny-happilyEverAfter-friendship stories? These movies also have some specific kind of soundtrack that I can hardly describe, but this game gives you the same feeling - but don't get me wrong, I am referring to the music only, not those Disney movies where they sing every 5 minutes for 10 minutes. 

[b]Visuals[/b]
Be aware, this game looks pretty colorful. Some people like that, some don't. Guess what? I like it a lot in this game. Also, some people don't like 2D games and then, too, you are out of luck here. Another issue with platformers can be that there are so many details drawn in the world that you cannot clearly distinct the background from the foreground - meaning you try to jump to something that [b]seems[/b] to be a platform but instead of landing on it you fall into your doom. This happened to me only a few times so nothing to be really frustrated about.

[b]Visuals[/b]
I have 2 healthy hands and I am used to play games with a controller - and for me this is a typical game to play with a controller. Should you prefer using mouse + keyboard or are somehow disabled regarding your hands, please ignore that part of the review. 
The controls feel great: Responsive as well as good and intuitive button assignment. Be aware that you gain more and more abilities as you progress through the game and you will encounter the principle of "easy to learn - hard to master". You get introduced to each ability but in the end you need to combine most of them to be able to beat the game. I have no comparison here but think it is an average difficulty for fans of platformers but probably (too?) high difficulty for more-casual gamers.

[b]Story[/b]
Guess again: Yes, I like the story. Most of the time you will be busy with doing your platforming stuff. I assume the "amount of story" could not fill a full-fledged movie. However, there are some parts that tell you more about the background and some parts continue the main story. Unexpectedly, the story is pretty emotional and again, it feels like a typical, modern Disney movie.

I really really want to like Ori and the Blind Forest but too many small grievances built up throughout playing it that I can't say with confidence that I felt satisfied at the end.  The graphics and sound design/music are excellent, but they got too lost in overwhelming visual effects and repetitive sound effects (like the attack noise - I ended up mashing a lot as I never got a good handle on the controls and wanted to get back to exploring asap).  There are elements of the game that would work really well if fit together slightly differently but the overall flow of the game was too inconsistent and frustrating that I couldn't appreciate them even if I wanted to.  The story is also good - I wouldn't herald it as incredible, but it was serviceable -  but I wasn't able to appreciate it either because it tended to be paired with a game mechanic that frustrated me or felt too sharp a turn from the exploration parts of the game.  A prime example would be the chase/timed sequences that pop up a couple times; they're valid game mechanics on their own, but when the rest of the game is untimed and frequently saving your progress becomes common, it feels too unnatural to have to repeat multiple rooms multiple times because you didn't react to an offscreen falling rock fast enough or you accidentally used your double jump and were instantly killed by a spike.  All in all, I would recommend giving the game a shot as I'm pretty sure it's more that it wasn't my kind of thing, but I feel like it could have benefitted from a little more balancing and mechanic refinement.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a Metroidvanian, adventure 2D platformer with great emphasis on exploration. You play as Ori, a white guardian spirit alongside Sein who is your guide in this world and helps you understand your role in this magical and beautiful world.

[h3] ⚔ Gameplay: [/h3] 
Rate: ★★★★★
 
Playing like Ori felt amazing. The controls are snappy, reactive, and fun. In the world, you collect special orbs to upgrade yourself and your abilities. You traverse through areas where there are puzzles and in often situations you are required to backtrack to unlock doors or pick up power-ups after collecting certain abilities.

Puzzles are at every step and the game can be rather difficult, but thanks to saving at any step of the game you get to traverse easily through a lot of them, with little difficulty once you get the hang of the controls.

At the end, once you collected and upgraded your powers to the max, you become a powerhouse that can melt enemies in seconds with a large variety of mobility skills that make traversing quick and effortless.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2894211293

[h3] 😄 Fun: [/h3] 
Rate: ★★★★★ 
 
I've had a lot of fun in this game from start to finish. The world feels fun and puzzle areas aren't too difficult if you plan to play this game on normal for the first time. If you wish to have a challenge there is something like that for you. Once you are at the end-game part, everything feels great and it's just fun to mess around with the abilities. Everything you do interacts with enemies and the world and it's a lot of fun to play.
 
[h3] 🏞 Visuals: [/h3] 
Rate: ★★★★★
 
The game visuals were the first thing that actually made me curious to try this game out. It's a beautiful-looking game even if it came with the definitive edition back in 2016. This game doesn't look like it aged at all and even if you plan to pick it now, you'll have a lot to appreciate.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2894211710
[h3] 🔊 Sound: [/h3] 
Rate: ★★★★★
 
One of the best soundtracks I've ever listened to. The main menu OST hits you in the feels right from the beginning. At the end, you're presented with a mix of the same OST that hits you right in the feels again. It has outstanding sound effects and could say voice acting is pleasant to listen to.
 
[h3] 📖 Story: [/h3] 
Rate: ★★★★★
 
This game is renowned for making people cry. I personally didn't have an issue, but it sure is a sad and beautiful story. You play as Ori, a guardian spirit sent into this magical world and looked after one of the last inhabitants of that world. Unfortunately, your parent dies and you're forced to find your way in this world until you discover Sein, the guide that introduces you in this world. From there your adventure starts and you discover who you are and what is your purpose.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j-DXHAevOoc&pp=wgIGCgQQAhgB
 
[h3] 🧵 Length: [/h3] 
 
☑️  Short 
☑️ Average 
🔲 Long  
🔲 Unlimited 
 
The game can be completed in under 3 hours as a speed runner. If you take your time about 12 hours to complete 100% of a run.
 
[h3] 🧩 Difficulty: [/h3] 
 
🔲 Easy 
☑️ Normal 
☑️ Hard 
☑️ Brutally Hard

There are several difficulties and I personally didn't play this game on easy. I started on normal and on my second and 3rd playthrough I've went for Hard and One Life Challenge. Saving at every step makes this a pleasant and easier platformer than most games I've played.

I can go on and on about what is wrong with this game so here is a TL;DR version (tho still quite long)

Being climatic does not make your shitty game design go away.
Movement and abilities are mixed package and sometimes feel super cool and sometimes clunky or unfair.
Default PC keyboard settings screem like a cereal game from 2005.
Saving mechanic feels very shitty. You can easily trap yourself with low hp in a terrible spot.
After dying your hp, energy, collectibles and even cutscenes are restored to previous state. You often times feels punished for not saving often enough. And later punished for not having more energy to save or saving with too low hp.
About half of mechanics are introduced by killing you, without built-in savespot just before them.
Some of platforming challenges are hard to read. Like a new mechanic that is introduced to you in the middle of longer challange and you cant play with it in isolation. Or multiple leap of faith, where you often die without knowing whats down there which force you to use energy to save even more often.
Spikes, spikes everywhere. And without proper save mechanic you die, and you die a lot. Often times you kill yourself, because there is no point in trying to finish a sequence with low hp.
Enemies are annoying or a slug to go through. "Bosses" are laughably easy.
Combat through most of the game means spamming one ability. You don't use most of other abilities as they share resource with saving the game. Like seriously, WTF?
Game is very linear. To the point where I really don't know why is it open world and not just separate levels you can go back to.
Story is meh.

To conclude. Game feels difficult not because of interesting challenges, but because on every step you feel like your character, terrain, enemies, level design etc tell you "f*ck you, thats why". If I wanted to suffer, I would play Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy. If you don't want to suffer, and you want hard, but fair game, then (re)play Celeste or Hollow Knight instead.

The cover pitch for Ori and the Blind Forest goes something like “a metroidvania with a cool aesthetic that emphasizes platforming over combat and a simplistic but powerful story with a pretty much universally-acclaimed orchestral soundtrack”. But I have heard all of these things criticized at one point or another (except the soundtrack, which really is excellent).

	Many have said that Blind Forest is not a “true” metroidvania - it is too short, and too linear. Most, if not all, backtracking is optional, and this is even more true of the Definitive Edition, which gives you fast-travel points to cut down on retreading of old ground. I would say this is fair, but I do not love Blind Forest because I love metroidvanias (although I usually do); I love it on its own merits, and while it resembles a metroidvania superficially it is truly its own thing. And while I’m sure I have played “better” titles, it is nonetheless my favorite single-player game of all time.

	Blind Forest is not so much a metroidvania as a platformer set within one massive, sprawling “level”. I have always loved platformers - back when I first saved up the money to buy a Nintendo Gamecube in, like, 2003, all the games I initially bought for it were platformers: Spyro, Mario, even Pac-Man World. Traversal of a perilous game world is a huge part of my gaming heritage, and Blind Forest delivers perilous traversal in spades. So while it doesn’t offer the freedom of exploration some might hope for, it seems custom-engineered for me.

	I have read criticism of Blind Forest’s movement, calling it floaty, or imprecise, but unlike the linearity I genuinely cannot understand this. Yes, Ori’s movement is lightweight - his jump is not that high, and his fall back to the ground is very gradual compared to, say, Hollow Knight. But imprecise it is not, and floatiness is not, of itself, a sin! Blind Forest’s platforming hugely emphasizes airtime and nimbly guiding Ori through obstacles without every really coming down to rest on the ground. Sometimes these sequences can be quite lengthy, not to mention formidably challenging, and in these cases the extra airtime empowers the player to make snap decisions on the fly - no other game has ever given me the feeling of almost literally improvising my way through a teeth-gritting platforming challenge like the Ori games.

	None of this would be possible without Ori’s signature move: the Bash. A little self-contained miracle of game design, Bash opens up new horizons for your traversal options. When you Bash on a suitable target, time freezes, you have a few moments to aim in any direction you wish, and then the pressure is released in a satisfying woosh that launches Ori in that direction and refreshes your midair jump. 

You can bash off hanging lanterns, which positively litter the game world; but you can also bash off enemies and/or their ranged projectiles, which allows you to incorporate them into your movement choreography. With Bash, enemies become stepstools rather than mere obstacles, and Blind Forest is elevated from being merely an aesthetically interesting game to a groundbreaking one. Bash is unique, and exciting, and is central to everything that makes the game work. It is supremely designed. The opening 30% of the game, before you unlock Bash, is by far its weakest as a result - my one genuine criticism of Blind Forest is that takes too long to become great. For someone less inclined toward platformers than myself, I can imagine giving up on the game early all too well.

But the other 70% is some of the most pristine and satisfying platforming I’ve ever had the pleasure of experiencing in a game. Nothing else scratches its itch. True, the combat is basic and unexciting, but the combat is not the point; Blind Forest knows to play to its strengths. Frankly, more games should.

Beautiful art and soundtrack. The story was a little lacking for my liking. It left me with more questions than answers, and not in a good mystery sort of way, but rather in a pushing a deep narrative that was really developed fully sort of way. 

All in all, it had fluid movement and played smoothly. My biggest gripes were the control and gameplay. Nothing being able to customise controls is one thing, but when the controls in place have a lot of finicky issues, it's makes things less enjoyable. I didn't care for S being two different actions, and also didn't like how many single buttons had 3+ purposes. The keyboard has dozens of keys guys, come on. 

Gameplay wise: 4 chase sequences? Really? 4? It got old after the second one, and when it dawned on me there would likely be more, I was pretty disappointed. When I got to them, I was thoroughly disappointed. Such a wasted use of the otherwise interesting abilities. 

I get thousands of people liked this but: if you're not into chase sequences, general fickle platforming, and single button-mashing, I don't think the art justifies the experience. It doesn't help that the plot felt incomplete too.
