Disclaimer: I rarely write positive reviews. There are two reasons for this: One, my negative reviews get more attention and, two, I feel like it's more of a service to point out the negatives of a game for those of you who don't have a to of time to waste playing something that is aggravating. Let's get into it.

Ori and the Blind Forest is what some people would call a Metroidvania, but it is not that. Metroidvanias are not 'difficult by design.' I have played many. People who claim this is a Metroidvania lack the understanding of what a Metroidvania-style game actually is. That being said, what this IS, is a side-scrolling action-adventure game more in the vein of the Lion-King on Sega Genesis than it is a Metroidvania. While it shares SOME aspects with the Metroid series, it's more akin to Megaman as well, with many one-hit kill sections, and serious platforming perfection requirements. Platform perfection is not something which Metroid games, or as far as I remember, Castlevania, frequently required in the times from which they are most known for: The Gameboy/SNES era of gaming. Combine this with the fact that you can save wherever you want  for the most part, and this further distances itself from what a Metroidvania is. Now that this is cleared up, let's talk the usual four subject-matters: Story, Gameplay, Graphics, and Sound.

===Story===
Many people are lauding this story as something amazing, but I can pretty much sum this up in a single sentence, in a single trope. "Young 'x' has village/home burnt down by marauding force that doesn't like what is happening, and 'x' must go on an adventure to restore the land." It's a tale older than recorded history, but that doesn't make it fantastic. There is actually very little story here, and at no point will it surprise you. Even the end was hardly worth more than a watch on Youtube. Maybe this is a game for children. I could see it, as it requires exceptional attention to perfection and can easily suck you in with that all-too-well-known feeling of 'well, I HAVE to do it, because if I don't I'll have wasted my time and I won't be able to tell everyone I beat it.'

Which, as it turns out, is about all this game has to offer: Bragging rights. To explain why, let's talk about Gameplay.

===Gameplay===
Gameplay consists of tight, but exceptionally difficult platforming sections which, were it not for the hundreds of cheap deaths and intentional 'screw yous' that the developer put in the strangest places, would probably clock the game in at about five hours, tops. There are a lot of enemies that can one-shot you for no reason, a lot of terrain spikes that can do the same, and a lot of just weird places where said terrain spikes are. It's as if they made the map, made the game, then realized they couldn't feasibly charge 19.99 for it or whatever it went for back in the day, and THEN decided that their game should be difficult to the point of being tone-deaf. 

The story was never worth the difficulty which was posed. The art is nice, but not worthy of the effort needed to see it. You can see good art online for free, and without having to jump through a series of frustratingly difficult jump puzzles. In fact, some of these puzzles actually break up the flow, and there were a lot of times where I was just contemplating leaving this game in a sin bin. It still belongs there, but I finished it and now have the 'gamer clout' necessary to criticize the hell out of it for being more annoying than it was fun. 

Games should be fun. Not work. This was work. I'm warning you now: If you don't want your free-time to be taken up by 'work,' then this may not be the game for you. 

===Graphics===
This is where the game shines, but perhaps only on a surface level. There is some environmental storytelling, but it's difficult to make any conclusions about it. For instance, there's a volcano, and there are ruins, but no real explanation or way to find out why or how they got there, unless they're from that once race that built some stuff in the cold mountains, had the ability to make heated seats, but still froze to death anyways. So what little environmental storytelling there is doesn't even make much sense, but the backgrounds are beautiful and Ori moves with the kind of grace befitting a forest spirit, so there's that.

===Sound===
The sound is only second to the graphics. Things feel appropriate across the board. Big chunking hits from a giant bird sound like it would to someone as small as Ori, who itself makes cute noises every so often. It's all very adorable, and again, at odds with its difficulty. Tonally deaf, though the game may be in some ways, what isn't tone-deaf is the music. It's absolutely fantastic, and I would say that it's worth a purchase on its own, even without the game. Or you could listen on Spotify. Why not both? They really outdid themselves, and even if I don't appreciate this latest decade's obsession with difficult gaming, the composer and team who did the sound and score deserve props.

Shame the terrible difficulty took away from the synergy that the sound and GOOD, ENJOYABLE gameplay would have brought. This would have been one of my favorite games of all time if it weren't for those 400 cheap deaths I encountered.

Did I mention it counts? Does it matter? Absolutely not.

===Conclusion===
Ori and the Blind Forest is difficult. Too difficult for how cute it is, and unfortunately leaves a sour taste in my mouth that only listening to the soundtrack made even remotely palatable. That's it. Play it if you REALLY like platformers, but otherwise just buy the soundtrack and watch someone else. It'll be much more entertaining, especially if they suck at it, like I did. Go buy the soundtrack instead. Did I mention the soundtrack? Go listen, then go buy. Do it. I dare you. Just maybe not the game itself. Just the soundtrack.

It’s a great, fairytale-style, challenging, platform game. The best part is the colorful art style, with some nice, deep backgrounds, but it’s complimented by a lot of other suiting stuff: Well-made, sound effects and music. An emotional story. Natural animations. Skills’ progression keeps things interesting, introducing timely change in pace and some challenging sequences and puzzles. Took 19 hours and 1.200 deaths on hard difficulty, for 100% completion, since it allows constant access to previously unlocked areas, necessary to access some secret areas/spots. Would probably take like 12h for a straight-up gameplay. Other than the occasional frustration, I found a small oversight, obstructing 100% completion if you mess up, but there’s a cheat-code solution online.

I'm not sure if I'm just big dumb or if this game isn't particularly intuitive but I didn't enjoy it. The gameplay okay, though I don't think I played enough to comment on that much. As for graphics and music, I didn't find anything wrong with the music but the art at the start of the game the shiny, glowly graphics felt almost excessive, but pretty. If you like extremely tight and precise platforming you might enjoy this, but I definitely wouldn't call it game of the year. I know how much people like a given media is subjective but I'm honestly sort of baffled by people saying they loved it over Hollow Knight. To be clear, I do like platformers. Celeste might be a good comparison; Celeste was also a bit too hard for me but I still enjoyed what I played and it was compelling right from the beginning in a way that made me want to push through it regardless of the difficulty. Ori just didn't do that for me. I also think the super detailed graphics impede the precision needed, especially at first when you're trying to learn the mechanics. I feel this is a good example on how there's a difference between challenging and frustrating. Wish I had closed the game earlier so I could return it.

As the developers of Moon Studios who made this Ori and The Blind Forest, I have to admit this game is remarkable because of the soundtrack but the gameplay may be dark and a bit tedious but that doesn't mean it's a underwhelming game, this type of Metroidvania looks promising as I'm not counting Will Of The Wisps but for me who has completed it from start to finish, I shouldn't have to give this anything less but positive, here's my review below.


Ori And The Blind Forests starts off lifeless, no light just in a dark forest near the small river, now it's your chance to bring everything to life and light as you progress since your Ori and you could be the light anyway there are collectables to collect and abilities to get from each little willow tree that is lurking in some areas for the first ability as an example you absorb the light from the little tree and you gain an ability to help you progress through the game, don't worry not going to mention any spoilers for those who haven't got the game yet but this little part should get you started with the game you also get collectables.


The Collectables include getting more life cells and energy cells, The Life Cells give you more health so that Ori doesn't die quickly the little light you play as think you start off with I believe 3 life cells and the energy cells help you create soul links which helps you save the game which is important incase you die, I mean good luck completing this game with 1 life mode because I find it impossible but back to the point, saving the game is important because you don't have to start all the way back so keep creating soul links from the energy cells it uses 1 energy cell per use but if you upgrade the collectable parts of orange cells as you defeat enemies or find Big Orange Cells which are all over the Ori and The Blind Forest map which gives you points collect enough orange cells from enemies as the round guage in the below middle of the screen, fill that up you get points which accumulate towards the skill tree.


These points will help you get through the game, it will help you on Offense which includes getting powerful as you attack in the offense skill line, there's one for collecting which you recover cells more frequently or getting more life cells/health and such so it's not just the offense skill line but there's one for collecting and I believe one is for Defense so you don't take as much damage from enemies and thron spike plants yeah those plants are everywhere in Ori and the blind forest game as you can die easily.


Above all this Ori And The Blind Forest is a masterpiece and it's easily replayable if you have the time but these days there are a lot of Metroidvanias and rogue like games out there and still many more to come in the future but if you haven't played Ori and the blind forest yet I suggest you pick it up it's a special Metroidvania that Microsoft Game Studios who published this, it's even better to take it on the go on the Steam Deck but It obviously does work on the PC, remarkable game which can not be missed or sleep on, More Metroidvanias for steam the better as it give you the time to enjoy it from start to finish like this one, that's my review and it's highly recommended if you haven't got it yet, The End.

When it comes to indie games it can be a hit or miss in its delivery and often its the latter when it comes to my own personal taste. Often it boils down to that you get lovely visuals but the story falls flat or comes off as amateur or it has a great story to tell but you have to like the choice of style in the decided art style which can look dated (intentionally or not). When it comes to Ori & The Blind Forest its a shockingly well executed game that has a fluid visuals, audio that defines it whether its effect or music, and a memorable (though simple) story to tell.

Visuals - You can keep it real simple when it comes to metroidvania games and as long as you can make it fun with some challenges to it I have to say this goes beyond that when they could of gone less. The lighting, layers and fluid movements of the world and characters is almost like a children's book come to life. How the trees sway in a violent storm or how the characters aside from Ori have a range of motions to show that the world is interactive and they're not just there to be there. It leaves an impression and a very positive one at that.

Gameplay - It is after all a metroidvania game and those that make them fun with their own version such as wall climbing, dashing or various attacks can make or break it. Controls are responsive in which I used an 8bitdo Pro 2 controller and though at times I felt inputs weren't always as on demand as I would prefer I would chock that up as my own lack of reaction speed or timing. The big difference is unlike most metrovania games this is more of a heavier puzzle solver and there are really no boss fights in a traditional sense. Upgrading your skills and getting new moves is fun and you find yourself using a lot of the kit as you progress and its used well in level design to make sure you don't slack on the mechanics you've learned so far.

Sound - The game recognizes its identity with its use of sound, music and unique dialogue. There is a charm to unknown languages being used to really bring you into the game's world. The ambience gives you immersion even when no music is present and when it does its a treat for the ears and is worth listening to outside of playing the game. Voice work feels right and though not much spoken dialogue is present it really makes the statement.

Story - The story isn't really anything new and has been seen before but the way it is done through the characters and world makes it a lovely spin that turns something old new again. Cast is limited however so don't expect a lot of interactions and anything in regards to feeling bonds between isn't much aside from your take on them. Most of the time you'll be getting snippets of story mostly opting for gameplay which most metroidvania titles focus on but when they give a longer cut of story it is well delivered and not wasted. It has heart and though sparse in plot and characters it still holds it all together and serves it purpose.

If I had any complaints I was honestly surprised that despite there being a villain there wasn't any battles to be done. As stated there are no tradition boss battles that have a life bar or use of damaging moves. There is also a section of the game that has its own gimmick mechanic that makes you have to play by its rules and your move set is very limited due to it which for the most part doesn't really make it enjoyable in most cases in games. I will not remember it fondly and it seems the developers took note to that since a friend told me that there isn't a similar level in Ori 2 and that there is a more traditional boss fight as well so what I had issues with in this game have supposedly been added or omitted in the sequel.

Ori & The Blind Forest is a fun game and can be challenging from time to time but I played it on normal difficult so the skill ceiling can be raised there. Lengthwise I got eleven hours out of it and did some backtracking so came is likely more nine hours but for completionist it might stretch to thirteen give or take since many sections were near completion when I was done with it. I am happy this game is in my collection and was well worth the price though purchased on a sale discount and didn't hold back on buying the sequel Will of the Wisp which was wishlisted and purchased on sale as well. I look forward to playing the next after completing a few different titles in between.

From the tip of the volcano to the depths of the forest Ori splits the earth and divides my opinion of it in two, and unfortunately, those parts are not of equal size. While Ori's fundamental mechanics are very pleasing, with a looong dash, double jump, slingshot, ground pound, wall climb, empowered jump, wall jump, and homing dash as a fine toolset, they are wasted on a poorly paced, exceedingly frustrating, and strangely contradictory gap in writing and gameplay that see Ori fall from potentially great heights to the cold, cold ground. Why, in any world, would a game like this have a leveled combat system, let alone enemies. At no point does combat feel meaningful or impactful except for getting right in your god-damned way through a hard section that you didn't bring... energy crystals for to establish a checkpoint? Resident-evil style ink ribbons, though in much greater supply, are an exciting new innovation in the realm of "how to soft-lock yourself into difficult sections" and, for no good reason, are also used for gateway breaking, and occasional xp drops. Visual clarity is thrown out the window at many locations and the ability to see what's coming is occasionally stripped away in the interest of excitement, though, I will give credit to a very, very well-crafted escape segment about halfway through. An effective map is locked behind ability upgrades, in a separate tree to movement upgrades (which in a platformer is an extremely boneheaded design choice already), pathing is unbelievably boring if you attempt to regard this as a metroidvania, and based on my 7 hour playtime and 1 month completion cycle I can comfortably say that there was really nothing making me come back to the game in the day to day... Which is mostly the story's fault. Cute, sure, but there's a strange disconnect between some surprisingly difficult sections of the gameplay and the easy-read children's book story, where the former assumes a player of capability and the latter assumes the player a gelatinuous mutant capable only of breathing, eating, and shidding. A rather crude ending to this review perhaps, but Ori and the Blind Forest is to this reviewer a competent game in its crudest form.

this review is being ripped out of a forum thread that i'm discussing the game in.  so keep in mind there are some references that would seem out of place if that were not mentioned.
-------------------
do take note that i am describing the first in series, not the second.

the first in series is a bad game. here is why:
controls are not only floaty, but sloggish as well. so many times the buttons just don't seem to activate. i am often double pressing buttons. mostly the R2 button. sometimes i'm gliding, sometimes i'm not.

down = dive. this is absolutely unforgivable. a terrible implementation to any platformer.
it would be so much better if it was down + jump. (or any combo really)
why dropping through a platform needs to have a combo button, but diving doesn't, truly is just bad design. i have examples of why it's even worse than i'm stating it, but i've been told this mechanic has completely dropped from the second in series. (huge saving grace to #2)

unfair lvl design. i am starting this on hard mode, but there's a shooting enemy at the end of nearly every platforming section. it's just tedious.
there are way too many blind jumps with multiple "gotcha" moments.

i can see why ppl call it a metroidvania, but i've never seen one designed in such a way.
your objective is always highlighted, you always basically know where to go. if you are getting lost it's because you didn't bother checking which direction you should be heading.
it's so damn linear. it's less a metroidvania, and more just a path with secret branches that aren't very much a secret.

the combat is not even combat. again, i'm doing this on hard, and everything is just a sponge, but that's not my gripe about combat. the issue is, it's just a 1-button spam, it's just not fun.

the comparison to super meat boy was pretty good. it's a lot more like an open world SMB or Celeste. however, i believe both SMB and Celeste are far superior when it comes to game-play. Celeste especially, has a flow to it. you die and respawn quickly, but everything lines up if you just start running and jumping immediately. Ori punishes you for such and forces you to slog through sections instead of speed-running it.

the big issue with this game, is that it's not really unique at all. it steals from a list a of games and mixes all them together. imo, every game it steals from, does those things better, as those things were the focus of the game. not an add-in.

the game looks good, and has a good music track. but that's about all i can give to it. i'd probably have rather watched this play instead of playing it. even the double jump sound effect is somewhat annoying.

the story is rather basic. it's not really a minus, but it's nothing special to really give it a plus either.

the save function is something i'm not fond of. 2 reasons.
1: i don't like how it's tied up with your skill points. this goes against my grain and makes me want to not save, just so i have points available to open doors or use a skill. however, since everything resets upon death, you are forced to save often.

2: bad saves. if you save in a rough spot with low health, you regret the decision almost immediately. there's nothing you can do but work your way out of it.

i know a lot of ppl are more attached to the visuals and music, which are things that were done well here. but as a "game", the game-play is just horrid.
i wouldn't even bother finishing this game if i didn't end up dedicated to this thread.

i'll stress again, that the floaty controls were tolerable. even the sloggish controls could be forgiven. the down = dive really is a game-breaker though. it's legit a sin to platforming.

as you can tell, i'm not happy with the first in series at all. if i wanted to play a combat based metroidvania, i'd play HK. if i wanted to play a tight platformer, i'd play Celeste.
both games do their respective genres very well. they were only after thoughts here just to check a bunch of boxes it seems. it truly feels the game-play was back-burner focus.

i do have reason to believe the second in series would be more enjoyable than the first, but i really have to say, the first in series is just a "bad game" with good visuals and music.

#2 is not something i would rush to play at this point. i'm more-so only interested in #2 for appeasement reasons. appeasement of myself, and others who genuinely seem interested in my thoughts. i almost feel i have to experience #2, i'm just afraid i won't like it at all either.

to my OP. if i was asking about the first Ori instead of the second Ori, i'd tell myself if i was to look at this as a "metroidvania" i'd be disappointed because it's the worst implementation of a metroidvania i've ever seen. again, props to the SMB comparison, at least for the first in series.

this game should never be compared to HK. ever. both games are nothing alike.
1 last time, this is all based on #1 in Ori series. not #2.

ok, i've beaten the "game" now.  i have even more complaints about the controls with the final stage, but i'm done.  should have been a short disney movie instead of a game.

I played half of this game on Steam Deck, half on my big screen. I found the clarity issues to be even worse on a small screen. Otherwise it worked perfectly. On Windows I had to disable DPI scaling in order to be able to select 4k resolution, so it was actually less hassle to play on Steam Deck than on Windows...

The music is fabulous. It has a consistent theme throughout the game.

The story is OK. It's not earth shattering, and is told mostly through few short cutscenes and 1-2 sentence narration here and there. It didn't make me tear up or anything, but I think it tried.

The graphics... Well, you've seen the screenshots, and you've seen the trailers. You know it looks beautiful. While this might appear as a big strength, it is also a big weakness of this game. The lush and vibrant environments hide important gameplay elements, like spikes, enemies, and other deadly things. You can play on big 4k TV, and you still won't notice a tiny spike at the end of the platform you thought safe. You won't realize that this fire is close enough to kill you, on a platform you thought was perfectly safe.

It will also be hard to read the locations. You'll think this lava flowing down is just a background prop, and you'll instantly die when trying to run by. Later you'll find similar looking lava flowing down, and since you did previously you'll think you have to disable it. But no, it's not dangerous, this time. Or you'll see platforms floating in the lava that you have to jump on, then run trough long and dangerous falling platforms, only to find a safe platform to jump on... That is just a background. And you'll fall into the lava and die instantly.

This brings us to the gameplay. The game is full of cheap deaths. There are spikes everywhere, instant death traps, that you won't avoid until you know they are there. Trough the whole game you'll be on 2-3 hits before dying. But often even things that kill you in multiple hits will be death, because they are in a hole you cannot go out of.

You can create a save point when you're standing in a safe spot almost at will. It costs a currency that is very easy to obtain, and there's almost nothing else to use it for. This means the game becomes slog of short pieces of game, where you'll die, and die and die until you memorize the motions needed to beat that section. You'll die to things that are too fast for humans to react, just to replay the scene and this time win since you already know it's there. It's not a fun level design. It's infuriating.

There are few "dungeons" in this game, and each ends with... if you guessed "boss battle" you guessed wrong. A runaway sequence was the right answer. So now you cannot make save spot, and instead you have to do very long escape sequence perfectly, or near perfectly. Those are all littered with instant death traps. You'll be dying over, and over, and over again. Have fun.

The combat system of this game is also painful. You basically have the best way to deal with each monster, and that's the only way it's possible/worth doing so. Otherwise they just take too many hits. While it might sound interesting it becomes tedious very quickly. And there's one frustrating enemy that you defeat by shooting bullets back, but after 2 hits they are left at 1% HP. Why not make it go down in two hits? I have no idea.

You unlock multiple skills on the way. One of the most used is an ability to jump of the enemy bullets, while shooting the bullet back at the enemy. Doing that you might end up airborne for long, long time (and you'll have to do so in runaway sequences). This can often be irritating, if the enemies won't shoot at you when you want them to... and you end up falling into lava and instantly dying.

I also didn't like the controls of the game. Due to the way the bullet jump works you basically need to use the analog for controls. But if you press down during jump by accident, you perform stomp attack, and fall into lava. It's very easy to do with the analog stick. You can also jump off the walls, but due to how it works you might accidentally start walking up or down the wall.

There is a very simple upgrade system with 3 lines, in which you can invest. Most of the skills are useful and you might want them. There are also hidden rooms and items that you have to figure out how to take. There are 3 types of collectibles, each of them are different colored balls of light. Life, energy and skill points. Rather boring.

The maps are quite varied and have some very neat ideas. Too bad those are wasted on a such frustrating game. I liked the misty forest section. I had 350+ deaths in my first run (the game actually counts it for you, so you will know that it doesn't just feel like you're dying a lot). There won't be a second run. It just wasn't fun. It's not even that difficult, it's just infuriating. Also, once I've died many times in one section I started to try less, and dying more, and more. I also found that killing Ori was often the best way to heal myself up, after getting hit on a cheap way, just so I had more health later on...

The map is quite good, but it doesn't show the secret spots you've found, which would be a bit irritating if I wanted to get all the collectibles.

All in all, I can see some types of players enjoying this game. But I think most people will drop it without even finishing it.

I'd say that a downside of the game is that it's not 100% clear on the map where you've to go next, so I found myself spending many minutes in some part of the map trying to pass it while I was not supposed to because I didn't have certain ability yet, but I thought it's just a hard part to pass. And also I'd say that adding more teleports would make the experience of getting the 100% of the map and all the secret areas significantly more satisfying. But still, worth every minute, it's an amazing game.

I want to preface this by saying I was hyped for this game When I saw the trailer, I genuienely cried a bit, as I found it just so beautiful.

I started playing about 2 or 3 years ago, and quickly stop; I didn't have a controller for my pc at the time, and playing on keyboard and mouse was attrocius.

I recently started a new game,from start, and finished the game in 5:00:25 in game time.
After 5 minutes, I wanted it to be over, and when the end finally came, I was like don't you put an end credit there, ain't no way is the ending this bad, it cannot be over, and I was laughing, especially when one of the character was clipping through the ground or moving weirdly during an end scene that, I think, was meant to be emotional, but I found it so bad it was comical.

Ori is an Amazing ambient Soundtrack with superb graphics but has the fault of having to be played. 

The good:

map/level design: great. It's intuitive, I didn't get lost a single time during my second playthrough, I believe, areas are varied, have differents gimmick, there is a sense of progression, and very importantly, backtracking is not terrible as the areas changes, meaning if you go through an area that you've already visited, you will not necessarily explore it the same way, that is great.

Soundtrack: I almost wish this was the only aspect of the game lol, it's REALLY good.

Graphics: INCREDIBLY GOOD LOOKING, for about 30 minutes. Then it gets old VERY old. The amount of bloom and other flashy thing is ridiculous and often would my screen look like a blurry flashy  mess, like a bullet hell type of game, even though there is very few projectile. Also, there is many levels of depth. That looks good for 2 minutes, before you think that the wall of lava is in the background and you run through it, or you try jumping onto a wall that is in the background, or something in the front  actually hide your character. like the dog assist trophy in super smash bros (yes I know weird comparison, but english ain't my first language, so it's sometime easier to make weird comparison to get people to understand my point).

The bad:

Punishing vs challenging: This game is not hard, it is punishing. So much of this game, due to the save mechanic or other system like to punish the player for his lack of skill or knowledge. Meanwhile, nothing actually feel rewarding, as it beeing not challenging, I actually don't feel proud when I overcome anything. It's bad when I lose and Meh when I win, instead of meh when you lose and GREAT when you win.  This made me quickly stop caring about much and I tried to explore as little of the world as I could, and still ended up finding a lot, as I simply didn't care, nothing felt rewarding enough for me to spend the time to get it and risk the chance of getting punished by losing.

SLOW: So much of this game is slow, this feels like a 3:30 or 4h game stretched to 5h, that feels like 10 hours. For example, every door that you open has an opening animation, that is slow, and sometime you can run through it, sometime not, (I think it depends on your side of the door related to the position of the two door parts). Other example,  A lot of time, you need to push some wooden bar down by acting as a hammer on it, well it doesn't take one hit to do it, but always multiple: WHY, the result is the same, it's not more challenging to do it thrice rather than once, it's just more time consumming. I know these sounds like nitpicks, because they are, but There are just so many nitpicks that can be done, they add  up to an entire game philosophy that this game has, SLOW THE PLAYER. I am not a fan of that.

Movement: LOVE THE BASH, genuinely one of the best mechanic I have seen in any plateformer ever. The dash, Idk, I unlocked it, very early on, but it never worked. I might have missed something. Every thing else feels either fine or clunky. And that is not a good thing when so much of this game require precise imput, and I am always unsure if my character will actually do what I am asking him to do,

Combat:  X to attack. You can also bash enemy projectile. INSANE!!! 

Story: It is definelty one of the story that have ever existed.

Overall what I thought of Ori and the blind forest was that it is a great thing that suffer from beeing a video game, as it actually ask of me to play it. I'd recommend just watching a playthrough of it on Youtube or just listening to the soundtrack. If you plan on actually playing it, I recommend playing it till after the first dungeon where you get the bash ability, as this thing is great, don't stop playing before that, I know I almost did. 

I recommend this game because I can see some people liking it, and I rarely not recommend game, This is my 41 review I believe, with only two thumbs down, and for a game to receive a thumbs down frome me, it either needs to be an experience that legitemetly hurt me, or a game that offer nothing that I can see of value: This game is neither. 

This game has some positive, negatives, evaluate both and know that we all have different opinion and has preferences are subjectives. no opinion is better than any other. I genuinely overall disliked my time with this game, but you might like it, 7 Canadian dollars isn't a lot.



Now as a small Tangent, imma rant for one small thing about story in general that applies to this game (SPOILLER SPOILLER): I fuking hate when they make past events irrelevant just to make sure that every one gets a happy ending. If somoene dies, let them be dead, otherwise, their death isn't meaningful in the first place, and now their life is meaningless as it should've ended. Let us have bad events happened so the character can evolve through their trauma and grow as individual. Rant Over.

While a lot of the current generation of metroidvanias are about crazy boss fights and precisely timed parries, this game is built around the atmosphere of its world and the grace of movement from its titular character. Ori and the world they inhabit resonate with a quiet innocence, starkly contrasted to the dangerous, predatory tension posed by the corrupted creatures that threaten them.

The story is told without many words, relying on body language and music to convey intense emotion, which is does effectively from the very start of the game to the very end. In between each step in the story, you are given a lush natural world to explore.

Controlling Ori is a delight, with movement being highly animated, quick and fluid as you dodge and weave through your environment. While each power adds to this, nothing changes the game as much as the Bash ability, which allows you to grab an enemy or projective in midair, and leapfrog away from them. This ability, which you get about halfway through the game, takes a great platformer and transforms it into something unique.

Speaking of unique, the way this game handles boss ‘battles’ is one of my favorite aspects of it. Instead of fights, the game features elaborate chase scenes, emphasizing the feeling that you are a small point of light in a world filled with big creatures of darkness. You have to use your speed and your wits to survive, rather than brute force.

Ori is a great game. If you’re a fan of metroidvanias, this is one of my top recommendations. It isn’t the longest or the most challenging, but that’s not what it is trying to be. Its presentation and emotional resonance are what makes it stand out, and it does those beautifully.

For the current price of 5 euros it is really a bargain.

I truly wanted to like this game. It was the first metroidvania game I've ever played and it was something new. Visuals were immersively stunning, soundtrack was emotional, and what I partly experienced of the story and later read about was fantastic, but the insipid gameplay ruined all of it for me. If there's one thing I've always vehemently despised in gaming, it's incessant backtracking and trial-and-error. I play games to have fun, not be forcibly subjected to aspects that comprise repetition and constant/easy death. Good for you if your dick gets hard from a challenge, but such attributes kill a game for me instantly, I don't care how much work is put into the story and visuals. 

Navigating the map was nothing but a tedious burden, the jumping was irritating, the acquisition of abilities was uneventful, there was a stupidly unnecessary amount of spikes, there's no blocking or dodging; it's just moving and mashing attack, there's an overabundance of inaccessible areas from the get-go; I defer you to my aforementioned complaint of backtracking, there's virtually no guidance, and you must use up energy, a necessary and integral resource, just to save the game.

Not even 3 hrs is all the time this game is worth to me, sadly.

Finished in 2 days in 11 hours, absolutely phenomenal

Pros:
- great animated visual, unmatched
- beautiful story, had tears in eyes in the beginning and in the end
- creative and sometimes VERY difficult platforming (both techincally and logically)
- cool metroidvania mechanics. The movement and combat are simple with all the items, yet challenging
- level design. Some levels, like the final Mount Horu, are so punishing that your every neuron will be focusing very hard to not slip up in many of the sections, where you dont have a break for at least a minute. The platforming here is like boss fights in soulslike games, you cant make almost any mistakes and when you do it at 20th time, you end up with a massive heartbeat

Cons:
- the game doesnt weigh on exploration as much as Hollow Knight, it has quest markers and although you have to find the path yourself, its not difficult
- pretty short
- some obstacle design is not clear, some barriers you can destroy by yourself, for some you have to stomp a nearby lever, for some something else and they all look similar

But those are small nitpicks compared all the pros, definitely a beautiful emotional journey, recommended to everyone

Here are my gripes with the game despite it being great:
1. Ori is too tiny and hard to keep track of sometimes
2. Every god damn enemy and bullet in the game is a glowing orb and it's incredibly hard to tell which glowing orb is which, the one floating beside ori the whole game, your glowing orb bullets, your glowing orb grenades, your glowing orb charge particles, the enemies glowing attack needles, the enemy itself, the enemy's counterable projectile, the enemy's uncounterable projectile, you get the picture. A little more variation and clarity would do the game a lot of good. They try to make it clearer by enemy bullets being a different color, but they all blend together on top of ori in the moment and it's impossible to tell which is which.
3. Needs some bosses. I felt the game could have used a couple of those to really flesh it out. Escape sequences are the "boss battles" of the game, and that's fine, but a couple of actual boss fights would have probably provided a bit of lasting appeal.
4. Enemy variety is pretty lacking. I was getting really tired of blobs designed to have just enough HP to not die before they hit you a couple of times by the end of the game.
5. Don't make speedrun, no damage, no-death, "don't use any of the skills in the game" achievements. Those should always remain self-imposed challenges because this game isn't worth playing for hundreds of hours to become good enough to do that for 99% of players.

Just sharing this for the sake of my sanity and to vent a little bit.... I know I'm VERY late to this game. Visually, this game is incredible. Story-wise, it is incredible. In fact, I may have actually shed many tears had I actually enjoyed playing this game.

 The major reason: chase sequences. Granted, I am not very good at video games. I will fully admit that. I enjoy a challenge though and the first chase sequence was great for that. However, after the second chase sequence I was SO DONE with the chase sequences. By the final one I was so frustrated I was slamming my hands down on my keyboard. Maybe I'm just too used to playing Hollow Knight, but the controls for this game are not nearly tight enough to warrant FOUR chase sequences. 

While playing this game I often found myself comparing it to Hollow Knight. Hollow Knight is a difficult game, and there were many moments I found myself feeling frustrated at that game, but I always felt it was because of my own mistakes. In this game, many of my failures were because the game was screwing me over, like the spitter dudes not spitting fast enough or projectiles at the wrong angle during a chase sequence. 

After this I don't even know if I'll play the second one... but I guess I'll be scouring the reviews to see if the controls are a little better and there are very few chase sequences.

EPIC

Nice enough game most of the time, but it takes itself too serious, and have some really dumb sequences, that it wants you to do perfectly and from the scratch everytime even if you don't want to and find it tedious.

The first bad place is before you get double jumb and bash, when we have really annoying wall jumping with no room for error (you can tell on achievements 80-90% of players get this far, only 50% gets to the achievements from double jump and bash). The issue is partially with the controls, especially jump controls. The game only recognizes the 8 directions even with an controller, has no simulation of momentum, and treats "jump up" as a failed jump. So the way to jump most up is to be equally to the left of right as you are below the point and then jump a 45deg jump. This makes for very limited correct off points, and is super non-intuitive.

Second problem is the escape sequences, which can rot in hell. Too linear, too long endless parts that needs to be done perfectly. Again part of the problem is the design, it is designed so you can not get ahead, the sequence do not allow you extra time if you do an earlier part faster. So if you end up being caught the natural thing for most gamers is to try to move faster, which is WRONG, because it gives you nothing, the correct thing is to take it slow, and do EVERY SINGLE jump and manuever perfectly, because that is how the game rolls. This is unintuitive and stupid, but that is how the game is designed.

Just buy it
If I had to give it a grade, 4.5/5
I'll start with the bad - combat is very mid. It boils down to spamming descending dar- ahem, stomp, on everything when you get it, managing i-frames from Bash and sometimes mashing X. Your movement abilities can be repurposed for killing mobs and experimenting with them is quite fun, but ultimately you don't **have** to do anything other than Bash and spam X.
You can also forget about mastering this game if you value your sanity. Both chase scenes and overworld include a large amount of instakill segments, and I dread to think how long it takes to get a deathless run.

Now for the good - everything else is amazing, really. Art direction is strong and well executed, background art can easily be taken out for wallpapers. Level design is great and segments are memorable, you can get around without a map easy after a few hours. Core gameplay loop - movement, is impeccable. Chase scenes, while somewhat easy to die in (falling rocks are a good mechanic😊), are still fun and not that hard.

I thought the game would be a bit like Hollow Knight, looking at the achievements and the description/some gamelplay. well combat isn´t really the main part of the game, and thats ok for me, but the jump and run parts aren´t that great either.

First of all, the grafic and the soundtrack are amazing, I would even say exactly like Hollow Knight: Nice, colorful and working on lower PCs too, i had no problem with lag.

But the jump and run parts, I really don´t get why people like it. It´s basicly an open world where you follow the story to gain abilitys to acselss new areas that you saw before but couldn´t reach. And in my opinion those aren´t really exiting. You move a rock there or you wall jump up there with one obstacle shooting at you. 
What was also really annoying: You have a meter, basicly mana that slowly recharges and guess what? It´s there to make respawn- and upgrade spots or to use your super ability that you need to breakt through that one wall and now you either look for the nearest way to refill it or you wait.

And one, nah 2 achievements are to finish the game without dying, basicly 2 times the same thing. And that would not be the end of the world, if it wasn´t for all the potential insta death spots. This one is really just me but i find it really not good desinged to do such a challenge with enemys and traps oneshotting you and spike pits that you take so fast damage in and that you can´t seem to escape because of no wall to get to... no thanks, there are better challenges out there.

Maybe at another time or just on youtube, but I don´t really like the gameplay

Okay fine I'll say the obvious thing first. This game is goddamn gorgeous. Even a cursory glance demonstrates one of the most visually stunning games in the past decade. The game bolsters this with a intensely atmospheric range of biomes and a large scale orchestral soundtrack that is all very good. Ori and the Blind Forest is almost worth playing for the spectacle alone.

However, I do feel like it's necessary to bring up gameplay for a game this long. Ori and the Blind Forest advertises itself as a "Metroidvania Platformer". Ori's movement and platforming is pretty basic, but has a lot of comboing moves together to keep things fast and energetic. The part I find confusing is the Metroidvania part. The game is pretty linear in terms of where you can go next and exploration is usually only rewarded by the occasional health upgrade. It's not a deal breaker, but expect this game to be a platformer first and foremost.

I had high hopes for this game.  i'll admit!  It looks stunning, The gameplay is smooth, the music is fantastic.....but the controls.

The controls/keybinds are absolutely HORRIBLE.  if you do play this game, DO NOT play with a mouse and keyboard.  This game isn't made for it.  

It does have a few "static" options for the keybinds but.....whoever came up with them, clearly doesn't play games.  i mean, for cryin out loud, "M" is the standard "map" button, but this game?  Nope.  it's Tab.  and the extra movement buttons are in awkward places and having to juggle the awkward keboard buttons with the mouse is just....frustrating.  And the keybinds aren't customize-able, which doesn't help things.

So, if you play, use a controller.

I really wanted this game to be "fun to play", but it's turned into "oh, mama didn't raise a quitter!  i'm gonna finish this freakin nightmare..."

Again, there are LOTS of positives to this game.  But since it's, arguably, unplayable.....i'd avoid it if you don't have a controller.

Very fun and charming game. The graphics are beautiful and the controls are generally responsive. One thing I like is that (while not intended) the game can be played with two people, one controlling Ori with the keyboard and the other being able to attack enemies with the mouse. There aren't very many characters or much of a story, but it's still simple and nice to play.

I seriously don’t understand what makes this game so highly rated. The character movement is mushier than Ori’s feelgood story, and the game itself is just prettier to look at than it is fun to play. What made me realize that I don’t like this game at all is how ambiguously vague the map is. I’ll summarize.

I began to retrace my explorations attempting to gain entry into previously inaccessible zones after accumulating better abilities. However, the map doesn’t have an indicator for some natural or fortified obstructions. The areas behind these obstructions are just grayed out, as if I didn’t bother to venture that way when I first discovered the area. There’s also no differentiation between some obstructions that require a specific skill or interaction. All I see on the map is a wall that can be broken. In either scenario, I find myself wasting massive amounts of time defeating the same enemies over and over as I navigate my way to something that isn’t even viable to my progression. There’s no way to quick travel either. I lost patience trying to reach something on the other side of the map, (and sometimes dying multiple times in my attempts) only to discover that I arrived there for nothing. So what do I do? I’ve played this out more times than I can stand to and still have fun, so I’m going to uninstall it.

I bought the sequel too, thinking this would be a fun story to play through. This game has killed my interest in that altogether.

An older game by this point, but still one of the best I have ever played.  I would 100% recommend this to anyone who's even considering picking it up, it's so much better than I expected and I loved every minute of it.

Honestly, I think Ori was a great game on its release and it has a lot of great things it did for metroidvanias, but having only played it around 2020 made the game feel a little dated for me. If this was one of the first action-adventure platformers I ever played, maybe I would have liked it more. 

The thing I dislike the most about it is probably the visuals. The extreme amount of brightness and bloom everywhere feels hurtful to look at the screen sometimes, while the fact that everything is extremely detailed made it rather hard to acknowledge which things would actually damage me - which felt a bit frustrating more than once.

The story is pretty cute though and the bash mechanic is amazing, slinging around with it was a lot of fun.

I don't think Ori is a bad game. I just think it's hard to recommend given what other great metroidvanias are around.

The short summary: 11/10
At its core, it's a simple platforming adventure.  But stunning visuals, masterful music, and fluid controls make this game a masterpiece and a prime example of video games as a form of art.  A brilliant game I didn't take the time to play for far too long. 

The full review:
The platforming formula is nothing new to the gaming industry, but Ori and the Blind Forest stands out from the crowd thanks to it's gorgeous visuals and atmospheric music.  Ori controls smoothly and intuitively, and as you gain new abilities and achieve objectives, more of the labyrinth-like forest becomes accessible to you.  Secrets abound, but not so much that it's tedious to uncover them all, and a healthy challenge on Normal difficulty.  The adventure is short and the story simple, yet it is told in a manner that doesn't impede gameplay nor require walls of dialogue.  

I absolutely love this game. I fell in love with it by the time the prologue concluded and found its story to be mesmerizing despite its relative simplicity.  There's enough of an enigma to be intriguing and has left me excited to set forth into the sequel.

If you have any interest in platformer adventure games, please give this one a try. Ori and the Blind Forest may be an older game, but it's a fantastic game and well worth the few hours it takes to play through it.

The game looks great and has a great story and atmosphere. But I'm really irritated by the controls and the way jumping works. I's meant to make you kill all the time. When I jump from one platform to another, Ori doesn't stop, but falls of the other side. When I jump up the wall and want to jump backward to reach another wall, most of the time I fall down.

This doesn't cause me joy, it makes me irritated insted. You should build some stickiness insto jumping. I don't care if you call it super easy or something similar, but even easy mode is extremely irritatingly hard this way.

Edit: after a couple of year I started again, and I am still as much frustrated by this game as in the beginning. Easy is not easy at all. I'm stuck at the Ginso tree and can't escape it. I've tried it a thousand times. On my Steam Deck, the game is unplayabla, bash is stuck and you can't aim it. On my PC with a controler it works, but I still can't beat it, the game is simply too fast for me and I can't even save halfway (I'm at the top).

I cried so much whilst playing this game. Everything about it is just perfect. The artstyle, the gameplay, the story, the music. I love it! This is handsdown the best game I have every played in my life and I am really curious about Will of the Wisps! Thank you so much dear Moon Studios.

Surprisingly good. I generally avoid patformers because I very rare find something unique in them. I only picked up this one because because of "Overwhelmingly Positive" rating.

[h1]Presentation (10/10)[/h1]
I was slightly put off by animation at first. Main character looks weird in closeups. Few animations in cutscenes looked awkward, like they were paper figure (or flash game) animations. I only noticed it a couple of times, so I can't really say the entire thing was bad.

Gameplay flow (physics and animations) are feel very fluid and natural.

I rarely noticed music, which is exactly how music should be in similar games. It's an amazing background tune, which creates atmosphere without drawing attention onto itself.

[h1]Gameplay (8//10)[/h1]
The moment gameplay started I forgot about few bad animations. Mobility is very fluid and fun on it's own.
Gameplay ramps up. You start out with just movement and basic jump and early experience is not great, but once you get some mobility skills the game flow improves considerably.

While on that point, most of this game is focused on mobility and most of the skills you gain are mobility skills. It might sound like boring progression, but it's among most unique ones I've seen in similar games. Don't get me wrong, this game doesn't invent anything new, but it focuses on mobility and gives more options than most games. That makes tackling exploration puzzles more fun. Especially if you find a non-intended solution.

The game allows you to place your own checkpoints, which is a lovely feature considering the game isn't always easy.

I have 2 reasons to deduct a few points: 
[list]
[*] Slow start. 
[*] Few long platforming sections where you cannot stop, cannot place checkpoints and you only beat them by memorizing it. I wouldn't complain about it in another game, but when your entire game is slow, deliberate and has free checkpoints these few hectic sections that flip the game on its head. It felt out of place.
[/list]

[h1]Exploration(8/10)[/h1]
Exploration is great, but value of rewards diminishes over time.
Puzzles are fun and unique among themselves. This game's puzzles are environmental. You sometimes don't know you're in one, until you're half-done.

Exploration rewards diminish.
[list]
[*]Skill points are always rewarding, as they buy you more/different mobility and combat power (among some utility things).
[*] XP (fraction of a skillpoint) is too little to matter. You already need 3 skillpoints to buy 1 skill later in game. XP orbs tend to give you something like 10-30% of 1 level.
[*] Health upgrades are good when you start out, but feel unnecessary when you have enough to absorb to survive 2 hits. Also, if you play on hard difficulty, you need 4 of these to survive 1 hit, to so 3/4 health upgrades don't change anything.
[*] Energy capacity upgrades are VERY useful early on as energy is used for creating save points(healing) and using energy abilities. I think I was sitting comfortably at 6, while maximum is 15.
[/list]

Ori and the Blind Forest is an absolutely brilliant game. Fluent gameplay, a simple but engaging story and gorgeous visuals make for an allround great experience. 
It really is the complete package of a great sidescrolling adventure, but for me the thing that makes it stand out, is that it is so very beautiful in every sense of the word. The visuals are dominated by rich colours and even though you get across darker areas and alot of things that want to harm you, you always have a somewhat cozy feeling. But not only the visuals are beautiful, the story is aswell. This game will break your heart within the first ten minutes and will continue to tell a story in a very simplistic, but very effective way, that has you engaged in it from start to finish. Last but not least I have to mention the incredible music. It matches the game perfectly and is also extremely beautiful, which is kind of the theme for this game. 

Pros:
+ incredibly beautiful visuals
+ fluent and fun gameplay
+ exceedingly beautiful music
+ engaging and beautiful story, that will pull at your heartstrings

Cons:
- none really (For me it was sometimes a bit frustrating, but that is because I am really bad at these kind of games.)

All in all, it's a lovely game and worth playing especially as it's inexpensive this late in the day. Check it out!

One the best 'metroid-vania' platformers of the decade. 8/10 - Worth your time.
[b]Tl;dr:[/b] Like a wholesome picture book you read as a kid in game form. Great for casual play if you have a spare hour or two. Play with controller (not Steam one) and get some decent headphones for the music. Check system specs but if you have a decent GPU you should be good without question.

[h1]Art:[/h1]
Beautiful. The art team and developers took their time creating the atmoshere for all characters and the environment and it definitely shows. The varying biomes , all each uniquely different make the Blind Forest feel organic, yet inhabited. 

[h1]Gameplay/Perfomance:[/h1]
Most abilities and skills feel earned (i.e the more you play and explore the world outside of key story beat the easier the game will be). Played majority of the game on normal difficulty and it was a breeze. By end-game I had a stacked Lifeforce and Spirit Points I felt like I was cheesing the enemies half the time. If you are competent at muscle memory and the platforming genre you will barely struggle. The only things I had a frustrating time with were the scripted sequences at the end of 'purifying' an area. REALLY unforgiving making you start from beginning if you slip up once although I guess that's part of the challenge. The only other thing lacking I can think of was no major bosses to fight against? You have the Owl but that is solely evasion in the scripted segments. Enemy types only go so far when you have a few per area + reskins. If you tried hard enough you could likely sequence break some things requiring abilities later if you know the ins and outs of mechanics. 


No noticeable stutter issues or major game-breaking bugs. One thing I found is I couldn't get a resolution of 1080 x 1920p, (a definitive edition version?!) which was annoying but I dealt with it. Still could get aspect ratio to 16:9 but couldn't go further than some obscure resolution. I don't know if this was because my monitor was unsupported or what... And for the love of God if you are planning to play on a Steam controller please don't. The more PC titles I play on Steam, the more I realise the functional and technical limitations the thing has. Just don't.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
It's serviceable. A 10 year old could probably understand the core themes of the story but that doesn't mean it's all bad. The dialogue isn't spoken in any coherent language and there are text bubbles to coincide. Likely because the game is set in a world not shared by humans but it also gives international accessibility via translation. A short and linear experience which is nothing to complain about for a metroid-vania platformer. I guess there is one query I had with the Spirit Tree being that it is not clearly understood why its actions were carried out as it is implied it has sentience. Ori is an innocent child who spreads love across all of the characters they meet. The score and art make up for what the story doesn't say or quite deliver well enough.

Gosh, I love this game so much! From the iconic soundtrack to the stunning visuals, from the fluid movement to the heartwarming story, I'm utterly blown away every time I take this journey through the forest of Nibel. Where do I even start?

The soundtrack features plenty of memorable pieces that seamlessly blend together, giving the impression of a single song that builds to a climax with each objective you complete. The title theme, in particular, gets reused and remixed throughout the game to convey a variety of emotions, like sorrow, danger, or tranquility. And the visuals are just as impressive, with parallax environments and level designs that really bring the world to life. It's a feast for the eyes as well as the ears.

The movement controls are tight and fluid, which is critical, considering the game has its fair share of difficult platforming sections. Falling victim to the same spike pit a dozen times may not be fun, but what makes up for it is how each major dungeon caps off with an awesome and intense escape sequence that would make the [i]Metroid[/i] series proud. Not to mention using the bash technique to dance your way through a room of enemies and projectiles like a leaf on the wind.

But what really brings this game together is an inspiring story about embracing hope instead of despair, about love overcoming hate. Top it off with an ending that makes me sob every time, and you have a masterpiece.

Go forth, Ori. Let your light shine.

After finishing my first game, I can confidently say I would recommend this game.  After the first day of playing I was obsessed and in love.  The story is moving, the graphics are beautiful, and the music is perfect.  I usually turn off game music because it gets repetitive after a few minutes, but the music for this game sets the scene and mood, and is very well composed so that it doesn't get irritating even after you've been in one region for an hour.  
I'm not very well experienced with this kind of "parkour" game for a lack of a better word, but even I managed to complete the story.  I will say that escaping the Ginso Tree is the absolute hardest part of the whole game, and if you can pass that, you can pass the rest.  I probably respawned over a hundred times in the Ginso Tree escape alone.  
The game is perfect, even for an inexperienced, uncoordinated person like myself.  Would recommend to anyone, but especially those who like adventure without gore.
Deceptively difficult game. Beautiful visuals and story completely marred by horrendous combat and frustrating platforming. What a shame.
The graphics look astounding, gameplay is very fluid. Although I get stuck in a lot of places, the amazing soundtrack keeps me going.

Ori and the Blind Forest was a hauntingly beautiful experience. The music and visuals are superb and I have nothing but praise for both.  Between traversing through the forest and backtracking to explore areas that I couldnt access before, I was hooked. In the end I 100% explored everything for fun so I could spend a little more time in this world.

 The control of Ori's movement and attacks felt exactly on point and if I was failing something, it was because I was doing it poorly. Also the theres an ability to save almost anywhere (but semi limited early on) which is an amazing way to make you not fear making a couple of mistakes on some platforming sections. 

There's only a few things I could critique in the entire game which is a testament to how well designed Ori and the Blind forest is. Notably I think would be the couple of times the difficulty spiked immensely to the point where deaths felt cheap. [spoiler]Specifically the water escape area after the first? boss. [/spoiler] However I am not always the best gamer so Im sure many people had no problems. You could also always lower the difficulty like I could on the fly for that one section. Make no mistake this is a hard game even on lower difficulties and you will die, but the repercussions for doing so are usually tiny. God speed if you try to do the achievement for a deathless run, youre a braver person than I am.

Also If I could suggest another change it would be to highlight the map a tiny bit better to see the sections that you hadnt explored. Some areas were pretty dark so it was difficult finding the last 2% or so of a section. It wasnt the end of the world though and there are many threads of people suggesting the most commonly missed areas. Maybe a hint system guiding you places to you missed? 

In the end I cant give high enough praise for this game and I look forward to the sequel when I have the itch for another platformer. 10/10 for me

Disclaimer: I only review games that I completely finish the main story mode of.

A beautiful soundtrack, stunning artwork, touching story, several unique and difficult challenges, this is one of the best adventure games I've ever come across. 
I really enjoyed how diverse each major "boss battle" was, and how many game-play concepts there are to unlock in order to progress the story. This keeps the game engaging throughout the whole experience. It's easy to get stuck replaying the same challenge over and over, frustrating too, but with each attempt you learn and improve your strategy, and the feeling of finally beating those challenges is so fulfilling. Once the credits rolled, I was so happy that I couldn't help taking several screenshots to remember. Excited to play the sequel! :)

Ori spent years in my wish list. When I saw it a few days ago bundled and on sale with the sequel I decided to finally buy it. I regret waiting so long.
It is, without a doubt the most beautifully rendered game I've ever played. (maybe until I start Will of the Wisps when I'm done posting this review?)
For the actual game play: 
The controls were pretty smooth, though I did find some of the ability upgrades confusing as to what they did. in the ability tree it listed the prerequisite to learn it,(always just the previous node on the tree) but not the prerequisite to use it. So some abilities I'd learn and only realize later they were upgrades for skills I had not acquired yet. 
It was cute how they occasionally used achievements to help tell the story. When "Run for Your Life" popped up I was like "huh, weird. what does that have to do with what I just..." then I immediately understood that it was instructions.  
Overall it was challenging without feeling arbitrary. There were a few deaths that were a surprise, but when I died, I was always able to tell why even if sometimes I had to die a few times to fully understand how to avoid it. 
The story was simple while still being able to engage the player and evoke an emotional response. I'm not going to lie, the first time I got to the end, I had to fight back tears when the credits started rolling.
Always makes me cry so damn hard for how beautiful it is. :'3

I wanna say that I have a love-hate relationship with this game, but there's no love. The artwork-graphics is amazing, the storytelling is immersive, the gameplay is fluid; but the level-design is phallic-thorny. Again, some hot-shot-wannabe level-designer implemented his dungeon-closet on to a could-have-been-a Classic Game. "Face Your Invisible Master, You Slimy Worms". the levels beckon out. The levels are so out-of-sync with the tone of the game that It ruins Everything. I play Cuphead and Super Meat Boy and they're both fun despite the Challenge. It never feels like someone is pouring out their issues on to a game just so that they can feel good about themselves. I'm not stuck anywhere, to be clear... just annoyed. 

I'll still play the game though, I have to admit. The game feels good. The forest here is dead too and most games feel too out-of-tone with the flow of the world.

OK. If you like side scrollers. But by their nature they lack dimension. As such, they can be quite boring and uninteresting. The pics and video they promote show a few select scenes with more dimension in the foreground/background, but a lot of the game isn't so well done as those parts.

The raving reviews for the story are seriously over promoted. The story is thin and lacking substance. It could be worse, but's no excuse for not making it better. Worse, a lot of it is nonsensical gibberish.

Perhaps the worst part of all is the difficulty. Sure, I understand. It's a jumping side-scroller, There wouldn't be much to it if there wasn't something to the difficulty. But when I chose the easiest difficulty so I can focus on the story, only to get so frustrated trying to make it through overly difficult jumping puzzles that I have to replay dozens of time to perfect so I can progress... well, it became all about the difficulty and none of the very thin story. I just quit, not finishing the game less than halfway through.

Overall, it's not a bad game. I cannot thumbs down it cuz those looking for what it advertises to be will get what they want. I guess I just expected something more. Ultimately I got bored and aggravated perfecting difficult jumping puzzles and forgetting where the 2 seconds of story was between the hours of jumping annoyance. And this, coming from someone who loves playing MMO's for mere exploration and jumping around to see if I can get somewhere I'm not supposed to be.

For a side-scroller jumping puzzle: 9/10

Interest: 6/10
Attention holder: 3/10

there are very few games I describe as "Beautiful" Ori and the Blind Forest tops that list without even trying. the music is beautiful, the environment is beautiful, the story is beautiful, everything about this game is beautiful. this game made me cry twice and tear up once, I have cried on less than a dozen games, and Ori did it in the FIRST 10 MINUTES.

The platforming is phenomenal. after about the first hour or so you really grasp how Ori moves, and the game does an excellent job setting up sequences for you to learn your abilities once you get them. 

Combat is.... well... its platformer combat. you can click to attack, or use some abilities to deal damage, however even if you focus on the combat tree, its just not very enjoyable. fortunately the game seems to know this, and you can just avoid most combat, although you shouldn't leveling up is extremely important in this game. and the main way to get xp is combat.

Now, my main stink about the game. it is so fucking hard sometimes, my god. ESPECIALLY the last portion of the game, almost EVERYTHING in the last escape section is an instant kill, too slow? instakill, too fast? instakill, wrong place? killed, wrong time? killed, just right?..... well.... fuck you anyway, here's a meteor you couldn't predict :)

It killed my entire enjoyment of the final section, and kind of ruined the ending, since I was pissed and celebrating so much, I could hardly care about the end, which, is a real shame, because the end of this game hits just as hard as the intro, but I couldn't give a shit because of how hard the last section was.

I'm sure I'll try Will of the Wisps, but I've heard its even harder and less forgiving, so, it'll be a year or two


also, fuck you for "no deaths" and "no deaths on hardest difficulty" achievements, there's no way humans are able to pull that shit off, wtf

It truly pains me to give this game the thumbs down, because it's literally beautiful and has one of the greatest soundtracks I've ever had the pleasure of listening to.
So why am I giving it the boo? Mostly for the platforming. The ideas are great, but with floaty controls, slippery footwork, the worst implementation of wall jumps I've ever seen, it's just so incredibly frustrating. If you're expecting responsive controls that do what you tell them to, you won't find that here.
Secondly, in the effort to make this game look like a piece of artwork it can be quite hard to see what is going on with all the overused particles and shaders. I was taking damage and having no idea what from, until I realized it was a tiny particle flying through the air.

I wish there was a neutral rating. I don't like "not recommending" this game, because quite frankly, it's more than earned its incredibly affordable price tag, but it's also hard recommending a game that made me want to rip my hair out and put my head through a wall because of floaty controls and dying to things I can't see,

Imagine buying a beautiful piece of artwork to hang on your wall, but someone defaced it by scribbling a moustache on the woman in the painting, so you couldn't enjoy it as much as you hoped. That's how Ori and the Blind Forest feels to me.
There's a real gem here, but it's sabotaged by unfair design choices.

I'm going to allow comments so people can yell at me. Have at it.

The movement is god tier, the music on point, and a brilliant story to top it off. If you like platformers, or even just 2-D games you'd be insane not to give this a try. It'll rip you heart out! The different biomes of the world are incredible, and there's a great sense of progression. Each biome has their unique challenges which all build up to the final biome, where the challenges and abilities learned from the entire world are put together for an explosive ending.

How can a game that is so infuriating to play be so pretty to look at? That is the simplest way to describe Ori and the Blind Forest. Did I enjoy the game? Sort of. Do I feel like this game is incredibly overhyped? Absolutely.

So, here's the problem. The artwork and music score are flawless. This game is beautiful from one end to the other. Mind you, I'm colorblind and had a hell of a time making out some of the scenery to the point where I repeatedly found myself running face-first into lava; but that's a "me" problem.

To begin actually ripping this game apart, we first need to talk about narrative flow. That first 15 minutes is gut wrenching. Had my tear ducts not been sealed shut from years of misuse, I'd have shed a tear or two in the same manner I did during the opening for Up. The problem is that the somber feeling gets absolutely obliterated between the dodgy level design that places enemies in very obtuse places and instant death on every wall toward the end of the game. That coupled with the lackluster ending that cheapens the opening sequence leaves my palate dry with rage. When the stakes are thrown out the window to supplant a quick narrative finish, it feels rather meaningless.

Now, I want to not recommend this game for that, but for some reason I actually enjoyed the experience when I wasn't screaming at my computer screen like the amateur video game enthusiast I happen to be. For some reason, pretty set design and fantastic music are overriding my desire to chuck this game into my forbidden games folder next to the Borderlands series. What the hell, man?

I want to like this game, I really do.  However, I just can't.  Here are the three main reasons why.

The controls feel...slow?  Not unresponsive, but it feels like it takes forever to change Ori's direction.  I find myself getting frustrated that Ori is not moving fast enough to dodge any projectiles.  You might be thinking that I just suck at this kind of game, but I have beaten Hollow Knight and I loved every minute of it.  Perhaps the responsiveness of Hollow Knight makes this game feel slow to me.

The game also uses lots of colors that I have a hard time seeing due to my protanopia (a type of colorblindness) and I have yet to find a colorblind mode.  Without, I am having an extremely hard time seeing certain enemy projectiles and often get hit before I even know where the projectile is.

On top of that, I am stuck in an early part of the game, and have not even the slighest of ideas as to what to do.  I have gone everywhere I am capable of going (at least I think so) but I can not seem to progress at all.  I'm not sure what everything on the map means because none of it was explained, and I am not even really sure which direction on the map I am supposed to be headed.  I am at a loss as to what I am supposed to be doing.  I'm probably going to play an hour or two more just to check everywhere, but if I don't find anything or anywhere to go, I doubt I will pick the game up again.

Again, I want to like this game, but I just have been getting frustrated with it at every turn.  Given my experience, I cannot recommend this game, which I think is unfortunate given the massive amount of positive reviews this game has gotten.  Am I just missing something?

EDIT: Played again.  Was great.  No real idea as to why I didn't like it before.
