nice challenge

The fundamentals here are really solid. Movement feels really good and the game makes good use of its mechanics both with its platforming challenges and integration of movement into its combat. Navigation and exploration are generally good and their weaker aspects are compensated for by a beautiful aesthetic design.

Where the game stutters is in taking those excellent fundamentals and translating them into consistently engaging gameplay. Everything up to [spoiler]the Ginzo Tree[/spoiler] was excellent and the [spoiler]escape sequence[/spoiler] there is a masterpiece, but a lot of the content beyond that point was a lot more mixed in quality. Some sections were still great and managed to keep me engaged without issue. But these were overshadowed by the flaws. [spoiler]Sorrow Pass[/spoiler] was probably the worst offender here, relying on [spoiler]wind and gliding[/spoiler] mechanics that were neither interesting nor enjoyable to use. [spoiler]Kuro's Feather[/spoiler] is honestly a net-negative on the game as a whole as it not only works poorly but also makes other platforming sections difficult since it uses the same key bindings as grabbing and climbing which caused frequent issues during my playthrough. [spoiler]Forlorn Ruins[/spoiler] are slow to get through and the [spoiler]gravity[/spoiler] mechanic they introduce is both confusing to learn and never develops in an interesting way. [spoiler]Mount Horu[/spoiler] was generally good, but the [spoiler]escape sequence[/spoiler] at the end was a disappointing conclusion to the game, suffering from unclear visual indicators, unpredictable obstacles that required multiple deaths to learn the pattern for, and (while a lot more subjective) felt jarring to complete as it felt really abrupt for the game to end right after the sequence finished.

I think Ori has the fundamentals of a masterpiece, but its currently lacking in execution. I haven't played Will of Wisps yet so I'm very excited to see how it developed on the great foundation this game provided because there really is some amazing stuff here that just needed the right world and enemy design to help make it shine. But its still easily worth the time and money.

Absolutely lovely game as far as graphics go. The game itself is highly engaging and has by far become my ideal for a platformer. It's fun, appropriately challenging at all difficulties, and engaging. Story wise- ah, let's not get too deep into that. it's touching, to say the least, and emotional, to say the most. I really don't have anything negative to say about this game, and I find myself coming back to it even after 100%ing several files.
Ori is a game with an incredible art, good level design and emotional story, it's a metroidvania, but not sucks if you don't enjoy this genre so much (like me)

It's a visually beautiful game that successfully executes many metroidvania tropes. But three things were frustrating:

1) The difficulty-spiking chase scenes at the end of each dungeon are less thrilling than frustrating.

2) The backtracking to reuse your new abilities to loot the map doesn't feel as good as it should. The map spells things out for you too easily, and the world is a chore to navigate. When I unlocked the last ability, the map told me exactly where to go and I knew what to do, but it just wasn't worth my time.

3) The story wasn't anywhere near as good as people say. It's simple picture-book stuff with loads of unexplained magic to string it together. Sweet, but not very meaningful or memorable. Still unsure of the difference between the main character and the glowy ball.

★★★★★ – GAMEPLAY
★★★★★ – ART / GRAPHICS
★★★★★ – MUSIC / SOUNDS

I'd still say it's not a bad game though, it's relatively short so none of these issues become too much of an annoyance over time thankfully, however I feel like this would be the case if this game was a bit longer which isn't a plus. This game never came across as "difficult platformer". I did not expect it to be a cake walk but this game has such infuriating design with how platform puzzles are presented. The whole time I thought "once i get a double jump it will be fine" but as I kept playing I noticed how floaty the controls were. So the double jump didnt help, in fact they presented new puzzles that were astoundingly frustrating. I just got done playing most of Hollow Knight and Blasphemous and *never* did I encounter this kind of frustration. 

Not to mention, combat is horrid. You just mash X until the enemy dies all the while dodging projectiles. Its just really boring. Theres no choreography with fights or anything, just mash X and win hopefully. Oh and don't even think about putting it on hard, you may as well not have a health bar. Spent most my hour and a half with one health. Even if i turned down the difficulty, I KNOW that the levels won't magically change. I do not get why this game has such overwhelmingly positive reviews. 

Its artstyle is super pretty and the story had me hooked, but christ if I gotta deal with the gameplay to see it then I don't really care.

The artstyle is by far the best part of it, although sometimes it can make it hard to fight some enemies or tell where spikes are. The controls are really good and really responsive and the music is quite good as well, nothing mind blowing though. The skill tree is something I also really like. The abilites you unlock are all really cool and get pretty good usage throughout the game as well...
That's the end of the good stuff unfortunately
The level design is often terrible
Very few memorable set pieces, instant death traps everywhere making it so you're always on edge and have to save every two seconds. It makes exploring the world less fun, plus the exploration itself is very limiting, the world is fairly big, but the linearity makes it feel so small. The game is hard but it only is that way because it has cheap tricks that make it hard, very few of my deaths felt fair. The only parts where this trial and error design worked were the escape sequences which are easily the best part of the game, although even those falter in quality a bit after the first one. The story wasn't anything special and honestly very dull. The combat is also incredibly lackluster, at the start it is literally just spam X, the bash move does help things a bit later down the line, but the very few enemy types makes it feel so repetitive and boring, and the complete lack of boss fights makes the combat feel even more worthless.
Overall
Ori is a beautiful looking game with so many cool ideas and abilities, but fails to execute those cool things in a good way leaving a game that greatly disappointed me. One of the most lackluster Metroidvania's I've ever played.

I had about 97% after the prologue. And when I logged back, how disappointed I was to know I went back to the last save BEFORE I continue to the final stage and prologue. The game DOESN'T ALLOW me to continue progression AFTER the prologue.

[h2] REVIEWER GAMEPLAY STATS [/h2]
[list]
[*]14+ hours played
[*]73% achievements
[/list]

[h1][u] 📋 FULL REPORT 📋 [/u][/h1]
2D is the new 3D after playing this beautiful Metroid-like platformer.  You play as some abstract animal going through a beautifully drawn world trying to save their home from a hostile force.  A somewhat generic plot yes, but its saved wonderfully by the hand drawn graphics, composed soundtrack, and lovable characters. As you advance through the game, you pick up additional abilities that help you get through more areas of the game (it's a somewhat open world in the sense that you can kind of go everywhere from the start of the game but you'll be held back severely without gaining some of those required abilities). The combination of the sound and music and environment evoke emotion which if you think about it, is what any game should do. With a sadness in my heart upon completion, I can only hope that I can relive such an emotional experience again in the sequel or future games.

[h2] 👍 THE GOOD 👍 [/h2]
[list]
[*] Beautiful soundtrack
[*] Artwork and graphics are beautiful for a 2D platformer
[*] Beautiful story and engaging characters
[/list]

[h2] 👎 THE BAD 👎 [/h2]
[list]
[*] No replay value (unless you're going for achievements)
[*] Controls take a bit of time to master, might be frustrating to some
[/list]

Hello all! TLDR: 9/10 please give it a try! This is why... Ori in the blind forest is an amazing platformer. This game is B-E-A-UTIFUL! You control a little spirit cat rabbit thing and it feels amazing. The controls are tight and anytime I missed a jump or messed up on a challenging platforming section I knew it was my fault not because of bad controls. The hidden areas holding power-ups and shmechles are not unrealistic to find especially if you're used to metrovanias. I played Hollow Knight before this and if you like this game you will like this game. If you want to know the negative here it is. The combat is nowhere near what hollow knight is. The combat is an afterthought and the enemies are nothing but annoying obsticals, not something I have fun running around killing for their shmechles. It looks like they addressed that in the sequel. That's about it from me. If you're looking for a fun metrovania / platformer please give this a try regardless of a sale!

As for the gameplay, I found it to be really fun even if it was ridiculously difficult at certain parts. I'm not the best at platformers and add to that the fact I played this on a keyboard instead of a controller, however there's a balance with the skills and abilities that help while not losing the game's default difficulty level. Anyways, I highly recommend this game and can't wait to play the sequel!

My main gripe is that there are some bugs that need to be addressed.  There is a strange resolution cap bug and this one block near the swamp warp point got stuck on me and I had to use the built-in backup save feature to redo that part.

[h1] "Metroidvania dazzle, with a side of salt" [/h1]
Review by Unam 

Unless you live under a rock, you've probably heard about this game, or its sequel (Ori and the Will of the Wisps), and as you've probably guessed, it's good. For anyone who enjoys Metoridvanias or combat then this is a no-brainer, but if you are on the fence, then keep reading.

Easily, the best aspect of the game is the visuals. There is no debate that this game is a masterpiece (visually) and it utilizes the 2D environments to create a unique and populated world. It is insane how polished this is. Another aspect I really enjoyed was the platforming / the abilities given to the player. These two go hand in hand since you are required to use the abilities that you get along your journey to traverse new areas or unlock secret areas. The boss fights or trials are a real highlight of the game, as they are incredibly entertaining, and offer an incredibly tough but fair challenge that will truly test your platforming skill in times of extreme pressure (from a game-play perspective, these are easily the best parts). The music is so majestic and atmosphere, it sucks you right in and combined with the visuals make the game feel alive. 
Ori is such an adorable protagonist and watching her grow as a character is very compelling. From the very beginning of the story, we see her as a very fragile being, this is especially seen in the first third of the game, where she has a very small HP and can't move as much. But as the player progresses through the game, Ori grows to become an adorable, and aware protagonist. It is impressive how they can create such a dynamic and round character with almost no dialogue. I commend the developers for the amount of work and time that they had to sacrifice to create such a majestic and rich world with an entertaining protagonist, Kudos to them.

However, there are some major flaws that hold it back from being a masterclass of Metroidvanias. Firstly, the combat is very (very) bad. The orb thing that hovers around you at all times and is your main attack method is very badly designed. You have to sit around spamming your attack button to kill everything, it gets tedious after 3 seconds. The enemy designs are also a huge letdown, compared to its sequel, these enemies feel one-note and very uninspired. 

But easily, the worst part of the game is the check point system.
[i] oh god the check point system [/i]

It is awful. There are no other ways to explain it. What seems like a neat idea (which is to let the player save whenever they want), quickly turns into the worst part of the game. Firstly. it takes some of your blue orb to save (which is usually used for your abilities) meaning that if you happen to stumble into a combat area and want to use your abilities, but you have saved seconds ago because you didn't know what you were getting yourself into, tough luck I guess. It also goes against everything that a Metroidvania stands for, as it removes every sense of intrigue that the player might have had when exploring a new area by allowing you to save at any point, basically annihilating the challenging and the intrigue the player might have had. 

Although it has some severe flaws (especially the checkpoint system) it is undeniable that Ori and the Blind Forest is a gorgeous Metroidvania that is driven by magnificent visuals & audio, a spirited protagonist, and tough-but-fair platforming & exploration. Should you buy this game full price? Ehh, wait for at least a 20% discount if you are on the fence.

I hate and love this game. Hate because this game platforming is hard as hell, some section become repetitive, and the combat is there just for the sake of "gameplay". Love because of the emotional story telling, beautiful soundtrack, and the art.

This game is worth the experience! And the whole story is heartwarming in a way especially I could not get over the atmosphere of the worldbuilding in nature...DEFINITELY, EVERYONE recommended this game before playing the sequel with understanding the context from the first one-

Alright, so the game was quite interesting. Nice sound and graphics platformer. Catchy due to some of the tricky puzzles but also the constant danger of minding your step and keeping an eye on enemies. But, like most platformers, the game couldn't have spared the user of the nasty parts. There are times, however cute that character may be or touching the story (for most people), you can't help but curse the game a bit. If you're willing to give it a try, you have to be armed with time and a lot of patience - expect to die a lot. Although in the beginning I felt like I was enjoying the game, I just can't recommend it anymore tbh.

One of the most beautiful gaming experiences I've ever had. 
The story follows Ori and her journey to restore the forest. The characters while they may not have any "Dialog", their character designs and animations really emote their personality which was really impressive. The story is simple for anyone to follow along and feel invested in, but its the gorgeous way that its told that will hold over players. 
The setting of Nibel is truly fantastic which each area correlating to a certain element or a colour pallet that add a whole lot of variety to the game and keep it from feeling stale. I also really like as throughout the game, the more you achieve within the story the world changes as it restores itself which was really cool to see unfold.
Visually, nothing short of perfect. Graphically, the game never had any bugs or issue and always had a consistent frame rate throughout, though this is a type of game where graphics really aren't the focal point. The art direction is genuinely some of the best that i have ever seen in a video game. Words can't even describe how gorgeous. You would honestly have to see for yourself.
Sound and Audio are on par with the visuals as these orchestral ballads really enrich the experience. The Audio for the likes of abilities, enemies and even just the world around you enhances the tone that this game is going for and its all really impressive. 
In terms of gameplay, it feels amazing to play as Ori. The movement is just so smooth and satisfying, with it coming into play with the multiple instances of platforming which i must say was a real challenge. The combat also feels great with enemies coming in all sorts of variety and bringing all kinds of attacks that make the experience that much more challenging. There are a good few collectables in terms of more heath etc. for the player to go and explore. The upgrade tree offers a lot for the player for them to overcome obstacles that they may face later in the game and it really feels like you truly benefit from unlocking it. The game can be tough but it does offer the player a lot of skills and chances to overcome a situation that it justifies its difficulty.
Overall, Ori and the Blind Forest is such a fantastic game and is another example of both a superb indie game and a perfecty designed Metroidvaina.

I love this game so much (i hate it), the story brought me to tears (the lack of skills did). The visuals are absolutely amazing and the music fits so well. I recommend this game (only if you enjoy bathing in pain) to anybody who loves a touching story, enjoyable playthrough and incredible visuals.

an absolutely beautiful game and a really satisfying playthrough.

the aesthetic of this game is just absolutely stunning - environment design is beautiful throughout. once you get some movement potential the game becomes incredibly satisfying and the puzzles do sometimes have multiple solutions. being skilled with movement abilities feels incredibly rewarding when you find a solution to an area that really wasn't the intended path.

my only gripe is with the save system, which is weird considering how easy it is to save.

it's very very easy to forget to save as there are an INCREDIBLY limited number of auto-saves (maybe 3 or 4 the entire game?), the rest is up to you as a player to consume energy in order to make a save point. late game, this doesn't really matter, as you'll have so much energy it won't matter, but very very early on when energy is a limited resource, it can feel incredibly punishing to not be able to save, and often times you'll find yourself blasting away at easy sections carefree only to get killed by the environment in some fashion and lose your progress.

that being said, even with that gripe, the game itself is absolutely worth investing in and worth the playthrough. the story, while basic, is very heartwarming. the gameplay is really fun and rewarding, there's plenty of exploration to do, and the scenery is just outright stunningly beautiful.

9/10 would definitely play the sequel.

Before I start my review, I must address that I played this game on the hardest difficulty, which I now think was a mistake for me. Although took away from my enjoyment of this game, it also highlighted some of its flaws that I wouldn’t have caught otherwise.

[b] Visuals [/b]
-as one can probably see from the screenshots the game looks absolutely stunning. The backgrounds and environments have some of the best art in a game I have ever seen, which greatly contributes to Ori and the Blind Forest’s amazing atmosphere
-unfortunately for my taste the game sacrifices too much visual clarity for its aesthetics. 
-your attack’s big and bright flashes, which have no reason for being this visible because you do not have to aim your attacks, overlap with enemy projectiles, making it hard to dodge. 
-sometimes objects/enemies having the same visuals do not mean they follow the same rules and pattern

[b] Music [/b]
-A+, very atmospheric

[b] Story [/b]
-the story was very emotional and impactful. Although it was told with the help of only a few cutscenes and the environments, I think it is the reason why many players absolutely fell in love this game
-a small point of critique is that the theme is pretty basic (light vs darkness, themes of corruption, etc.) but it was executed really well

[b] Gameplay [/b]
-the jumping felt sluggish (because of a long and slow air time) to me and it was often times difficult to control where Ori lands because of her small model, which is unusual for a platformer
-the small model also can make you lose track of her when a lot is happening on screen
-some enemy attacks are too quick to dodge, which encourages a passive (and boring) playstyle, like repeating attacking and running away, or hiding behind the safety wall to attack
-the fighting consists of senseless button mashing and keeping a safe distance
-in some aspects the game is really slow, like:
	-opening doors taking a long time
-a lot of level design is made through waiting for obstacles to be passable
-the game is made with the thought of tanking through hits, as you get a huge health bar throughout the game (which is not really possible on the high difficulty, because you get oneshot a lot), instead of actually learning how to defeat each enemy
-sometimes you get attacked from enemies that are not visible on the screen (especially at the top and bottom), or fall into enemies and their projectiles with no time to react )
-the platforming had a pretty good difficulty most of the time, but there were also a lot of times where you suddenly have to make perfect, unforgiving jumps, especially when it involved spikes as obstacles
-i think there was way too much fighting for it to be so monotone
-the ideas and the types of puzzles are great, but the finetuning of the platforming is lackluster
-the quality of level design is also inconsitent, the worst parts usually being a lot of enemies dumped after another

[b] Systems [/b]
-the skill tree being split into three lines, while having vastly different skills within those lines is frustrating and missing out on general utility because you want to level your fighting or being weak for half of the game because you want the utility first is not enjoyable
-your ability to create checkpoints shares the same resource with an ability to attack and an ability to open doors, so it can happen that you run out of said resource and have to either search around the map for nodes for said resource, or you’ll have to complete a difficult passage without any checkpoints. How this system made it into the game is honestly mind boggling to me
-when dying, the game does not remember what you picked up after the last time you saved, so you will have to retrace your steps every time and there is a good chance of missing a pickup because you forgot collecting it again
-I don’t understand the necessity of map stones (revealing a small portion of the map after finding a hidden pickup), there was no situation i found it useful
-pickups from defeated enemies despawn after a short time which can be annoying 
-enemy respawning happen to frequent for my taste
-why is there a cooldown on saving the game?

[b] Miscellaneous [/b]
-there are pop up tutorials for eeeeverything, for example you get a pop up for every major pickup you collect, even if you collected 5 of them already
-the font used doesn’t suit the game
-there is a lot of teasing the player with rewards they cannot get, because they haven’t gotten the ability yet, which doesn’t bother me and is a nice incentive, but it really happened A LOT
-unskippable cutscenes, which get really frustrating, because they play anew every time you die and get to that point again

In conclusion, this sounds like I wouldn’t recommend this, but it is the opposite. When I write reviews I tend to focus on the negatives. This game was frustrating for me a lot of the time, but I attribute that to my own stubbornness of not changing to an easier difficulty. Ori and the Blind Forest’s strongest points are definitely its story and its visuals. The platforming is good for the most part and while I did not enjoy the combat, it will be more tolerable on an easier difficulty.

As a person who absolutely adored Hollow Knight, this game was amazing and had stunning visuals. It can be pretty difficult so if you want to focus on the story I highly recommend playing the game on the easy difficulty since it has enough challenge, but not to the point where you'd want to smash your controller. I played it on easy and by doing that, I felt that the gameplay and story flowed very nicely as opposed to struggling more on normal or hard mode. Overall a very good game and I recommend it to people who enjoyed Hollow Knight or similar Metroidvanias.

I want desperately to like this game and I honestly partly do. It is beautiful, the art is truly gorgeous. But past that it ranged from mediocre to frustratingly bad. I have done several playthroughs and have considered whether or not to write a positive or negative review and I came to the conclusion that I simply can't recommend this. When it comes to indie metroidvanias there are simply too many other significantly better experiences out there. 

The combat in this game is absolutely atrocious, it is quite literally just button mashing while standing vaguely near the enemy. The further you progress the more options you get, but these options are severely underpowered and not really practical to use in most situations. It is not engaging at ALL.

The platforming is not all that enjoyable or precise in my personal opinion, which is really disappointing because this game very clearly wants to pride itself on its platforming but its just not that interesting. It is very floaty and that is just not my personal taste for this type of game.

The story is... hard to describe but it feels very... self righteous? It plays out like it thinks of itself as deeply important/meaningful but honestly its very predictable and it isn't fleshed out with enough meaningful detail to really make much of a lasting impact on me. 

The save function is garbage and it lends itself to placing you to having to repeat cutscenes pretty frequently which can be insanely frustrating especially on the harder difficulties where you get killed in 1-2 hits. 

The exploration is decent I suppose but despite being a metroidvania it is honestly super linear, very scripted and overall everything in this game aside from the art feels half baked. Like they had good ideas but didn't have enough of an idea on how to really wrap everything together into a consistently enjoyable experience.

I am hoping to enjoy the sequel more but I cannot personally recommend this game

Poetry in Motion.
I cannot describe it better than this.
This game breathes art, together with a touching story.

PRO:
- If you are fan of the Metroidvania genre, you must have this game
- Outstanding artistic design and beautiful animations
- Fantastic audio, especially during the "escape sequences"
- The Definitive Edition provides new areas, abilities and story details, that beautifully expands the original world, and fits perfectly with the game atmosphere
- Around 8 hours to finish it without pushing for secrets, but if you want 100%, you can count around 12 to 15, depending by your skill level
- I got it for 5 EUR on Steam

CONS:
- The "escape sequences" are awesome, but excessively based on trial-and-error and memorization rather than being skill-based
- Level design provides an unbalanced difficulty curve. Very easy sections alternate to extremely challenging segments
- Lacking of any real "boss fight" makes the game feeling incomplete

VOTE : 8 out of 10

A fantastic platformer metroidvania with a very lovely soundtrack. Some parts of the game can be quite challenging but the wonders of a game like this is that every failure is just practice for when you eventually beat the part you get stuck on. The "Run for Your Life" Achievement is easily one of the best and most helpful achievements I've ever seen.
If you haven't already then absolutely pick this game up if you enjoy platformer games.
Great story, incredible visuals, great soundtrack, a total treat.

I can't believe people sleep on this for games like Hollow Knight.
Ori and the Blind Forest is among the prettiest, most well flowing, and rewarding games I have ever played. 

Every part of the map is illustrated in a way that envelopes the player in it's atmosphere. Whereas many metroidvanias like Hollow Knight has its massive map being a mostly samey lost sprawl, Ori's journey is distinct, memorable, and unique from just how diverse its art portrays each part of the game.

Ori's combat isn't his strength, so each stage flow so naturally from area to area where you come to really appreciate the style and music the developers put into the world you inhabit. There was no part of the game that was soul-crushingly difficult, with every item or power-up being rewarding and compelling the player to explore. (Unlike HK)

Ori's Journey is comparatively short with me finishing the game in 15 hours, telling a sappy but neat story (which I had to stop myself shedding a tear or two from) which is only accentuated by its amazing soundtrack. So...

...if you love Platformers, you'll love this game. if you love Metroid, play this game. If you love beautiful visuals and music, play this game.

It's the best $9.99 you can spend on Steam.
This game and its sequal are so beautiful, plus the game is a looot of fun.
this made me sad :(

When my friend first recommended Ori to me, I had never heard of it before. I decided to give it a try, and started playing.

The game starts out okay, with a cool (albeit extremely long) cutscene and some typical platformer-tutorial stuff. The first few sections went well, until I got the Bash ability. The problem with this is that sometimes puzzles require you to launch yourself, and sometimes they require you to redirect projectiles in the opposite direction. This was confusing, but at least time stops for a few seconds while you aim.

The real problems began in Sorrow Peak. I genuinely liked some parts of it (for instance, the falling-rock section), but the flying controls are just too damn finicky. If you're going to make your game's controls that complicated and hard to use, don't make the (FREQUENT) platforming sections of said game punish you with a one- or two-shot kill.

Amazing visuals, an incredible soundtrack and a simple but very cute story. In terms of gameplay, it is again really well-made and polished but a bit too focused on platforming for my taste. I enjoy a good bit of focus on combat in my metroidvanias as well; perhaps a gauntlet here, a few bosses there, and maybe some more enemy variety. The enemies themselves are barely a threat compared to the environmental hazards and platforming challenges in this game on the other hand for most of the time, and are almost solely used as a part of the path to get where you want to be after some point (Think of how you can bounce in the air by hitting enemies below you in Hollow Knight for instance, that sort of stuff). Again, this didn't ruin anything. I still find the game quite enjoyable and would recommend, but know what you're getting into.

I wrote a Positive Review, then changed it to negative, and now back to positive. That's how playing this game will make you feel. You'll love it, and then hate it, and then love it again. Ultimately, this is an amazing game. Beautiful artwork and animations, amazing music, great controls and gameplay. However; it has some challenging parts that you'll find yourself trying over and over and over.

<<THE GOOD>>

Visually appealing with beautiful and diverse landscaping/level design.
Fantastic soundtrack!
Easy to learn controls (except ground pound... that was annoying).
Learn new skills, gain exp and level up via a skill tree. This adds a lot to the game.
Cute, likable characters with a great story.
Fun boss battles and unique chase scenes.

<<THE BAD>>

Very repetitive button mashing combat.

Not a lot of diverse enemies and reusing enemies with only slightly different attacks.

Annoying chase scenes that make you start completely over when you die.

Upgrade your health bar but this doesn't seem to matter. No matter how big your health is... the enemies scale and you still die in 2-3 hits. What's the point?

A LOT of instant deaths. You can have a full health bar... and there are countless ways to die immediately. This gets very tedious and annoying.

<<BAD or MAYBE GOOD?>>

Heavy metroidvania game. Tons of secrets that you must wait to uncover until you unlock that ability. I'm not a fan of this style of gamplay. A lot of backtracking, remembering where you need to go, etc. However; they did a good job to make it less confusing than others, and I never felt like I was wandering around for hours trying to figure out where to go next.

I recently completed this game on switch, with about 14 hours of playtime I think, and damn what a beautiful and enjoyable game. You have to be prepared for some trial and error for some of the sequences, and you have to accept that death will happen, and to get over it, especially if you don't play a lot of platformers (Like me). 
The controls are great, and easy to get used to, the visual design is gorgeous, the game play design is impeccable, the story is fascinating. Altogether, just a really great game and had to play the second game immediately after. (even better game play, but ten times more heart wrenching)

A short but very nice little platformer. The platforming never gets hellishly difficult, but there are sections that are challenging enough to be fun, particularly the white-knuckle setpieces that conclude each 'chapter' and that require you to tie together all the movement skills you've gained thus far, and that feel really satisfying to complete after dying a bunch of times. Ori's movement through the air has a very acrobatic and flowing, graceful feel to it, without sacrificing clean and responsive controls.

The other main strength of the game is the gorgeous visuals and music. They're great.

There are also a few minor puzzle elements, and there's combat but it's very simple (the combat is at its best when it's integrated with the platforming, e.g. in places where there is an enemy making it hard for you to jump somewhere, or where you have to decide whether to kill an enemy or use it to help you move around the environment).

The most fun and rewarding movement ability in the game is "Bash", which lets you grab onto an enemy, projectile, or falling rock, and shoot yourself off of it in one direction while also shooting it off in the other direction; this both gives you tons of options for creative things to do and also has the potential to mess up your plans in unexpected but fun ways (like when you have a great idea to blast an enemy's fireball back into its face, but you didn't anticipate that that would also make you blast yourself into some spikes... or when you want to use an enemy's fireballs to bounce yourself higher and higher, until you accidentally kill that same enemy with one of its own fireballs).

I've done all of this before, but now I have to do it 5 more times before I make any progress.  It completely contradicts your ability to save whenever needed. This game is pretty fun! Because of it's art style and gameplay, I'd honestly compare it less to others in the metroidvania genre, and more to something like Rayman or Donkey Kong, albeit, with a few more puzzles thrown in. 

The moments where it shines best are definitely the moments with heavily emphasized platforming, as the combat is, in all honesty, pretty terrible. I think the devs know this though, because there's like 2 bosses, and most of the enemies can be defeated pretty easily. 

If you're coming from a game like Hollow Knight, know that this game has a much more nature focused atmosphere, and will not live up to your expectations unless you really like platformers like I do. This game is definitely a platformer first and a metroidvania second, with a fairly set out linear path with minimal backtracking and on-your-own exploration, though optional post-game content is much better in this regard. Not at all to say that that's a bad thing though, the game definitely delivers on the strengths of linearity, offering very well thought out and balanced challenges, and though it kind of felt as if the main story was a bit short, a good narrative.

The music is phenomenal, It really gets you in the mood, and compliments the style of the game very well. If I had to rate it, it's only slightly better than the music of Donkey Kong, and only marginally worse than Hollow Knight's music, which is a big praise since those are some of the best soundtracks!

 It's definitely worth the low cost to play too, definitely recommend this.

A solid 8 hour journey first time through. The first 5 minutes pull on your heart strings to get you emotionally invested right away.

Positives:
-Great ambience, visually pleasing mix of foreground and background.
-Player has the freedom to solve puzzles in more ways then one. Like there's the obvious way, but you can skip half of it if you use your movement abilities in creative ways.
-Music does a great job at triggering the right emotions at the right time throughout the journey.
-You quickly get abilities that make you feel fast and agile while playing.

Negatives:
-The combat is fairly basic. You get a homing orb that zaps nearby enemies, so you don't even need to aim.
--After upgrading your orb, it gets harder to see enemy projectiles due to the visual effects your orb does.
-There are "runner" sections where you gotta keep moving or die. My main issue is these sections can be pretty long and there are no checkpoints, there are also objects that can 1 shot you or stunlock you, making it feel like a cheap death as you don't have much time to react. This is a shame due to these moments being climatic parts of the game, only to be instant killed by XYZ and having to start all over again. However these moments are minimal.

Now this is a special one. The Blind Forest caught my eye with its beautiful visuals and fluid gameplay the moment I laid eyes on the steam trailer. Not to mention the cheap price it was pretty much a pretty quick purchase.

The game's reputation now is still very well set even with the sequel existing. From the moment you press new game and the swift transition taking you through the whole 10 minute intro was entrancing enough to tell me that this game  was going to be something precious.

The story itself isn't anything too impressive on paper but on your first playthrough you wouldn't even really notice that as the game does such a good job at expressing the important moments with the colorful visuals, amazing cinematography, and fluid animations.

Speaking of fluidity, when the act of just moving your character is fun then you know the whole gameplay is bound to be exciting. Paired with the game's iconic bash ability which allows Ori to use objects and enemies as catapults to launch her further into the air, the entire game will feel like you are just swimming through water.

The combat of Ori however has always felt like the least properly developed part of the whole package. It all comes down to spamming the attack button when the enemy is close and maneuvering away from incoming attacks. While Ori does have a ground pound and the bash move at her disposal it doesn't help that the combat overall is still pretty shallow.

The developers clearly knew that as instead of boss fights the game puts you up with intense chase sequences in place of them. To take in mind that the first chase sequence often gets complaints from players as being a major difficulty spike from what was presented beforehand. They may come off as very intimidating but once you memorize the sequence patterns and pay attention to your surroundings you will soon realize that they are all designed pretty fairly. It is just takes quite a while of getting used to.

Ori and the Blind Forest is still considered to be one of Xbox's best games they have put out in the last decade and persists pretty strong visually even in the next generation of consoles.

Good but sometimes frustrating. Art, music and narrative are great; strong sense of atmosphere. Traversal of the world is often satisfying. Combat is dull, consisting purely of spamming an attack button while dodging not-always-that-easy-to-see projectiles. It's not always easy to see what will do damage to you and what is harmless terrain. Further, most areas end in a set piece of some kind which, while interesting, also essentially required you to die a few times to learn the route you were supposed to take (all while on a pretty strict timer). Recommendable but imperfect

I've played this game three times now, twice on Steam, once on Switch. This is clearly the superior way to play Ori, on Steam. For not even that much money you get about 9 hours of insanely fun and great gameplay straight form the getgo, something I cannot say for even games like Super Metroid. It is possibly peak art design, both visual and musical, and the gameplay is absolutely INSANE. (Bash is super fun btw) The only thing I don't really care about is the plot. It's weird and not very satisfying for me, but that's counteracted by the fun exploration and easy to follow controls. Play this game. Now.
Nice looking game. It is challenging but still fun.

Coming off the back of Hollow Knight, this didn't do it for me. There's a lack of precision in both platforming and combat that just feels clumsy. Combat boils down to spamming x and jumping to avoid tiny fast-moving multidirectional, sometimes homing, sometimes exploding projectiles. Remember Primal Aspids from HK? Yeah, it's that sort of bullshittery only with most enemies. You unlock the ability to launch from projectiles but even timing that your best bet is button mashing.

Movement is floaty and at odds with how a demanding action platformer should control; I never felt completely in control of Ori, sometimes I even lost track of their tiny blue ass between the backdrop, the glorified reticle of matching colour/size, looking where I was going and dodging projectiles. Most of the game is poorly checkpointed trial and error with limited manual saves that your abilities use the same pool as (which just makes me avoid using abilities altogether so I can ration my saves). Gandhi forbid you forget to save.

I was ready to quit the game until I saw greyed out metroidvania tunnels on the map and giddily got into my Dora boots. But I soon discovered there's no sense of adventure in the exploration, no secret bosses/characters/quests/lore to find, you're just looking for keys, map fragments, XP and additional vitality/power. It's unfulfilling. And personally I felt nothing but a gnawing emptiness in my soul for the Disney art style, storytelling and music (way too loud). I thought it was cheesy.

I've played three hours now, the overall presentation and production value is good and I see why it has so many good reviews, but I've found the controls to be frustrating enough to tarnish all the other positive aspects of the game. The physics, especially surrounding jumping and ESPECIALLY surrounding wall jumping, just seem to require way more precision than the game actually makes possible. The way acceleration, floating, and mid-air changes in direction work all seem really inconsistent and imprecise compared to the physics in other platformers.

The three hours I've played has all been using a keyboard and mouse, so I'm going to try with a controller later and see if I have a different experience. I am still looking for a way that I can say "Oh, this is how the controls are actually supposed to work, I was just doing it wrong." We'll see.

The rat controls like hot garbage, floating when he shouldn't, falling when he shouldn't, not wall jumping, going into a wall jump animation before the game decides that you actually did land on the platform but you already pressed jump and were holding the direction so you fling yourself off the platform... The game demands precision platforming, but gives you the worst, inconsistent controls ever. The rat moves around like he ate Sonic and Luigi from Super Mario Bros 2. I have never had such a rage inducing time getting a platformer character to actually do what I wanted. The game is horribly inconsistent, I cannot state this enough.
The visuals, though nice at first, quickly make it so you can't see anything going on. Diarrhea Christmas lights to the max, plus everything is so small and fast it makes it near impossible to track what's going on, especially once you get the burst ability and actually have to use enemies to move through the environment and puzzles.
Can't recommend to anyone that wants a good platforming experience. Would have been a fantastic and challenging experience, but the horrible, horrible control makes that impossible. No amount of pretty visuals and great music can overcome terrible gameplay.

This game is difficult. Brutally so. If you have seen the trailers, you should have gotten the gist of what kind of platforming is expected from you as a player. It's highly challenging and can be frustrating at times; it's almost guaranteed that you'll get past a platforming area after dying so many times. So if you're feeling stuck and on the verge of rage quitting, remember that it's totally reasonable to feel that way.

My advice to those jumping into Ori's world for the first time would be to pick Easy difficulty. I made the mistake of choosing Normal difficulty and after getting real tired of listening to Ori's weak dying whimper, I was about to drop the game for good when I finally remembered that I could change difficulty. If I could turn back time, I'd pick Easy difficulty in a heartbeat. That way I could enjoy Ori's beautiful world without so much agony.

(Please note that Easy difficulty doesn't make the platforming challenges easier. It does, however, decrease damages from enemies and environmental hazards.)
Great artwork. Great gameplay. Easy to get lost and need to use a lot of brain to pass certain levels. I am dead and weak.

My second experience with a metroidvania, which is fast becoming my favorite game type. The enemies aren't anything to write home about, but the heavy emphasis on platforming more than makes up for it because that's where the game really shines, especially with the "bash" ability, which is easily the best in the moveset. The art and music do a wonderful job of setting up the atmosphere as well. Like a lot of other people I'd have to say the Ginso tree was my favorite part, but I also loved the volcano a lot. Really all three of the "dungeon" levels were really well done. My only complaint is that the full moveset feels like a bit "too much" at some points, but the game does a good job at staggering the introductions of each new move and makes sure you know how to use them before progressing. That aside, this was definitely a nice experience and I'm looking forward to trying out the sequel.

It's a fun game. I would say a pretty good introduction to metroidvanias if this was your first (it wasn't mine) but the focusing on the platforming was definitely an interesting decision. I'm excited to see how the sequel improves on the platforming and level design.

Uppers:
1. Beautiful, varied environments
2. Solid combat with significant upgrades throughout (by endgame you're a fully-torqued super saiyan).
3. Perfect change of pace from giant, open-world rpg's
4. Rewarding for both explorers and speed runners

Downers:
1. There are skills that can be purchased in the skill tree at any point, but can't be used until unlocked later on in the game. This is not explained at all and caused moderate frustration.
2. Some areas cannot be revisited (most can); completionists beware!
3. One instance when the game wouldn't allow me to progress past an area after after completing the requirements, This was solved with a simple restart.

The hype is real, yo.

This is one of those games where the Steam rating system would be better served with ranked scoring than a simple "yay or nay" vote.  There should be no debate that the game is beautiful on both an audio and visual level.  It also gets high marks from me for its clever puzzles.

The theme of the game gets neutral marks as it's fairly standard fantasy fare.  The concept of some nature sprite travelling to different element-themed dungeons to unlock the powers of air, water and fire for the 500 millionth time in gaming history is certainly not breaking any new ground.  Even if you're a child, you've probably played a game with this exact premise numerous times in your life by now.

Which brings me to the negatives: the game mechanics and the game design seem to completely clash.  The cute aesthetic puts a deceptively friendly face on a game that is ultimately driven by unforgiving precision platforming.  The game is thick with environmental hazards such as lava, poisoned water, spike pits and lasers which kill you instantly regardless of your available health pool.  Furthermore, the vast majority of the platforming is spontaneous and random rather than static, so dying is not simply an issue of tightening up the pace and timing of your jumps.  To reach most of the areas you have to platform off of enemies and their projectiles in a long-series of complex aerial maneuvers (this doesn't just apply to reaching secret areas, it's a core mechanic of story progression).  Miss just one step in any maneuver and you're more likely to be killed instantly from environmental hazards than you are to simply take damage from an errant projectile.

This means that the collection/upgrade aspect of the game (finding life cells to expand your health pool or collecting ability cells to upgrade your damage capabilities) doesn't truly make the hero less prone to dying.  There are only a few types of enemies and they're all fairly easy to defeat (even with the most basic of abilities).  In my experience, you're far more likely to be killed because you moved just out of aggro range and missed a potential "platform" necessary for an air jump than to be killed directly by an enemy.

However, with the ability to save at will almost anywhere on the map, the game will still take full advantage of getting some cheap kills on you by magically respawning projectile-firing enemies right next to your save point.  Given the developer's sadistic designs for some levels, the at-will save ability is the true redeeming factor of this game.  It's the only thing keeping this game from being a boring "Souls-like" series of endless backtracks through the same locations (due to split-second misses rather than sheer incompetence).

The fact that you are prohibited from using this feature during the "escape" gauntlet runs that follow each dungeon level makes the game much more frustrating than it needed to be.  They could have instead implemented periodic auto-saves after particularly challenging portions of each gauntlet run, and they consciously chose not to.  This doesn't appear to be because they felt it would ruin the quick pacing of the escape.  They are perfectly happy to throw you directly back into the frying pan at the beginning of the gauntlet and kill you off with the "moving wall of death" without giving you any recovery time.

As an example, I died 95 times (the game tracks your deaths) just trying to escape the very first dungeon of the game.  It's not because I'm terrible at these games, it's because these gauntlets are explicitly designed to be very difficult to pass in one attempt.  That approach to design is acceptable, but it seems rather vindictive to require over 50 perfect precision jumps without any breaks or auto-saves to track your progress.  I rage-quit three separate times and almost deleted the game before even beating the first dungeon (the only thing bringing me back were the endless reviews about how "perfect" this game is and I sense that I must be missing something).  I can't help but feel that this sense of frustration was explicitly by design because these portions contain very obvious scenic transitions that seem perfectly designed for "checkpoints" that are conspicuously missing.  It begs the question of what type of reaction the developers were going for when I've beaten games on "Nightmare" difficulty that were honestly easier and less frustrating than this game was on "Normal".

That's ultimately what makes this a mixed review for me.  Is it a beautifully designed game?  Yes.  Does it include some rather complex puzzles and unique platforming mechanics that make it a bit more interesting than the average platformer?  Yes.  Is it a game that is legitimately more "fun" and "rewarding" to play than it is frustrating?  Only about half the time and you'd never know you were in for a "bang-your-head-against-the-wall" type of experience from the way it is designed and marketed.

There is some redemption in that the sequel (Ori and the Will of the Wisps) seems to have addressed the negative aspects of the original.  It plays quite similar, yet it improves monster AI and adds boss fights while reducing the danger of environmental hazards.  Therefore, playing this game first prepares you for the sequel, which is the prime reason to recommend it.  However, if you're the type of person that doesn't get any enjoyment from developing callouses on your thumbs, I'd recommend that you just watch a video of someone else playing this game and then just skip ahead to the second one.

Not really sure what to think of this, and I feel insane, because people love it. It's... frustrating. I've just unlocked the ability to double jump, and the feeling of freedom I felt like I had was immediately tarnished by the feeling of not knowing why i died. The game looks good, but it seems to cause issues between the graphics and hitboxes of what's exactly damaging you. Went into this game really wanting to love it, came out two hours later just wanting to play something else.

I want to start this review off by saying 2 things. 1) I am incredibly late to playing this game as it's 6 years old now so I do not know how useful this review will be and 2) I have finished this game and will be buying will of the wisps at some point.

Before playing this game I already considered this game to be a classic and a masterpiece just judging off of what I had heard and seen, and after finishing the game that hasn't changed. I recommend this game off the art style, sound design, and music alone. This is one of the prettiest games I have ever played. Every single frame of this game looks like a painting that people are still hanging up in museums hundreds of years later, it is incredible to look at and the music just makes it even better.

The gameplay is solid the platforming is fun, the controls are precise. Overall I enjoyed the game enough to keep playing from the gameplay. However, there is this difficulty spike that I just was not expecting and I personally don't think should be there or at least should be able to be turned down. Don't get me wrong I finished the game however I saw this game as a "kids game" after playing the game I don't think that due to the sad and depressive nature of some parts of the story, but I thought due to the art style and the fact that this is more of a story game that it would be accessible to most people. I feel like due to the very sharp curve towards the mid point of the game I think some people may have quit because of the more demanding platforming required to progress. I did struggle a good bit and I'm not amazing at games by any means but I have played many different games spanning all types of genres and I like a challenge but I think that people who this may be there first game of this type or first game in general will really struggle and may not be able to complete this game at all due to this difficulty spike. I think it's worth it I do but I see this being a really big problem for others.

Overall I liked this game and as said I will be buying and playing the sequel at some point. The art style and music in this game is some of the best in the industry right now and I understand why this game got the praise it did. Yes the gameplay frustrated me at times but I pushed through. I think due to the type of game and overall very fun art style I think the difficulty is a little out of place but it's still a fun game. I recommend this game very much if not for the art style alone. Looking forward to the sequel. Have fun!

The art - both the visuals and the music - are fantastically crafted and is definitely the highlight of the game. The combat starts off slow and fights are tedious, but it does improve after acquiring skills as you progress and encountering more types of enemies. The fluid and elegant movement feels great. However, it should be pointed out that the game’s more floaty movement does not allow for the level of precision required in some platforming areas of the game. On most occasions the platforming is very forgiving to make up for the airy and sluggish movement. Though I dismissed it as clunky at first, the movement (just like the combat) improves as you acquire more skills (the dash and bash skills in particular makes traversing more enjoyable). In general it just takes some time to get used to the movement until it becomes fun.

The level design feels varied enough to differentiate each area, but the lack of enemy types makes it so that the areas all blur together so each individual section isn’t as memorable, making backtracking slightly difficult. However, these are only some nitpicks of mine that don't affect the game that much. It’s a decent game and I would recommend it if you have 9-12 hours to spare.

If you played WotW and are looking for more of the same: this will scratch the itch. It's got a slower start and some slightly remixed (although not necessarily worse) systems but the excellent level design and fluid, satisfying platforming are still present. 

Ori feels absolutely incredible to control. This game and its sequel are the most highly-tuned "floaty" platformers I've ever played. 

Collectibles are tantalizingly just out of reach, daring and challenging you to use your moveset and the environment in creative ways.

Again, it does start off a bit slower that WotW and frankly I had a hard time getting into it as a result. The instant you unlock the double jump the game goes from good to great and never really stops escalating. This game is a pillar of the genre for a reason.

Ori and The Blind Forest is a graphically stunning metroidvania with an emotional story about hope, kindness, and love that could bring you to tears. You are Ori, the child of the Spirit Tree, who takes on a journey to revive their forest from the evils that have overtaken its flora and fauna. Along the way, you will encounter beautifully designed areas,  challenging platforming, and moving music pieces.  There are secrets for the explorer who leaves no stone unturned. 

One of my favorite things about the game have to be the story and the art design. Self explanatory, really. The platforming is just as spectacular, each of Ori's learned abilities will be put to the test as you jump from ledge to ledge. There are some small puzzle elements in the game, I really dig that.  The ability tree gives players the option to play how they want to play, choosing exploration, combat, or extra abilities like a dash and a charge. 

You should definitely check out this unique and wonderful experience of a game! 7/10
Quite a good game. If you like adventurous games this one is for you

Looking at the price of this game now, I'm shocked that I'd even need to advocate for people to get this game. $5 for one of the best Metroidvanias of the 2010s is such a steal that it might as well be a Steam library staple: if you have a Steam account, get [i]Ori and the Blind Forest.[/i] I started playing the original version of [i]Ori and the Blind Forest[/i] years ago on a 2010 desktop, and even with low graphic settings at 30 FPS, this game was a spectacle. Fast forward to 2022 with 4K 60 FPS visuals, and I can confirm that [i]Ori and the Blind Forest[/i] is a stunning game from front to back, and I don't think that'll change decades from now. Many of my favorite screencaps I've taken so far come from this game, and each one could be a wallpaper.

[i]Ori and the Blind Forest[/i] also introduced gamers to modern video game composer legend Gareth Coker. While he worked on a couple projects before this one, his soundtrack for [i]Blind Forest[/i] immediately shifted him from obscure composer to god-tier. The motifs are striking, the tone fits every environment it appears in, and the blend of awestruck wonder and heart-racing intensity is genuinely mindblowing. The first escape sequence combined with Restoring the Light, Facing the Dark is one of the most unforgettable experiences I've ever had playing video games.

I could go on all day about all the things [i]Ori and the Blind Forest[/i] excels at. The fluid movement, the engaging leveling system, the evolving combat, and my beloved Bash ability - it's all fantastic. For me, though, all of that is in service of the breathtaking audiovisual experience at its core. [i]Ori and the Blind Forest[/i] is a game to play with headphones on, the room darkened, and get lost in its wondrous world and bittersweet story. While I have some issues regarding the beginning of the game's combat getting tiring and occasional nitpicks, all of its strengths carry it through those minor problems.

I don't think I need to say anything more. [i]Ori and the Blind Forest[/i] currently $5, and it was more than worth it when I got it for $20. If you somehow don't own this gem of a game, buy it now.

Ori And The Blind Forest is an incredible game with beautiful visuals, story, and soundtrack. It had been a while since I played a platformer and this game just made me realize that I was missing an entire genre of video games.

Gameplay-wise, Ori And The Blind Forest is an accessible yet challenging game. Never in my time playing this game I felt that the gameplay was unfair. Not only that, the game isn't bloated, it doesn't force you to backtrack to farm and upgrade abilities. Guess what, you can complete the game without upgrading abilities but, it will take more time. Upgrading abilities and finding health and energy upgrades help a lot and add to the experience. Gameplay 9/10

As I mentioned above, the game isn't bloated and the same goes for the story. It doesn't drag anything out. The narrative is not only focused but also beautiful. If I go any further, I'll just spoil it. But, it was a beautiful and emotional experience. Story 9/10

Graphically, Ori isn't a heavy game but the art direction is just amazing. Everything area you explore is unique and beautiful to look at. The use of colors for each of the game's region is beautiful done. It immerses you and make you feels like you are is a different region than before. Visuals 9/10

Overall, Ori and The Blind Forest is an incredible experience and I look forward to playing the sequel. Final Score 9/10

A beautiful game that has made me shed more than a few tears, out of happiness, sadness, and frustration. Even if you think this game isn't for you like I did, try it out. The story alone is worth it.

This game is pretty "meh". I mean, it's not a bad game; far from it. But it didn't blow my mind either.

The game is short and has a quite straightforward story. It's more or less a platforming puzzle dexterity game. You have to combine platforming with some problem solving, along with (sometimes) quick reactions to dodge and/or move around.

The environment looks nice and the music fits the mood.

The ending was kind of cheesy/childish though; I usually hate reading that, but it painfully felt that way to me. 

If the game was way too easy, I would have understood the ending, since it would mean it would be marketed towards young children. But even if it wasn't insanely difficult, it wasn't so easy either.

Overall, you can play it as long as you don't expect too much out of it. It's not bad, although I found Hollow Knight (which I played right before) to be much more mindblowing, even if it started out as a very simple game. Then again, it's not the same kind of game and the difficulty can be exponential.

Personally, I expected much more from this game. I wouldn't say that it's overrated, but it's very close to it. It's far from being a crappy game, but it's nothing more than an okay one that was done properly.

I struggled to enjoy this game a lot, and many times, I got so frustrated that I put it down for months at a time. I don't enjoy metroidvanias, and Ori and the Blind Forest was a brutal reminder of that. But this is a positive review, because as much as I didn't enjoy the game, I can recognize that it's a beautiful experience that fans of this genre would absolutely love. The environments are gorgeous, and the music is immersive and perfect. The story is a good one too, and the creatures, especially Ori, are adorable. My biggest complaint with this game is that a lot of the environmental hazards that kill you are super hard to distinguish from the rest of the world. So many of my deaths were caused by spikes I couldn't see or lava I couldn't distinguish from the hot rocks right beside it. This made the experience all the more stressful, since it felt like I was being punished for having bad eyesight. Another gripe is that the base game and the Definitive Edition come bundled, and I can't get rid of one without the other, so I have a game in my library I'll never touch and can't get rid of. This version doesn't have trading cards either, so it makes me wonder if I should have played the other edition. All in all, though I hated my experience with this game, I can tell it was beautifully made and would be fun for a lot of other people, so I still recommend it.

Dude this game is really great. The platforming is really fun and it's mixed to perfection with puzzles that really flex Moon Studio's creative muscle. The only downsides of the game are the simplistic combat and the save system. The combat is fine. It's a platforming focused game after all. The save system on the other hand is abysmal. You can't save your game unless you have energy, which isn't as common as I'd like in the early game. Later on this stops being an issue, since you (hopefully) have a lot more energy cells by then. For inexperienced players, this system forces you to go back like 10 minutes worth of progress because you forgot to save. Other than those issues, this game is great and definitely worth picking up. (The second game, Ori and the Will of the Wisps fixes both these issues and does everything even better than the first, including platforming.)

Having +35 hours, I just can say one thing, the game is a masterpiece.

To be honest, I met the game while listening a playlist in Spotify made out of games soundtracks, and I swear that when I listened to "Light of Nibel" for the first time, I needed to know where it was from (I know, maybe it's strange to met a game like this, many years later, and because of Spotify, but meh, that's not the point).

After a few years, I finally had the possibility of playing it, and guys, it worth every damn cent paid for it.

The art is beautiful, the soundtrack couldn't be more amazing, at such point that it evokes many fellings while you play (seriously, the game makes you cry in just the first 5 minutes), and last, but not least, the story is beautiful.

And if that's not enough, if you are obsessed with finishing every game at it's 100% (like me), you'll enjoy searching for every secret hidden in the map, unlocking every ability, etc (and this adds more replayability to the game, what is very possitive).

Summing up, the game deserves every second/cent invested on it. If you have the chance, play it, you won't regret. And for god's sake, BUY THE OST, I'TS BEAUTIFUL

Dionysus (/daɪ.əˈnaɪsəs/; Greek: Διόνυσος Dionysos) is the god of the grape-harvest, winemaking, orchards and fruit, vegetation, fertility, insanity, ritual madness, religious ecstasy, festivity, and theatre in ancient Greek religion and myth.[2][3] He is also known as Bacchus (/ˈbækəs/ or /ˈbɑːkəs/; Greek: Βάκχος Bacchos), the name adopted by the Romans;[4] the frenzy that he induces is bakkheia. As Eleutherios ("the liberator"), his wine, music, and ecstatic dance free his followers from self-conscious fear and care, and subvert the oppressive restraints of the powerful. His thyrsus, a fennel-stem sceptre, sometimes wound with ivy and dripping with honey, is both a beneficent wand and a weapon used to destroy those who oppose his cult and the freedoms he represents.[5] Those who partake of his mysteries are believed to become possessed and empowered by the god himself.[6]

His origins are uncertain, and his cults took many forms; some are described by ancient sources as Thracian, others as Greek.[7][8][9] In Orphic religion, he was variously a son of Zeus and Persephone; a chthonic or underworld aspect of Zeus; or the twice-born son of Zeus and the mortal Semele. The Eleusinian Mysteries identify him with Iacchus, the son or husband of Demeter. Most accounts say he was born in Thrace, traveled abroad, and arrived in Greece as a foreigner. His attribute of "foreignness" as an arriving outsider-god may be inherent and essential to his cults, as he is a god of epiphany, sometimes called "the god that comes".[10]

Wine was a religious focus in the cult of Dionysus and was his earthly incarnation.[11] Wine could ease suffering, bring joy, and inspire divine madness.[12] Festivals of Dionysus included the performance of sacred dramas enacting his myths, the initial driving force behind the development of theatre in Western culture.[13] The cult of Dionysus is also a "cult of the souls"; his maenads feed the dead through blood-offerings, and he acts as a divine communicant between the living and the dead.[14] He is sometimes categorised as a dying-and-rising god.[15]

Romans identified Bacchus with their own Liber Pater, the "Free Father" of the Liberalia festival, patron of viniculture, wine and male fertility, and guardian of the traditions, rituals and freedoms attached to coming of age and citizenship, but the Roman state treated independent, popular festivals of Bacchus (Bacchanalia) as subversive, partly because their free mixing of classes and genders transgressed traditional social and moral constraints. Celebration of the Bacchanalia was made a capital offence, except in the toned-down forms and greatly diminished congregations approved and supervised by the State. Festivals of Bacchus were merged with those of Liber and Dionysus.

Just finished the game... 

Graphics? Gorgeous. Music? Phenomenal. Story? Heartwrenching. 

Ori and the Blind Forest is a story about love and sacrifice, and just how far you are willing to go for those you love. Without spoilers, I've cried so much during this game's cutscenes. The gameplay is fun and was challenging for me. The music is something that I can listen to on repeat over and over again. This game... This game is a complete masterpiece and I recommend it. If this game has been on your radar, it is well worth it. I loved every second of it, no matter how agonizing some parts were to complete. This game is one of the greatest games I have ever had the pleasure of playing, and damn straight am I heading into the second on as soon as I finish mourning the completion of this one. 

9.5/10 for me. Some parts were frustrating to get through (Normal difficulty) but otherwise this game was absolutely perfect to me.

Great visual journey with challenging platforming sections

(To provide context for my review, my system specs are Windows 10/RTX 2080/i9 10980HK)

[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- As you've probably noticed from the screenshots, the game looks amazing. The different areas of the game all feel fairly distinct and nice to look at (especially Moon Grotto, Misty Woods, and Lost Grove areas)
- In order to get it to look amazing on your display, you're going to have to change the resolution, probably. It's bugged to be capped at 1920x1080. Track down the .exe, right click, go to Properties -> Compatability -> Change high DPI settings, then check the box next to "Override high DPI scaling behavior." Make sure the "Scaling performed by" box is set to "Application." After that, you should be able to change the resolution from the menu
- The music is great. It adds to the sense of mystery and offers a nice accompaniment to your exploration. I still have the main theme stuck in my head

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- Honestly, the story is a little thin. It's revealed little-by-little as you explore new areas, but there's very little exposition. One could argue that this game is much more about the gameplay, but I was still left with a lot of questions about the forest and Ori, Naru, and Gomu's world
- That said, the small snippets revealed about the characters are pretty cute
- The visuals, music, and narrative (sparse as it is) all contribute to the game's air of mystery. I feel like my experience was heightened by playing it at night with the windows open

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- The basic gameplay loop involves being told to go somewhere on the map, exploring until you get there, picking up a new ability, then making your way to the next place on a path that heavily involves that new mechanic. I enjoyed how mastery of the various skills was necessary to complete the final area of the game
- Backtracking can be rewarding. You'll often pass inaccessible areas on your way to picking up a new skill, then realize that's what you needed in order to get the ability points, health upgrades, or spirit capacity hidden inside
- This game is very demanding of your reflexes, timing, and attention to detail. There are often times that you'll understand what the game wants you to do, but doubt your ability to do it. Keep trying! The game is fair, it's just hard. I'm not very good at games and was still able to finish this one. It was a rewarding game to conquer
- The controls are precise and responsive, but I found that my gameplay improved drastically after plugging in my controller instead of playing via bluetooth. That tiny reduction in input lag made a surprising difference
- It's not often that I'm happy that a game is short, but my roughtly 9-hour (with an additional 3 hours paused) experience was about all I wanted out of the game. Any more would have felt like filler

[b]Overall Impressions[/b]
- The game ran extremely well and looked amazing once I got the resolution set to 4K for my TV
- I didn't encounter any bugs other than display issue, and I didn't encounter any framiness or audio issues. Well-made and well-optimized. Just wish they'd patch the display problem for new players

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]8.5/10[/b]. Definitely pick this one up if you like challenging platformers. It may look cute, but don't be fooled. It's a great game and only costs like $5. I highly recommend it

This game is really, really good. The artwork and music are especially incredible. However, the movement, story, and overall level design is very well-thought out and plays really nicely. The game only took me about 7 hours to beat on normal difficulty, but I think for $5, it's absolutely worth it. I would like to try Ori and the Will of Wisps later on, since this game gave me a very good impression.

The game is beautiful. Playful graphics, nice music, charming characters. But the game is a precision platformer and imho that does not really work with the chosen graphic style. The foreground adds a lot of nice little details to the world but it also makes some enemies and projectiles difficult to see. So many times I've died to stuff I simply could not see. And this is a dealbreaker for a precision platformer.
The world with all its details and squiggles makes it sometimes also difficult to properly assess hitboxes and enviromental hazards.
I also find the combat system rather annoying as enemies often have way too much health for it to be fun. And one of the core mechanics of the game is that you can/must manually place your savepoints with a limited resource. While this SOUNDS interesting, the typical gamer mentality makes you want to save that resource, often having to repeat sections way too often because you were too "resourceful" to place another savepoint. Sure, that is your fault but the game mechanic encourages this behaviour actively leading to frustration. Games like "They Bleed Pixels" implement such a system better. Also you have to watch cutscenes or door opening animations over and over if your savepoint was shortly before the corresponding section. Not being able to skip cutscenes in a game where you are meant to die a lot is just bad game design.

Too much frustrating bullshit to enjoy all the "feels" you're feverishly trying to cram into the game. The sweeping orchestral soundtrack becomes grating after retrying the same stupid section a hundred times. The beautiful hand crafted art becomes an obstacle in actually trying to see what you're doing. It's hard to know what's background and what's interact-able most of the time. Also, Ori feels terrible to control sometimes. There's this slippery yet frustratingly pixel-precise feeling of movement that makes me want to pull my hair out as Ori just won't do what you want. Other times you're hopping effortlessly around like a majestic deer or something. Typically depends on the terrain. And, FRICK the combat. I made sure to max out combat as soon as possible just to get those annoying goobers off my screen faster. Ugh. Unnecessarily frustrating experience. Still a beautiful one. Maybe put it on the easiest setting and don't look back.
